Can we somehow avoid that ? Also as pointed out in (3) limiting number of rows makes sense here.Besides these, I found a missing '+' (see inline comments which makes me suspect this is not the version you have in your local box since this version doesn't work out of the box unless someone changes code himself - is it ?)

text: Patch Set 2:Hi pranav, Well actually this patch was my first interaction with toolbar, so i was planning to rewrite some parts of it better. (e.g. we have jQuery but as a habit i didn't use it often) I'm going to follow your suggestions while fixing it. > 1. tpstatus label is obscured; not clearly visible. Maybe better if > we add a background below this label, or something to make it > visible clearly ?An empty (white) background should take care of it. > 2. It should be possible to close the dialog when user clicks > somewhere else. Currently, only way to close the dialog is to hit > again on the toolbar button.Definitely, this is my first priority > 3. I think we should limit the dimensions of table user can create > with this new toolbar button just like we do in desktop, because if > we don't it would stick to the mouse movements and user will have a > hard time to find an empty space to close the dialog button. This > is pretty annoying from user POV, I think.I can limit it like 20x20. I guess it would be enough? > 4. I noticed that the state of this new toolbar button doesn't get > reset whenever user manages to close the dialog. So for eg: if user > closed the dialog with table dimensions 12 x 12 selected, the next > time he opens it, it would still be at 12 x 12. The state should be > reset everytime dialog is closed.I should add this to onClick and Close events. >  > 5. Currently, user has to move his mouse slowly to select desired > dimensions. If he moves the mouse little faster, the dialog doesn't > notice that.With combining (3) and this maybe we should consider adding a selectable fixed size 20x20 table, anyway I'll look into this and try to understand what's wrong with it.  >  > 6. You have limited the width of dialog unlike its height. I think > you intend to limit the number of columns user can choose here (?), > _but_ if user moves his mouse back and forth near the right edge, > more number of columns gets added to the same width increasing the > number of cells per row - density - which makes the grid a mess. > Can we somehow avoid that ? Also as pointed out in (3) limiting > number of rows makes sense here. > Hmm, weird. I think its related to `evo-pop` since i haven't limited the width of dialog :-) anyway solving (3) should fix this and using `evo-pop` wasn't a good choice. > Besides these, I found a missing '+' (see inline comments which > makes me suspect this is not the version you have in your local box > since this version doesn't work out of the box unless someone > changes code himself - is it ?)Ah, while writing this patch i was on a hack-fest with a computer with heat issues (can't compile LibreOffice before it shut itself down) and was working on a remote machine and had to hard-copy to commit to my own box, while fixing white-spaces etc. i have removed them by mistake probably.Thank you very much for your review.

If he moves the mouse little faster, the dialog doesn't > notice that.With combining (3) and this maybe we should consider adding a selectable fixed size 20x20 table, anyway I'll look into this and try to understand what's wrong with it.  >  > 6. You have limited the width of dialog unlike its height. I think > you intend to limit the number of columns user can choose here (?), > _but_ if user moves his mouse back and forth near the right edge, > more number of columns gets added to the same width increasing the > number of cells per row - density - which makes the grid a mess. > Can we somehow avoid that ? Also as pointed out in (3) limiting > number of rows makes sense here. > Hmm, weird. I think its related to `evo-pop` since i haven't limited the width of dialog :-) anyway solving (3) should fix this and using `evo-pop` wasn't a good choice. > Besides these, I found a missing '+' (see inline comments which > makes me suspect this is not the version you have in your local box > since this version doesn't work out of the box unless someone > changes code himself - is it ?)Ah, while writing this patch i was on a hack-fest with a computer with heat issues (can't compile LibreOffice before it shut itself down) and was working on a remote machine and had to hard-copy to commit to my own box, while fixing white-spaces etc. i have removed them by mistake probably.Thank you very much for your review.

text: Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2I'm still not happy with the whole approach as I think it is not something we want to do. I would have most likely only given a warning to the user that we had some problems fitting his text and not bothered with anything else. IMHO we are trying to be too clever for our own good with this algorithm.However I don't care enough to block this patch. This message should be enough encouragement for anyone who wants to revert that behavior.
Text: Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2I'm still not happy with the whole approach as I think it is not something we want to do. I would have most likely only given a warning to the user that we had some problems fitting his text and not bothered with anything else. IMHO we are trying to be too clever for our own good with this algorithm.However I don't care enough to block this patch. This message should be enough encouragement for anyone who wants to revert that behavior.

text: Patch Set 8:(21 comments)So I have one general comment related to the concept and a few related to the actual implementation.I'm not sure if that is really a good approach. In general I think instead of trying to change the equation we should make it clear to the user that we could not layout his chart correctly and that he should look into fixing the layout. So a more make the user aware of the problems than trying to work around problems.I suggest that you contact the UX team and tell them about your idea and my concerns.Related to the code:I'm not happy with some of the special values, especially the use of 0 as formula length to signal that the formula length can be ignored. I think a cleaner solution is something like sal_Int32* pFormulaLength = NULL and require the caller to use a NULL pointer to signal that the parameter needs to be ignored. That makes IMHO the code cleaner as it is directly obvious that we are not talking about a zero length string.I'd also like to see a comment why the aValueString checks are necessary despite the earlier checks that this value is not handled in that place.I'm going to look into the localization issue that I saw as that looks like a serious problem.And finally I was unable to follow all corner cases in the new code. So if we are really going to merge this code, I'd like to see a unit test for nearly all special cases. Additionally a few comments explaining what we are doing would be helpful. Currently it is nearly impossible to figure out why some cases need special handling. An exmaple for that (which I have still no idea why it is correct) is that in one case we multiply nFormulaLength by 2 if aValueString is "1".This was a really review and I suggest that you start by talking to the UX guys. If they have more questions they can contact me.

text: Patch Set 8:I suppose the commit message should talk about OpenGLContext. The OpenGLHandler is supposed to be only using OpenGL methods, normally only creating a context is platform dependent.Sadly I think that even this split is not perfect as the OpenGL context creation is not completely aligned to platforms. E.g. EGL vs GLX on Unix like platforms.
Text: Patch Set 8:I suppose the commit message should talk about OpenGLContext. The OpenGLHandler is supposed to be only using OpenGL methods, normally only creating a context is platform dependent.Sadly I think that even this split is not perfect as the OpenGL context creation is not completely aligned to platforms. E.g. EGL vs GLX on Unix like platforms.

text: Patch Set 3:> For now it looks like a lot of code for something that should be > easily detectable in the codeIt isn't that much code (just get the encoding + block changing it later), it's just spread across many files due to the nature of sc classes (BaseClass->BaseClassImpl etc.), and ~half of the change is for the test. > and I would not even mind showing a > dialog when we don't find a CODEPAGE entry.OK, but Eike said in tdf#94382 that he doesn't like this. That was the main reason I did it that way.There is also another reason: This is not only about files w/o CODEPAGE, but also about files with *wrong* CODEPAGE (and also *wrong* data in the FONT record), e.g tdf#37408, tdf#90210.There are lots of 3rd party apps the create BIFF5 files, manyof them are broken in different ways. Giving users some way toopen all those files is worth it IMHO.
Text: Patch Set 3:> For now it looks like a lot of code for something that should be > easily detectable in the codeIt isn't that much code (just get the encoding + block changing it later), it's just spread across many files due to the nature of sc classes (BaseClass->BaseClassImpl etc.), and ~half of the change is for the test. > and I would not even mind showing a > dialog when we don't find a CODEPAGE entry.OK, but Eike said in tdf#94382 that he doesn't like this. That was the main reason I did it that way.There is also another reason: This is not only about files w/o CODEPAGE, but also about files with *wrong* CODEPAGE (and also *wrong* data in the FONT record), e.g tdf#37408, tdf#90210.There are lots of 3rd party apps the create BIFF5 files, manyof them are broken in different ways. Giving users some way toopen all those files is worth it IMHO.

text: Patch Set 5:> Maxim, why did you push this without waiting for comments and an > outcome of the discussion, effectively ignoring concerns?Ah, sorry. This patch is about a week in review, and I was bit unsure what the silence means, does it mean that you're not interested to comment on it, or maybe silent agreement. And I was not comfortable to ping you again... Also Markus raised some questions, and I tried to answer, but didn't get any response on that, which confused me even more. And I can't keep the patch forever in the review queue, just because of this uncertainty... So turns out I didn't understand the situation right, sorry for that.What should I do now? Should I revert this patch?

text: Patch Set 5:> Ah, sorry. This patch is about a week in review, and I was bit > unsure what the silence means, does it mean that you're not > interested to comment on it, or maybe silent agreement.Well, you submitted this on Friday, then was a long weekend with Mondaybeing a public holiday, on which Markus even aded his comments, and thenyou got impatient already after two days. > And I was > not comfortable to ping you again... Also Markus raised some > questions, and I tried to answer, but didn't get any response on > that, which confused me even more.You have to be more patient. We all do also other things than reviewingpatches, and if there is no answer after two days then just wait longer,or ping after a week. > And I can't keep the patch > forever in the review queue, just because of this uncertainty...Of course you can. A patch can linger in gerrit for longer time thanjust a week. Pushing nevertheless and silently ignoring and overridingconcerns of others makes people angry. This is not good style. > So > turns out I didn't understand the situation right, sorry for that.Ok, let's go on to be productive. > What should I do now? Should I revert this patch?I guess that's the best at the current stage.

text: Patch Set 4:When you upload a new patch set that addresses reviewers' comments, please keep it based on the same parent commit as the previous patch set.  Otherwise, checking how the comments have been addressed becomes very difficult, and reviewers effectively need to restart from scratch.
Text: Patch Set 4:When you upload a new patch set that addresses reviewers' comments, please keep it based on the same parent commit as the previous patch set.  Otherwise, checking how the comments have been addressed becomes very difficult, and reviewers effectively need to restart from scratch.

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1This approach of transporting a localized "wrong password" hint via the css.ucb.AuthenticationRequest.Diagnostic field is still problematic:  For one, it links the GUI-agnostic ucb code to GUI-specific, localized strings in svtools.  (The Diagnostic field is intended to pass through additional, protocol-dependent information from a server, which necessarily needs to be non-localized.)  For another, it only addresses the cmis UCP, not other UCPs using the AuthenticationRequest in a similar way, ftp and webdav.In f88554edd46d2dc8d6c8eaba74c89ccd3e537104 "Related tdf#98644: In login dialog, give a hint that the password was wrong" I have now extended the uui's (GUI) AuthenticationRequest handler, to give a better hint that a login dialog is presented to the user because the previously entered password was wrong.I would suggest to drop from this change those parts that set a localized "wrong password" hint in the AuthenticationRequest's Diagnostic field, and instead just make sure that the AuthenticationRequest's Password field is set when an old, wrong password from a previous, failed login attempt is already available.
Text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1This approach of transporting a localized "wrong password" hint via the css.ucb.AuthenticationRequest.Diagnostic field is still problematic:  For one, it links the GUI-agnostic ucb code to GUI-specific, localized strings in svtools.  (The Diagnostic field is intended to pass through additional, protocol-dependent information from a server, which necessarily needs to be non-localized.)  For another, it only addresses the cmis UCP, not other UCPs using the AuthenticationRequest in a similar way, ftp and webdav.In f88554edd46d2dc8d6c8eaba74c89ccd3e537104 "Related tdf#98644: In login dialog, give a hint that the password was wrong" I have now extended the uui's (GUI) AuthenticationRequest handler, to give a better hint that a login dialog is presented to the user because the previously entered password was wrong.I would suggest to drop from this change those parts that set a localized "wrong password" hint in the AuthenticationRequest's Diagnostic field, and instead just make sure that the AuthenticationRequest's Password field is set when an old, wrong password from a previous, failed login attempt is already available.

text: Patch Set 6:> I don't think this is a good change.  The default css.task.InteractionHandler > service that is created here presents UI to the user.  It should be > controllable by the UCP's client what kind of interaction shall > happen; if no interaction handler is given, the UCP shall fail the > client's request with an exception.it will still fail if it's the case, the hanlder it's only used in case of Web/DAV authentication needed, not in exception bypass.That is, if an exception is thrown, it will be reported back, cancelCommandExecution will still work using the original CommandEnv, the one set by the client.
Text: Patch Set 6:> I don't think this is a good change.  The default css.task.InteractionHandler > service that is created here presents UI to the user.  It should be > controllable by the UCP's client what kind of interaction shall > happen; if no interaction handler is given, the UCP shall fail the > client's request with an exception.it will still fail if it's the case, the hanlder it's only used in case of Web/DAV authentication needed, not in exception bypass.That is, if an exception is thrown, it will be reported back, cancelCommandExecution will still work using the original CommandEnv, the one set by the client.

text: Patch Set 6:> > I don't think this is a good change.  The default > css.task.InteractionHandler > > service that is created here presents UI to the user.  It should > be > > controllable by the UCP's client what kind of interaction shall > > happen; if no interaction handler is given, the UCP shall fail > the > > client's request with an exception. >  > it will still fail if it's the case, the hanlder it's only used in > case of Web/DAV authentication needed, not in exception bypass. >  > That is, if an exception is thrown, it will be reported back, > cancelCommandExecution will still work using the original > CommandEnv, the one set by the client.I think you misunderstood me.  If the client code (on purpose) passes in no interaction handler for some command to the UCP, and the UCP gets into a situation where it would want to consult a passed-in interaction handler, then the UCP must abort the command by throwing an exception back to the client, instead of creating its own interaction handler out of thin air.
Text: Patch Set 6:> > I don't think this is a good change.  The default > css.task.InteractionHandler > > service that is created here presents UI to the user.  It should > be > > controllable by the UCP's client what kind of interaction shall > > happen; if no interaction handler is given, the UCP shall fail > the > > client's request with an exception. >  > it will still fail if it's the case, the hanlder it's only used in > case of Web/DAV authentication needed, not in exception bypass. >  > That is, if an exception is thrown, it will be reported back, > cancelCommandExecution will still work using the original > CommandEnv, the one set by the client.I think you misunderstood me.  If the client code (on purpose) passes in no interaction handler for some command to the UCP, and the UCP gets into a situation where it would want to consult a passed-in interaction handler, then the UCP must abort the command by throwing an exception back to the client, instead of creating its own interaction handler out of thin air.

text: Patch Set 6:> > > Tested and it solved the problem. > > > > which problem? >  > it provides a handler here: > http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/ucb/source/ucp/webdav-neon/NeonSession.cxx#455 >  > needed for certificate display/storing.But that doesn't answer my question:  What is the problem this change wants to solve?
Text: Patch Set 6:> > > Tested and it solved the problem. > > > > which problem? >  > it provides a handler here: > http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/ucb/source/ucp/webdav-neon/NeonSession.cxx#455 >  > needed for certificate display/storing.But that doesn't answer my question:  What is the problem this change wants to solve?

text: Patch Set 6:> But that doesn't answer my question:  What is the problem this > change wants to solve?I'll try to give an explanation, by describing what happens.Please have a look at this gerrit already pushed (originally it was in the same series with this one):https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/gitweb?p=core.git;a=commitdiff;h=e1ae21889a214ea3b6f79018d3c710d75fc8fba6probably I should have kept both merged in a single gerrit patch set.Anyway, Kendy description I removed explained what this patch fixes.This is the callback Kenky is referring to in his comment (NeonSession_CertificationNotify):http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/ucb/source/ucp/webdav-neon/NeonSession.cxx#354in this callback, here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/ucb/source/ucp/webdav-neon/NeonSession.cxx#455the interaction handler is needed because it's the only way the user is notified that something went wrong during web connection because of SSL certificate problem.If a CommandEnv is available, the certificate is further checked, the real check is performed here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/uui/source/iahndl-ssl.cxx#248In handleCertificateValidationRequest_  the user is asked if the certificate can be trusted anyway, should some of the checks carried out there fails.Upon returning of a successfull interaction '0' is returned to neon, which go on processing the request.In the use case addressed with the patch (e.g. accessing a mozilla web site) the user interaction is not called, because the test Kendy reports as failing("In the case of services.addons.mozilla.com, the certificate is for versioncheck.addons.mozilla.com, but it also has...") is addressed inside handleCertificateValidationRequest_starting here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/uui/source/iahndl-ssl.cxx#276down to this last check:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/uui/source/iahndl-ssl.cxx#300That can't be done if CommandEnv is missing.If this patch is not present, NeonSession_CertificationNotify always returns '1', returning '1' to neon, neon will stop the processing notifiying the caller 'Server certificate verification failed: issuer is not trusted',which in due time it's converted to a 'ucb::InteractiveNetworkReadException'.The root call to access file is this:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/cui/source/options/personalization.cxx#582As you can see the catch clause doesn't deal with the exception mentioned above, and besides, nothing can be done by the UCB client if SSL certificates aresuspicious or wrong or in need of a deeper check.The missing CommandEnv is common in UCB client use of Web/WebDAV connection, what do we do when we end up with the same problem, about certificates?Or in another possibility, not yet addressed, if the remote web server challenges to obtain credentials and no interaction handler is available to serve them?

checks carried out there fails.Upon returning of a successfull interaction '0' is returned to neon, which go on processing the request.In the use case addressed with the patch (e.g. accessing a mozilla web site) the user interaction is not called, because the test Kendy reports as failing("In the case of services.addons.mozilla.com, the certificate is for versioncheck.addons.mozilla.com, but it also has...") is addressed inside handleCertificateValidationRequest_starting here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/uui/source/iahndl-ssl.cxx#276down to this last check:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/uui/source/iahndl-ssl.cxx#300That can't be done if CommandEnv is missing.If this patch is not present, NeonSession_CertificationNotify always returns '1', returning '1' to neon, neon will stop the processing notifiying the caller 'Server certificate verification failed: issuer is not trusted',which in due time it's converted to a text: Patch Set 6:> > XSimpleFileAccess wrapper does have a method to set the > interaction > > handler >  > Ah, right, css.ucb.XSimpleFileAccess.setInteractionHandler.  The > code in cui/source/options/personalization.cxx can supposedly only > be triggered by GUI interaction, so it should be OK to call >  > xFileAccess->setInteractionHandler( > css::task::InteractionHandler::create(xContext)); >  > there to set the default (GUI) interaction handler.this is what I checked first.Works, but in case of errors (Internet connection, temporary DNS problem or anything such) there is a verbose error indication coming out of ucbhelper::cancelCommandExecution.Looking at the code in cui/source/options/personalization.cxx the original developer intended disabling it.I was thinking more on the line to implement something similar tocomphelper::StillReadWriteInteraction in order to interact with the user only when certificate problems are involved and have the other exception reported back, specifically thought to be used when a simple file access is needed.May came in handy on other occasions (some of them I already spotted for WebDAV).What do you think. ?
Text: Patch Set 6:> > XSimpleFileAccess wrapper does have a method to set the > interaction > > handler >  > Ah, right, css.ucb.XSimpleFileAccess.setInteractionHandler.  The > code in cui/source/options/personalization.cxx can supposedly only > be triggered by GUI interaction, so it should be OK to call >  > xFileAccess->setInteractionHandler( > css::task::InteractionHandler::create(xContext)); >  > there to set the default (GUI) interaction handler.this is what I checked first.Works, but in case of errors (Internet connection, temporary DNS problem or anything such) there is a verbose error indication coming out of ucbhelper::cancelCommandExecution.Looking at the code in cui/source/options/personalization.cxx the original developer intended disabling it.I was thinking more on the line to implement something similar tocomphelper::StillReadWriteInteraction in order to interact with the user only when certificate problems are involved and have the other exception reported back, specifically thought to be used when a simple file access is needed.May came in handy on other occasions (some of them I already spotted for WebDAV).What do you think. ?

text: Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Verified+1rewrote your patch to use the original files as from google's repo (i.e. black version), and use android:tint to make them white instead.Also use appcompat support for vector images (i.e. no need for creating/shipping png versions of the icons anymore), although requires a quirk for TextView image, as reading vector from resource was disabled in 23.3.0 version, see https://plus.google.com/+AndroidDevelopers/posts/iTDmFiGrVne for details ÔÇô no such problem when you can use android:icon or android:src (as appcompat:srcCompat) though.Also extended the set of replaced icons to cover all except the laser pointer one and applogo/icon.laser pointer one could probably also be replaced by using LayerDrawable based on ic_adjust_black_24dp.xml (at least the pointer-off version can be replaced by that easily)
Text: Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Verified+1rewrote your patch to use the original files as from google's repo (i.e. black version), and use android:tint to make them white instead.Also use appcompat support for vector images (i.e. no need for creating/shipping png versions of the icons anymore), although requires a quirk for TextView image, as reading vector from resource was disabled in 23.3.0 version, see https://plus.google.com/+AndroidDevelopers/posts/iTDmFiGrVne for details 脭脟么 no such problem when you can use android:icon or android:src (as appcompat:srcCompat) though.Also extended the set of replaced icons to cover all except the laser pointer one and applogo/icon.laser pointer one could probably also be replaced by using LayerDrawable based on ic_adjust_black_24dp.xml (at least the pointer-off version can be replaced by that easily)

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)step 1 was to find all unused using declarationsby searching all and check if the symbol reappears in the source file. Even if it's in dead code or comments, but exclude appearances in #include statements.this was done by script, header were excluded the top removes symbols were:72	xinterface60	exception *36	xmultiservicefactory35	mutexguard35	runtimeexception *20	xpropertyset14	xpropertysetinfo13	illegalargumentexception *13	xparameters13	xpreparedstatement12	xcloseable11	wrappedtargetexception11	xcomponent11	xmodel10	nosuchelementexception *10	theme10	xresultset*) unclear to me where they usually come from#!/bin/bashIFS=$'\n'str_search="^\s*using\s+[\w:]+::\w+;"for str_using in $( git grep -nP "$str_search" ); do        filename=$(echo $str_using | sed -r 's/^(.*\.\w+):.*;.*/\1/')        symbol=$(echo "$str_using" | perl -pe "s|^.*using\s+(?:(?:::)?\w+)*::(\w+);.*|\1|")        line=$(echo "$str_using" | perl -pe "s|^.*:([0-9]+):.*;|\1|")        lines=$(git grep -P "([^\w"\""/]|^)$symbol([^\w]|$)" $filename| wc -l)        usages=$(($lines - 1))        echo 'in file '$filename': symbol: '$symbol' usages: '$usages        if [ $lines -eq 1 ]        then                echo 'in file '$filename':#'$line' declaration of '$symbol' is unused'                sed -i -r "/[^[:alnum:]_]$symbol;/d" "$filename"        fidonenext step will be to check if removed declarations had a included header with the same name in the file and try to remove them.e.g. using ::com::sun::star::lang::XServiceInfo; got removed so remove#include <com/sun/star/lang/XServiceInfo.hpp> too.
Text: xresultset*) unclear to me where they usually come from#!/bin/bashIFS=$'\n'str_search=""^\s*using\s+[\w:]+::\w+;""for str_using in $( git grep -nP ""$str_search"" ); do        filename=$(echo $str_using | sed -r 's/^(.*\.\w+):.*;.*/\1/')        symbol=$(echo ""$str_using"" | perl -pe ""s|^.*using\s+(?:(?:::)?\w+)*::(\w+);.*|\1|"")        line=$(echo ""$str_using"" | perl -pe ""s|^.*:([0-9]+):.*;|\1|"")        lines=$(git grep -P ""([^\w""\""""/]|^)$symbol([^\w]|$)"" $filename| wc -l)        usages=$(($lines - 1))        echo 'in file '$filename': symbol: '$symbol' usages: '$usages        if [ $lines -eq 1 ]        then                echo 'in file '$filename':#'$line' declaration of '$symbol' is unused'                sed -i -r ""/[^[:alnum:]_]$symbol;/d"" ""$filename""        fidonenext step will be to check if removed declarations had a included header with the same name in the file and try to remove them.e.g. using ::com::sun::star::lang::XServiceInfo; got removed so remove#include <com/sun/star/lang/XServiceInfo.hpp> too."

text: Patch Set 2:> Note that some sub-menus are implemented as separate popup menu > controllers, and as such populated only upon menu activation. So if > you really need the full menu structure without executing the vcl > menu, you should at least do a fake call to the vcl menu activation > callback. (The other alternative would be to change > ResourceMenuController to create the MenuBarManager instance > earlier for this case, and then change also MenuBarManager::FillMenuManager > to create the controllers).I opted for the first one: doing a fake call, and that seemed to have done the trick. >  > But be aware that some popup menu controllers don't use standart > dispatch command for their items, as they implement them > internally. So the approach of "get the .uno command from the menu > structure, and later execute it" won't work for such cases.I guess we would deal with that later.Thanks for your pointers and suggestions. Saved me some time looking here and there and then realizing :-)

text: Patch Set 1:Note that some sub-menus are implemented as separate popup menu controllers, and as such populated only upon menu activation. So if you really need the full menu structure without executing the vcl menu, you should at least do a fake call to the vcl menu activation callback. (The other alternative would be to change ResourceMenuController to create the MenuBarManager instance earlier for this case, and then change also MenuBarManager::FillMenuManager to create the controllers).But be aware that some popup menu controllers don't use standart dispatch command for their items, as they implement them internally. So the approach of "get the .uno command from the menu structure, and later execute it" won't work for such cases.
Text: Patch Set 1:Note that some sub-menus are implemented as separate popup menu controllers, and as such populated only upon menu activation. So if you really need the full menu structure without executing the vcl menu, you should at least do a fake call to the vcl menu activation callback. (The other alternative would be to change ResourceMenuController to create the MenuBarManager instance earlier for this case, and then change also MenuBarManager::FillMenuManager to create the controllers).But be aware that some popup menu controllers don't use standart dispatch command for their items, as they implement them internally. So the approach of "get the .uno command from the menu structure, and later execute it" won't work for such cases.

text: Patch Set 5:> In this case, nDstLocation was > always 0, so nDstLocation<<1 (multiply by 2, right?) didn't do > anything this time, but in other situations it might be critical.I'm not sure what had in mind that the person who wrote this code to do the nDstLocation*2, I think that it tries to compensate later for fTemp but as this was always 0, that didn't work correctly.In any case with the new code this is not necessary anymore, it was only used when mirroring and the new code has the same behavior as the original when there is no mirroring and additionally, treats also mirroring correctly >  > Also, if nOutDimention == 1, you will have a divide by zero > exception.Correct, a have added a condition to check for this and make fReverseScale equal to 0 in this situation. Thanks :)Apologizes for the delay in answering.
Text: Patch Set 5:> In this case, nDstLocation was > always 0, so nDstLocation<<1 (multiply by 2, right?) didn't do > anything this time, but in other situations it might be critical.I'm not sure what had in mind that the person who wrote this code to do the nDstLocation*2, I think that it tries to compensate later for fTemp but as this was always 0, that didn't work correctly.In any case with the new code this is not necessary anymore, it was only used when mirroring and the new code has the same behavior as the original when there is no mirroring and additionally, treats also mirroring correctly >  > Also, if nOutDimention == 1, you will have a divide by zero > exception.Correct, a have added a condition to check for this and make fReverseScale equal to 0 in this situation. Thanks :)Apologizes for the delay in answering.

text: Patch Set 2:Not providing a code review - don't feel qualified b/c I don't understand all of the logic.The fix worked for the test document on Mint 12.04.  (16.04 already worked before the fix.)  However, I'm afraid that too much may have been changed in the code - so that it works for this instance, but doesn't work in other situations.  In this case, nDstLocation was always 0, so nDstLocation<<1 (multiply by 2, right?) didn't do anything this time, but in other situations it might be critical. Also, if nOutDimention == 1, you will have a divide by zero exception.So perhaps your logic is fine (I don't know), but my gut feeling is that it fits the test case only and will break other situations.
Text: Patch Set 2:Not providing a code review - don't feel qualified b/c I don't understand all of the logic.The fix worked for the test document on Mint 12.04.  (16.04 already worked before the fix.)  However, I'm afraid that too much may have been changed in the code - so that it works for this instance, but doesn't work in other situations.  In this case, nDstLocation was always 0, so nDstLocation<<1 (multiply by 2, right?) didn't do anything this time, but in other situations it might be critical. Also, if nOutDimention == 1, you will have a divide by zero exception.So perhaps your logic is fine (I don't know), but my gut feeling is that it fits the test case only and will break other situations.

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2I've updated the patch slightly, most notably I've added a on/off switch to the Writer's menu, and removed the env. var (not needed when there is a switch in the menu).Unfortunately I fear we have to abandon this approach because the sfx2 childwindows appear only inside the shell; while here it is desirable to show the notebookbar outside of the shell (ideally between the menu and the toolbars).Szymon - unless Samuel has an idea how to actually use the sfx2 childwindow but a better way, I fear we should not merge this; but still, this for sure counts as an advanced Easy Hack for the GSoC (please do quote me on this should anybody ask).Not abandoning it yet, for the case Samuel has a way how to fix the concern, and yet still use the childwindow...
Text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2I've updated the patch slightly, most notably I've added a on/off switch to the Writer's menu, and removed the env. var (not needed when there is a switch in the menu).Unfortunately I fear we have to abandon this approach because the sfx2 childwindows appear only inside the shell; while here it is desirable to show the notebookbar outside of the shell (ideally between the menu and the toolbars).Szymon - unless Samuel has an idea how to actually use the sfx2 childwindow but a better way, I fear we should not merge this; but still, this for sure counts as an advanced Easy Hack for the GSoC (please do quote me on this should anybody ask).Not abandoning it yet, for the case Samuel has a way how to fix the concern, and yet still use the childwindow...

text: Patch Set 3:> Unfortunately I fear we have to abandon this approach because the sfx2 childwindows appear only inside the shell; while here it is desirable to show the notebookbar outside of the shell (ideally between the menu and the toolbars).Do we really need to have both the classic toolbars *and* the Notebookbar visible? I wouldn't have this as a requirement.Although it might become a problem that the Sidebar child window takes away width from the Notebookbar, but maybe there's a solution for that?
Text: Patch Set 3:> Unfortunately I fear we have to abandon this approach because the sfx2 childwindows appear only inside the shell; while here it is desirable to show the notebookbar outside of the shell (ideally between the menu and the toolbars).Do we really need to have both the classic toolbars *and* the Notebookbar visible? I wouldn't have this as a requirement.Although it might become a problem that the Sidebar child window takes away width from the Notebookbar, but maybe there's a solution for that?

text: Patch Set 3:This picture discusses the toolbar docking areas, not the childwindow docking areas; the childwindows (and sidebar too) are inside the thing that is marked as "Document View" in the picture.Wrt. the toolbars + notebookbar visible at the same time - that's not a requirement for the tabbed notebookbar for sure, but I fear still necessary for the other use cases, like the simplebar or extendedbar :-( - at least for some transition period.To improve the positioning in this patch though, it's actually possible to do:-    SetAlignment(SfxChildAlignment::TOP);+    SetAlignment(SfxChildAlignment::HIGHESTTOP);that positions that over the sidebar, but still, it's all inside the "Document View".
Text: Patch Set 3:This picture discusses the toolbar docking areas, not the childwindow docking areas; the childwindows (and sidebar too) are inside the thing that is marked as "Document View" in the picture.Wrt. the toolbars + notebookbar visible at the same time - that's not a requirement for the tabbed notebookbar for sure, but I fear still necessary for the other use cases, like the simplebar or extendedbar :-( - at least for some transition period.To improve the positioning in this patch though, it's actually possible to do:-    SetAlignment(SfxChildAlignment::TOP);+    SetAlignment(SfxChildAlignment::HIGHESTTOP);that positions that over the sidebar, but still, it's all inside the "Document View".

text: Patch Set 4:OK, so managed to plug it together; the core of the work still stays is the vcl (and has to, I'm afraid), but it is now created (and can be potentially managed) via the childwindow infrastructure.If we continue this way, I suppose we'll need to add some code to show / hide according to what the childwindow does, as we cannot just do a SetWindow(pNotebookBarWindow); but otherwise the approach looks usable - the buttons are clickable etc.I think I'll just remove .uno:Notebookbar from the menu.xml, and we can push this to master :-)
Text: Patch Set 4:OK, so managed to plug it together; the core of the work still stays is the vcl (and has to, I'm afraid), but it is now created (and can be potentially managed) via the childwindow infrastructure.If we continue this way, I suppose we'll need to add some code to show / hide according to what the childwindow does, as we cannot just do a SetWindow(pNotebookBarWindow); but otherwise the approach looks usable - the buttons are clickable etc.I think I'll just remove .uno:Notebookbar from the menu.xml, and we can push this to master :-)

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1(5 comments)So there seem to be still a few merge errors in the patch (e.g. in configure.ac) as well as the handling of ENABLE_GLTF which of course depends on ENABLE_OPENGL.Now for the bigger question that I tried to discuss with thorsten once. As I think we will never advertise such a build configuration (IMHO the concept is completely broken (either OpenGL is an optional dependency and no mandatory feature may depend on it or there is no need to make anything optional based on OpenGL)) you should make sure that there is a big warning in the configure output that nobody using this configuration can expect any help or support from the project. In general I think that adding that many #if statements that are not localized is a bad idea but as far as I know I'm the only one with sub objections.
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1(5 comments)So there seem to be still a few merge errors in the patch (e.g. in configure.ac) as well as the handling of ENABLE_GLTF which of course depends on ENABLE_OPENGL.Now for the bigger question that I tried to discuss with thorsten once. As I think we will never advertise such a build configuration (IMHO the concept is completely broken (either OpenGL is an optional dependency and no mandatory feature may depend on it or there is no need to make anything optional based on OpenGL)) you should make sure that there is a big warning in the configure output that nobody using this configuration can expect any help or support from the project. In general I think that adding that many #if statements that are not localized is a bad idea but as far as I know I'm the only one with sub objections.

text: Patch Set 2:> (5 comments) >  > So there seem to be still a few merge errors in the patch (e.g. in > configure.ac) as well as the handling of ENABLE_GLTF which of > course depends on ENABLE_OPENGL. >  > Now for the bigger question that I tried to discuss with thorsten > once. As I think we will never advertise such a build configuration > (IMHO the concept is completely broken (either OpenGL is an > optional dependency and no mandatory feature may depend on it or > there is no need to make anything optional based on OpenGL)) you > should make sure that there is a big warning in the configure > output that nobody using this configuration can expect any help or > support from the project. In general I think that adding that many > #if statements that are not localized is a bad idea but as far as I > know I'm the only one with sub objections.The next upload will fix the problem you mentioned. This build configuration without dependencies to libraries not available on typical server installations has been around for ages. End users will of course not use them. But you are right that features that are needed to load/save/print/API-manipulate documents  should not depend on 'optional' libraries or should have a headless alternative.

As I think we will never advertise such a build configuration > (IMHO the concept is completely broken (either OpenGL is an > optional dependency and no mandatory feature may depend on it or > there is no need to make anything optional based on OpenGL)) you > should make sure that there is a big warning in the configure > output that nobody using this configuration can expect any help or > support from the project. In general I think that adding that many > #if statements that are not localized is a bad idea but as far as I > know I'm the only one with sub objections.The next upload will fix the problem you mentioned. This build configuration without dependencies to libraries not available on typical server installations has been around for ages. End users will of course not use them. But you are right that features that are needed to load/save/print/API-manipulate documents  should not depend on 'optional' libraries or should have a headless alternative.

text: Patch Set 2:>  > This build configuration without dependencies to libraries not > available on typical server installations has been around for ages. > End users will of course not use them. But you are right that > features that are needed to load/save/print/API-manipulate > documents  should not depend on 'optional' libraries or should have > a headless alternative.Actually my argumentation is the other way around. Currently OpenGL is accepted as a dependency of LibreOffice and we have been adding features based on OpenGL so we should not make it optional. Any change to this policy would need to go through the ESC.

text: Patch Set 2:What do you mean about virtual methods / overrides? I didn't see any better option that would allow to reduce code duplication :)The instance method/singleton, I added it because I need to pass C-style function to OS APIs instead of non-static class method. And inside that function I need to access the class members (callSignalHandler, etc.), so I cannot just make it static.Though maybe it is possible to make all class members static, but I think I saw some difficulties with this approach too...
Text: Patch Set 2:What do you mean about virtual methods / overrides? I didn't see any better option that would allow to reduce code duplication :)The instance method/singleton, I added it because I need to pass C-style function to OS APIs instead of non-static class method. And inside that function I need to access the class members (callSignalHandler, etc.), so I cannot just make it static.Though maybe it is possible to make all class members static, but I think I saw some difficulties with this approach too...

text: Patch Set 9:so do i see it right that CURL was actually shipping its own trusted CA database, and with this patch it uses (on linux) the NSS bundled CA database (nssckbi.so) instead?and this means that we can drop the nss-pem.patch too since that was some mystery stuff added for curl, presumably because curl's bundled CAs are stored as PEM ?
Text: Patch Set 9:so do i see it right that CURL was actually shipping its own trusted CA database, and with this patch it uses (on linux) the NSS bundled CA database (nssckbi.so) instead?and this means that we can drop the nss-pem.patch too since that was some mystery stuff added for curl, presumably because curl's bundled CAs are stored as PEM ?

text: Patch Set 9:> so do i see it right that CURL was actually shipping its own > trusted CA database, and with this patch it uses (on linux) the NSS > bundled CA database (nssckbi.so) instead? >  > and this means that we can drop the nss-pem.patch too since that > was some mystery stuff added for curl, presumably because curl's > bundled CAs are stored as PEM ?What I found is that without the --without-ca-bundle --without-ca-path curl configure option curl was activating a hard coded path that differed from TDF's build baseline (CentOS) wrt mine. Actually disabling ssl+curl in a cross build situation (e.g. build on rpm pack distro, use in a deb pack distro).The bundle curl config options refers to are CA certificates.This <https://curl.haxx.se/docs/sslcerts.html>, topic 'Certificate Verification' - point 3. below may give some terse explanation.
Text: Patch Set 9:> so do i see it right that CURL was actually shipping its own > trusted CA database, and with this patch it uses (on linux) the NSS > bundled CA database (nssckbi.so) instead? >  > and this means that we can drop the nss-pem.patch too since that > was some mystery stuff added for curl, presumably because curl's > bundled CAs are stored as PEM ?What I found is that without the --without-ca-bundle --without-ca-path curl configure option curl was activating a hard coded path that differed from TDF's build baseline (CentOS) wrt mine. Actually disabling ssl+curl in a cross build situation (e.g. build on rpm pack distro, use in a deb pack distro).The bundle curl config options refers to are CA certificates.This <https://curl.haxx.se/docs/sslcerts.html>, topic 'Certificate Verification' - point 3. below may give some terse explanation.

text: Patch Set 9:oh now i find it in curl's acinclude.m4dnl regarding the paths this will scan:dnl /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt Debian systemsdnl /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt Redhat and Mandrivadnl /usr/share/ssl/certs/ca-bundle.crt old(er) Redhatdnl /usr/local/share/certs/ca-root.crt FreeBSDdnl /etc/ssl/cert.pem OpenBSDdnl /etc/ssl/certs/ (ca path) SUSE- so (as usual) there is a ridiculous nightmare of pointless distribution incompatibility and this would pick some random path depending on the build host, which is going to be pretty useless anyway
Text: Patch Set 9:oh now i find it in curl's acinclude.m4dnl regarding the paths this will scan:dnl /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt Debian systemsdnl /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt Redhat and Mandrivadnl /usr/share/ssl/certs/ca-bundle.crt old(er) Redhatdnl /usr/local/share/certs/ca-root.crt FreeBSDdnl /etc/ssl/cert.pem OpenBSDdnl /etc/ssl/certs/ (ca path) SUSE- so (as usual) there is a ridiculous nightmare of pointless distribution incompatibility and this would pick some random path depending on the build host, which is going to be pretty useless anyway

text: Patch Set 3:Hi Bj├Ârn,of course this is only an in-between step due to working with the (old) Rectangles. In the future this may all go to basegfx::B2DRange where these values may be valid input.The reason shit happens here is that Rectangle::GetWidth() substracts Right from Left, both are long. Thus, the source data has double the range of the result. It is questionable (and I thought about and decided against) to correct this in the Rectangle itself - what value to return then...?Also preventing correction is that in Rectangle, sometimes Right being smaller than Left is *used* to e.g. express that the object is mirrored - one of the rasons to base basegfx::B2DRange on Min/Max, so that can not happen by design.
Text: Patch Set 3:Hi Bj鈹溍俽n,of course this is only an in-between step due to working with the (old) Rectangles. In the future this may all go to basegfx::B2DRange where these values may be valid input.The reason shit happens here is that Rectangle::GetWidth() substracts Right from Left, both are long. Thus, the source data has double the range of the result. It is questionable (and I thought about and decided against) to correct this in the Rectangle itself - what value to return then...?Also preventing correction is that in Rectangle, sometimes Right being smaller than Left is *used* to e.g. express that the object is mirrored - one of the rasons to base basegfx::B2DRange on Min/Max, so that can not happen by design.

text: Patch Set 4:Yes, I thought about that when doing it, eventually to add a semaphor there, but decided against. Setting the flag is quite a single-operation and the last one the spawned task does. Even in the badest case (task switch at that moment) all would be good since only return and end-of-method codes are executed. It is no atomic opertation in the semaphor sense, but safe enough in this case from my POV.I will take a look at std::atomic_flag/std::atomic<bool>...
Text: Patch Set 4:Yes, I thought about that when doing it, eventually to add a semaphor there, but decided against. Setting the flag is quite a single-operation and the last one the spawned task does. Even in the badest case (task switch at that moment) all would be good since only return and end-of-method codes are executed. It is no atomic opertation in the semaphor sense, but safe enough in this case from my POV.I will take a look at std::atomic_flag/std::atomic<bool>...

text: Patch Set 4:Hi Mike, the test doc is very complete, as it needs to be. Looks as if we are very close to what PPT does. Still, I see some differences.- Impressive how close we get in many cases- Green is hard to read against blue, if it is simple to change that I would prefer something with more ocntrast- Diffs on some pages, e.g. Page1, shape 'Oval 71'4th line, 2nd from left, centerd on PPT, left in our version. Other diffs 'Oval 73', 'Oval 74', 'Oval 75-79' (hard to see with green), 'Oval 91-99', 'Oval 111, 113-119'- More on other pagesI hope you do not think I am too nit-picking, but of course to get that right is central for compatibility. It might be that green and red mean something like 'this should work, this not' that I do not know. I did not compare to current state without your change yet, so cannot say if it got better/worse, will do so now.For automatic comparison (test case): Hm. That would need to compare against PPT state or against a saved PPT state. Do we have a bitmap compare - it would be possible to get a bitmap from a whole page in a good resolution and compare against a saved PPT one of that page. Also single shapes, but that may be too expensive/runtime extensive
Text: Patch Set 4:Hi Mike, the test doc is very complete, as it needs to be. Looks as if we are very close to what PPT does. Still, I see some differences.- Impressive how close we get in many cases- Green is hard to read against blue, if it is simple to change that I would prefer something with more ocntrast- Diffs on some pages, e.g. Page1, shape 'Oval 71'4th line, 2nd from left, centerd on PPT, left in our version. Other diffs 'Oval 73', 'Oval 74', 'Oval 75-79' (hard to see with green), 'Oval 91-99', 'Oval 111, 113-119'- More on other pagesI hope you do not think I am too nit-picking, but of course to get that right is central for compatibility. It might be that green and red mean something like 'this should work, this not' that I do not know. I did not compare to current state without your change yet, so cannot say if it got better/worse, will do so now.For automatic comparison (test case): Hm. That would need to compare against PPT state or against a saved PPT state. Do we have a bitmap compare - it would be possible to get a bitmap from a whole page in a good resolution and compare against a saved PPT one of that page. Also single shapes, but that may be too expensive/runtime extensive

text: Patch Set 3:> Hm I don't like that you introduced a new method in > commandinfoprovider.Yes, this method doesn't fit at all with the current design of commandinfoprovider, and duplicates some code. Hopefully someone will pick the task of refactoring it anytime soon. > Is there a way to get the current frame in dbaccess?XDesktop::getCurrentFrame like everywhere else. The problem is that the code in question is used in the new db wizard, which isn't a frame by itself, so e.g. if you click "Base Database" in the start center, you'll get the start center as the current frame, and if you start as 'soffice --base' there will be no active frame at all.
Text: Patch Set 3:> Hm I don't like that you introduced a new method in > commandinfoprovider.Yes, this method doesn't fit at all with the current design of commandinfoprovider, and duplicates some code. Hopefully someone will pick the task of refactoring it anytime soon. > Is there a way to get the current frame in dbaccess?XDesktop::getCurrentFrame like everywhere else. The problem is that the code in question is used in the new db wizard, which isn't a frame by itself, so e.g. if you click "Base Database" in the start center, you'll get the start center as the current frame, and if you start as 'soffice --base' there will be no active frame at all.

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1Sorry - it is unclear to me why we do this work - calling GetEnglishSearchFontName un-conditionally - while the assert simplification looks nice (using analagous methods for both) the aClonedFamilyName intermediate looks unfortunate.Did GetEnglishSearchFontName become so cheap recently that we don't need the // FIXME: this is rather expensive ? - I worry about doing it again un-conditionally for no purpose outside of the debug build; but perhaps I'm missing the point (?).
Text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1Sorry - it is unclear to me why we do this work - calling GetEnglishSearchFontName un-conditionally - while the assert simplification looks nice (using analagous methods for both) the aClonedFamilyName intermediate looks unfortunate.Did GetEnglishSearchFontName become so cheap recently that we don't need the // FIXME: this is rather expensive ? - I worry about doing it again un-conditionally for no purpose outside of the debug build; but perhaps I'm missing the point (?).

text: Patch Set 1:Reverting commit f571104ef38ba9f7f6073e22c2374add7aa73887 (say commit A) fixes the problem with the first attachment of tdf#97897 and does not give a problem with the attachment of fdo#69244 (for which the reverted commit was). To be clear: with or without reverted commit A I cannot reproduce the problem of fdo#69244 with the attachment of fdo#69244.That makes me think that reverting commit A should be safe; AFAIK there was no performance goal of commit A.As this is an annoying/confusing bug, I would like the backport it to 5.0 and 5.1.The recalculation process with SetDirty and FormulaTree in unfamiliar terrain for me, I may well overlook important negative consequences.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)While this generally works there is some odd behavior if an area was selected and "Current selection only" checked. The result includes unrelated empty cells not part of the data area (note that the result should not include all empty cells of the sheet..) if the selection started left or above the actual data area.For example, data in C5 and C7 and C9, select B4:C9 and search string ^$ in selection only, Find All, and see columns A:B selected and also C1:C4.Witch "Current selection only" unchecked and Find All the result is correct. also if the selection does not start left or above the data area.Probably SearchAndReplaceEmptyCells() has a broken range detection.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)While this generally works there is some odd behavior if an area was selected and "Current selection only" checked. The result includes unrelated empty cells not part of the data area (note that the result should not include all empty cells of the sheet..) if the selection started left or above the actual data area.For example, data in C5 and C7 and C9, select B4:C9 and search string ^$ in selection only, Find All, and see columns A:B selected and also C1:C4.Witch "Current selection only" unchecked and Find All the result is correct. also if the selection does not start left or above the data area.Probably SearchAndReplaceEmptyCells() has a broken range detection.

Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Stephen,I changed the following files and got errors in the following ones when I removed the empty methods ->vba_compression.cxxvba_encryption.cxxwebdav_local_neon.cxxNot sure why that is happening.Could you give some insight.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2> Hi Stephen, > I changed the following files and got errors in the following ones > when I removed the empty methods -> > vba_compression.cxx > vba_encryption.cxx > webdav_local_neon.cxx > Not sure why that is happening. > Could you give some insight.Ah, right, those derive from test::BootstrapFixture[Base], which already overrides setUp/tearDown with functions that actually do something, and these tests don't want to get that done, so override a second time with empty functions.  Smells like those tests don't want to derive from test::BootstrapFixture[Base] in the first place.  I'll take a look at them independent of this gerrit change.
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2> Hi Stephen, > I changed the following files and got errors in the following ones > when I removed the empty methods -> > vba_compression.cxx > vba_encryption.cxx > webdav_local_neon.cxx > Not sure why that is happening. > Could you give some insight.Ah, right, those derive from test::BootstrapFixture[Base], which already overrides setUp/tearDown with functions that actually do something, and these tests don't want to get that done, so override a second time with empty functions.  Smells like those tests don't want to derive from test::BootstrapFixture[Base] in the first place.  I'll take a look at them independent of this gerrit change.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1This is a band-aid patch probably (although it seems valid in it's own right IMHO). The deeper issue is why there are multiple levels of FOCUSED accessibility items within the svx table.  Likely they should have lost that status when a cell gained it.  That kind of debugging gets really hairy - accessible things getting destroyed and re-created at will, along with event handling.  Often there are exceptions because of missing EditViewForwarder in SetFocus and ProcessQueue.
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1This is a band-aid patch probably (although it seems valid in it's own right IMHO). The deeper issue is why there are multiple levels of FOCUSED accessibility items within the svx table.  Likely they should have lost that status when a cell gained it.  That kind of debugging gets really hairy - accessible things getting destroyed and re-created at will, along with event handling.  Often there are exceptions because of missing EditViewForwarder in SetFocus and ProcessQueue.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1This looks lovely to me ! Martin - are you certain that this will work on Windows XP ? - ie. that the missing symbols: eg. GetDWriteFaceFromHDC while un-resolved there will not cause problems ? I'd be pleased if we don't have to manually look all of those symbols up ourselves with GetProcAddress - though (normally) building an array of nicely typed function pointers is what is done here.Anyhow - am eager to be using DirectWrite myself in font rendering to overcome some of the horrors =) so thrilled to see it.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1This looks lovely to me ! Martin - are you certain that this will work on Windows XP ? - ie. that the missing symbols: eg. GetDWriteFaceFromHDC while un-resolved there will not cause problems ? I'd be pleased if we don't have to manually look all of those symbols up ourselves with GetProcAddress - though (normally) building an array of nicely typed function pointers is what is done here.Anyhow - am eager to be using DirectWrite myself in font rendering to overcome some of the horrors =) so thrilled to see it.

text: Patch Set 3:> Let me explain in more detail... >  > It is common in code to use a clever trick to get more informative > text into the message from a failed assert(). For instance, one > could have (this a generic example, not from LibreOffice): >  > assert(nFoo > 0 && "We should have at least one foo widget"); >  > with the intent being that in case nFoo is <= 0, instead of the > message: >  > Assertion failed: nFoo > 0 >  > one would get this message, with a longer explanation: >  > Assertion failed: nFoo > 0 && "We should have at least one foo > widget" >  > In the code lines here, the string literal contains what is > essentially identical to the expression on the left side of the && > operator, so it does not give any additional information.ohh, now i understand. Actually i never used assert in any of my programming projects. I'm a 1-2 yr amatuer C++ programmer. Whatever the result may be, open source coding is always a great learning experience. Thanks for such a great explanation. I would update all of my patches tommorow morning.
Text: Patch Set 3:> Let me explain in more detail... >  > It is common in code to use a clever trick to get more informative > text into the message from a failed assert(). For instance, one > could have (this a generic example, not from LibreOffice): >  > assert(nFoo > 0 && "We should have at least one foo widget"); >  > with the intent being that in case nFoo is <= 0, instead of the > message: >  > Assertion failed: nFoo > 0 >  > one would get this message, with a longer explanation: >  > Assertion failed: nFoo > 0 && "We should have at least one foo > widget" >  > In the code lines here, the string literal contains what is > essentially identical to the expression on the left side of the && > operator, so it does not give any additional information.ohh, now i understand. Actually i never used assert in any of my programming projects. I'm a 1-2 yr amatuer C++ programmer. Whatever the result may be, open source coding is always a great learning experience. Thanks for such a great explanation. I would update all of my patches tommorow morning.

text: Patch Set 1:Let me explain in more detail...It is common in code to use a clever trick to get more informative text into the message from a failed assert(). For instance, one could have (this a generic example, not from LibreOffice):assert(nFoo > 0 && "We should have at least one foo widget");with the intent being that in case nFoo is <= 0, instead of the message:Assertion failed: nFoo > 0one would get this message, with a longer explanation:Assertion failed: nFoo > 0 && "We should have at least one foo widget"In the code lines here, the string literal contains what is essentially identical to the expression on the left side of the && operator, so it does not give any additional information.
Text: Patch Set 1:Let me explain in more detail...It is common in code to use a clever trick to get more informative text into the message from a failed assert(). For instance, one could have (this a generic example, not from LibreOffice):assert(nFoo > 0 && "We should have at least one foo widget");with the intent being that in case nFoo is <= 0, instead of the message:Assertion failed: nFoo > 0one would get this message, with a longer explanation:Assertion failed: nFoo > 0 && "We should have at least one foo widget"In the code lines here, the string literal contains what is essentially identical to the expression on the left side of the && operator, so it does not give any additional information.

text: Patch Set 6:Thank you for your comments, I will look into them and correct the code where possible.In general:-I switched from vector< double > to array of doubles in an attempt to improve performance; but didn't try to measure the difference; I haven't looked into leaks and leak-protection, so I may switch them back to vector.-Some vectors were maintained as they are sorted or have to passed as vector to existing functions.-I now have 8 new functions, of which Excel doesn't have 3 (the multiplicative method, which is more realistic and IMHO of more use when forecasting). These 3 functions don't have an _xlfn prefix in OOXML as they don't exist there. I haven't fully checked yet if all entries in formulabase.cxx and xlformula.cxx are correct here.-My main efforts so far have been to get the functions working as they should (and changing constraints where MS Excel preaches them but does _not_ apply them).I want to change one last constraint (the time(X)-interval needs to be constant, but in case of dates an interval of months (28 to 31 days) is accepted by Excel. I have to find out how much deviation is accepted by Excel and how to incorporate this in the code, with interpolation in forecasts etc..Then I want to do a lot of numerical comparisons between Calc and Excel - where possible.Then I need to make a unit test; simple no-difference check with Excel is not possible as it is a forecast and the result depends on the exact method and sometimes random numbers.Then I want to go through the code again with a toothbrush.Then I want to prepare help-text (for someone else to put into the repository).And then my draft could become a real submission.We'll be in 2016 be then, it's a huge job - for me, at least ;)

These 3 functions don't have an _xlfn prefix in OOXML as they don't exist there. I haven't fully checked yet if all entries in formulabase.cxx and xlformula.cxx are correct here.-My main efforts so far have been to get the functions working as they should (and changing constraints where MS Excel preaches them but does _not_ apply them).I want to change one last constraint (the time(X)-interval needs to be constant, but in case of dates an interval of months (28 to 31 days) is accepted by Excel. I have to find out how much deviation is accepted by Excel and how to incorporate this in the code, with interpolation in forecasts etc..Then I want to do a lot of numerical comparisons between Calc and Excel - where possible.Then I need to make a unit test; simple no-difference check with Excel is not possible as it is a forecast and the result depends on the exact method and sometimes random numbers.Then I want to go through the code again with a toothbrush.Then I want to prepare help-text (for someone else to put into the repository).And then my draft could become a real submission.We'll be in 2016 be then, it's a huge job - for me, at least ;)

text: Patch Set 3:Hi,I have addressed most of the comments you made above except few.1. @tml, @ash: Lets refactor the pipeFlags thing in a separate patch since the same code snippet already exists in LOOLBroker.cpp. Makes more sense to fix both of them in separate patch.2. @ash: Regarding singleton Admin class. I would prefer to do this in a separate patch too if we want to enforce the singleton behavior to admin class since it was not a singleton before this patch too.I have also factored out the common pipe reading logic to avoid duplicate code.
Text: Patch Set 3:Hi,I have addressed most of the comments you made above except few.1. @tml, @ash: Lets refactor the pipeFlags thing in a separate patch since the same code snippet already exists in LOOLBroker.cpp. Makes more sense to fix both of them in separate patch.2. @ash: Regarding singleton Admin class. I would prefer to do this in a separate patch too if we want to enforce the singleton behavior to admin class since it was not a singleton before this patch too.I have also factored out the common pipe reading logic to avoid duplicate code.

text: Patch Set 2:> Did you check that KDE specific setting in "system setting -> > Default components" are respected by xdg-open?xdg-open appears to follow kde-open to the letter with functionality.One note, with changing the default email client, ask Thunderbird to set the default... The system-settings email item doesn't seem to work for either xdg or kde...I tested this (website and mailto:) on Ubuntu 14.04 and 16.04 dev  > Same for the TDE environment.It should be noted that for TDE in LO we hardcoded email applications to launch.  So while xdg-open is a bit messy, it opens Konqueror on everything apparently, it does then launch Thunderbird if it's the default mail client after.As an aside, if xdg-open is broken on specific desktop environments, we should stop hiding *their* bugs.  It just makes it extra confusing especially on desktops that could have multiple environments installed.
Text: Patch Set 2:> Did you check that KDE specific setting in "system setting -> > Default components" are respected by xdg-open?xdg-open appears to follow kde-open to the letter with functionality.One note, with changing the default email client, ask Thunderbird to set the default... The system-settings email item doesn't seem to work for either xdg or kde...I tested this (website and mailto:) on Ubuntu 14.04 and 16.04 dev  > Same for the TDE environment.It should be noted that for TDE in LO we hardcoded email applications to launch.  So while xdg-open is a bit messy, it opens Konqueror on everything apparently, it does then launch Thunderbird if it's the default mail client after.As an aside, if xdg-open is broken on specific desktop environments, we should stop hiding *their* bugs.  It just makes it extra confusing especially on desktops that could have multiple environments installed.

text: Patch Set 1:AFAICS SetStyle is a rather straightforward "setter" member function of the LineInfo class: void LineInfo::SetStyle( LineStyle eStyle ){ ImplMakeUnique(); mpImplLineInfo->meStyle = eStyle;}It doesn't perform any checks for internal consistency or otherwise.(ImplMakeUnique() doesn't do anything in this case, because the default constructor was used to declare LineInfo and *mpImplLineInfo is already unique.)

text: Patch Set 7:The main reason to wait for load acknowledgment and issue commands only after 'statusindicatorfinish' is received is also how we currently handle the docalreadyloaded, nodocloaded cases on the server side. Currently we have a very lame condition on the server side checking for docURL. If docURL != "" for the server, it means doc is loaded which is clearly not true since the load operation can fail.Hence, IMO, it is best to wait for the result of such an important command like 'load' to finish before we can issue commands from the front-end.
Text: Patch Set 7:The main reason to wait for load acknowledgment and issue commands only after 'statusindicatorfinish' is received is also how we currently handle the docalreadyloaded, nodocloaded cases on the server side. Currently we have a very lame condition on the server side checking for docURL. If docURL != "" for the server, it means doc is loaded which is clearly not true since the load operation can fail.Hence, IMO, it is best to wait for the result of such an important command like 'load' to finish before we can issue commands from the front-end.

text: Patch Set 3:The SAL_WARN/INFO[_IF] macros automatically terminate their output with a newline, so any \n at the end of a message that may have been necessary with previous notification mechanisms are no longer useful and should be removed.Arnold, could you do a follow-up patch that removes any such unnecessary \n from the places modified by this patch?
Text: Patch Set 3:The SAL_WARN/INFO[_IF] macros automatically terminate their output with a newline, so any \n at the end of a message that may have been necessary with previous notification mechanisms are no longer useful and should be removed.Arnold, could you do a follow-up patch that removes any such unnecessary \n from the places modified by this patch?

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1(4 comments)I've added a few comments, please see inline.But the biggest issue I have is with the design. We should avoid unnecessary complexity. When the user opens a password-protected document (without providing a password, or with wrong password) it will fail. Loading will fail. End of story.The UI should report the failure and prompt for password. Another load request should then be sent to the server, with the password, to try loading again.There is no need to have a password command, or remembering the jail url, or having a new callback (modify load callback to take the optional password) etc. All we need is for 'load' to have an optional password that is passed to the right API when provided.If 'load' fails, then everything fails and the user can try again. It's a fatal error to load a document and without a document there is no need to maintain anything at all (certainly no child). I'd even close the socket and cleanup everything. The UI should handle this case in a friendly fashion.Fail, return, prompt the user, and let them try again.Let's discuss if there are any design questions. Thanks!
Text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1(4 comments)I've added a few comments, please see inline.But the biggest issue I have is with the design. We should avoid unnecessary complexity. When the user opens a password-protected document (without providing a password, or with wrong password) it will fail. Loading will fail. End of story.The UI should report the failure and prompt for password. Another load request should then be sent to the server, with the password, to try loading again.There is no need to have a password command, or remembering the jail url, or having a new callback (modify load callback to take the optional password) etc. All we need is for 'load' to have an optional password that is passed to the right API when provided.If 'load' fails, then everything fails and the user can try again. It's a fatal error to load a document and without a document there is no need to maintain anything at all (certainly no child). I'd even close the socket and cleanup everything. The UI should handle this case in a friendly fashion.Fail, return, prompt the user, and let them try again.Let's discuss if there are any design questions. Thanks!

text: Patch Set 3:Ashod: Hmm, the design concern is actually a good point; unfortunately on the LibreOffice side, it asks for the password interactively, so the LOK API was (naturally) extended so that we can interactively answer.Having said that, on the loolwsd level, it can be done as you suggest - return from load with "no password provided" error, ask the user for the password, and re-try the load completely (now with the password remembered).  That is safer (the load is not blocked), but OTOH more expensive (2x starting the load).Maybe we can even change the LOK API this way; but not sure what is best :-(Michael S.: Any view on this, please?
Text: Patch Set 3:Ashod: Hmm, the design concern is actually a good point; unfortunately on the LibreOffice side, it asks for the password interactively, so the LOK API was (naturally) extended so that we can interactively answer.Having said that, on the loolwsd level, it can be done as you suggest - return from load with "no password provided" error, ask the user for the password, and re-try the load completely (now with the password remembered).  That is safer (the load is not blocked), but OTOH more expensive (2x starting the load).Maybe we can even change the LOK API this way; but not sure what is best :-(Michael S.: Any view on this, please?

text: Patch Set 4:> (7 comments) > What stopped me from submitting is strdup :) > I'll guess it was muscle memory :) >  > Seriously, why not use std::string instead of the naked char*?My only concern was documents having password as empty string, "", and std::string's default initialization to "". Also, LOK's setDocumentPassword function treats an empty string as a password attempt, and would get triggered again unless I pass a nullptr to it to abort the load operation, but of course that could easily be dealt with.If there are no empty strings passwords for documents, then yeah, we can change it to std::string, assuming "" to be no password provided
Text: Patch Set 4:> (7 comments) > What stopped me from submitting is strdup :) > I'll guess it was muscle memory :) >  > Seriously, why not use std::string instead of the naked char*?My only concern was documents having password as empty string, "", and std::string's default initialization to "". Also, LOK's setDocumentPassword function treats an empty string as a password attempt, and would get triggered again unless I pass a nullptr to it to abort the load operation, but of course that could easily be dealt with.If there are no empty strings passwords for documents, then yeah, we can change it to std::string, assuming "" to be no password provided

text: Patch Set 4:> > (7 comments) > > What stopped me from submitting is strdup :) > > I'll guess it was muscle memory :) > > > > Seriously, why not use std::string instead of the naked char*? >  > My only concern was documents having password as empty string, "", > and std::string's default initialization to "". > Reasonable. It's probably better to have a bool to track if we have a password (i.e. the user has provided a password) rather than track a pointer (and free). Btw, I don't think I noticed a call to free() anywhere.If we clean this part, I'm good to submit and your other comments are reasonable and can be dealt with later.

text: Patch Set 7:Please, no need to describe the various phases of the gerrit review process in the commit message. That is just confusing when somebody is reading the commit message after some time. Just describe what the change does, as a whole, at the current (last) stage. Also, use present tense, as in "Add new Freeze...". Sorry for nit-picking, but good commit messages are important.
