text: Patch Set 1:> how could one remove such graphics?Well, that's an egg-or-chicken question.We should now answer it here. The problem is: the standard doesn't impose this restriction, and so documents with such graphics are legitimate. Moreover, they actually exist. Failing to import them is not a good option. There may be restriction at the UI level that doesn't allow e.g. creating those, and a UI may be developed to handle them if needed (e.g., like in AutoCAD that includes a tool to whipe zero-sized objects, or a navigator update that would include graphics list, including zero-sized). But that's a different task.Also, silently dropping those objects isn't good, too, because that would impair round-trip of documents.
Text: Patch Set 1:> how could one remove such graphics?Well, that's an egg-or-chicken question.We should now answer it here. The problem is: the standard doesn't impose this restriction, and so documents with such graphics are legitimate. Moreover, they actually exist. Failing to import them is not a good option. There may be restriction at the UI level that doesn't allow e.g. creating those, and a UI may be developed to handle them if needed (e.g., like in AutoCAD that includes a tool to whipe zero-sized objects, or a navigator update that would include graphics list, including zero-sized). But that's a different task.Also, silently dropping those objects isn't good, too, because that would impair round-trip of documents.

text: Patch Set 4:The source is given, "[basic.lookup.unqual]/6", i.e., paragraph 6 of the [basic.lookup.unqual] section of the C++ Standard, e.g., <http://open-std.org/JTC1/SC22/WG21/docs/papers/2015/n4567.pdf>.
Text: Patch Set 4:The source is given, "[basic.lookup.unqual]/6", i.e., paragraph 6 of the [basic.lookup.unqual] section of the C++ Standard, e.g., <http://open-std.org/JTC1/SC22/WG21/docs/papers/2015/n4567.pdf>.

text: Patch Set 4:> The source is given, "[basic.lookup.unqual]/6", i.e., paragraph 6 > of the [basic.lookup.unqual] section of the C++ Standard, e.g., > <http://open-std.org/JTC1/SC22/WG21/docs/papers/2015/n4567.pdf>.Thanks. So the standard paper mentions exactly our test case:  namespace A {      namespace N {          void f();      }  }  void A::N::f() {      i = 5;      // The following scopes are searched for a declaration of i:      // 1) outermost block scope of A::N::f, before the use of i      // 2) scope of namespace N      // 3) scope of namespace A      // 4) global scope, before the definition of A::N::f  }where A::N is connectivity::mork. So according to the standard the declaration of i (ORowSetValue)) should be searched in connectivity namespace, where it's located. So this is clearly a MSVC bug.
Text: Patch Set 4:> The source is given, "[basic.lookup.unqual]/6", i.e., paragraph 6 > of the [basic.lookup.unqual] section of the C++ Standard, e.g., > <http://open-std.org/JTC1/SC22/WG21/docs/papers/2015/n4567.pdf>.Thanks. So the standard paper mentions exactly our test case:  namespace A {      namespace N {          void f();      }  }  void A::N::f() {      i = 5;      // The following scopes are searched for a declaration of i:      // 1) outermost block scope of A::N::f, before the use of i      // 2) scope of namespace N      // 3) scope of namespace A      // 4) global scope, before the definition of A::N::f  }where A::N is connectivity::mork. So according to the standard the declaration of i (ORowSetValue)) should be searched in connectivity namespace, where it's located. So this is clearly a MSVC bug.

text: Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1Hi Chris!  Can we please avoid the changes like:     , m_pImpl( new Impl(nMaskSet) ) { } + MediaItem::MediaItem( const MediaItem& rItem )     : SfxPoolItem( rItem )     , m_pImpl( new Impl(*rItem.m_pImpl) )This creates nightmares for rebasing / cherry-picking :-(  More than 1 line between functions / methods confuses patching, and easily creates copies of stuff that was moved around.I am tempted to -2 this even, as we agreed in the ESC some time ago that no large scale cosmetic changes should be done until after x.y.2, so that it is easier to merge back to the stable branches; but for the moment -1 at least for the added whitespace - sorry about that...

text: Patch Set 1:(3 comments)It is working good as is in my test case, and I think the changes I made were fairly safe.  I'm mostly baffled about why Cell's IsTextEditActive depends on a ParaOutliner that often is not created yet even though the cell has the cursor - so I'm afraid to change that function in case something uses that to ensure that ParaOutliner exists.  I'm guessing that anything in accessibility asking for the "Active Cell" just used the IsTextEditActive function because it already existed - and not because it really needs more than just the cursor.

text: Patch Set 6:Yes, I know they're illegal, and it was by coincidence that I used a negative value as a font size, in fact I believe no one would use them, but this commit is just a 'just in case commit' because if we use a negative value in the current implementation, the text is rotated 180 degrees, which is uglier than just using the default font size

text: Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1Have you read my comment in tdf#97383? I think it is a wrong approach to do direct manipulation in the else-part. If the image has no preserveAspectRatio set, then the variable rRatio has to be set to the default values, which are specified for this case. And then the part, which is now in the then-part, is valid in both cases and can be executed outside of if-then-else.
Text: Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1Have you read my comment in tdf#97383? I think it is a wrong approach to do direct manipulation in the else-part. If the image has no preserveAspectRatio set, then the variable rRatio has to be set to the default values, which are specified for this case. And then the part, which is now in the then-part, is valid in both cases and can be executed outside of if-then-else.

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1(14 comments)this is trickier than it appears :)some of these appear to be  obvious candidates for using assert(), which is much better at getting developer's attention because it exits the program if the condition is violated.assert() does not take a message, only a condition; in many cases the message is really superfluous, like when requiring that some pointer isn't null or some index is in obvious bounds, so the message can just be removed.but if you see a message that's worth keeping, you can use a trick and write assert(condition && "message); - that will evaluate to the same value as the condition since the string literal "message" converts to a boolean value of true.
Text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1(14 comments)this is trickier than it appears :)some of these appear to be  obvious candidates for using assert(), which is much better at getting developer's attention because it exits the program if the condition is violated.assert() does not take a message, only a condition; in many cases the message is really superfluous, like when requiring that some pointer isn't null or some index is in obvious bounds, so the message can just be removed.but if you see a message that's worth keeping, you can use a trick and write assert(condition && "message); - that will evaluate to the same value as the condition since the string literal "message" converts to a boolean value of true.

text: Patch Set 6:(1 comment)I won't comment on the code for now, as it basically just moved around without changing much, I'll drop some comments on functionality thoughClicking on Add button, while no effect is selected freezes Impress, makes it eat 100% of CPU and eventually freezes the whole desktop session (on Linux). Bad bad bad bad :) One of the ways out is to disable Add button when nothing's selectedThe list of effects lost its context sensitivity e.g. when a text object is selected, font effects (in emphasis section, like change font, enlarge font etc.) are no longer offered.The controls somehow update incorrectly, e.g. Emphasis category, click Change fill colour -> nothing happens. I'd expect a listbox with colour selection to replace whatever control is underneath immediately. Now it replaces it only after clicking on 'Add'

text: Patch Set 9:Yes the new workflow is good, but there are a few bugs here and there that need to be tweaked.1) When nothing is selected clicking on a entry in the list doesnt activate category and effect.2) When pressing add, it should add Entrance-Appear not Emphasis-Change Fill Color and no automatic preview should not be executed3) When clicking on an entry in Effect, there is refreshing in the sidebar that causes problems. e.g. Effect list refreshes and selected entry goes to the top of the list, flicker of the add/delete/up/down buttons.Most of the other suggestions are in the google doc. :DOn a separate note, is it possible to make the Effect group, e.g. Entrance-Special left aligned rather than centered and the effects under it indented?
Text: Patch Set 9:Yes the new workflow is good, but there are a few bugs here and there that need to be tweaked.1) When nothing is selected clicking on a entry in the list doesnt activate category and effect.2) When pressing add, it should add Entrance-Appear not Emphasis-Change Fill Color and no automatic preview should not be executed3) When clicking on an entry in Effect, there is refreshing in the sidebar that causes problems. e.g. Effect list refreshes and selected entry goes to the top of the list, flicker of the add/delete/up/down buttons.Most of the other suggestions are in the google doc. :DOn a separate note, is it possible to make the Effect group, e.g. Entrance-Special left aligned rather than centered and the effects under it indented?

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2Received further (re-)education by sberg that we for now cant use constexpr, as MSVC is too stupid for it: https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=38835#c22There is SAL_CONSTEXPR which can be used instead for now in some cases. Since that would only provide a minor benefit, I merge this patch as is. Feel free to use SAL_CONSTEXPR in the future though.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2Received further (re-)education by sberg that we for now cant use constexpr, as MSVC is too stupid for it: https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=38835#c22There is SAL_CONSTEXPR which can be used instead for now in some cases. Since that would only provide a minor benefit, I merge this patch as is. Feel free to use SAL_CONSTEXPR in the future though.

text: Patch Set 1:oh that is clever, i didn't think of that - did you test that it actually works?basically the firebird build system does this the wrong way around, they should expect -j (or job server) by default on the top-level and then invoke the non parallel safe makefiles with "-j1".or even better fix their dependencies.
Text: Patch Set 1:oh that is clever, i didn't think of that - did you test that it actually works?basically the firebird build system does this the wrong way around, they should expect -j (or job server) by default on the top-level and then invoke the non parallel safe makefiles with "-j1".or even better fix their dependencies.

text: Patch Set 1:It works for me: top-level "PARALLELISM=0 make firebird" top-level "make firebird" (with implicit PARALLELISM value > 1) cd external/firebird && make -j2 cd external/firebird && make -j16 cd external/firebird && make -r -s # no -jIf I move my ccache cache out of the way, I see an appropriate number of parallel g++ processes in "ps -Af f"A previous version was filtering MAKEFLAGS to remove the problematic "-r" and leave all the rest, but in the end I thought it better to be more minimalistic. For future reference, here's the filtering code:if echo '$(MAKEFLAGS)' | egrep -q '^-'; then \  MAKEFLAGS='$(filter-out -r,$(MAKEFLAGS))'; \else \  MAKEFLAGS='$(subst r,,$(word 1,$(MAKEFLAGS))) $(wordlist 2,$(words $(MAKEFLAGS)),$(MAKEFLAGS))'; \fi; \
Text: Patch Set 1:It works for me: top-level "PARALLELISM=0 make firebird" top-level "make firebird" (with implicit PARALLELISM value > 1) cd external/firebird && make -j2 cd external/firebird && make -j16 cd external/firebird && make -r -s # no -jIf I move my ccache cache out of the way, I see an appropriate number of parallel g++ processes in "ps -Af f"A previous version was filtering MAKEFLAGS to remove the problematic "-r" and leave all the rest, but in the end I thought it better to be more minimalistic. For future reference, here's the filtering code:if echo '$(MAKEFLAGS)' | egrep -q '^-'; then \  MAKEFLAGS='$(filter-out -r,$(MAKEFLAGS))'; \else \  MAKEFLAGS='$(subst r,,$(word 1,$(MAKEFLAGS))) $(wordlist 2,$(words $(MAKEFLAGS)),$(MAKEFLAGS))'; \fi; \

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1While this works when pasting one row or several rows that were copied of a consecutive range, it fails with rows of a multi-selection, then the second pasted row overlaps/hides the existing rows. Apparently this is only a redraw problem, so maybe chasing that would be sufficient.For example * increase height of rows 3 and 5 significantly * select rows 3 and 5 (without row 4) with Ctrl-Click * copy to clipboard * paste onto row 8 * notice that the number 8 in the row headers may get duplicated * notice that rows 10, 11, 12 or so are covered by the new pasted row * Shift+Ctrl+R or traveling with the cursor through the rows will repaint and apparently things are good then * Ctrl+Z Undo does not restore the previous original heights
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1While this works when pasting one row or several rows that were copied of a consecutive range, it fails with rows of a multi-selection, then the second pasted row overlaps/hides the existing rows. Apparently this is only a redraw problem, so maybe chasing that would be sufficient.For example * increase height of rows 3 and 5 significantly * select rows 3 and 5 (without row 4) with Ctrl-Click * copy to clipboard * paste onto row 8 * notice that the number 8 in the row headers may get duplicated * notice that rows 10, 11, 12 or so are covered by the new pasted row * Shift+Ctrl+R or traveling with the cursor through the rows will repaint and apparently things are good then * Ctrl+Z Undo does not restore the previous original heights

text: Patch Set 2:Oh yes. Sry. Just woke up.Had to fix it as it broke the build and forgot to leave a message.For the solution how to push such a patch to gerrit. You need to update to a git checkout that ncludes the pushed patch already. One solution to avoid long recompile times is to have a separate push tree + charry-picking the commit from current master. Then only add the new commit to the push tree (which already contains the pushed commit) and push to gerrit for review.Gerrit complained that you tried to push a patch that has been merged already to gerrit review. This happens because the Change-Id of the patch was the same as the merged one.
Text: Patch Set 2:Oh yes. Sry. Just woke up.Had to fix it as it broke the build and forgot to leave a message.For the solution how to push such a patch to gerrit. You need to update to a git checkout that ncludes the pushed patch already. One solution to avoid long recompile times is to have a separate push tree + charry-picking the commit from current master. Then only add the new commit to the push tree (which already contains the pushed commit) and push to gerrit for review.Gerrit complained that you tried to push a patch that has been merged already to gerrit review. This happens because the Change-Id of the patch was the same as the merged one.

text: Patch Set 10: Verified-1this fails to build because there is no include path to dtrans/source/inc in the makefile StaticLibrary_dtobj.mkyou can add this like so:$(eval $(call gb_StaticLibrary_set_include,dtobj,\	-I$(SRCDIR)/dtrans/source/inc \	$$(INCLUDE) \))(note that it's gb_StaticLibrary_set_include because this is a static library, not a normal one, and it's $$(INCLUDE) with 2 $ to delay evaluation of the variable to the right time)
Text: $$(INCLUDE) \))(note that it's gb_StaticLibrary_set_include because this is a static library, not a normal one, and it's $$(INCLUDE) with 2 $ to delay evaluation of the variable to the right time)"

text: Patch Set 2:This bug is the case itself :)If you do a dry-run on 'nextmessage' frame going in prisoner -> master direction, you would notice that it would get stuck in the original if/else block because 'nextmessage' is a single-line message also. Hence, it is necessary for us to move this block above so that such 'nextmessage' frames are not skipped.I think it was always wrongly placed there, but we were never able to notice it because only few documents hit the 200000 limit (char buffer[200000] in SocketProcessor() function ).
Text: Patch Set 2:This bug is the case itself :)If you do a dry-run on 'nextmessage' frame going in prisoner -> master direction, you would notice that it would get stuck in the original if/else block because 'nextmessage' is a single-line message also. Hence, it is necessary for us to move this block above so that such 'nextmessage' frames are not skipped.I think it was always wrongly placed there, but we were never able to notice it because only few documents hit the 200000 limit (char buffer[200000] in SocketProcessor() function ).

text: Patch Set 2:(1 comment)> I think it was always wrongly placed there, but we were never able > to notice it because only few documents hit the 200000 limit (char > buffer[200000] in SocketProcessor() function ).The assumption was that the only multi-line message was nextmessage. That is, everything else evaluated to single-line, so the sequence was reasonable (that's my understanding).At any rate, I think we need to review these assumptions. For example the code now expects 3 cases: nextmessage, single-line, and a 3rd undocumented case.Please add the const (see note) and I'll submit this patch, then we need to review the protocol(.txt) and the code and make sure we have a solid situation. Thanks.
Text: Patch Set 2:(1 comment)> I think it was always wrongly placed there, but we were never able > to notice it because only few documents hit the 200000 limit (char > buffer[200000] in SocketProcessor() function ).The assumption was that the only multi-line message was nextmessage. That is, everything else evaluated to single-line, so the sequence was reasonable (that's my understanding).At any rate, I think we need to review these assumptions. For example the code now expects 3 cases: nextmessage, single-line, and a 3rd undocumented case.Please add the const (see note) and I'll submit this patch, then we need to review the protocol(.txt) and the code and make sure we have a solid situation. Thanks.

text: Patch Set 2:A very minor comment, but it is good to learn to do this right from the beginning: Please use present tense in a commit comment. The comment should say what the change *does*, not what has "been done". In other words, here the comment should be "Delete 'css::uno::Sequence'".
Text: Patch Set 2:A very minor comment, but it is good to learn to do this right from the beginning: Please use present tense in a commit comment. The comment should say what the change *does*, not what has "been done". In other words, here the comment should be "Delete 'css::uno::Sequence'".

text: Patch Set 2:Another thing to take into consideration is that JUnit's assertEquals takes its arguments in the somewhat odd order "expected, actual" (which is important when JUnit reports a failure, and labels one value as "expected" and the other as "actual").  According to <https://docs.python.org/3/library/unittest.html>, the arguments to Python's unittest.testEqual are only named "first, second" (so not making it clear which should be the expected and which the actual value), but the examples on that page all use it so that the actual value comes first (which is probably also the more intuitive, albeit non-xUnit-style, way of ordering the arguments).
Text: Patch Set 2:Another thing to take into consideration is that JUnit's assertEquals takes its arguments in the somewhat odd order "expected, actual" (which is important when JUnit reports a failure, and labels one value as "expected" and the other as "actual").  According to <https://docs.python.org/3/library/unittest.html>, the arguments to Python's unittest.testEqual are only named "first, second" (so not making it clear which should be the expected and which the actual value), but the examples on that page all use it so that the actual value comes first (which is probably also the more intuitive, albeit non-xUnit-style, way of ordering the arguments).

text: Patch Set 3:> Don't we have to quote double and single quotes when using single > quotes for DBGARGS, as printf already uses escaped double quotes in > the string to write?Beats me what you mean with that.The best way I'm aware of to pass an argument verbatim through GNU make into a sh printf invocation is with a recipe line of  printf '%s' '$(subst ','\'',$(value ARG))'(where the '%s' argument could of course also be given as "%s", but why use that form of quoting when it is not necessary to do so?).  I'm only aware that it fails if ARG contains a newline.

I'm only aware that it fails if ARG contains a newline.

text: Patch Set 3:> The changed line writes a double quoted string to the file,Ah, right, missed that part; it should arguably write single quotes instead.GDB documentation appears to be unhelpful in documenting the exact syntax of the "set args" command, but some experimentation makes it look like it supports sh-like quoting of that command's arguments.  So you would want to document in gbuild.help.txt that the value of DBGARGS provided by the user needs to be in such a form that it can validly be spliced verbatim into a "set args" command's argument text.

Your SHELL environment variable (if it exists) specifies what shell gdb uses."

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1First this combines several independent changes that need to be split into independent patches.Now to the actual changes: IMHO the only one that makes really sense is the int to bool one. All other changes are just preferences (e.g. I would prefer rRet to rReturn as it is shorter, and e.g. changing rRet to rS is IMHO actually hurting).So if I would be a math developer I would only accept the int to bool change and reject the rest. As I'm not it is open to whoever makes the decision. The -1 is for splitting the patch up which needs to happen anyway.

text: Patch Set 1:It is pointless to refer to specific comments in some gerrit change request in a commit message. Commit messages are supposed to be readable and understandable by themselves. text: Patch Set 2:When cleaning up this, especially now with people from multiple companies working on LibreOfficeKit, it would be important to make the HAS macros actually work in the presence of all the UNSTABLE stuff.As discussed on IRC with vmiklos, currently it doesn't work as perhaps intended. In a LibreOffice instance, the UNSTABLE parts are compiled in, and thus the nSize member of the structs are initialised to include the size of the pointers to the unstable methods.So if we have a LibreOffice instance from before the addition of freeError (or other methods that will be added in the near future), and a client compiled against a bleeding-edge header (with the freeError present), the client will think that the freeError is present in the struct that the LibreOffice instance presents to it, even if it isn't, because the nSize is large enough to cover where freeError would be, even if what actually is in that location in the LibreOffice instance is some unstable function pointer.This will bite us hard at some point in the future unless we fix it soon. My initial suggestion, off-hand, is to move all the unstable function pointers into separate structs, and have a single pointer to such a struct as part of the *stable* API.
Text: Patch Set 2:When cleaning up this, especially now with people from multiple companies working on LibreOfficeKit, it would be important to make the HAS macros actually work in the presence of all the UNSTABLE stuff.As discussed on IRC with vmiklos, currently it doesn't work as perhaps intended. In a LibreOffice instance, the UNSTABLE parts are compiled in, and thus the nSize member of the structs are initialised to include the size of the pointers to the unstable methods.So if we have a LibreOffice instance from before the addition of freeError (or other methods that will be added in the near future), and a client compiled against a bleeding-edge header (with the freeError present), the client will think that the freeError is present in the struct that the LibreOffice instance presents to it, even if it isn't, because the nSize is large enough to cover where freeError would be, even if what actually is in that location in the LibreOffice instance is some unstable function pointer.This will bite us hard at some point in the future unless we fix it soon. My initial suggestion, off-hand, is to move all the unstable function pointers into separate structs, and have a single pointer to such a struct as part of the *stable* API.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1This is wrong for several reasons.First, it sets hard alignment attributes depending on the number format type.Second, it ignores and overrides any alignment attribute the user may have set already.Third, it ignores RTL (Right-To-Left) context. In RTL languages you do not want text to be suddenly left aligned unless requested by the user.Instead of using and setting hard alignment attribution this should be evaluated in view context. See sc/source/ui/view/output2.cxx ScOutputData::LayoutStrings() where getAlignmentFromContext() is used.

In RTL languages you do not want text to be suddenly left aligned unless requested by the user.Instead of using and setting hard alignment attribution this should be evaluated in view context. See sc/source/ui/view/output2.cxx ScOutputData::LayoutStrings() where getAlignmentFromContext() is used.

So could you please let me know how to get the new number format that the user selected inside LayoutStrings() ?

text: Patch Set 3:Hi Armin, in svgio it has always been 12px, function SvgStyleAttributes::getFontSize() return 12.0 but default: http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/svgio/source/svgreader/svgstyleattributes.cxx#2301 which makes me thing whether it's correct or it should be 15.0, as the PPI is 90 http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/svgio/inc/svgio/svgreader/svgtools.hxx#39, and 90 / 6 : 15px. In firefox or chrome, the default font is 16 because they use 96 points per inch.
Text: Patch Set 3:Hi Armin, in svgio it has always been 12px, function SvgStyleAttributes::getFontSize() return 12.0 but default: http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/svgio/source/svgreader/svgstyleattributes.cxx#2301 which makes me thing whether it's correct or it should be 15.0, as the PPI is 90 http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/svgio/inc/svgio/svgreader/svgtools.hxx#39, and 90 / 6 : 15px. In firefox or chrome, the default font is 16 because they use 96 points per inch.

text: Patch Set 3:BTW: If we have the 90 dpi default (in Vcl?) which I think we have and if it's a constant, maybe we could express the dependency by using the evtl. global (hoping) 90-dpi-default value to fill the default font size value in svgio. That would make clear the dependency if someone later sees it.
Text: Patch Set 3:BTW: If we have the 90 dpi default (in Vcl?) which I think we have and if it's a constant, maybe we could express the dependency by using the evtl. global (hoping) 90-dpi-default value to fill the default font size value in svgio. That would make clear the dependency if someone later sees it.

text: Patch Set 3:LO uses 90px/in (=90px/72pt) in its own export to svg (at least on my PC, what do you get?). So where a conversion is needed on import, it should use the same setting.I have no strong opinion about how many px should be used for font-size="medium". This value alone says nothing about the rendered size. The unit px is equal to the 'user unit' at the place where px it currently used. Therefore the real size depends highly on viewBox and transformations.Other application have no unique value. Browser base the font-size="medium" to the user's default font size. Google Chrom and Seamonkey seem to use "medium"=16px as predefined value, Internet Explorer 18px, Batik seems to use 12px, and Corel Draw uses a value between 10px and 11px.For the table of scaling values for the other absolute-size keywords, I would stick to factor 1.2, as it is recommended in the first edition of CSS2, because factor 1.5 was noticed as bad. All the other things mentioned in the later specification of CSS2 (e.g. resolution of the device, quality and availability of fonts, no fixed ratio, avoiding <9px) are not necessary in a first implementation. I suggest, to improve the mapping in case of user complains.
Text: Patch Set 3:LO uses 90px/in (=90px/72pt) in its own export to svg (at least on my PC, what do you get?). So where a conversion is needed on import, it should use the same setting.I have no strong opinion about how many px should be used for font-size="medium". This value alone says nothing about the rendered size. The unit px is equal to the 'user unit' at the place where px it currently used. Therefore the real size depends highly on viewBox and transformations.Other application have no unique value. Browser base the font-size="medium" to the user's default font size. Google Chrom and Seamonkey seem to use "medium"=16px as predefined value, Internet Explorer 18px, Batik seems to use 12px, and Corel Draw uses a value between 10px and 11px.For the table of scaling values for the other absolute-size keywords, I would stick to factor 1.2, as it is recommended in the first edition of CSS2, because factor 1.5 was noticed as bad. All the other things mentioned in the later specification of CSS2 (e.g. resolution of the device, quality and availability of fonts, no fixed ratio, avoiding <9px) are not necessary in a first implementation. text: Patch Set 2:I was a little afraid of using a long list of pointers, but that's how the other tab_over_margin code works.  A shorter string in this case was GetVsh()ÔåÆgetIDocumentSettingAccess().get, but there were clues that this path might not always exist, and thus fail for headless work?  I decided to choose copy/paste programming.-based on previous code, my checking of the tabstop and ensuring a right tabstop exists might be excessive.  But in another sense it still isn't ÔÇ£limitingÔÇØ enough because it applies to the entire paragraph even if there is no tab character used.  I couldn't find out how to nicely identify if a tab character was actually present on that line.  I figured it didn't really matter.

Text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1 Verified+1Code looks good, but there are some merge conflict with the current master.you need to do"git pull" on master, to have the newest, "git checkout -b test1""git fetch git://gerrit.libreoffice.org/core refs/changes/65/20765/4 && git cherry-pick FETCH_HEAD" to cherry pick you change set.then git will report the conflicts.

text: Patch Set 2:> (1 comment) >  > Is there any corresponding issue in bugzilla? It will be easier to > understand the design if description of the problem and the > expectation were presented. With the test case you uploaded, > orientation doesn't seem to have any difference in MSO2010 and > LO5.0.3. It also confused why sectd mustn't reset landscape flag.I don't found any issue. It's not about the presentation but about the landscape flag because the presentation only depends on paperw and paperh.You are right, I should'nt reset landscape flag in \sect but in the RTF spec, landscape define a default value for the flag like paperw or paperh and I don't find a command to set portrait orientation in this default value.I found an interesting information in the RTF spec:\lndscpsxn: Page orientation is in landscape format. To mix portrait and landscape sections within a document, the \landscape control should not be used so that the default for a section is portrait, which may be overridden by the \lndscpsxn control.So, I think my files are incorrectly formatted:\sect \paperw16837 \paperh11905 \landscape \sectdThe file should use pgwsxn, pghsxn and lndscpsxn instead of paperw, paperh and landscape and sectd should be before paperw.----I will update my patch :- remove reset section in sectd- implement lndscpsxn to set the current value- let landscape to set the current and default value- edit commit messageAre you agree with that ?
Text: Patch Set 2:> (1 comment) >  > Is there any corresponding issue in bugzilla? It will be easier to > understand the design if description of the problem and the > expectation were presented. With the test case you uploaded, > orientation doesn't seem to have any difference in MSO2010 and > LO5.0.3. It also confused why sectd mustn't reset landscape flag.I don't found any issue. It's not about the presentation but about the landscape flag because the presentation only depends on paperw and paperh.You are right, I should'nt reset landscape flag in \sect but in the RTF spec, landscape define a default value for the flag like paperw or paperh and I don't find a command to set portrait orientation in this default value.I found an interesting information in the RTF spec:\lndscpsxn: Page orientation is in landscape format. To mix portrait and landscape sections within a document, the \landscape control should not be used so that the default for a section is portrait, which may be overridden by the \lndscpsxn control.So, I think my files are incorrectly formatted:\sect \paperw16837 \paperh11905 \landscape \sectdThe file should use pgwsxn, pghsxn and lndscpsxn instead of paperw, paperh and landscape and sectd should be before paperw.----I will update my patch :- remove reset section in sectd- implement lndscpsxn to set the current value- let landscape to set the current and default value- edit commit messageAre you agree with that ?

text: Patch Set 2:It sounds good to implement lndscpsxn though I'm not sure what do you mean by "set current issue". My personal suggestion (although not a requirement ) is that you report an issue first on bugzilla so that others would know the context of the issue and the reason why you have to make the change. Upload some real samples that generated by other software, Word for example, and describe the expected and observed result. The original test case you uploaded seems very simple that I guess it is manually crafted. Without real world example, I felt that we were risking fixing the wrong thing if your interpretation of the problem is wrong.
Text: Patch Set 2:It sounds good to implement lndscpsxn though I'm not sure what do you mean by "set current issue". The original test case you uploaded seems very simple that I guess it is manually crafted. text: Patch Set 2:No, I don't find any bug on bugzilla.It's not a bug which imply a crash or a bad rendering, the orientation flag "IsLandscape" just doesn't contain the good value because : - \landscape is not used by Word (I tried with Word 2000, 2003, 2007, 2010 and 2013)RTF specification recommended to not use it because it defines a default value and it is not possible to invert it- \lndscpsxsn is currrently not implemented. And it permit to define the orientation flag for the current section (The next secd will reset it)I will edit my patch to implement lndscpsxsn
Text: Patch Set 2:No, I don't find any bug on bugzilla.It's not a bug which imply a crash or a bad rendering, the orientation flag "IsLandscape" just doesn't contain the good value because : - \landscape is not used by Word (I tried with Word 2000, 2003, 2007, 2010 and 2013)RTF specification recommended to not use it because it defines a default value and it is not possible to invert it- \lndscpsxsn is currrently not implemented. And it permit to define the orientation flag for the current section (The next secd will reset it)I will edit my patch to implement lndscpsxsn

text: Patch Set 1:Using rtl_UriEncodeIgnoreEscapes I discovered another small issue in:<https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/gitweb?p=core.git;a=commitdiff;h=0398e1e3967332c49b6451b5d41bcf0357052d0b#patch1>Where there's a wrong conversion to username, using INetURLObject::NO_DECODE instead of INetURLObject::DECODE_WITH_CHARSET, as the cmis::URL class ctor does.I'm testing the change, with an Alfresco 5 CMIS server on a local VM to check for regression.When I'm satisfied I'push the new version.

text: Patch Set 2:Usually I would agree that error checking (as in checking that all bytes are actually written) is good, but in this case, what is there to do anyway, in case (for some weird reason) they aren't? text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2Similar to 'tdf#47262 SVG: Parse gradient styles twice if the referred...' data referenced by other data is parsed preferred (pre-parsed). When there are more cases like these (as it seems) moving from parsing in one step to multiple or som priority-based parsing should be considered. This patch solves the imminent problem (so should be good for now), but shows a general problem in this importer and leads to the question: How many more bugs will there be due to single-parsing is the wrong approach? Each of these fixes makes the code more cluttered and harder to read, too...Just my 2ct, still good and will work AFAIK.
Text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2Similar to 'tdf#47262 SVG: Parse gradient styles twice if the referred...' data referenced by other data is parsed preferred (pre-parsed). When there are more cases like these (as it seems) moving from parsing in one step to multiple or som priority-based parsing should be considered. This patch solves the imminent problem (so should be good for now), but shows a general problem in this importer and leads to the question: How many more bugs will there be due to single-parsing is the wrong approach? Each of these fixes makes the code more cluttered and harder to read, too...Just my 2ct, still good and will work AFAIK.

text: Patch Set 2:Maxim: Thanks so much for working on this, and for your careful approach to this!To reduce the complexity (overall, not only the to address the immediate needs here), removing the "AlwaysAllowSave" sounds to me as the preferred solution.  The only reason for the disabling used to be the indication of the state, and that will be retained by changing the icon.So if you don't have major obstacles with that, I'd encourage you to kill the "AllwaysAllowSave", and change the code so that it behaves if it was set to true.
Text: Patch Set 2:Maxim: Thanks so much for working on this, and for your careful approach to this!To reduce the complexity (overall, not only the to address the immediate needs here), removing the "AlwaysAllowSave" sounds to me as the preferred solution.  The only reason for the disabling used to be the indication of the state, and that will be retained by changing the icon.So if you don't have major obstacles with that, I'd encourage you to kill the "AllwaysAllowSave", and change the code so that it behaves if it was set to true.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1> Hopefully benign, since a simple addition - would be good to have > in -5-0 though, otherwise bootstrapping via in-tree JARs suddenly > loses features ...What feature loss?The @since tags should really stay at "LibreOffice 5.1" (now that the corresponding master commit has been backported to -5-1); we don't add new features on micros (and there's no meaningful total order on major.minor.micro revs, only on major.minor ones).  Backporting this 5.1 feature to 5.0.5 would necessarily be "under the radar."
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1> Hopefully benign, since a simple addition - would be good to have > in -5-0 though, otherwise bootstrapping via in-tree JARs suddenly > loses features ...What feature loss?The @since tags should really stay at "LibreOffice 5.1" (now that the corresponding master commit has been backported to -5-1); we don't add new features on micros (and there's no meaningful total order on major.minor.micro revs, only on major.minor ones).  Backporting this 5.1 feature to 5.0.5 would necessarily be "under the radar."

text: Patch Set 1:> > Hopefully benign, since a simple addition - would be good to have > > in -5-0 though, otherwise bootstrapping via in-tree JARs suddenly > > loses features ... >  > What feature loss?It's not feature loss in LO core, but in library using it (noa-libre). It used to have its own bootstrapping mechanism, which wasn't working with new LO anymore, so I killed it in favour of javaunohelper bootstrap. It however used to have the feature of passing custom options to bootstrapped soffice, which core LO didn't have until this commit.
Text: Patch Set 1:> > Hopefully benign, since a simple addition - would be good to have > > in -5-0 though, otherwise bootstrapping via in-tree JARs suddenly > > loses features ... >  > What feature loss?It's not feature loss in LO core, but in library using it (noa-libre). It used to have its own bootstrapping mechanism, which wasn't working with new LO anymore, so I killed it in favour of javaunohelper bootstrap. It however used to have the feature of passing custom options to bootstrapped soffice, which core LO didn't have until this commit.

text: Patch Set 1:My concern is:the point of TabsRelativeToIndent setting is to differentiate between two clearly distinct modes:1. When tabs are relative to this paragraph' start (e.g. 5 cm from paragraph left margin in LTR);2. When tabs are relative to page margin (e.g. 5 cm from page left)They are really different: in first, changing paragraph origin (e.g. moving table cell border, or wrapping from one column to another) moves the coresponding tab stops, while in second, the tab stop positions should stay positioned to absolute values on page, regardless the paragraph origin shift.But it's clearly not the case in current implementation, and was never so from the very beginning. Also, the bug existed from the start, too. So, I think I'd rather let the current way of operation and fix only the ruler bug, instead of forcing the (likely) intended logic with the risk of many existing documents' broken layout. Essentially, now this variable does not alter the tab placement logic, and affects only their saving to file/loading from file.
Text: Patch Set 1:My concern is:the point of TabsRelativeToIndent setting is to differentiate between two clearly distinct modes:1. When tabs are relative to this paragraph' start (e.g. 5 cm from paragraph left margin in LTR);2. When tabs are relative to page margin (e.g. 5 cm from page left)They are really different: in first, changing paragraph origin (e.g. moving table cell border, or wrapping from one column to another) moves the coresponding tab stops, while in second, the tab stop positions should stay positioned to absolute values on page, regardless the paragraph origin shift.But it's clearly not the case in current implementation, and was never so from the very beginning. Also, the bug existed from the start, too. So, I think I'd rather let the current way of operation and fix only the ruler bug, instead of forcing the (likely) intended logic with the risk of many existing documents' broken layout. Essentially, now this variable does not alter the tab placement logic, and affects only their saving to file/loading from file.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I seem to be missing the point of removing the non-relative-to-indent tab stop handling within the ruler.Writer (unfortunately) was initially designed in a way that tab stops are calculated from the left paragraph indent.To be compatible to doc/docx a non-relative usage of tab stops has been added which is (again unfortunately) only used for doc/docx import. If you remove that code the ruler will show wrong tab stops in docx/doc import.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I seem to be missing the point of removing the non-relative-to-indent tab stop handling within the ruler.Writer (unfortunately) was initially designed in a way that tab stops are calculated from the left paragraph indent.To be compatible to doc/docx a non-relative usage of tab stops has been added which is (again unfortunately) only used for doc/docx import. If you remove that code the ruler will show wrong tab stops in docx/doc import.

text: Patch Set 1:> I seem to be missing the point of removing the non-relative-to-indent > tab stop handling within the ruler.Please take a look at tdf#95846, which itself is based on tdf#76005 (linked there as See Also...). I noted the relevant OOo issue there, too. > Writer (unfortunately) was initially designed in a way that tab > stops are calculated from the left paragraph indent. > To be compatible to doc/docx a non-relative usage of tab stops has > been added which is (again unfortunately) only used for doc/docx > import.I see; that is what I explain in my first comment here... > If you remove that code the ruler will show wrong tab stops in > docx/doc import.The whole point is that _having_ this code in ruler _does_ make it show wrong tab stops in doc/docx import. You may notice in the tdf issue, that I discuss the bug manifestation vector to be exactly that: importing docx. Actually, you confirm that the flag is used on import only, and then the tabs are stored in memory in usual LO way (relative to left paragraph indent). From there, they are fed into the ruler code (being usual relative-to-indent), so why does it need to treat them differently in this case?

From there, they are fed > into the ruler code (being usual relative-to-indent), so why does > it need to treat them differently in this case?To me this looks like a related but different problem.Just open a docx with you patch active and apply some tab stops and then add a left paragraph indent. You will notice that in this situation the tabs in the ruler and the document don't match anymore.The problem of tdf#95846 might be that the column offset of the table calculated into the left indent.

text: Patch Set 1:A different take on tdf#86784 -- as suggested in tl;dr bug comments and now abandoned gerrit patch, this one creates an overloaded bootstrap() method taking String[] as an argument. text: Patch Set 3:Pet peeve: Please don't introduce boolean parameters with default values... text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1> I'm not sure why Michael used Threads rather than Cores.Logically because thread is the correct term. I have right now a 4 core system with 119 threads (in total) running. In modern systems with libraries like lwp and (in systems like android) demand switching, there are no relationship between CPU/Core and threads. > My patch is a first step to improving what was very unclear and we > can always a follow up patch to fix whatever is agreed on, as it > needs to be sent to master as well.I would very much prefer we agree first, then send the patch. Your patch does not contain a lot more so no reason to merge this first.

text: Patch Set 1:This seems a ridiculous discussion to me ;-) doer decides is a vital meritocratic principle =) quibbling adds little value it seems to me.Beyond that - there is nothing simple about APU hardware; we have both GPU and CPU compute resources with things akin to threads in them. Cores is also an horribly misleading term in a SMT world. There are even pending law-suits around "what is a core" - how many resources can be shared etc. There is no "obvious" answer to this question.What we are returning is: the result of std::thread::hardware_concurrency() - we can provide a hyper-descriptive label for this: but then we'll be sending a truck-load of these across the net for years, and there is only so much space in Help->About =)What is in the patch has the merit of brevity; if someone wants to change it to CPU Threads Hardware Concurency - to follow STL or whatever, they are welcome to - preferably in a separate, follow-up patch - that also line-wraps this for Help->About.
Text: Patch Set 1:This seems a ridiculous discussion to me ;-) doer decides is a vital meritocratic principle =) quibbling adds little value it seems to me.Beyond that - there is nothing simple about APU hardware; we have both GPU and CPU compute resources with things akin to threads in them. Cores is also an horribly misleading term in a SMT world. There are even pending law-suits around "what is a core" - how many resources can be shared etc. There is no "obvious" answer to this question.What we are returning is: the result of std::thread::hardware_concurrency() - we can provide a hyper-descriptive label for this: but then we'll be sending a truck-load of these across the net for years, and there is only so much space in Help->About =)What is in the patch has the merit of brevity; if someone wants to change it to CPU Threads Hardware Concurency - to follow STL or whatever, they are welcome to - preferably in a separate, follow-up patch - that also line-wraps this for Help->About.

text: Patch Set 1:The same. The filter you work on gets an SVG, interprets it and creates a Draw document and shapes in it. What you need to do is get an SVG, do not interpret it, create a Draw document with a single GraphicObject on the 1st page which uses the SVG as Graphic. Should be all in there, just need to strip all the unnecessary stuff. It should be okay to experiment in the filter, finishing it would need stripping and cleanup. HTH!
Text: Patch Set 1:The same. The filter you work on gets an SVG, interprets it and creates a Draw document and shapes in it. What you need to do is get an SVG, do not interpret it, create a Draw document with a single GraphicObject on the 1st page which uses the SVG as Graphic. Should be all in there, just need to strip all the unnecessary stuff. It should be okay to experiment in the filter, finishing it would need stripping and cleanup. HTH!

text: Patch Set 1:Upps, I got you wrong - It is not the same in the aoo project - in aoo there is no SVG filter in filter, but it opens SVGs at file/open as intended. That happens more using the filter configuration and type detection, opening the default app and inserting the graphic. This is also possible, but will not support multi-page SVGs AFAIK
Text: Patch Set 1:Upps, I got you wrong - It is not the same in the aoo project - in aoo there is no SVG filter in filter, but it opens SVGs at file/open as intended. That happens more using the filter configuration and type detection, opening the default app and inserting the graphic. This is also possible, but will not support multi-page SVGs AFAIK

text: Patch Set 2:> This will work if UNX symbol defined, in Linux should be defined > because it works, though I didn't find where UNX symbol is defined.gb_OSDEFS in solenv/gbuild/platform/unxgcc.mk etc. > Re. cpp unit test: in this specific case the test should be enabled > only when UNX is defined. > Ucb lacks completely cpp unit test case, there is something in java > only.i really wouldn't hold up this patch for lack of a unit test: as you found, we currently have not a single test that tests network protocols, and that probably requires a bit of work because you obviously need to start a server for the protocol before you can test it.also when timers are involved there is the case of running the test with heavy-weight instrumentation like ASAN, valgrind or DrMemory that may cause it to timeout and fail unexpectedly.
Text: Patch Set 2:> This will work if UNX symbol defined, in Linux should be defined > because it works, though I didn't find where UNX symbol is defined.gb_OSDEFS in solenv/gbuild/platform/unxgcc.mk etc. > Re. cpp unit test: in this specific case the test should be enabled > only when UNX is defined. > Ucb lacks completely cpp unit test case, there is something in java > only.i really wouldn't hold up this patch for lack of a unit test: as you found, we currently have not a single test that tests network protocols, and that probably requires a bit of work because you obviously need to start a server for the protocol before you can test it.also when timers are involved there is the case of running the test with heavy-weight instrumentation like ASAN, valgrind or DrMemory that may cause it to timeout and fail unexpectedly.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Nice, generally works, but there's a problem when used from within the Function Wizard, where usually when selecting a range with the mouse as parameter the reference dialog is opened, and closed on mouse-button up. When clicking a column or row header the dialog is not closed and stays there and can only be closed with Escape or Enter or selecting a different range. Additionally, when in that state clicking inside the edit field of the dialog, moving the mouse cursor acts as if the mouse button is still pressed, selecting/deselecting the reference text when moving left/right.It would also be nice if more than one column or row could be selected using the headers. Actually it works when using Shift+Click to extend the range, but not by just selecting the headers with the mouse.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Nice, generally works, but there's a problem when used from within the Function Wizard, where usually when selecting a range with the mouse as parameter the reference dialog is opened, and closed on mouse-button up. When clicking a column or row header the dialog is not closed and stays there and can only be closed with Escape or Enter or selecting a different range. Additionally, when in that state clicking inside the edit field of the dialog, moving the mouse cursor acts as if the mouse button is still pressed, selecting/deselecting the reference text when moving left/right.It would also be nice if more than one column or row could be selected using the headers. Actually it works when using Shift+Click to extend the range, but not by just selecting the headers with the mouse.

text: Patch Set 4:> Works, but.. ;) something strange is going on: >  > in A1 type =sum( > select column B > press Enter > in A2 type =sum( >  > and as soon as the opening ( parenthesis is typed, the string > ,B1048576 is inserted before, so the resulting string is >  > =sum,B1048576(Noticed that this happens when user types "=sum" and then presses one of the keys (alt, ctrl, shift). This only happens when user did not move/touch the mouse after last mouse-button-up event. Also found that void ScHeaderControl::MouseMove is getting called when the above mentioned keys (alt, ctrl, shift) is pressed even though there is no actual mouse movement !To solve this I had to work around by adding a flag bDoneInitRef.
Text: Patch Set 4:> Works, but.. ;) something strange is going on: >  > in A1 type =sum( > select column B > press Enter > in A2 type =sum( >  > and as soon as the opening ( parenthesis is typed, the string > ,B1048576 is inserted before, so the resulting string is >  > =sum,B1048576(Noticed that this happens when user types "=sum" and then presses one of the keys (alt, ctrl, shift). This only happens when user did not move/touch the mouse after last mouse-button-up event. Also found that void ScHeaderControl::MouseMove is getting called when the above mentioned keys (alt, ctrl, shift) is pressed even though there is no actual mouse movement !To solve this I had to work around by adding a flag bDoneInitRef.

text: Patch Set 4:> """ > sc/source/ui/inc/hdrcont.hxx : line 115 >  > ScViewData pointer(pViewData) is used in ScColBar/ScRowBar(inherited > from ScHeaderControl) in many places, so is it good to make > function calls pTabView->GetViewData() at all those places rather > than just doing it once in the ScColBar/ScRowBar constructors and > storing it as their private member ? > """ >  > Hi Eike, Could you please let me know your thoughts on my last > question on patch set 4 ? Thanks.Ah, sorry, yes. ScTabView::GetViewData() is an inexpensive call that just returns a reference to its ScViewData, so can be called once whenever needed.
Text: Patch Set 4:> """ > sc/source/ui/inc/hdrcont.hxx : line 115 >  > ScViewData pointer(pViewData) is used in ScColBar/ScRowBar(inherited > from ScHeaderControl) in many places, so is it good to make > function calls pTabView->GetViewData() at all those places rather > than just doing it once in the ScColBar/ScRowBar constructors and > storing it as their private member ? > """ >  > Hi Eike, Could you please let me know your thoughts on my last > question on patch set 4 ? Thanks.Ah, sorry, yes. ScTabView::GetViewData() is an inexpensive call that just returns a reference to its ScViewData, so can be called once whenever needed.

text: Patch Set 4:Ok, it seems that I'm unable to come out with a unit test here.If I try to proceed with the approach of patch set 4, then I end up with both static and dynamic linking of sd; static is needed because I try to access internal functions and structs unavailable externally (ViewShell::GetViewShellBase, slidesorter::SlideSorterViewShell::GetSlideSorter, slidesorter::SlideSorter::GetController, etc). Dynamic linking results from external dependencies (sfx) that link sd dll. As static linked structures don't get properly initialized, I cannot use the functions that happen to be statically linked (e.g. SfxObjectShell::GetFactory().GetViewFactory()).I think I need to revert to patch set 2, that is fix only, without unit test.
Text: Patch Set 4:Ok, it seems that I'm unable to come out with a unit test here.If I try to proceed with the approach of patch set 4, then I end up with both static and dynamic linking of sd; static is needed because I try to access internal functions and structs unavailable externally (ViewShell::GetViewShellBase, slidesorter::SlideSorterViewShell::GetSlideSorter, slidesorter::SlideSorter::GetController, etc). Dynamic linking results from external dependencies (sfx) that link sd dll. As static linked structures don't get properly initialized, I cannot use the functions that happen to be statically linked (e.g. SfxObjectShell::GetFactory().GetViewFactory()).I think I need to revert to patch set 2, that is fix only, without unit test.

text: Patch Set 3:Tried the behaviour out and think people will be highly confused by it. What would be useful is to have it as a split button and when Save is not accessible, the main button is disabled, but the down arrow is still accessible.
Text: Patch Set 3:Tried the behaviour out and think people will be highly confused by it. What would be useful is to have it as a split button and when Save is not accessible, the main button is disabled, but the down arrow is still accessible.

text: Patch Set 3:> Tried the behaviour out and think people will be highly confused by > it.I'm not sure. I think most people can learn the new behavior quickly. We can also change the icon and tooltip dynamically, to make it clear what the button does in each state. > What would be useful is to have it as a split button and when > Save is not accessible, the main button is disabled, but the down > arrow is still accessible.This will make the dropdown non-discoverable, as the only difference between enabled and disabled dropdown button is its color ( black vs. grey).But I want to propose another solution: Currently the dropdown has 2 items: Save as - which already has its own button, and Save Remote File, which is actually a variation of Save As... - So why not leave alone the save button - and implement the dropdown only for Save As. This new dropdown will include Save Remote File, as well as other proposed items like saving to different formats etc.
Text: Patch Set 3:> Tried the behaviour out and think people will be highly confused by > it.I'm not sure. I think most people can learn the new behavior quickly. We can also change the icon and tooltip dynamically, to make it clear what the button does in each state. > What would be useful is to have it as a split button and when > Save is not accessible, the main button is disabled, but the down > arrow is still accessible.This will make the dropdown non-discoverable, as the only difference between enabled and disabled dropdown button is its color ( black vs. grey).But I want to propose another solution: Currently the dropdown has 2 items: Save as - which already has its own button, and Save Remote File, which is actually a variation of Save As... - So why not leave alone the save button - and implement the dropdown only for Save As. This new dropdown will include Save Remote File, as well as other proposed items like saving to different formats etc.

text: Patch Set 3:Yes i think if the icon and tooltip changed, that would likely make it easier to identify, but i would assume the .uno:Save command (File > Save) should be rendered disabled when its in the Save As mode.About your other suggestion, Save Remote File is a save option more than an a Save As option, as the option to save a file to a remote location isnt available in the Save dialog. Save As is primarily used to save to a different format.
Text: Patch Set 3:Yes i think if the icon and tooltip changed, that would likely make it easier to identify, but i would assume the .uno:Save command (File > Save) should be rendered disabled when its in the Save As mode.About your other suggestion, Save Remote File is a save option more than an a Save As option, as the option to save a file to a remote location isnt available in the Save dialog. Save As is primarily used to save to a different format.

text: Patch Set 3:> Yes i think if the icon and tooltip changed, that would likely make > it easier to identify,Can you please suggest the icon/tooltip to use? > but i would assume the .uno:Save command > (File > Save) should be rendered disabled when its in the Save As > mode.Sure. It doesn't affect the menu in any way.BTW, I forgot to mention that the behavior of this button is now configurable through "expert config". Any user is free to revert it to the state before this patch, or even to drop the dropdown completely:Type "SaveToolbarController" in the search field and hit Enter.To revert to the previous state, change "Controller" to "com.sun.star.comp.framework.GenericPopupToolbarController", and "Value" to ".uno:SaveAsMenu". Leaving "Value" empty will bring back the old simple button.
Text: Patch Set 3:> Yes i think if the icon and tooltip changed, that would likely make > it easier to identify,Can you please suggest the icon/tooltip to use? > but i would assume the .uno:Save command > (File > Save) should be rendered disabled when its in the Save As > mode.Sure. It doesn't affect the menu in any way.BTW, I forgot to mention that the behavior of this button is now configurable through "expert config". Any user is free to revert it to the state before this patch, or even to drop the dropdown completely:Type "SaveToolbarController" in the search field and hit Enter.To revert to the previous state, change "Controller" to "com.sun.star.comp.framework.GenericPopupToolbarController", and "Value" to ".uno:SaveAsMenu". Leaving "Value" empty will bring back the old simple button.

text: Patch Set 1:Mat├║┼í - seems like there is something wrong with the original fix too - it isn't working the way it did earlier in all my testing.  The test document opens fine, but when you save it and then re-open, the table often starts on a new page again.   If you edit the preceding paragraph it will "jump up close" again, but after saving and re-opening, it again starts on a new page.  I don't remember that ever happening in earlier testing.  Are you seeing the same thing?For the first page formating, change the spacing to single spacing. text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1I agree with you V Stuart but then I compared a bit some mapping color name/RGB values with HTML and, for example, light gray seems wrong.Indeed, LO gives C0C0C0 (http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/include/tools/color.hxx#47) whereas w3cschool defines it as D3D3D3 (see http://www.w3schools.com/tags/ref_color_tryit.asp?color=LightGray).So I think we may push this patch for the moment, the mapping color name/rgb code will need a clean in a specific patch.

text: Patch Set 6:> FnHashSet ? - what is the function ? surely a better, more descriptive type name is possibleI have renamed as AsyncLoads in the patch set 6.> Also - I suggested a much clearer name for this hash; but ... this is not it =)I had already changed the member variable name, but you checked an older patch set (patch set 3 instead of the last 5 at that time). > Why have this variable rather than using an empty-hash (and hence no lookup match) ?I have already removed that code in the patch set 6.> Why are we erasing here ? this seems inexplicable to me; I commented on it before; you seem to have responded to the comment - but this is not clear.> If the load of this filename is in-progress - then we prematurely remove it from being in-progress here, before it is loaded (right?) - why ?We want to skip only one LoadFile_Impl() call to avoid immediate paint and recursive image loadings. This skipped LoadFile_Impl() call is the last for the object, when the image loading is finished (see backtrace "Second LoadFile_Impl() call of an asynchronous image loading" in the Bug 95614).Or this call can be the first LoadFile_Impl() call of an other SvFileObject loading the same picture, so we won't start that image loading immediately.This stops freezing with linked images and recent scheduler.Many thanks for the review.
Text: Patch Set 6:> FnHashSet ? - what is the function ? surely a better, more descriptive type name is possibleI have renamed as AsyncLoads in the patch set 6.> Also - I suggested a much clearer name for this hash; but ... this is not it =)I had already changed the member variable name, but you checked an older patch set (patch set 3 instead of the last 5 at that time). > Why have this variable rather than using an empty-hash (and hence no lookup match) ?I have already removed that code in the patch set 6.> Why are we erasing here ? this seems inexplicable to me; I commented on it before; you seem to have responded to the comment - but this is not clear.> If the load of this filename is in-progress - then we prematurely remove it from being in-progress here, before it is loaded (right?) - why ?We want to skip only one LoadFile_Impl() call to avoid immediate paint and recursive image loadings. This skipped LoadFile_Impl() call is the last for the object, when the image loading is finished (see backtrace "Second LoadFile_Impl() call of an asynchronous image loading" in the Bug 95614).Or this call can be the first LoadFile_Impl() call of an other SvFileObject loading the same picture, so we won't start that image loading immediately.This stops freezing with linked images and recent scheduler.Many thanks for the review.

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1Seems reasonable enough I guess - I would name the member variable something sensible; m_aAsyncLoadsInProgress.I'm also really unclear why we erase the item from the hash if it is already there - when requesting the image [ that seems ... odd ] Surely we want to erase that when the async loading has completed (whether it succeeded or failed) - rather than when the 2nd image request is made (what about a 3rd request ?).Anyhow - conceptually loading the same graphic twice does indeed look bogus & good to stop; though whether this is truly the root cause of the freeze is unclear to me =)Thanks.
Text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1Seems reasonable enough I guess - I would name the member variable something sensible; m_aAsyncLoadsInProgress.I'm also really unclear why we erase the item from the hash if it is already there - when requesting the image [ that seems ... odd ] Surely we want to erase that when the async loading has completed (whether it succeeded or failed) - rather than when the 2nd image request is made (what about a 3rd request ?).Anyhow - conceptually loading the same graphic twice does indeed look bogus & good to stop; though whether this is truly the root cause of the freeze is unclear to me =)Thanks.

text: Patch Set 1:Jan, what is gerrit#19785 ? a reference to a gerrit review ?if so:1/ if the said patch has been merged already you want to reference the git commitwhich is stable and will be useful to anyone reading the log, which will have handy the git log but not necessarily gerrit2/ if it has not been merged the reference may become 'dangling' as the patch is not guaranteed to ever make it to the repoIn any case that reference is more appropriate in the 'body' of the comment than the title line (it explain the why we got there, not the what and/or how)
