text: Patch Set 4:> what other part of the patch makes this become necessary now?Most of the issues I'm trying to fix (containment of macros, namespace conflicts, etc) I discovered while working on improving pch files (patch to follow shortly). I made sure this patch was purely defensive and doesn't include any breaking changes, so nothing in this patch requires this.However, changing the order of includes, or adding certain files in pch, breaks a lot of files (this patch and a handful others that I've submitted hardened our code and fix those issues). The breaking of files has a domino effect, so they are rather hard to find and fix (and consume an inordinate amount of time to track the source and figure out a workaround). My attempt was to make the minimum change to fix macro leaks and other conflicts across headers and files. This patch is for Windows related issues only.RGB happens to be defined by wingdi.h and leaks from multiple places. This was the easiest/simplest fix; to undef it where it conflicts. For other cases it was enough to undef them in postwin.h and make sure it's called after including windows headers.
Text: Patch Set 4:> what other part of the patch makes this become necessary now?Most of the issues I'm trying to fix (containment of macros, namespace conflicts, etc) I discovered while working on improving pch files (patch to follow shortly). I made sure this patch was purely defensive and doesn't include any breaking changes, so nothing in this patch requires this.However, changing the order of includes, or adding certain files in pch, breaks a lot of files (this patch and a handful others that I've submitted hardened our code and fix those issues). The breaking of files has a domino effect, so they are rather hard to find and fix (and consume an inordinate amount of time to track the source and figure out a workaround). My attempt was to make the minimum change to fix macro leaks and other conflicts across headers and files. This patch is for Windows related issues only.RGB happens to be defined by wingdi.h and leaks from multiple places. This was the easiest/simplest fix; to undef it where it conflicts. For other cases it was enough to undef them in postwin.h and make sure it's called after including windows headers.

text: Patch Set 4:> RGB happens to be defined by wingdi.h and leaks from multiple > places. This was the easiest/simplest fix; to undef it where it > conflicts. For other cases it was enough to undef them in postwin.h > and make sure it's called after including windows headers.But wouldn't it be better to handle undef'ing RGB in postwin.h, and make sure any include of wingdi.h is wrapped in prewin/postwin.h?  The current fix allows workdir/CustomTarget/officecfg/registry/officecfg/Office/Common.hxx to be included, but if a source file happens to first include that officecfg/Office/Common.hxx, then include wingdi.h, and later wants to acutally use the struct RGB from Common.hxx, it still runs into a problem.
Text: Patch Set 4:> RGB happens to be defined by wingdi.h and leaks from multiple > places. This was the easiest/simplest fix; to undef it where it > conflicts. For other cases it was enough to undef them in postwin.h > and make sure it's called after including windows headers.But wouldn't it be better to handle undef'ing RGB in postwin.h, and make sure any include of wingdi.h is wrapped in prewin/postwin.h?  The current fix allows workdir/CustomTarget/officecfg/registry/officecfg/Office/Common.hxx to be included, but if a source file happens to first include that officecfg/Office/Common.hxx, then include wingdi.h, and later wants to acutally use the struct RGB from Common.hxx, it still runs into a problem.

text: Patch Set 4:> > RGB happens to be defined by wingdi.h and leaks from multiple > > places. This was the easiest/simplest fix; to undef it where it > > conflicts. For other cases it was enough to undef them in > postwin.h > > and make sure it's called after including windows headers. >  > But wouldn't it be better to handle undef'ing RGB in postwin.h, and > make sure any include of wingdi.h is wrapped in prewin/postwin.h? I tried that. And can give it another try. But it would require a much bigger change, obviously. The main problem is that wingdi.h is actually included from other windows headers too. So we can't fully control when it's included. But can give it another shot and narrow it down further. In fact, I spent hours trying to find what file includes the conflicting values to create this patch. > The current fix allows workdir/CustomTarget/officecfg/registry/officecfg/Office/Common.hxx > to be included, but if a source file happens to first include that > officecfg/Office/Common.hxx, then include wingdi.h, and later wants > to acutally use the struct RGB from Common.hxx, it still runs into > a problem.Well, that would be be a problem _only_ if wingdi.h was already included _before_ Office/Common.h, and in that case the build would fail because the macro would conflict with the declaration of RGB (my patch avoids this situation).However, if wingdi.h was _not_ included at the point of #undef RGB, then nothing bad would happen if it is included afterwards. Unless I missed something, I don't see how there would still be a problem, as wingdi.h will define RGB without issue.I should add that I hated this particular line of my patch. I share your view that it's best avoided altogether. But I couldn't find a better solution. Will try again though.
Text: Patch Set 4:> > RGB happens to be defined by wingdi.h and leaks from multiple > > places. This was the easiest/simplest fix; to undef it where it > > conflicts. For other cases it was enough to undef them in > postwin.h > > and make sure it's called after including windows headers. >  > But wouldn't it be better to handle undef'ing RGB in postwin.h, and > make sure any include of wingdi.h is wrapped in prewin/postwin.h? I tried that. And can give it another try. But it would require a much bigger change, obviously. The main problem is that wingdi.h is actually included from other windows headers too. So we can't fully control when it's included. But can give it another shot and narrow it down further. In fact, I spent hours trying to find what file includes the conflicting values to create this patch. > The current fix allows workdir/CustomTarget/officecfg/registry/officecfg/Office/Common.hxx > to be included, but if a source file happens to first include that > officecfg/Office/Common.hxx, then include wingdi.h, and later wants > to acutally use the struct RGB from Common.hxx, it still runs into > a problem.Well, that would be be a problem _only_ if wingdi.h was already included _before_ Office/Common.h, and in that case the build would fail because the macro would conflict with the declaration of RGB (my patch avoids this situation).However, if wingdi.h was _not_ included at the point of #undef RGB, then nothing bad would happen if it is included afterwards. Unless I missed something, I don't see how there would still be a problem, as wingdi.h will define RGB without issue.I should add that I hated this particular line of my patch. I share your view that it's best avoided altogether. But I couldn't find a better solution. Will try again though.

text: Patch Set 4:> > The current fix allows workdir/CustomTarget/officecfg/registry/officecfg/Office/Common.hxx > > to be included, but if a source file happens to first include that > > officecfg/Office/Common.hxx, then include wingdi.h, and later wants > > to acutally use the struct RGB from Common.hxx, it still runs into > > a problem. >  > Well, that would be be a problem _only_ if wingdi.h was already > included _before_ Office/Common.h, and in that case the build would > fail because the macro would conflict with the declaration of RGB > (my patch avoids this situation). >  > However, if wingdi.h was _not_ included at the point of #undef RGB, > then nothing bad would happen if it is included afterwards. Unless > I missed something, I don't see how there would still be a problem, > as wingdi.h will define RGB without issue.But assume wingdi.h does  #define RGB foo(or whatever exactly it defines RGB to), and the .cxx file including first officecfg/Office/Common.hxx and then wingdi.h then has code  officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::RGB::Red::get();that would be pre-processed to  officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::foo::Red::get();and fail to compile.
Text: Patch Set 4:> > The current fix allows workdir/CustomTarget/officecfg/registry/officecfg/Office/Common.hxx > > to be included, but if a source file happens to first include that > > officecfg/Office/Common.hxx, then include wingdi.h, and later wants > > to acutally use the struct RGB from Common.hxx, it still runs into > > a problem. >  > Well, that would be be a problem _only_ if wingdi.h was already > included _before_ Office/Common.h, and in that case the build would > fail because the macro would conflict with the declaration of RGB > (my patch avoids this situation). >  > However, if wingdi.h was _not_ included at the point of #undef RGB, > then nothing bad would happen if it is included afterwards. Unless > I missed something, I don't see how there would still be a problem, > as wingdi.h will define RGB without issue.But assume wingdi.h does  #define RGB foo(or whatever exactly it defines RGB to), and the .cxx file including first officecfg/Office/Common.hxx and then wingdi.h then has code  officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::RGB::Red::get();that would be pre-processed to  officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::foo::Red::get();and fail to compile.

text: Patch Set 4:>  > But assume wingdi.h does >  > #define RGB foo >  > (or whatever exactly it defines RGB to), and the .cxx file > including first officecfg/Office/Common.hxx and then wingdi.h then > has code >  > officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::RGB::Red::get(); >  > that would be pre-processed to >  > officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::foo::Red::get(); >  > and fail to compile.Of course. But my change will neither help nor harm that case :)(I only fixed the reverse, which is that wingdi.h is included before Common.hxx.)And I believe that case doesn't exist now (if they existed, I fixed them).Containing windows headers in postwin.h will help (which I fully support). But even then, once a header that includes wingdi.h (directly or indirectly) is included in the pch, then we still face the same issue. So it's really tricky.Since I was working on pch files, it was this latter case that really made things complicated. The way to avoid that is to never include an uncontained header that leaks in the pch, which is what we do. So the only case that breaks the build is when RGB is defined before Office/Common.hxx, which I patched.Actually, I think what we should do is add #undef RGB to postwin.h (even when currently it's not needed). I think that's the right thing to do and guarantee that wingdi.h is as contained as possible at all times.
Text: Patch Set 4:>  > But assume wingdi.h does >  > #define RGB foo >  > (or whatever exactly it defines RGB to), and the .cxx file > including first officecfg/Office/Common.hxx and then wingdi.h then > has code >  > officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::RGB::Red::get(); >  > that would be pre-processed to >  > officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::foo::Red::get(); >  > and fail to compile.Of course. But my change will neither help nor harm that case :)(I only fixed the reverse, which is that wingdi.h is included before Common.hxx.)And I believe that case doesn't exist now (if they existed, I fixed them).Containing windows headers in postwin.h will help (which I fully support). But even then, once a header that includes wingdi.h (directly or indirectly) is included in the pch, then we still face the same issue. So it's really tricky.Since I was working on pch files, it was this latter case that really made things complicated. The way to avoid that is to never include an uncontained header that leaks in the pch, which is what we do. So the only case that breaks the build is when RGB is defined before Office/Common.hxx, which I patched.Actually, I think what we should do is add #undef RGB to postwin.h (even when currently it's not needed). I think that's the right thing to do and guarantee that wingdi.h is as contained as possible at all times.

text: Patch Set 1:Hi Xisco, that is true, and it should have been right from the beginning.It was not. But when you reload your document and it looks different from last time, *very* many users will be unhappy - and that is the main criteria from my POV. Would you like your docs from last year/month/week look different after upgrading LO?We may be lucky and this does not happen - that's why I ask if you checked. Concrete:- sw with orig LO- add SVG (various methods/possibilities, in text, in tables, anchored differently, try to check all)- load with changed LO-> does it change?Same needed in Draw/Impress/Calc with DrawObjects, once BitmapObject (insert/picture), once DrawObject with BitmapFill (repeated, ...).To decide to do or not to do means to have a table in which of these cases the loaded, existing docs at the user side will change in layout. We need that table from my POV.
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Xisco, that is true, and it should have been right from the beginning.It was not. But when you reload your document and it looks different from last time, *very* many users will be unhappy - and that is the main criteria from my POV. Would you like your docs from last year/month/week look different after upgrading LO?We may be lucky and this does not happen - that's why I ask if you checked. Concrete:- sw with orig LO- add SVG (various methods/possibilities, in text, in tables, anchored differently, try to check all)- load with changed LO-> does it change?Same needed in Draw/Impress/Calc with DrawObjects, once BitmapObject (insert/picture), once DrawObject with BitmapFill (repeated, ...).To decide to do or not to do means to have a table in which of these cases the loaded, existing docs at the user side will change in layout. We need that table from my POV.

text: Patch Set 6:Norbert, thanks for CCing me. Although I'm being added after this is merged...On the one hand, I'm not happy about the lost features, which to my eye are somewhat important. Ironically, I don't think they are important for Base itself, but more for the services that Base provides to other components: namely the capacity for Writer to do mail merges on Outlook, Outlook Express, Thunderbird and LDAP address books (on Windows 32 bit).Oh the other hand, I understand and see that this whole old precompiled binary mozilla thing is a monstrosity that cannot continue indefinitely, in addition of being against our FLOSS principles. The timing of this instigates doubt that one of the reasons is to level down the Win32 and Win64 versions to the same feature set.As to "could be rewritten from scratch", yes, it could; the absence of activity on bugs 56903 56905 and 57322 suggests that we don't have the volunteer manpower to do that. Maybe leaving the glaring difference between the Win32 and Win64 builds would have brought some energy, who knows.Why do two files in connectivity/source/drivers/mozab/bootstrap survive?

The timing of this instigates doubt that one of the reasons is to level down the Win32 and Win64 versions to the same feature set.As to "could be rewritten from scratch", yes, it could; the absence of activity on bugs 56903 56905 and 57322 suggests that we don't have the volunteer manpower to do that. Maybe leaving the glaring difference between the Win32 and Win64 builds would have brought some energy, who knows.Why do two files in connectivity/source/drivers/mozab/bootstrap survive?

text: Patch Set 4:I wish we had aw080 already, all SdrObjects fully transformable, mirroring preserved...The current Rectangle unfortunately allows such bad/inconsistent states (left() > right()), thats why justify is needed (and why B2DRange is better, this can not happen). The Rectangle is *not* the place to keep such information. It's place is at the model (the SdrObject). See ::TRGetBaseGeometry implementations where the mirroring is coming from - e.g in SdrObjCustomShape it *is* a model member (X and Y).Currently - except for the SdrObjCustomShape and SdrGrafObj - the mirrored states are not preserved - the mirroring is geometrically *executed* on the existing geometry, that's it (aw080 changes this).You can see this sad truth e.g. at the graphic object - insert one in Draw/Impress and add text. Hor mirror does not change the text at all, vertical mirror uses a 180 deg rotation, *not* a true vert mirroring.This only does not come to more attention due to the fact that nearly all shapes are CustomShapes nowadays...Do not forget: mirror in X and Y equals a 180 deg rotation (can be seen/proved looking at the corrresponding homogen matrix)
Text: Patch Set 4:I wish we had aw080 already, all SdrObjects fully transformable, mirroring preserved...The current Rectangle unfortunately allows such bad/inconsistent states (left() > right()), thats why justify is needed (and why B2DRange is better, this can not happen). The Rectangle is *not* the place to keep such information. It's place is at the model (the SdrObject). See ::TRGetBaseGeometry implementations where the mirroring is coming from - e.g in SdrObjCustomShape it *is* a model member (X and Y).Currently - except for the SdrObjCustomShape and SdrGrafObj - the mirrored states are not preserved - the mirroring is geometrically *executed* on the existing geometry, that's it (aw080 changes this).You can see this sad truth e.g. at the graphic object - insert one in Draw/Impress and add text. Hor mirror does not change the text at all, vertical mirror uses a 180 deg rotation, *not* a true vert mirroring.This only does not come to more attention due to the fact that nearly all shapes are CustomShapes nowadays...Do not forget: mirror in X and Y equals a 180 deg rotation (can be seen/proved looking at the corrresponding homogen matrix)

text: Patch Set 2:> Works alot better with the sample document i was usingThanks for testing. Is that a +1? :) >  > Only issue i have is that when enabling/disabling it, it jumps to > the cursor position after it finishes rather than to keeping the > position of where i was when i changed the state.Tricky. When changing the state, the layout is invalidated and the the default logic of repaginating and page-layout does its thing on next idle timer event. So changing this behavior will affect others as well. While changing the position is not desirable, changing the cursor and losing selection is even more problematic--both of which I prevent in this patch. >  > On a separate issue, it might be better to have the entry labelled > 'Whitespace' and change the toggle behaviour, so when its > unchecked, it goes into hide whitespace mode.Interesting point. The 'Hide Whitespace' was chosen to be similar to MSO. Would 'Show Whitespace' be better or just 'Whitespace'? Should I change it (in separate patch) or you want to confirm (possibly by getting input from others) ?

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2yes this would probably avoid a whole bunch of more obvious threading issues in practice - but it is fundamentally the wrong place to add a mutex guard since SwModify is not a public API entry point but an implementation detail of writer.i'd say it's better to fix the API entry points instead, which i've started to do some years ago but isn't finished yet (see also i#105557 and i#107771 and fdo#72695 ) - that would also fix the less obvious threading issues in the uno wrappers that aren't about usage of SwModify.but the DBG_TESTSOLARMUTEX() would be nice to have in these SwModify functions, however it's possible that make check does not pass currently with it added.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2yes this would probably avoid a whole bunch of more obvious threading issues in practice - but it is fundamentally the wrong place to add a mutex guard since SwModify is not a public API entry point but an implementation detail of writer.i'd say it's better to fix the API entry points instead, which i've started to do some years ago but isn't finished yet (see also i#105557 and i#107771 and fdo#72695 ) - that would also fix the less obvious threading issues in the uno wrappers that aren't about usage of SwModify.but the DBG_TESTSOLARMUTEX() would be nice to have in these SwModify functions, however it's possible that make check does not pass currently with it added.

text: Patch Set 3:Re-reading that I think the entire approach is unnecessary. GetSubIndex() already returns a case-sensitive match if there is one. The change wouldn't result in anything different. Sorry for confusion.I think the fill (analyse) routine should know whether a case-sensitive or insensitive match was found, and only for insensitive it may alter casing of resulting elements.
Text: Patch Set 3:Re-reading that I think the entire approach is unnecessary. GetSubIndex() already returns a case-sensitive match if there is one. The change wouldn't result in anything different. Sorry for confusion.I think the fill (analyse) routine should know whether a case-sensitive or insensitive match was found, and only for insensitive it may alter casing of resulting elements.

text: Patch Set 4:Thanks Eike,  that was an interesting idea,  and it did manage to get rid of a lot of extra code.  Do you think we should aim to get the out-of-the-box case conversion to work in this change?  Currently I've been testing by adding a few custom sort-lists.
Text: Patch Set 4:Thanks Eike,  that was an interesting idea,  and it did manage to get rid of a lot of extra code.  Do you think we should aim to get the out-of-the-box case conversion to work in this change?  Currently I've been testing by adding a few custom sort-lists.

text: Patch Set 2:Another idea:FillAnalyse calls ScUserList::GetData().  ScUserList is container of all ScUserListData.ScUserListData::GetSubIndex() is case insensitive.ScUserList::GetData() currently has a loop that calls GetSubIndex() on every ScUserListData object.If we change GetData() to have two loops, first does case-sensitive search on all ScUserListData objects, second loop does case-insensitive search,  and we add extra default sort lists for each case,  that might do it as well.I think this change wouldn't add much overhead because GetSubIndex does a case-sensitive search first and then a case-insensitive one.  By this change we'd just be changing the order of the searches.
Text: Patch Set 2:Another idea:FillAnalyse calls ScUserList::GetData().  ScUserList is container of all ScUserListData.ScUserListData::GetSubIndex() is case insensitive.ScUserList::GetData() currently has a loop that calls GetSubIndex() on every ScUserListData object.If we change GetData() to have two loops, first does case-sensitive search on all ScUserListData objects, second loop does case-insensitive search,  and we add extra default sort lists for each case,  that might do it as well.I think this change wouldn't add much overhead because GetSubIndex does a case-sensitive search first and then a case-insensitive one.  By this change we'd just be changing the order of the searches.

text: Patch Set 2:That mirrors my question about the whole reason for needing this patch.  Why?  What for?   Why are we worried about people unintentionally and randomly pressing an odd Alt-X combination, and then having something strange happen in the extremely unlikely situation described (and which I have never been able to produce).The reason why to allow it is for someone (like a developer) who truly DO want to see what "character" is there.  I would expect it more likely for someone to be frustrated that they can't see what control character is there, than for someone to be frustrated because they randomly did something that they have no idea what the result should be, and then have something bad happen.

text: Patch Set 1:The problem can be reproduced by quickly doing the `zoom` operations in gtktiledviewer. To reproduce this bug more reliably, a dbg-util or debug build is required otherwise tiles would render too quickly before we could do another zoom operation. We want zoom operation to happen when there are still some tiles to be rendered. A debug build should introduce the necessary delay in rendering tiles.
Text: Patch Set 1:The problem can be reproduced by quickly doing the `zoom` operations in gtktiledviewer. To reproduce this bug more reliably, a dbg-util or debug build is required otherwise tiles would render too quickly before we could do another zoom operation. We want zoom operation to happen when there are still some tiles to be rendered. A debug build should introduce the necessary delay in rendering tiles.

text: Patch Set 2:ordinary number string like 123:  Microsoft Word works the same way.  No U+ is required there.  I very intentionally wrote it to work the way it does.control codes:  It could be useful to be able to SEE what code exists, by toggling FROM the control code TO hex notation.   Of course, once you do that, you want to be able to get back to the original code again with another toggle just like you would do with every other character...  (Well, there is always undo instead I guess.)  MSWord doesn't work from 0-1f either I see.  I didn't see any harm in allowing it.  Inadvertent use of Alt-X will always result in unexpected results (as with any feature).
Text: Patch Set 2:ordinary number string like 123:  Microsoft Word works the same way.  No U+ is required there.  I very intentionally wrote it to work the way it does.control codes:  It could be useful to be able to SEE what code exists, by toggling FROM the control code TO hex notation.   Of course, once you do that, you want to be able to get back to the original code again with another toggle just like you would do with every other character...  (Well, there is always undo instead I guess.)  MSWord doesn't work from 0-1f either I see.  I didn't see any harm in allowing it.  Inadvertent use of Alt-X will always result in unexpected results (as with any feature).

text: Patch Set 3:> Now it the real VS2015 released, we should make sure that our > VS2015 stuff works for somebody who has only the release version > installed, and no betas, RCs etc.Sure. But how should I be able to verify this change supports final MSVC 14.0 before it was released? >  > Also, I am not sure why you remove the 10.0A SDK from the > WINDOWS_SDK_ACCEPTABLE_VERSIONS. Surely the default should be that > the SDK included with the compiler is sufficient and default?May be I got it wrong, but I haven't found SDK on the net that has this name. But yes, there is SDK 10.0, but note, that this SDK is not included with the compiler. This is confusing. Only universal CRT is included under C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10 directory. So you cannot build LO, when only MSVC 14.0 compiler is installed, you still need SDK 8.1 or 10.0 (this is explained in the commit message). I tested this change against SDK 8.1.
Text: Patch Set 3:> Now it the real VS2015 released, we should make sure that our > VS2015 stuff works for somebody who has only the release version > installed, and no betas, RCs etc.Sure. But how should I be able to verify this change supports final MSVC 14.0 before it was released? >  > Also, I am not sure why you remove the 10.0A SDK from the > WINDOWS_SDK_ACCEPTABLE_VERSIONS. Surely the default should be that > the SDK included with the compiler is sufficient and default?May be I got it wrong, but I haven't found SDK on the net that has this name. But yes, there is SDK 10.0, but note, that this SDK is not included with the compiler. This is confusing. Only universal CRT is included under C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10 directory. So you cannot build LO, when only MSVC 14.0 compiler is installed, you still need SDK 8.1 or 10.0 (this is explained in the commit message). I tested this change against SDK 8.1.

text: Patch Set 2:I think this is possible, but I do not think this is a good idea.Bug was not because images were stored in WMF instead of PNG, but that created WMF was invalid. text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1> Did you check if the runtime was actually installed? Maybe dev > builds do not install it (I don't remember!). Either > --enable-release-build, or state VC_REDIST=1 in command line, > something like > msiexec /i LibreOfficeDev-.....msi VC_REDIST=1 > I'm at the ODF Plugfest with a Linux notebook, I cannot check > further easily.I just searched in the entire C: for vcruntime140.dll and friends on this new VM, with Windows 10 installed, where the only package installed is LibreOffice. In fact I've found vcruntime140.dll and friends installed in C:/System64 folder (only)* concrt140.dll* msvcp140.dll* vccorelib140.dll* vcruntime140.dllSo this is clearly a wrong location for those files. We also have this error report: [1], but there they claim that:  The Microsoft_VC140_CRT_x64.msm merge module installs its 64bit DLLs in the SysWOW64 folder.In our case the folder seems to be entirely different. In fact after deinstallation of LibreOffce msi, the entire directory C:/System64 with its content is removed again.* [1] https://connect.microsoft.com/VisualStudio/feedback/details/1746644/microsoft-vc140-crt-x64-msm-merge-module-installs-c-c-runtime-dlls-in-x32-folder
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1> Did you check if the runtime was actually installed? Maybe dev > builds do not install it (I don't remember!). Either > --enable-release-build, or state VC_REDIST=1 in command line, > something like > msiexec /i LibreOfficeDev-.....msi VC_REDIST=1 > I'm at the ODF Plugfest with a Linux notebook, I cannot check > further easily.I just searched in the entire C: for vcruntime140.dll and friends on this new VM, with Windows 10 installed, where the only package installed is LibreOffice. In fact I've found vcruntime140.dll and friends installed in C:/System64 folder (only)* concrt140.dll* msvcp140.dll* vccorelib140.dll* vcruntime140.dllSo this is clearly a wrong location for those files. We also have this error report: [1], but there they claim that:  The Microsoft_VC140_CRT_x64.msm merge module installs its 64bit DLLs in the SysWOW64 folder.In our case the folder seems to be entirely different. In fact after deinstallation of LibreOffce msi, the entire directory C:/System64 with its content is removed again.* [1] https://connect.microsoft.com/VisualStudio/feedback/details/1746644/microsoft-vc140-crt-x64-msm-merge-module-installs-c-c-runtime-dlls-in-x32-folder

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1OMG, just checking on MSVC 12.0 (aka VS 2013) and seeing that all VS projects filea are not compatible any more with MSVC < 1900. Universal runtime was introduced only in MSVC 14.0 and it is hard coded in project files, so no wonder the compilation is failing with:  LINK : fatal error LNK1104: Datei "ucrtd.lib" kann nicht geÔûÆffnet werden.   [C:\Users\david\projects\libo\workdir\UnpackedTarball\python3\PCBuild\pylauncher.vcxproj]Now what?  Python 3.5 cannot be compiler with VS 2013 out of the box (I havn't looked how hard would be to fix that). Python 3.3 cannot be compiled with VS 2015. I wonder if we can conditionally switch between Python 3.3 and 3.5 during configuration process? But makefile changes are very intrusive (see this change), so it would be a lot of fun to support different compiler versions. So probably the only option is disruptive change: discontinue VS 2013 in favor of VS 2015.
Text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1OMG, just checking on MSVC 12.0 (aka VS 2013) and seeing that all VS projects filea are not compatible any more with MSVC < 1900. Universal runtime was introduced only in MSVC 14.0 and it is hard coded in project files, so no wonder the compilation is failing with:  LINK : fatal error LNK1104: Datei "ucrtd.lib" kann nicht ge脭没脝ffnet werden.   [C:\Users\david\projects\libo\workdir\UnpackedTarball\python3\PCBuild\pylauncher.vcxproj]Now what?  Python 3.5 cannot be compiler with VS 2013 out of the box (I havn't looked how hard would be to fix that). Python 3.3 cannot be compiled with VS 2015. I wonder if we can conditionally switch between Python 3.3 and 3.5 during configuration process? But makefile changes are very intrusive (see this change), so it would be a lot of fun to support different compiler versions. So probably the only option is disruptive change: discontinue VS 2013 in favor of VS 2015.

text: Patch Set 2:Thanks Eike, I had missed that.  In the new patch,  I copied the block instead of moving,  so that nStartRow would get calculated again after rDoc.ShrinkToUsedDataArea().This way it wouldn't go out of range if there is only header followed by empty rows or any other way.
Text: Patch Set 2:Thanks Eike, I had missed that.  In the new patch,  I copied the block instead of moving,  so that nStartRow would get calculated again after rDoc.ShrinkToUsedDataArea().This way it wouldn't go out of range if there is only header followed by empty rows or any other way.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1While this works for Find, it doesn't for Replace/ReplaceAll, which would be even more confusing for the user than if searching didn't work on formatted strings at all..Also, I think we should have an option in the dialog, for example "Search formatted display string", and switch between those two methods instead of doing both (which would also be better performance-wise). Otherwise some regular expressions may give unexpected matches if we silently search for both. Note also that search can occur via API.

text: Patch Set 3:"If we use DECODE_TO_IURI, decoded result will be 'foo%252Fbar'."  No.Also, looking more closely at the code in MediaDescriptor::requestAndVerifyDocPassword, disregarding the unfortunate variable name "aDocumentName" and the equally unfortunate naming of corresponding css.task.Document[MS]PasswordRequest members as "Name" ("the name of the document," ts ts), what is apparently intended is to pass the document's URI (cf. PasswordDialog ctor in uui/source/passworddlg.cxx, where the corresponding value is more properly named "aDocURL").  So it is probably better to mark-up the URI in a more "user friendly" way directly in that PasswordDialog ctor instead.Also, given that tdf#89694's example involves a filename also containing a space, an even more "user friendly" way might be to use DECODE_UNAMBIGUOUS instead of DECODE_TO_IURI even (which would display the space as " " instead of as "%20").  Note that there is no single "right" answer whether to use NO_DECODE, DECODE_TO_IURI, or DECODE_UNAMBIGUOUS here.  Each produces a string that could unambiguously be converted back into a true URI, just with varying degrees of "user friendliness" of the produced string.  On the other hand, DECODE_WITH_CHARSET produces a string that in general cannot unambiguously be converted back into a true URI, so loses information and potentially presents a misleading result to the user.
Text: Patch Set 3:"If we use DECODE_TO_IURI, decoded result will be 'foo%252Fbar'."  No.Also, looking more closely at the code in MediaDescriptor::requestAndVerifyDocPassword, disregarding the unfortunate variable name "aDocumentName" and the equally unfortunate naming of corresponding css.task.Document[MS]PasswordRequest members as "Name" ("the name of the document," ts ts), what is apparently intended is to pass the document's URI (cf. PasswordDialog ctor in uui/source/passworddlg.cxx, where the corresponding value is more properly named "aDocURL").  So it is probably better to mark-up the URI in a more "user friendly" way directly in that PasswordDialog ctor instead.Also, given that tdf#89694's example involves a filename also containing a space, an even more "user friendly" way might be to use DECODE_UNAMBIGUOUS instead of DECODE_TO_IURI even (which would display the space as " " instead of as "%20").  Note that there is no single "right" answer whether to use NO_DECODE, DECODE_TO_IURI, or DECODE_UNAMBIGUOUS here.  Each produces a string that could unambiguously be converted back into a true URI, just with varying degrees of "user friendliness" of the produced string.  On the other hand, DECODE_WITH_CHARSET produces a string that in general cannot unambiguously be converted back into a true URI, so loses information and potentially presents a misleading result to the user.

text: Patch Set 3:(1 comment)Thank you for your advice.I also think that the variable name "aDocumentName" is very misleading.1. About the insert point to decode URL.As you wrote, I think that the best way to convert is in PasswordDialog ctor.However, to reduce the influence I now was according to the method for the other formats(odf,etc...).For the other formats, probably insert points to decode URL are just before calling the UNO API, Document(MS)PasswordRequest(2). (e.g.   http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sfx2/source/appl/appopen.cxx#245  http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/filter/ww8/ww8par.cxx#5468)Somehow, those APIs want "the name of the document"... Therefore, in the case of OOXML, I think that the insert point to decode URL is either within MediaDescriptor::requestAndVerifyDocPassword() in unotools or DocPasswordHelper::requestAndVerifyDocPassword() in comphelper.Because the latter point has a smaller effect, I will modify the patch.(I think in the comphelper, INetURLObject can not be used because of the module dependencies. So, I will call directly rtl::url::decode().)2. About decodeMechanism for converting URL.I tried the two ways of rtl_UriDecodeWithCharset and rtl_UriDecodeToIuriRI, I have attached screen shots to bug report tdf#89694.https://bug-attachments.documentfoundation.org/attachment.cgi?id=113966https://bug-attachments.documentfoundation.org/attachment.cgi?id=113967I used this patch.https://bug-attachments.documentfoundation.org/attachment.cgi?id=113965I think the case in rtl_UriDecodeWithCharset is more user-friendly.If I mistake,  please point out.

text: Patch Set 3:Re "1. About the insert point to decode URL.":  Those other places are misguided in passing a marked-up "document name" instead of a URI.  The only reasonable design is to centrally mark-up the URI in the PasswordDialog ctor in uui/source/passworddlg.cxx, where it is presented to the user.  The PasswordDialog ctor gets it right in calling it "aDocURL," all the other places unfortunately get it wrong in vaguely calling it a "document name."Re "2. About decodeMechanism for converting URL.":  See my earlier "Also, given that tdf#89694's example involves a filename also containing a space [...]" comment.
Text: Patch Set 3:Re "1. About the insert point to decode URL.":  Those other places are misguided in passing a marked-up "document name" instead of a URI.  The only reasonable design is to centrally mark-up the URI in the PasswordDialog ctor in uui/source/passworddlg.cxx, where it is presented to the user.  The PasswordDialog ctor gets it right in calling it "aDocURL," all the other places unfortunately get it wrong in vaguely calling it a "document name."Re "2. About decodeMechanism for converting URL.":  See my earlier "Also, given that tdf#89694's example involves a filename also containing a space [...]" comment.

text: Patch Set 2:How will this not result in different rendering once LibreOffice saves the document. All the code that is behind the *MSO* flags in the chart2/source/view/* code will only be hit for documents that have been saved by MSO.None of these code paths will be hit if the same document has been saved by LibreOffice.Additionally I consider the idea to put such code into the chart2/source/view/* the worst idea since the decision to use UNO inside chart2/*. The chart2/source/view code should never ever contain checks for the file format and even less for the producer of the file.At least I would never accept such code inside of chart2.

The chart2/source/view code should never ever contain checks for the file format and even less for the producer of the file.At least I would never accept such code inside of chart2.

text: Patch Set 1:This patch set seems to work as it should be, with one exception:The add-in function in the UI still is WEEKNUM_ADD, although I changed odffmap.cxx and I can't find any 'WEEKNUM_ADD' with git grep...I fiddled with date-time-functions.ods to have both old-style and new-style saved WEEKNUM function calls. This way the backward compatibility is tested too. Disadvantage is that as soon as anyone changes the file, the old-style WEEKNUM function calls are gone.

text: Patch Set 4:> I am not sure, but a compiler should use some optimizations for > loops here and it will not affect basic operations as much.What optimization do you have in mind? > Moreover (I am sure that you know about it :) ) sum, sum of square, > count and product for a single reference, a range of cells and a > list of values (I mean e.g. "=SUM(2;3;4)") are calculated by the > ScInterpreter::IterateParameters, not by ScMatrixImpl methods. The > second ones are called for values in brackets ("=SUM({5;3;1}"). I > probably missed something, cause I'm still finding new things in > the code, but I think a bit worse performance could be noticeable > only in some corner cases, e.g. when user will type by hand a few > thousand numbers between parenthesis ...but still.You're missing generated matrix operations in array context, for example {=SUM(some_condition_of(range))}(entered as array formula with Shift+Ctrl+Enter) for range A:A willproduce a one million rows matrix of 1 and 0 values whether thecondition is met for each cell in range and count the number of matches(sum of 1 elements). This is not a far fetched example, it is commonspreadsheet practice. Actually you could test/time performance beforeand after your change with a simple {=SUM(A:A=2)}after having filled column A with alternating values of 2 and 3. Usinga millisecond timer resolution probably already should show thedifference.Things may get worse if multiple conditions are evaluated using forexample multiplication, which acts like a logical AND in {=SUM(condition1(range1)*condition2(range2))} > Similarly for average, max and min values - most of the time they > are calculated by ScInterpreter, not ScMatrix methods. Could it be > changed to have one operation in one place?I dont know what you mean. > I made this change thinking, beside performance, also about further > code reductions. It will be nice to have one functor for all > operations resulting in a single value, but it seems that I didn't > take a few elements (e.g. some operations count elements, other do > not) into account and it's rather a premature optimization than a > real gain. In the end, for now, the solution with two templates > seems to be the best for me.Probably, yes.
Text: Patch Set 4:> I am not sure, but a compiler should use some optimizations for > loops here and it will not affect basic operations as much.What optimization do you have in mind? > Moreover (I am sure that you know about it :) ) sum, sum of square, > count and product for a single reference, a range of cells and a > list of values (I mean e.g. "=SUM(2;3;4)") are calculated by the > ScInterpreter::IterateParameters, not by ScMatrixImpl methods. The > second ones are called for values in brackets ("=SUM({5;3;1}"). I > probably missed something, cause I'm still finding new things in > the code, but I think a bit worse performance could be noticeable > only in some corner cases, e.g. when user will type by hand a few > thousand numbers between parenthesis ...but still.You're missing generated matrix operations in array context, for example {=SUM(some_condition_of(range))}(entered as array formula with Shift+Ctrl+Enter) for range A:A willproduce a one million rows matrix of 1 and 0 values whether thecondition is met for each cell in range and count the number of matches(sum of 1 elements). This is not a far fetched example, it is commonspreadsheet practice. Actually you could test/time performance beforeand after your change with a simple {=SUM(A:A=2)}after having filled column A with alternating values of 2 and 3. Usinga millisecond timer resolution probably already should show thedifference.Things may get worse if multiple conditions are evaluated using forexample multiplication, which acts like a logical AND in {=SUM(condition1(range1)*condition2(range2))} > Similarly for average, max and min values - most of the time they > are calculated by ScInterpreter, not ScMatrix methods. Could it be > changed to have one operation in one place?I dont know what you mean. > I made this change thinking, beside performance, also about further > code reductions. It will be nice to have one functor for all > operations resulting in a single value, but it seems that I didn't > take a few elements (e.g. some operations count elements, other do > not) into account and it's rather a premature optimization than a > real gain. In the end, for now, the solution with two templates > seems to be the best for me.Probably, yes.

text: Patch Set 3:I am not sure, but a compiler should use some optimizations for loops here and it will not affect basic operations as much.Moreover (I am sure that you know about it :) ) sum, sum of square, count and product for a single reference, a range of cells and a list of values (I mean e.g. "=SUM(2;3;4)") are calculated by the ScInterpreter::IterateParameters, not by ScMatrixImpl methods. The second ones are called for values in brackets ("=SUM({5;3;1}"). I probably missed something, cause I'm still finding new things in the code, but I think a bit worse performance could be noticeable only in some corner cases, e.g. when user will type by hand a few thousand numbers between parenthesis ...but still.Similarly for average, max and min values - most of the time they are calculated by ScInterpreter, not ScMatrix methods. Could it be changed to have one operation in one place?I made this change thinking, beside performance, also about further code reductions. It will be nice to have one functor for all operations resulting in a single value, but it seems that I didn't take a few elements (e.g. some operations count elements, other do not) into account and it's rather a premature optimization than a real gain. In the end, for now, the solution with two templates seems to be the best for me.
Text: Patch Set 3:I am not sure, but a compiler should use some optimizations for loops here and it will not affect basic operations as much.Moreover (I am sure that you know about it :) ) sum, sum of square, count and product for a single reference, a range of cells and a list of values (I mean e.g. "=SUM(2;3;4)") are calculated by the ScInterpreter::IterateParameters, not by ScMatrixImpl methods. The second ones are called for values in brackets ("=SUM({5;3;1}"). I probably missed something, cause I'm still finding new things in the code, but I think a bit worse performance could be noticeable only in some corner cases, e.g. when user will type by hand a few thousand numbers between parenthesis ...but still.Similarly for average, max and min values - most of the time they are calculated by ScInterpreter, not ScMatrix methods. Could it be changed to have one operation in one place?I made this change thinking, beside performance, also about further code reductions. It will be nice to have one functor for all operations resulting in a single value, but it seems that I didn't take a few elements (e.g. some operations count elements, other do not) into account and it's rather a premature optimization than a real gain. In the end, for now, the solution with two templates seems to be the best for me.

text: Patch Set 3:Now I am confused, are these really equivalent?
Text: Patch Set 3:Now I am confused, are these really equivalent?

text: Patch Set 3:Replying to myself: Yeah, they are.USING_X11 is TRUE when we are building for a platform that uses X11, and we haven't used the --without-x option. with_x is "no" when we have used the switch --without-x (which used to be called --enable-headless), and that de facto has been developed only for platforms where X11 *could* be used. So USING_X11!=TRUE turns out to be equivalent to with_x==no. Unless I miss something;)In theory one could also imagine building a LibreOffice for Windows or OS X that would not use any display-oriented APIs, but that would be fairly pointless, as that functionality is always present in the OS anyway. It isn't like Linux, where some people think it is useful to have installations without any X11 stuff.
Text: Patch Set 3:Replying to myself: Yeah, they are.USING_X11 is TRUE when we are building for a platform that uses X11, and we haven't used the --without-x option. with_x is "no" when we have used the switch --without-x (which used to be called --enable-headless), and that de facto has been developed only for platforms where X11 *could* be used. So USING_X11!=TRUE turns out to be equivalent to with_x==no. Unless I miss something;)In theory one could also imagine building a LibreOffice for Windows or OS X that would not use any display-oriented APIs, but that would be fairly pointless, as that functionality is always present in the OS anyway. It isn't like Linux, where some people think it is useful to have installations without any X11 stuff.

text: Patch Set 2:Using UNDO_START and UNDO_END allows the inside functions to define the comment - which they properly do.  Without providing a SwRewriter argument, the variables are left undefined.
Text: Patch Set 2:Using UNDO_START and UNDO_END allows the inside functions to define the comment - which they properly do.  Without providing a SwRewriter argument, the variables are left undefined.

text: Patch Set 1:> Please, do you confirm that, to be tested, this patch must be > installed over the previous patch : git pull git://gerrit.libreoffice.org/core > refs/changes/81/17281/9 ?Yes sir, these are incremental. I'm working on page size, which will also be incremental, but would like to see these tested and with issues resolved (and ideally committed) before I push a potentially large patch (or multiple small ones).Please keep in mind that the menu entry for Hide Whitespace is already committed. We should either get a minimal working version of this feature committed before the next release, or temporarily disable the menu entry (which is not functional without this and the previous patch).

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1I propose a little exercise for you: Please try not to use the word ÔÇ£fixÔÇØ in your commit messages. The verb ÔÇ£to fixÔÇØ is vague on its own, but the way you use it doesnÔÇÖt allow for the commits to be scannable without looking at the code, which defeats the purpose of git log and git blame. In this particular case, by reading the commit message alone I canÔÇÖt tell at all what the commit is doing.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1Hmm, this breaks gtktiledviewer, as it uses lok_doc_view_reset_view() when changing parts -- so after e.g. changing to the next slide, it would be left without a loaded document. So I guess the best would be if you could add a new lok_doc_view_close_document() that uses lok_doc_view_reset_view() internally to avoid code duplication, but reset_view() is left unmodified. Could you do that, please?
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1Hmm, this breaks gtktiledviewer, as it uses lok_doc_view_reset_view() when changing parts -- so after e.g. changing to the next slide, it would be left without a loaded document. So I guess the best would be if you could add a new lok_doc_view_close_document() that uses lok_doc_view_reset_view() internally to avoid code duplication, but reset_view() is left unmodified. Could you do that, please?

text: Patch Set 1:Adobe Flash isn't available as part of LibreOfficeKit (IMHO) for Android, etc.  It also won't be available on Linux after 2017.  Or on Linux with Wayland.I made a note for myself to warn people using Plug-ins (from discussions around bug 45071) that the support might be removed in the future and that it's badly supported.
Text: Patch Set 1:Adobe Flash isn't available as part of LibreOfficeKit (IMHO) for Android, etc.  It also won't be available on Linux after 2017.  Or on Linux with Wayland.I made a note for myself to warn people using Plug-ins (from discussions around bug 45071) that the support might be removed in the future and that it's badly supported.

text: Patch Set 1:Undo:  I don't see any example code in calc that sets an undo message, and from what I DO see the text is a hard-coded response based on the type of 'edit'.  If I just type regular text, I also only get "input" (from InsertText() call) with no extra detail.  So what I have works identically to regular changes, and I don't see ANY ability to set an undo comment. cell editing:  This would need to be done in a totally different section.  In the editsh EXECUTE(), the Alt-X keystroke isn't even being captured when the cell is only selected.  So, effectively Calc is not in edit mode yet, and thus Alt-X doesn't apply.  If the "cursor" is either in the cell itself OR in the top editview, then the alt-x function works.  I would expect people to be editing the text when they use Alt-X, not finding an entire cell of data and trying to convert the whole thing.  So I don't think it is necessary to duplicate all of this code to handle that situation.
Text: Patch Set 1:Undo:  I don't see any example code in calc that sets an undo message, and from what I DO see the text is a hard-coded response based on the type of 'edit'.  If I just type regular text, I also only get "input" (from InsertText() call) with no extra detail.  So what I have works identically to regular changes, and I don't see ANY ability to set an undo comment. cell editing:  This would need to be done in a totally different section.  In the editsh EXECUTE(), the Alt-X keystroke isn't even being captured when the cell is only selected.  So, effectively Calc is not in edit mode yet, and thus Alt-X doesn't apply.  If the "cursor" is either in the cell itself OR in the top editview, then the alt-x function works.  I would expect people to be editing the text when they use Alt-X, not finding an entire cell of data and trying to convert the whole thing.  So I don't think it is necessary to duplicate all of this code to handle that situation.

text: Patch Set 1:Possible usecase for cell-level Alt-X support: building a table demonstrating unicode characters.  Select a row of cells, Alt-X and convert all to unicode character (or vice versa).  I'll look into what that will take.  It would be a separate patch.
Text: Patch Set 1:Possible usecase for cell-level Alt-X support: building a table demonstrating unicode characters.  Select a row of cells, Alt-X and convert all to unicode character (or vice versa).  I'll look into what that will take.  It would be a separate patch.

text: Patch Set 5:> I'm not enough expert to tell :-( My goal is only to make (or at > least to try) multi selection work in the most simplest way. > Do you think the change you suggest should be debated? If yes, > perhaps you may add a comment on the opened thread on dev mailing > list and putting M Meeks in cc? > If no, I can create a separate patch if you want.Yes, please keep the fix (which is to make all the various file picker implementations acutally support XFilePicker2, IIUC) separate from the (backwards-incompatible) "convenience improvement" of making XFilePicker3 derive from XFilePicker2.  (When all file picker implementations do implement XFilePicker2, client code can still make use of it---via explicit queryInterface---even without XFilePicker3 being derived from it.)
Text: Patch Set 5:> I'm not enough expert to tell :-( My goal is only to make (or at > least to try) multi selection work in the most simplest way. > Do you think the change you suggest should be debated? If yes, > perhaps you may add a comment on the opened thread on dev mailing > list and putting M Meeks in cc? > If no, I can create a separate patch if you want.Yes, please keep the fix (which is to make all the various file picker implementations acutally support XFilePicker2, IIUC) separate from the (backwards-incompatible) "convenience improvement" of making XFilePicker3 derive from XFilePicker2.  (When all file picker implementations do implement XFilePicker2, client code can still make use of it---via explicit queryInterface---even without XFilePicker3 being derived from it.)

text: Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1You need to adapt all the UNO service implementations implementing XFilePicker3 along with this incompatible change (cf e.g. <http://ci.libreoffice.org/job/lo_gerrit_master/4895/Gerrit=Gerrit,Platform=MacOSX/console>).  (Which is one reason why I would still first get all file picker implementations support XFilePicker2 before taking care of this "convenience improvement" change.)
Text: Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1You need to adapt all the UNO service implementations implementing XFilePicker3 along with this incompatible change (cf e.g. <http://ci.libreoffice.org/job/lo_gerrit_master/4895/Gerrit=Gerrit,Platform=MacOSX/console>).  (Which is one reason why I would still first get all file picker implementations support XFilePicker2 before taking care of this "convenience improvement" change.)

text: Patch Set 2:Actually, it seems changing it to not use pointers would be more work that I originally anticipated. The updated patch just renames the member variable to m_aFilter. At least this patch should get rid of some of the GCC 5 deprecation warnings.
Text: Patch Set 2:Actually, it seems changing it to not use pointers would be more work that I originally anticipated. The updated patch just renames the member variable to m_aFilter. At least this patch should get rid of some of the GCC 5 deprecation warnings.

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Ah the irony =) they're only disabled temporarily. I wanted to look at those guys and see if we can't improve them. We previously had tests that passed reliably =) I had hoped that eg. taking the median mark/space ratio between a few dozen AutoTimer triggers and comparing that to what it is supposed to be would show us whether we were spinning the mainloop hard rather than doing nice periodic updates eg.But I didn't read the unit test code too carefully - thanks so much for re-basing the cleanups =) lets submit as/when CI builds it cleanly if it can.
Text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Ah the irony =) they're only disabled temporarily. I wanted to look at those guys and see if we can't improve them. We previously had tests that passed reliably =) I had hoped that eg. taking the median mark/space ratio between a few dozen AutoTimer triggers and comparing that to what it is supposed to be would show us whether we were spinning the mainloop hard rather than doing nice periodic updates eg.But I didn't read the unit test code too carefully - thanks so much for re-basing the cleanups =) lets submit as/when CI builds it cleanly if it can.

text: Patch Set 4:> Ah the irony =) they're only disabled temporarily. I wanted to look > at those guys and see if we can't improve them. We previously had > tests that passed reliably =)My tests are far more stringent than previous tests, AFAIK. > I had hoped that eg. taking the > median mark/space ratio between a few dozen AutoTimer triggers and > comparing that to what it is supposed to be would show us whether > we were spinning the mainloop hard rather than doing nice periodic > updates eg.That would work. The tests I wrote were counting the number of times the timers trigger in a multi-timer scenario. What I had discovered is that there is a lack of consistency, which I have plans to fix/address.For example, when two timers have the same timeout and priority, one could get a very low trigger rate (or none at all). This is because the trigger logic always picks the one with highest priority that is next in line, and so can end up picking the same timer to trigger every time, starving the other(s).I have a patch to address this and also to fix make IdleTimer fire only when the process idles. >  > But I didn't read the unit test code too carefully - thanks so much > for re-basing the cleanups =) lets submit as/when CI builds it > cleanly if it can.The reason I had disabled the fail condition when the new tests were excluded is because the remaining code is useful in detecting timers that don't trigger during the watchdog timeout. That is, timers should eventually trigger, even if they don't trigger with any accuracy. So I was effectively disabling the accuracy test, but the timers should've triggered during the dozen seconds that the watchdog ways (which you've increased). The test not passing reliably was because of the strictness of the precision tests, not the fact that timers weren't triggering (which would be a real bug). The precision tests are only meaningful if they come with some delta, and I had used 10-20%, increasing it would mean more passing runs, but less useful precision tests. Let's keep them disabled for now.Thanks again for the reviews and helping with this. And please expect more patches on timers.

This is because the trigger logic always picks the one with highest priority that is next in line, and so can end up picking the same timer to trigger every time, starving the other(s).I have a patch to address this and also to fix make IdleTimer fire only when the process idles. >  > But I didn't read the unit test code too carefully - thanks so much > for re-basing the cleanups =) lets submit as/when CI builds it > cleanly if it can.The reason I had disabled the fail condition when the new tests were excluded is because the remaining code is useful in detecting timers that don't trigger during the watchdog timeout. So I was effectively disabling the accuracy test, but the timers should've triggered during the dozen seconds that the watchdog ways (which you've increased). The test not passing reliably was because of the strictness of the precision tests, not the fact that timers weren't triggering (which would be a real bug). The precision tests are only meaningful if they come with some delta, and I had used 10-20%, increasing it would mean more passing runs, but less useful precision tests. Let's keep them disabled for now.Thanks again for the reviews and helping with this. And please expect more patches on timers.

text: Patch Set 2:(1 comment)I wonder whether we really want those dispose calls all over the place? I'm assuming that the SvxFontNameBox_Impl case is unique, in sense that it owns the FontList and the FontList holds references to SvxFontNameBox_Impl, so none of them can be destructed. Is it the case in other places too? In case the FontInfo dtor *is* called, why call also the dispose method?See also one inline comment.

text: Patch Set 6:> so there isnt a to need hide left and right margins,Should we hide left/right margins in book-view and multipage-view ?Let me update the patch and let you play with left/right margins hidden only in book- and multipage-view, and see what you think. > It seems that removing the header and > footer also causes content to jump to the previous page, as the > page isnt being cropped but instead the content is allowed to flow > within the full size of the page space.Yes. I mentioned this somewhere as a limitation. The reason for this is that the page size is the same, but the margins are removed/reduced. So the text is allowed to fill in more surface area. This could be solved by changing the page dimensions in hide-whitespace mode. I didn't try to do that, again, to get initial feedback. > In case i didnt mention it before, i am part of the design and UX > teams. :DFantastic! Thanks again.

text: Patch Set 1:> by the way "include-what-you-use" should report these as well, > although not in windows-only code yet because we'd need to be able > to build with clang on windows first. >  > see also easy-hack  https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=42949Thanks Michael. Good to know. The reason I wrote this script is because I have another patch that improves pch generation (a rewrite of update_pch in python that updates every single pch in the codebase in a few seconds). It was obvious to me that to improve the pch generation to make builds faster I had to deal with the problem of conflicting headers (that are excluded from pch) and required headers (that will break the build if left out). This script solves the latter problem, so now what is included in pch headers is purely to accelerate builds, not to prevent the build from breaking.Will submit the update_pch script and updated pch files sometime soon, as time permits.
Text: Patch Set 1:> by the way "include-what-you-use" should report these as well, > although not in windows-only code yet because we'd need to be able > to build with clang on windows first. >  > see also easy-hack  https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=42949Thanks Michael. Good to know. The reason I wrote this script is because I have another patch that improves pch generation (a rewrite of update_pch in python that updates every single pch in the codebase in a few seconds). It was obvious to me that to improve the pch generation to make builds faster I had to deal with the problem of conflicting headers (that are excluded from pch) and required headers (that will break the build if left out). This script solves the latter problem, so now what is included in pch headers is purely to accelerate builds, not to prevent the build from breaking.Will submit the update_pch script and updated pch files sometime soon, as time permits.

text: Patch Set 3:(2 comments)> (2 comments) >  > Please don't default-enable unstable unit tests for default build > setups. You were complaining about unreliable jenkins results > yourself.Thanks for the review. You mean I should disable it by default?The tests are designed to be as stable as possible (obviously). I only submitted when I was confident enough that they won't cause immediate instability (evident from the commit message and the test design/code). What I'm saying in the message is that there are no strong guarantees from the OS, and the tests _can_ fail (doesn't mean _will_ fail). I just don't know how often. I suspect they will not fail any more than other fragile tests fail, and far less often than jenkins fails randomly (I know because I tested extensively).I think we should disable only when there is evidence that it is not stable.I will replace the static buffer with dynamic one.

text: Patch Set 3:I think the problem is that there is this case where an empty rectangle is passed as the control region, and the spinbutton area is passed down as a controlvalue. The empty control region gets mirrored for rtl from left(0), top(0), empty, empty to right(number), top(0), empty, empty and so the cairo_translate call is given a non-0 number and it all falls apart.Lets try not mirroring the empty rectangle arg, and take the first hunk of this patch which is clearly ok and then the second isn't needed.Hopefully this doesn't break any other native-rendering platforms, looks ok for gtk2 and gtk3 for me at least
Text: Patch Set 3:I think the problem is that there is this case where an empty rectangle is passed as the control region, and the spinbutton area is passed down as a controlvalue. The empty control region gets mirrored for rtl from left(0), top(0), empty, empty to right(number), top(0), empty, empty and so the cairo_translate call is given a non-0 number and it all falls apart.Lets try not mirroring the empty rectangle arg, and take the first hunk of this patch which is clearly ok and then the second isn't needed.Hopefully this doesn't break any other native-rendering platforms, looks ok for gtk2 and gtk3 for me at least

text: Patch Set 5:> Hi Ashod - is it -really- the case that our periodic timers don't > work  =) I'd be really worried if that was so - we need a unit test > for it. Any chance you can create one ? > Thanks !Depends what you mean by "work." The timers of course _do_ work, but that is not the problem I'm fixing. I'm fixing the issue with high idle CPU utilization. Periodic timers should reset their start time so that they re-fire only after the duration has expired. The issue, I found, is that Timer thinks it's ready to fire again at the next tick. Ticks come in for the _soonest_ next timer delay (this is because we really have only one system timer callback, and we need it to fire for the next timer in the queue). In the worst case they come in immediately (after 1ms) and in those cases Timer thinks it's ready to fire again, which it does. This doesn't cause any obvious problems, other than CPU utilization where there shouldn't be any (because Timer handles background jobs, like spellchecking, which wastes some CPU and returns, but the waste is proportional to the document size and number of documents open).It is clear from the code that nowhere is the start-time reset. Of course I had the luxury of debugging and seeing what was happening, but the code and my comments make it almost trivial to trace the variable in question and see that without changing it, it will trick Timer into firing again. (See Timer::ReadyForSchedule where mnUpdateTime is used.)I can add unittest for this but, from experience, timers are not reliable enough to trap them within a reasonable time frame from make the test meaningful. On a non-realtime OS, they come with no guarantees. And they are less consistent across a number of OSes. We can have a crude "test fire once" and "test don't fire too soon" but it's harder to have "fired too late." Also, it's much harder to simulate the myriads of jobs we have and the arbitrary periods of each (and how they overlap).I'll give it a shot, but applying and running a large document with this 1 liner will show that the idle CPU utilization does go to 0.
Text: Patch Set 5:> Hi Ashod - is it -really- the case that our periodic timers don't > work  =) I'd be really worried if that was so - we need a unit test > for it. Any chance you can create one ? > Thanks !Depends what you mean by "work." The timers of course _do_ work, but that is not the problem I'm fixing. I'm fixing the issue with high idle CPU utilization. Periodic timers should reset their start time so that they re-fire only after the duration has expired. The issue, I found, is that Timer thinks it's ready to fire again at the next tick. Ticks come in for the _soonest_ next timer delay (this is because we really have only one system timer callback, and we need it to fire for the next timer in the queue). In the worst case they come in immediately (after 1ms) and in those cases Timer thinks it's ready to fire again, which it does. This doesn't cause any obvious problems, other than CPU utilization where there shouldn't be any (because Timer handles background jobs, like spellchecking, which wastes some CPU and returns, but the waste is proportional to the document size and number of documents open).It is clear from the code that nowhere is the start-time reset. Of course I had the luxury of debugging and seeing what was happening, but the code and my comments make it almost trivial to trace the variable in question and see that without changing it, it will trick Timer into firing again. (See Timer::ReadyForSchedule where mnUpdateTime is used.)I can add unittest for this but, from experience, timers are not reliable enough to trap them within a reasonable time frame from make the test meaningful. On a non-realtime OS, they come with no guarantees. And they are less consistent across a number of OSes. We can have a crude "test fire once" and "test don't fire too soon" but it's harder to have "fired too late." Also, it's much harder to simulate the myriads of jobs we have and the arbitrary periods of each (and how they overlap).I'll give it a shot, but applying and running a large document with this 1 liner will show that the idle CPU utilization does go to 0.

text: Patch Set 5:vmiklos: I looked up how to do an undo block and added it to Writer.  Draw already does the replacement in a single step, so I didn't modify that section.vmiklos: DelLeft is a VERY heavy function call.  When I run it against a 256 length notation string I can watch the cursor step backwards.  Under normal conditions it can't be seen.  I'll just leave it since the AltX feature will rarely be used - unless you have a recommendation.erAck: nitpicks adjusted.  However, there doesn't seem to be much point in implementing this feature if it isn't tied to Alt-X.  A user can always remap to a different accelerator key.
Text: Patch Set 5:vmiklos: I looked up how to do an undo block and added it to Writer. text: Patch Set 2:Replacing module-local debug functionality with sal one is always a good thing. But I think the commit message is a bit misleading; --enable-verbose is about the verbosity of the _build_ process, while the VERBOSE thing in canvas sounds like the _runtime_ logging verbosity, or did I miss something?
Text: Patch Set 2:Replacing module-local debug functionality with sal one is always a good thing. But I think the commit message is a bit misleading; --enable-verbose is about the verbosity of the _build_ process, while the VERBOSE thing in canvas sounds like the _runtime_ logging verbosity, or did I miss something?

text: Patch Set 2:Oh, I see, actually canvas indeed uses VERBOSE to influence runtime behavior, scary. :-)Please before you would kill --enable-verbose, talk to Linux packagers, I think some of them do use that switch, e.g. to check that their custom build flags got into the compiler commandline.
Text: Patch Set 2:Oh, I see, actually canvas indeed uses VERBOSE to influence runtime behavior, scary. :-)Please before you would kill --enable-verbose, talk to Linux packagers, I think some of them do use that switch, e.g. to check that their custom build flags got into the compiler commandline.

text: Patch Set 1:Well, this null check is harmless, of course, but the real bug is in the definition of SID_SEARCH_RESULTS_DIALOG:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sc/sdi/scalc.sdi#3282As you can see, the parentheses are empty, while they should have the boolean argument. That will make the macro recorded in the right way. Maybe it also makes sense to declare it as "NoRecord", so it won't be recorded at all.
Text: Patch Set 1:Well, this null check is harmless, of course, but the real bug is in the definition of SID_SEARCH_RESULTS_DIALOG:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sc/sdi/scalc.sdi#3282As you can see, the parentheses are empty, while they should have the boolean argument. That will make the macro recorded in the right way. Maybe it also makes sense to declare it as "NoRecord", so it won't be recorded at all.

text: Patch Set 1:> -() > +(SfxBoolItem Sel FN_PARAM_1))Several things:1. You have there two closing parentheses. I suppose that's the source of the failure you have.2. Replace "Sel" with something meaningful, like "Visible".3. The ID must be the same we're using in the source with pReqArgs->HasItem. So replace FN_PARAM_1 with SID_SEARCH_RESULTS_DIALOG. > About NoRecord, should I just add it with RecordPerSet in > sc/sdi/scalc.sdi?You should add it *instead* of RecordPerSet.
Text: Patch Set 1:> -() > +(SfxBoolItem Sel FN_PARAM_1))Several things:1. You have there two closing parentheses. I suppose that's the source of the failure you have.2. Replace "Sel" with something meaningful, like "Visible".3. The ID must be the same we're using in the source with pReqArgs->HasItem. So replace FN_PARAM_1 with SID_SEARCH_RESULTS_DIALOG. > About NoRecord, should I just add it with RecordPerSet in > sc/sdi/scalc.sdi?You should add it *instead* of RecordPerSet.

text: Patch Set 2:Eike: To see the splash + messages, the best is to clear the user profile, and then to run soffice.bin directly. text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Hi Daniel - nice patch; a few comments though - I was expecting this to be a 2x liner but ... ;-) lets see.The primary problem I think is that you replaced the HPBYTE typedef with Scanline instead of sal_uInt8 * =) which is what it should be replaced with. So - I think we need to undo that everywhere.The twain header re-defines HPBYTE for its own internal use - we shouldn't touch that I think; please drop that piece.Otherwise I think you've got it =)If you re-push a tweaked version with s/Scanline/sal_uInt8*/ in your changes - and git commit --amend locally - ie. keeping the same change-id and re-push; then it should update this commit & re-trigger a CI build.Thanks muchly :-)
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Hi Daniel - nice patch; a few comments though - I was expecting this to be a 2x liner but ... ;-) lets see.The primary problem I think is that you replaced the HPBYTE typedef with Scanline instead of sal_uInt8 * =) which is what it should be replaced with. So - I think we need to undo that everywhere.The twain header re-defines HPBYTE for its own internal use - we shouldn't touch that I think; please drop that piece.Otherwise I think you've got it =)If you re-push a tweaked version with s/Scanline/sal_uInt8*/ in your changes - and git commit --amend locally - ie. keeping the same change-id and re-push; then it should update this commit & re-trigger a CI build.Thanks muchly :-)

text: Patch Set 1:> The primary problem I think is that you replaced the HPBYTE typedef with Scanline instead of sal_uInt8*So you're saying we should replace all instances of HPBYTE and Scanline with sal_uInt8*? Or just replace all instances of HPBYTE with sal_uInt8*?Thinking about it in more detail, I personally think it makes the code clearer to replace them all with sal_uInt8*, but then again, if we're replacing Scanline and HPBYTE what about ConstScanline?>The twain header re-defines HPBYTE for its own internal use - we shouldn't touch that I think; please drop that piece.Thanks for the tip, I'll drop that.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1Thanks for looking into it. What I actually meant is to just use lib.include all the way. Right now you're iterating include paths to find all the headers there. Next you're iterating headers to get include paths back. You can just use lib.include directly, regardless whether it's a workdir path or not.Also please strip white space changes from the commit. This is indeed good to clean (and there are other places in this file as well), but it isn't related to this change. Thanks.
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1Thanks for looking into it. What I actually meant is to just use lib.include all the way. Right now you're iterating include paths to find all the headers there. Next you're iterating headers to get include paths back. You can just use lib.include directly, regardless whether it's a workdir path or not.Also please strip white space changes from the commit. This is indeed good to clean (and there are other places in this file as well), but it isn't related to this change. Thanks.
