text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Looks good.I think this needs some follow-up though. The configuration's default "Use formula syntax" doesn't match the actual default value used in INDIRECT() now. The configuration dialog probably has to check also mbHasStringRefSyntax and if not set present the "Calc A1 | Excel A1" setting selected instead.Also, there are a few places left where meStringRefAddressSyntax is set directly, e.g. sc/source/core/tool/formulaopt.cxx in ScFormulaCfg::UpdateFromProperties() that doesn't handle CONV_A1_XL_A1 and doesn't set via SetStringRefSyntax() so mbHasStringRefSyntax remains unset. Also in ScFormulaCfg::ImplCommit() CONV_A1_XL_A1 is not handled.In sc/source/filter/oox/workbookhelper.cxx in WorkbookGlobals::initialize() has aCalcConfig.meStringRefAddressSyntax = getConvention(xDocProps); where getConvention() returns CONV_OOO if the generator was not Microsoft. That looks odd and maybe should be CONV_A1_XL_A1 instead.
Text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Looks good.I think this needs some follow-up though. The configuration's default "Use formula syntax" doesn't match the actual default value used in INDIRECT() now. The configuration dialog probably has to check also mbHasStringRefSyntax and if not set present the "Calc A1 | Excel A1" setting selected instead.Also, there are a few places left where meStringRefAddressSyntax is set directly, e.g. sc/source/core/tool/formulaopt.cxx in ScFormulaCfg::UpdateFromProperties() that doesn't handle CONV_A1_XL_A1 and doesn't set via SetStringRefSyntax() so mbHasStringRefSyntax remains unset. Also in ScFormulaCfg::ImplCommit() CONV_A1_XL_A1 is not handled.In sc/source/filter/oox/workbookhelper.cxx in WorkbookGlobals::initialize() has aCalcConfig.meStringRefAddressSyntax = getConvention(xDocProps); where getConvention() returns CONV_OOO if the generator was not Microsoft. That looks odd and maybe should be CONV_A1_XL_A1 instead.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2Looks reasonable to me; I'm not aware of any stream compression in OLE2 storages, just block lists.Then again - no stream should be larger than its list of blocks in the FAT - surely - I imagine we compare those two.Either way the patch looks quite sensible =) though whether it stops our ability to read corrupted files where this data is screwed up I've no idea, IIRC we check for circularity in the block / FAT chain anyhow - but i really do forget all the details there.Thanks for the chance to review =)
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2Looks reasonable to me; I'm not aware of any stream compression in OLE2 storages, just block lists.Then again - no stream should be larger than its list of blocks in the FAT - surely - I imagine we compare those two.Either way the patch looks quite sensible =) though whether it stops our ability to read corrupted files where this data is screwed up I've no idea, IIRC we check for circularity in the block / FAT chain anyhow - but i really do forget all the details there.Thanks for the chance to review =)

text: Patch Set 1:The point of the change is that without this, part switching in Calc does not work, as Calc does not invalidate everything after a part switch (unlike Impress), and we suppose the right fix for this is to let the clients throw away the tiles, rather than letting Calc send out invalidations, too.
Text: Patch Set 1:The point of the change is that without this, part switching in Calc does not work, as Calc does not invalidate everything after a part switch (unlike Impress), and we suppose the right fix for this is to let the clients throw away the tiles, rather than letting Calc send out invalidations, too.

text: Patch Set 2:Address reuse shouldn't be a problem any more than with plain Python objects - as long as the PyUNO object exists as a dict key or set entry, it hasn't been destroyed, so the intended use case is covered. The hash code isn't itself a unique identifier, it must be used together with an object equality check through __cmp__() (PyUNO_cmp)Neither is the hash supposed in this instance to be a guarantee of content equality. If what the UNO object points to changes somehow, in content or by a (more) remote bridge doing something odd, that's still irrelevant - this is exactly comparable to the hashing behaviour of ordinary user created Python objects: by default, __hash__ is id(object) (... which is really its memory address), and an object is equal exactly and only to itselfMore specifically, the requirements are:- The hash value must not change over the lifetime of the object (true, the address of the wrapped UNO object can't change, and the same wrapped object is reused even if pulled across the bridge several times)- Hashable objects which compare equal must have the same hash value (true, PyUNO objects only compare equal if they have the same wrapped object)
Text: Patch Set 2:Address reuse shouldn't be a problem any more than with plain Python objects - as long as the PyUNO object exists as a dict key or set entry, it hasn't been destroyed, so the intended use case is covered. The hash code isn't itself a unique identifier, it must be used together with an object equality check through __cmp__() (PyUNO_cmp)Neither is the hash supposed in this instance to be a guarantee of content equality. If what the UNO object points to changes somehow, in content or by a (more) remote bridge doing something odd, that's still irrelevant - this is exactly comparable to the hashing behaviour of ordinary user created Python objects: by default, __hash__ is id(object) (... which is really its memory address), and an object is equal exactly and only to itselfMore specifically, the requirements are:- The hash value must not change over the lifetime of the object (true, the address of the wrapped UNO object can't change, and the same wrapped object is reused even if pulled across the bridge several times)- Hashable objects which compare equal must have the same hash value (true, PyUNO objects only compare equal if they have the same wrapped object)

text: Patch Set 1:hmm... rtlRandomPool definitely needs to use some real entropy instead of the ridiculous __rtl_random_initPool()but i'm not sure if reading from /dev/urandom in __rtl_random_initPool is a good idea - how much do we read from there? where is this rtlRandomPool used? will that drain the kernel's entropy pool (so that other process reading /dev/random block)? would it be better to only initialize the pool from /dev/urandom and then use the old MD5 based generator from there?
Text: Patch Set 1:hmm... rtlRandomPool definitely needs to use some real entropy instead of the ridiculous __rtl_random_initPool()but i'm not sure if reading from /dev/urandom in __rtl_random_initPool is a good idea - how much do we read from there? where is this rtlRandomPool used? will that drain the kernel's entropy pool (so that other process reading /dev/random block)? would it be better to only initialize the pool from /dev/urandom and then use the old MD5 based generator from there?

text: Patch Set 1:/dev/urandom is non blocking and is already 'PRNG'There is 2 uses case:either we want just 'random-like enough' numbersand then we could just use c1++ mt19937, primed with /dev/urandomor we need crypto-level random data, and we need /dev/urandom | rand_s straight. trying to re-implement a second layer of CSPRNG would simply, at best do what urandom does, with the additional risk of fuck-upsince rtlRandomPool does not distinguish both case afaikit would be safer to take the second approachNote using /dev/urandom does not make /dev/random block more afaik
Text: Patch Set 1:/dev/urandom is non blocking and is already 'PRNG'There is 2 uses case:either we want just 'random-like enough' numbersand then we could just use c1++ mt19937, primed with /dev/urandomor we need crypto-level random data, and we need /dev/urandom | rand_s straight. trying to re-implement a second layer of CSPRNG would simply, at best do what urandom does, with the additional risk of fuck-upsince rtlRandomPool does not distinguish both case afaikit would be safer to take the second approachNote using /dev/urandom does not make /dev/random block more afaik

text: Patch Set 1:AFAIK on Linux /dev/urandom will deplete the entropy pool while entropy is available and fall back to PRNG if no entropy left, while /dev/random uses entropy pool only - so you can use urandom to DOS random.e.g. "man urandom" says      The kernel random-number generator  is  designed  to  produce  a  small       amount  of  high-quality  seed material to seed a cryptographic pseudo-       random number generator (CPRNG).  It  is  designed  for  security,  not       speed, and is poorly suited to generating large amounts of random data.       Users should be very economical in the amount  of  seed  material  that       they  read  from  /dev/urandom (and /dev/random); unnecessarily reading       large quantities of data from this device will have a  negative  impact       on other users of the device.*however* it may well be that the problem is not with the implementation of rtlRandomPool but with its *usage*.what you say about using it only for cryptographic purpose and using std::random for everything else makes a lot of sense and we shouldn't generate too much actually cryptographic data.problem is, during OOo times the rtlRandomPool was basically the only thing available that was better than rand() so it was used for a lot of things that have no need for CSPRNG but would be happy with Mersennetwister.but i guess we can merge this and see what happens.hmmm there is a file to get the available entropy:/proc/sys/kernel/random/entropy_availwonder what happens if you add this patch and do a "make check" :)
Text: Patch Set 1:AFAIK on Linux /dev/urandom will deplete the entropy pool while entropy is available and fall back to PRNG if no entropy left, while /dev/random uses entropy pool only - so you can use urandom to DOS random.e.g. "man urandom" says      The kernel random-number generator  is  designed  to  produce  a  small       amount  of  high-quality  seed material to seed a cryptographic pseudo-       random number generator (CPRNG).  It  is  designed  for  security,  not       speed, and is poorly suited to generating large amounts of random data.       Users should be very economical in the amount  of  seed  material  that       they  read  from  /dev/urandom (and /dev/random); unnecessarily reading       large quantities of data from this device will have a  negative  impact       on other users of the device.*however* it may well be that the problem is not with the implementation of rtlRandomPool but with its *usage*.what you say about using it only for cryptographic purpose and using std::random for everything else makes a lot of sense and we shouldn't generate too much actually cryptographic data.problem is, during OOo times the rtlRandomPool was basically the only thing available that was better than rand() so it was used for a lot of things that have no need for CSPRNG but would be happy with Mersennetwister.but i guess we can merge this and see what happens.hmmm there is a file to get the available entropy:/proc/sys/kernel/random/entropy_availwonder what happens if you add this patch and do a "make check" :)

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1the only MIME types that are valid without an "x-" prefix are the ones registered with IANA:http://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtmlneither "image/eps" nor "image/bmp" are on that list.it doesn't really matter much if some random website lists these, as whoever wrote that could be completely clueless, or worse, a PHP programmer.filter/source/config/fragments/types has some MediaType properties that arguably should be considered as some sort of precedent; in any case we should be consistent across the codebase.Regina is mostly right, except that we historically use "image/x-eps" for EPS; it's arguable whether EPS is the "same" format as PostScript, since it has an additional header and restrictions on the content (for an image, only one page is allowed, and it needs to have a bounding box).for WMF we currently use "image/x-wmf" - not sure which one is the "right" one, none of them is registered with IANA.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1the only MIME types that are valid without an "x-" prefix are the ones registered with IANA:http://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtmlneither "image/eps" nor "image/bmp" are on that list.it doesn't really matter much if some random website lists these, as whoever wrote that could be completely clueless, or worse, a PHP programmer.filter/source/config/fragments/types has some MediaType properties that arguably should be considered as some sort of precedent; in any case we should be consistent across the codebase.Regina is mostly right, except that we historically use "image/x-eps" for EPS; it's arguable whether EPS is the "same" format as PostScript, since it has an additional header and restrictions on the content (for an image, only one page is allowed, and it needs to have a bounding box).for WMF we currently use "image/x-wmf" - not sure which one is the "right" one, none of them is registered with IANA.

text: Patch Set 1:I know that previous argumentation was so weak for the questions, basing on not official websites.I agree some of them are not on the IANA list, but we must be consistent across the codebase. I've found the mime types used in the filter OOXML (oox/source/export/drawingml.cxx, function:  DrawingML::WriteImage, line 818). This function uses the same mime type than my proposal for ODF, except for ".eps".....        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_GIF:            sMediaType = "image/gif";            pExtension = ".gif";            break;        // #i15508# added BMP type for better exports        // export not yet active, so adding for reference (not checked)        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_BMP:            sMediaType = "image/bmp";            pExtension = ".bmp";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_JPG:            sMediaType = "image/jpeg";            pExtension = ".jpeg";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_PNG:            sMediaType = "image/png";            pExtension = ".png";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_TIF:            sMediaType = "image/tif";            pExtension = ".tif";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_WMF:            sMediaType = "image/x-wmf";            pExtension = ".wmf";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_MET:            sMediaType = "image/x-met";            pExtension = ".met";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_PCT:            sMediaType = "image/x-pict";            pExtension = ".pct";....

I've found the mime types used in the filter OOXML (oox/source/export/drawingml.cxx, function:  DrawingML::WriteImage, line 818). This function uses the same mime type than my proposal for ODF, except for ".eps".....        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_GIF:            sMediaType = "image/gif";            pExtension = ".gif";            break;        // #i15508# added BMP type for better exports        // export not yet active, so adding for reference (not checked)        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_BMP:            sMediaType = "image/bmp";            pExtension = ".bmp";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_JPG:            sMediaType = "image/jpeg";            pExtension = ".jpeg";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_PNG:            sMediaType = "image/png";            pExtension = ".png";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_TIF:            sMediaType = "image/tif";            pExtension = ".tif";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_WMF:            sMediaType = "image/x-wmf";            pExtension = ".wmf";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_MET:            sMediaType = "image/x-met";            pExtension = ".met";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_PCT:            sMediaType = "image/x-pict";            pExtension = ".pct";....

text: Patch Set 1:The first problem is that it returnsRectangle(aRect.x, aRect.y, aRect.width, aRect.height)when Rectangle takes right and botton not width and height for its two last args so this is the wrong Rectangle anyway except for the monitor 0 case where its close enough.The other problem is that these tooltips are positioned by ImplSetHelpWindowPos in vcl/source/app/help.cxx taking into account the Rectangle returned by GetDesktopRectPixel to ensure the tooltip is put inside the DesktopRectangle. That just calls this directly. In this GetDesktopRectPixel the help window hasn't been positioned yet, so it is still on monitor 0, so you always get monitor 0 dimensions not 1. One could query the parent window here, which would also make it work a lot of the time when the tooltip should be displayed on the monitor that most of the parent is on, but that'll fail in the case that you display a tooltip on a minority part of a window that's over two monitors.But anyway I guess the bottom line is that this method is apparently expected to return the usable rectangle of the overall desktop rather than of the individual monitor the window is on
Text: Patch Set 1:The first problem is that it returnsRectangle(aRect.x, aRect.y, aRect.width, aRect.height)when Rectangle takes right and botton not width and height for its two last args so this is the wrong Rectangle anyway except for the monitor 0 case where its close enough.The other problem is that these tooltips are positioned by ImplSetHelpWindowPos in vcl/source/app/help.cxx taking into account the Rectangle returned by GetDesktopRectPixel to ensure the tooltip is put inside the DesktopRectangle. That just calls this directly. In this GetDesktopRectPixel the help window hasn't been positioned yet, so it is still on monitor 0, so you always get monitor 0 dimensions not 1. One could query the parent window here, which would also make it work a lot of the time when the tooltip should be displayed on the monitor that most of the parent is on, but that'll fail in the case that you display a tooltip on a minority part of a window that's over two monitors.But anyway I guess the bottom line is that this method is apparently expected to return the usable rectangle of the overall desktop rather than of the individual monitor the window is on

text: Patch Set 1:This patch needs a careful review by someone who understands how redlines and SPRMs work.  I don't understand this code - I just figured out something that fixed my problem and tried to make it as targeted as possible.  I'm not really sure of the implications - it just didn't seem to do anything bad to my sample document....  The biggest problem is that this is called at the end of EVERY cell, regardless of whether it is touching a redline. I couldn't figure out how to recognize when that occurs.	What I think is happening is that the WriteCR attribute from the PREVIOUS cell is being attached to the redline group and merged together.   However, although the IncludeEndOfParaCRInRedlineProperties() method seems to try to handle these things, it isn't catching this case.	How to write a automated compile testcase for this fix is beyond me since I don't understand what is happening deep in the code, and I can only see the problem when looking at the document in Word.  Several manual testcases are attached to the bug report.
Text: How to write a automated compile testcase for this fix is beyond me since I don't understand what is happening deep in the code, and I can only see the problem when looking at the document in Word.  Several manual testcases are attached to the bug report."

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)Apart from the ascii-alnum problem it would also be nice if inside of quoted literal strings no tooltip was displayed, e.g.  =LEN("bet  displays the tip for BETA.DIST, but you can do that as a follow-up commit if you want.Regarding the =ABS(2) behaviour, the old behaviour wasn't correct either because it displayed the below-tip with arguments (though without argument position indicator) while the cursor was on the function name, contrary to all other cases where the parameter-tip is displayed only when the cursor is actually within the function's parentheses.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)Apart from the ascii-alnum problem it would also be nice if inside of quoted literal strings no tooltip was displayed, e.g.  =LEN("bet  displays the tip for BETA.DIST, but you can do that as a follow-up commit if you want.Regarding the =ABS(2) behaviour, the old behaviour wasn't correct either because it displayed the below-tip with arguments (though without argument position indicator) while the cursor was on the function name, contrary to all other cases where the parameter-tip is displayed only when the cursor is actually within the function's parentheses.

text: Patch Set 3:Line 789 in layout.hxx is required to make sure that controls on tab pages receive the relevant command messages to inform them that the alt key has been pressed. I believe that line needs to list all "container" objects; i.e. ones which can hold other objects; the omission of tab controls from it seemed wrong to me.

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1Don't merge this yet (and I mean it) ...now the two scenarios from commit msg work, but a regression has crept in:* go to Writer -> Format -> Page * select page format and orientation, if possible a different one than the default in your env. * File -> Print -> Properties now shows those values (and not the default values from the printer)* Change orientation to the opposite one (landscape if you have portrait, portrait if you have landscape), save* Revisit Properties * Howl, because the page orientation doesn't stick and it returns back to whatever is in the document
Text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1Don't merge this yet (and I mean it) ...now the two scenarios from commit msg work, but a regression has crept in:* go to Writer -> Format -> Page * select page format and orientation, if possible a different one than the default in your env. * File -> Print -> Properties now shows those values (and not the default values from the printer)* Change orientation to the opposite one (landscape if you have portrait, portrait if you have landscape), save* Revisit Properties * Howl, because the page orientation doesn't stick and it returns back to whatever is in the document

text: Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1OK - false alarm.  Sorry - I'm making false connections in my mind about what the old code actually did, and all of the situations it messed up.  The old code DID only handle increasing sequential links - just sometimes it ran across the bigger one first, and then matched with the first higher/lower one that it came across.  It was MY example that actually was numbered in the reverse order and so wouldn't have worked on the old logic.  OK - shouldn't be a regression after-all.  And your test document loaded/looked fine.
Text: Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1OK - false alarm.  Sorry - I'm making false connections in my mind about what the old code actually did, and all of the situations it messed up.  The old code DID only handle increasing sequential links - just sometimes it ran across the bigger one first, and then matched with the first higher/lower one that it came across.  It was MY example that actually was numbered in the reverse order and so wouldn't have worked on the old logic.  OK - shouldn't be a regression after-all.  And your test document loaded/looked fine.

text: Patch Set 6:OK - false alarm.  Sorry - I'm making false connections in my mind about what the old code actually did, and all of the situations it messed up.  The old code DID only handle increasing sequential links - just sometimes it ran across the bigger sequence first, and then reversed the logic to matched with the lower one.  It was MY example doc (albeit vml) that actually was numbered in the reverse order and so wouldn't have worked on the old logic. And your test document loaded/looked fine.  So in my mind I'm combining all that plus some things I saw (can't remember all where) about mso-layout-flow-alt indicating a reverse sequence - where the highest number starts the chain instead of ends the chain, but although this alt-flow is put in the grabbag, it is never used.  In the end the lack of reverse chaining is still a (potentially) missing feature, not a regression.
Text: Patch Set 6:OK - false alarm.  Sorry - I'm making false connections in my mind about what the old code actually did, and all of the situations it messed up.  The old code DID only handle increasing sequential links - just sometimes it ran across the bigger sequence first, and then reversed the logic to matched with the lower one.  It was MY example doc (albeit vml) that actually was numbered in the reverse order and so wouldn't have worked on the old logic. And your test document loaded/looked fine.  So in my mind I'm combining all that plus some things I saw (can't remember all where) about mso-layout-flow-alt indicating a reverse sequence - where the highest number starts the chain instead of ends the chain, but although this alt-flow is put in the grabbag, it is never used.  In the end the lack of reverse chaining is still a (potentially) missing feature, not a regression.

text: Patch Set 1:I'm assuming that right to left text is also zero based and logically positions the cursor in the same way as left to right text. text: Patch Set 7:(1 comment)More thoughts:* Do not introduce a function returning std::vector into the stable URE API.  Things like libstdc++'s __cxx11 namespace show that std entities /do/ change in ways that would make it unnecessarily complicated for us to maintain backwards compatibility in the URE API.* That implies that getElementsAsVector should be #ifdef LIBO_INTERNAL_ONLY (and in a PRIVATE_* section in gcc3.map).* That, however, implies that external code needs to continue to call getElements, which now incurs a performance impact (as it always needs to call the equivalent of comphelper::containerToSequence).  Not sure the (assumed?) performance improvements of switching from Sequence to vector justify that (assumed) performance degradation.
Text: Patch Set 7:(1 comment)More thoughts:* Do not introduce a function returning std::vector into the stable URE API.  Things like libstdc++'s __cxx11 namespace show that std entities /do/ change in ways that would make it unnecessarily complicated for us to maintain backwards compatibility in the URE API.* That implies that getElementsAsVector should be #ifdef LIBO_INTERNAL_ONLY (and in a PRIVATE_* section in gcc3.map).* That, however, implies that external code needs to continue to call getElements, which now incurs a performance impact (as it always needs to call the equivalent of comphelper::containerToSequence).  Not sure the (assumed?) performance improvements of switching from Sequence to vector justify that (assumed) performance degradation.

text: Patch Set 3:> I'd say it is intentional. Child nodes should follow the setting of their parent node.OK.> I think you need to capture bIsPhantom, not this.Let me clarify your suggestion.Because specifying a member variable in lambda-capture is not allowed,I think possible working expressions are:bool b = bIsPhantom;ForEachNonNull(this, [&b](SmNode *pNode){pNode->SetPhantom(b);});or:ForEachNonNull(this, [this](SmNode *pNode){pNode->SetPhantom(bIsPhantom);});or:ForEachNonNull(this, [&](SmNode *pNode){pNode->SetPhantom(bIsPhantom);});or:ForEachNonNull(this, [=](SmNode *pNode){pNode->SetPhantom(bIsPhantom);});or else?But all the last 3 cases are caputuring "this" either by copy or by referencein this case, in my understanding of C++11.
Text: Patch Set 3:> I'd say it is intentional. Child nodes should follow the setting of their parent node.OK.> I think you need to capture bIsPhantom, not this.Let me clarify your suggestion.Because specifying a member variable in lambda-capture is not allowed,I think possible working expressions are:bool b = bIsPhantom;ForEachNonNull(this, [&b](SmNode *pNode){pNode->SetPhantom(b);});or:ForEachNonNull(this, [this](SmNode *pNode){pNode->SetPhantom(bIsPhantom);});or:ForEachNonNull(this, [&](SmNode *pNode){pNode->SetPhantom(bIsPhantom);});or:ForEachNonNull(this, [=](SmNode *pNode){pNode->SetPhantom(bIsPhantom);});or else?But all the last 3 cases are caputuring "this" either by copy or by referencein this case, in my understanding of C++11.

text: Patch Set 3:> Because specifying a member variable in lambda-capture is not allowed, I think possible working expressions are:> bool b = bIsPhantom; ForEachNonNull(this, [&b](SmNode *pNode){pNode->SetPhantom(b);});All right, I missed that limitation. So I think we should use this variant to be on the safe side. Just a nitpick: it is pointless to capture a bool (or any other integral type) by a reference.
Text: Patch Set 3:> Because specifying a member variable in lambda-capture is not allowed, I think possible working expressions are:> bool b = bIsPhantom; ForEachNonNull(this, [&b](SmNode *pNode){pNode->SetPhantom(b);});All right, I missed that limitation. So I think we should use this variant to be on the safe side. Just a nitpick: it is pointless to capture a bool (or any other integral type) by a reference.

text: Patch Set 1:Some things I'm not so sure about in this patch* Getting mColor member variable from parent class (SvxColorItem::GetValue,::SetValue) all the time is maybe a bad (clumsy) style. Is it better to make it protected in SvxColorItem? Or introduce a private member variable also in SvxBackgroundColorItem?* I reused MID_GRAPHIC_TRANSPARENT as member ID, although it strictly speaking belongs to SvxBrushItem (and text background colour doesn't use that one). Should I add a new member ID specific to SvxBackgroundColorItem to reduce possible confusion?
Text: Patch Set 1:Some things I'm not so sure about in this patch* Getting mColor member variable from parent class (SvxColorItem::GetValue,::SetValue) all the time is maybe a bad (clumsy) style. Is it better to make it protected in SvxColorItem? Or introduce a private member variable also in SvxBackgroundColorItem?* I reused MID_GRAPHIC_TRANSPARENT as member ID, although it strictly speaking belongs to SvxBrushItem (and text background colour doesn't use that one). Should I add a new member ID specific to SvxBackgroundColorItem to reduce possible confusion?

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1Hmm, I think unfortunately this patch is not correct. The bug is about "if there is no \par at the end of the doc, then no newline should be inserted when the paste is finished". But that means if there *is* a \par at the end of the file, then we still need a newline. The bug claims that this is a regression, as it was OK in 3.3; and that's what 3.3 did.I'll check the writerfilter part, I can easily imagine that your changes are mostly OK, it's just that you mirrored the ODT import code, which always adds an empty paragraph at the end of the import result in case of pasting, and writerfilter has to do the same if we want the correct end result.
Text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1Hmm, I think unfortunately this patch is not correct. The bug is about "if there is no \par at the end of the doc, then no newline should be inserted when the paste is finished". But that means if there *is* a \par at the end of the file, then we still need a newline. The bug claims that this is a regression, as it was OK in 3.3; and that's what 3.3 did.I'll check the writerfilter part, I can easily imagine that your changes are mostly OK, it's just that you mirrored the ODT import code, which always adds an empty paragraph at the end of the import result in case of pasting, and writerfilter has to do the same if we want the correct end result.

text: Patch Set 3:Right, hold on. :-) I have some writerfilter changes that will make the uiwriter hunk unnecessary, then the rest of the change looks OK.
Text: Patch Set 3:Right, hold on. :-) I have some writerfilter changes that will make the uiwriter hunk unnecessary, then the rest of the change looks OK.

text: Patch Set 3:> The bug is > about "if there is no \par at the end of the doc, then no newline > should be inserted when the paste is finished". But that means if > there *is* a \par at the end of the file, then we still need a > newline.No. You may just check that LO does add \par at the end of any text copied to clipboard (its RTF part). Then, if You paste it to, say,MSWord or Write for Windows, You don't have newline.The same is true for RTF files. You may create a file with the samecontents that You used in unit test, and see that LO/OOo/AOO, and Write/MSWord doesn't add newline in the end. But if You add another\par (with just one space or CRLF) before last one, You'll havethat newline.While RTF spec does say about \par as special character, it isdeclared "End of paragraph", not "newline", as described in "SpecialCharacters".RTF spec is not quite consistent about it: "Paragraph Test" saysthat "\par" is "New paragraph". But the <textpar> says that \par must be followed by <para>, that includes at least one character."Mathematics" says similar: "A math paragraph may be part of a text paragraph (text ending in a \par and either starting a document or following a \par)." > The bug claims that this is a regression, as it was OK in > 3.3; and that's what 3.3 did.No; it was marked as "Inherited from OOo" in Oct 2013 > I'll check the writerfilter part, I can easily imagine that your > changes are mostly OK, it's just that you mirrored the ODT import > code, which always adds an empty paragraph at the end of the import > result in case of pasting, and writerfilter has to do the same if > we want the correct end result.Well, however you may change the copying to buffer part, you should not treat ending single \par as newline to be consistent with reference implementations; so the old unit test is still incorrect.
Text: Patch Set 3:> The bug is > about "if there is no \par at the end of the doc, then no newline > should be inserted when the paste is finished". But that means if > there *is* a \par at the end of the file, then we still need a > newline.No. You may just check that LO does add \par at the end of any text copied to clipboard (its RTF part). Then, if You paste it to, say,MSWord or Write for Windows, You don't have newline.The same is true for RTF files. You may create a file with the samecontents that You used in unit test, and see that LO/OOo/AOO, and Write/MSWord doesn't add newline in the end. But if You add another\par (with just one space or CRLF) before last one, You'll havethat newline.While RTF spec does say about \par as special character, it isdeclared "End of paragraph", not "newline", as described in "SpecialCharacters".RTF spec is not quite consistent about it: "Paragraph Test" saysthat "\par" is "New paragraph". But the <textpar> says that \par must be followed by <para>, that includes at least one character."Mathematics" says similar: "A math paragraph may be part of a text paragraph (text ending in a \par and either starting a document or following a \par)." > The bug claims that this is a regression, as it was OK in > 3.3; and that's what 3.3 did.No; it was marked as "Inherited from OOo" in Oct 2013 > I'll check the writerfilter part, I can easily imagine that your > changes are mostly OK, it's just that you mirrored the ODT import > code, which always adds an empty paragraph at the end of the import > result in case of pasting, and writerfilter has to do the same if > we want the correct end result.Well, however you may change the copying to buffer part, you should not treat ending single \par as newline to be consistent with reference implementations; so the old unit test is still incorrect.

text: Patch Set 3:Hi,If that's OK for you, I will tweak writerfilter to emit different doc model for documents having a final \par or not, then merge your patch to properly remove the second fake node.If you would like to have RTF copy&paste not create a newline when the paste is from LO, I would rather tweak the RTF export to do that: so that what we export is in what e.g. Wordpad does.I think tweaking our import to work around what can be improved on the export side is suboptimal. :-)And yes, sorry about the mess, bug 90260 and 70318 is really similar, but only one is marked as a regression, I looked into fixing the regression one, you did the other -- I wish these linked somehow together before we started fixing them. ;-)Thanks,Miklos
Text: Patch Set 3:Hi,If that's OK for you, I will tweak writerfilter to emit different doc model for documents having a final \par or not, then merge your patch to properly remove the second fake node.If you would like to have RTF copy&paste not create a newline when the paste is from LO, I would rather tweak the RTF export to do that: so that what we export is in what e.g. Wordpad does.I think tweaking our import to work around what can be improved on the export side is suboptimal. :-)And yes, sorry about the mess, bug 90260 and 70318 is really similar, but only one is marked as a regression, I looked into fixing the regression one, you did the other -- I wish these linked somehow together before we started fixing them. ;-)Thanks,Miklos

text: Patch Set 2:In Patch Set 1 I added a check for that case. It fixes the abovementioned bug.I have some concerns here:1. Is it safe to avoid formatting at all in this specific case?2. Is there a better way to do this? like a flag saying that thetext is invisible due to too small space? Ordinary Format() doesn'thang in this case; but I couldn't understand its logic3. Isn't it better to change SwTxtFormatter::FormatLine to include check for that, and in that case just modify its SwTxtFormatInfo to return true from IsStop()? In feels more "correct", but may have wider consequencies.
Text: Patch Set 2:In Patch Set 1 I added a check for that case. It fixes the abovementioned bug.I have some concerns here:1. Is it safe to avoid formatting at all in this specific case?2. Is there a better way to do this? like a flag saying that thetext is invisible due to too small space? Ordinary Format() doesn'thang in this case; but I couldn't understand its logic3. Isn't it better to change SwTxtFormatter::FormatLine to include check for that, and in that case just modify its SwTxtFormatInfo to return true from IsStop()? In feels more "correct", but may have wider consequencies.

text: Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2so.. as I mentioned otherwise, this has an impact onCharacters.../Position/Spacing/Expended 1.0ptWith this patch, a expended spacing of 1pt has no more effect at all, since the adjustment get gobbled in the +/-1pt filter.otoh that is a pretty exotic feature, best suited for full-blow publishing tool, that is already broken in many ways.. (like under/over line by words not adjusting accordingly)So in balance.. yeah I'd agree that for most people the trade of is in favor of this patch.

text: Patch Set 4:@Kohei : After textdetect filter call, in the call to SfxMedium::GetMedium_Impl()both pImp->xStream and pImp->xInputStream are populated. At line number 2340, in this method, pImp->m_pInstream is populated from pImp->xStream rather than pImp->xInputStream due to the order of if-else statements. I think that pImp->xStream is uncompressed as I did not set MediaDescriptor::PROP_STREAM property in media descriptor in the detect code.The csv import dialog uses the xInputStream directly where as the ScDocShell::ConvertFrom() uses SvStream from SfxMedium::GetInStream()I tried to reverse the order of if-else statement in SfxMedium::GetMedium_Impl() (starting at line number 2340). But soon realized that it is not correct as1) it breaks some unit tests (import of pdf files failed)2) Though the spreadsheet now shows uncompressed data, the csv import dialog shows empty data !. I thought it was due to file stream position set to the end, but seeking the pImp->xInputStream to the beginning did not solve that.So I reverted this change and instead tried assigning to both MediaDescriptor::PROP_STREAM and MediaDescriptor::PROP_INPUTSTREAM properties in the textdetect filter code as follows :uno::Reference<io::XStream> xStreamDecompressed(new utl::OStreamWrapper(*pDecompressedStream));                                                                                                    aMediaDesc[MediaDescriptor::PROP_STREAM()] <<= xStreamDecompressed;                                                                                                                                aMediaDesc[MediaDescriptor::PROP_INPUTSTREAM()] <<= xStreamDecompressed->getInputStream();This change seems to work, no unit test failed, and uncompressed data in both spreadsheet and csv import dialog. I will push this patch to gerrit shortly.
Text: Patch Set 4:@Kohei : After textdetect filter call, in the call to SfxMedium::GetMedium_Impl()both pImp->xStream and pImp->xInputStream are populated. At line number 2340, in this method, pImp->m_pInstream is populated from pImp->xStream rather than pImp->xInputStream due to the order of if-else statements. I think that pImp->xStream is uncompressed as I did not set MediaDescriptor::PROP_STREAM property in media descriptor in the detect code.The csv import dialog uses the xInputStream directly where as the ScDocShell::ConvertFrom() uses SvStream from SfxMedium::GetInStream()I tried to reverse the order of if-else statement in SfxMedium::GetMedium_Impl() (starting at line number 2340). But soon realized that it is not correct as1) it breaks some unit tests (import of pdf files failed)2) Though the spreadsheet now shows uncompressed data, the csv import dialog shows empty data !. I thought it was due to file stream position set to the end, but seeking the pImp->xInputStream to the beginning did not solve that.So I reverted this change and instead tried assigning to both MediaDescriptor::PROP_STREAM and MediaDescriptor::PROP_INPUTSTREAM properties in the textdetect filter code as follows :uno::Reference<io::XStream> xStreamDecompressed(new utl::OStreamWrapper(*pDecompressedStream));                                                                                                    aMediaDesc[MediaDescriptor::PROP_STREAM()] <<= xStreamDecompressed;                                                                                                                                aMediaDesc[MediaDescriptor::PROP_INPUTSTREAM()] <<= xStreamDecompressed->getInputStream();This change seems to work, no unit test failed, and uncompressed data in both spreadsheet and csv import dialog. I will push this patch to gerrit shortly.

text: Patch Set 8:@Kohei :1) While pursuing your second method, I found that the impl_detectTypeAndFilter() [1] is not getting called while clicking "Edit Document" button on the read-only document, hence the automatic decompression is skipped and it fills the spreadsheet with compressed raw data.[1] http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/framework/source/loadenv/loadenv.cxx#365Should I try to make it call impl_detectTypeAndFilter() by setting some flag in mediadescriptor during the readonly load phase in textdetect filter detect code ?But I feel that it is very inefficient to retry all filter detect code again.Unfortunately I could not find the place where X[Input]*Stream objects are recreatedduring the reload.2) Another thing I tried is instead of setting READONLY flag in text filter detect function, I set PROP_ASTEMPLATE in media descriptor to true, and then it loads a new untitled document with the uncompressed content. The issue here is that the document title is "Untitled 1" though the sheet name is intact.3) I also tried this : Without setting READONLY flag, I modified the PROP_URL property of media descriptor in text filter detect function within gzip detection block as : OUString aURL = aMediaDesc.getUnpackedValueOrDefault(MediaDescriptor::PROP_URL(), OUString() );                                                                                                    sal_Int32 nIdx = aURL.lastIndexOf(".gz");                                                                                                                                                          if (nIdx != -1)                                                                                                                                                                                      aMediaDesc[MediaDescriptor::PROP_URL()] <<= aURL.replaceFirst(".gz", "", &nIdx);Now Calc loads up the uncompressed data and when I modify the document and hit save, it saves to *.csv file rather than to *.csv.gz
Text: Patch Set 8:@Kohei :1) While pursuing your second method, I found that the impl_detectTypeAndFilter() [1] is not getting called while clicking "Edit Document" button on the read-only document, hence the automatic decompression is skipped and it fills the spreadsheet with compressed raw data.[1] http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/framework/source/loadenv/loadenv.cxx#365Should I try to make it call impl_detectTypeAndFilter() by setting some flag in mediadescriptor during the readonly load phase in textdetect filter detect code ?But I feel that it is very inefficient to retry all filter detect code again.Unfortunately I could not find the place where X[Input]*Stream objects are recreatedduring the reload.2) Another thing I tried is instead of setting READONLY flag in text filter detect function, I set PROP_ASTEMPLATE in media descriptor to true, and then it loads a new untitled document with the uncompressed content. The issue here is that the document title is "Untitled 1" though the sheet name is intact.3) I also tried this : Without setting READONLY flag, I modified the PROP_URL property of media descriptor in text filter detect function within gzip detection block as : OUString aURL = aMediaDesc.getUnpackedValueOrDefault(MediaDescriptor::PROP_URL(), OUString() );                                                                                                    sal_Int32 nIdx = aURL.lastIndexOf(".gz");                                                                                                                                                          if (nIdx != -1)                                                                                                                                                                                      aMediaDesc[MediaDescriptor::PROP_URL()] <<= aURL.replaceFirst(".gz", "", &nIdx);Now Calc loads up the uncompressed data and when I modify the document and hit save, it saves to *.csv file rather than to *.csv.gz

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1ok dtardon already reviewed it, please fix the problems identified... iirc an earlier patch from you had the SwTxtNode::GetAttr() call in it to retrieve the item?to fix your patch, first use "git checkout filename HEAD~" to restore the unnecessarily changed files.then "git commit --amend" to modify your patch with the changes.  important: do not edit the Change-Id in the commit message.maybe you need to "git add" the files, i forgot, check with "git show" that the unnecessary changes are gone and if not use "git add" and amend again.then submit the patch to gerrit again, gerrit will recognize the Change-Id and update this here with a new revision.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1ok dtardon already reviewed it, please fix the problems identified... iirc an earlier patch from you had the SwTxtNode::GetAttr() call in it to retrieve the item?to fix your patch, first use "git checkout filename HEAD~" to restore the unnecessarily changed files.then "git commit --amend" to modify your patch with the changes.  important: do not edit the Change-Id in the commit message.maybe you need to "git add" the files, i forgot, check with "git show" that the unnecessary changes are gone and if not use "git add" and amend again.then submit the patch to gerrit again, gerrit will recognize the Change-Id and update this here with a new revision.

text: Patch Set 1:(All mentioned C++ functions are member of SCInterpreter)Creating a slightly different version of GetNumberSequenceArray() will make functions like WORKDAY.INTL and NETWORKDAYS.INTL to work with inline text arrays representing dates.But it will prevent e.g. function MEDIAN to work with inline text arrays representing dates, which is the case with Excel.That's why I used one version of GetNumberSequenceArray(). I wanted to make all functions using GetSortArray() and GetNumberSequenceArray() to accept inline text arrays representing dates. I made attachments for both tdf89872 and tdf88547 containing a bit of both types of function calls.These attachments give the same result in Excel as in Calc (with this patch set).I have not tested Excel with inline text arrays like {"1","3","4"}; my patch will accept this.IMHO the sort of patch you suggest will keep a difference between Excel and Calc and therefor will lead to a bug report sooner or later. Better discuss this now, don't you agree?
Text: Patch Set 1:(All mentioned C++ functions are member of SCInterpreter)Creating a slightly different version of GetNumberSequenceArray() will make functions like WORKDAY.INTL and NETWORKDAYS.INTL to work with inline text arrays representing dates.But it will prevent e.g. function MEDIAN to work with inline text arrays representing dates, which is the case with Excel.That's why I used one version of GetNumberSequenceArray(). I wanted to make all functions using GetSortArray() and GetNumberSequenceArray() to accept inline text arrays representing dates. I made attachments for both tdf89872 and tdf88547 containing a bit of both types of function calls.These attachments give the same result in Excel as in Calc (with this patch set).I have not tested Excel with inline text arrays like {"1","3","4"}; my patch will accept this.IMHO the sort of patch you suggest will keep a difference between Excel and Calc and therefor will lead to a bug report sooner or later. Better discuss this now, don't you agree?

text: Patch Set 2:Please note: First, bug 90447 has not been marked as "NEW" yet - only partially verified by a third party.Second, the ::End() function really should be fully re-written, but that is way beyond my current skills, and also would be a "design from scratch" effort.  The big problem is that it changes the current cursor position and so "flashes around a lot" especially when multiple tabs are involved.  Instead the function should quietly compute the cell.Third, I bundled two related items into one bug report (my bad).  This fixes the ::end function.  The ::find function does work quietly, but adds a ->Select() at the end of the function.  The select could (should?) easily be commented out, but I assume that will break some people's code or something else.  Is it worth breaking bad vb coding to make the program act more like Excel in this case?  I'd like whoever reviews this code to comment on that.
Text: Patch Set 2:Please note: First, bug 90447 has not been marked as "NEW" yet - only partially verified by a third party.Second, the ::End() function really should be fully re-written, but that is way beyond my current skills, and also would be a "design from scratch" effort.  The big problem is that it changes the current cursor position and so "flashes around a lot" especially when multiple tabs are involved.  Instead the function should quietly compute the cell.Third, I bundled two related items into one bug report (my bad).  This fixes the ::end function.  The ::find function does work quietly, but adds a ->Select() at the end of the function.  The select could (should?) easily be commented out, but I assume that will break some people's code or something else.  Is it worth breaking bad vb coding to make the program act more like Excel in this case?  I'd like whoever reviews this code to comment on that.

text: Patch Set 3:the A?=B syntax is a way in Makefileto doif A has no value then A=Belse keep A's valuethat way one can export A= before the invocation of makeand the user value is honored.seehttps://www.gnu.org/software/make/manual/html_node/Setting.html#index-_003f_003d-1The proper way is to run the pch script from Makefile, in which case A would be set naturally with the appropriate value.Note our makefile support the target 'cmd' for that very purpose:make cmd cmd="./bin/update_pch.sh [..]"which avoid the evil use of get_config_variables
Text: Patch Set 3:the A?=B syntax is a way in Makefileto doif A has no value then A=Belse keep A's valuethat way one can export A= before the invocation of makeand the user value is honored.seehttps://www.gnu.org/software/make/manual/html_node/Setting.html#index-_003f_003d-1The proper way is to run the pch script from Makefile, in which case A would be set naturally with the appropriate value.Note our makefile support the target 'cmd' for that very purpose:make cmd cmd="./bin/update_pch.sh [..]"which avoid the evil use of get_config_variables

text: Patch Set 2:Thanks Miklos. Done as suggested.Two notes: Although I don't think the parallelism of the build is really related to this, I agree that this approach is cleaner and is a good starting point. Later we can add command line argument to override the parallelism to override the build parallelism.Second, for me at least, the PARALLELISM entry in the config_host.mk looks weird. There is an extra question-mark after the name (a non-printable character?) and the next entry has an extra space. Not sure what's going on. In any event, I added a fallback to '0' so xargs would decide the number level of parallelism if we fail to get a sane result from config_host.mk.export PARALLELISM?=20 export GNUCOPY=C:/Bin/cygwin64/bin/cp
Text: Patch Set 2:Thanks Miklos. Done as suggested.Two notes: Although I don't think the parallelism of the build is really related to this, I agree that this approach is cleaner and is a good starting point. Later we can add command line argument to override the parallelism to override the build parallelism.Second, for me at least, the PARALLELISM entry in the config_host.mk looks weird. There is an extra question-mark after the name (a non-printable character?) and the next entry has an extra space. Not sure what's going on. In any event, I added a fallback to '0' so xargs would decide the number level of parallelism if we fail to get a sane result from config_host.mk.export PARALLELISM?=20 export GNUCOPY=C:/Bin/cygwin64/bin/cp

text: Patch Set 1:It is a good idea to include a reference to the bug number in the commit comment's first line. text: Patch Set 2:This works as expected. I hope I understand the non-execute API of vcl::Dialog correctly.Guess it's not the expected fix. If someone has a real use case to do changes in the wizard, while the mail merge is still running, feel free to complain.And is wasn't a simple exception, as the wizards cancel doesn't actually cancel the MM, but just freed some allocated stuff from the rMergeDescriptor, so rMergeDescriptor.pMailMergeConfigItem->AddMergedDocument( aMergeInfo ) failed.
Text: Patch Set 2:This works as expected. I hope I understand the non-execute API of vcl::Dialog correctly.Guess it's not the expected fix. If someone has a real use case to do changes in the wizard, while the mail merge is still running, feel free to complain.And is wasn't a simple exception, as the wizards cancel doesn't actually cancel the MM, but just freed some allocated stuff from the rMergeDescriptor, so rMergeDescriptor.pMailMergeConfigItem->AddMergedDocument( aMergeInfo ) failed.

text: Patch Set 3:>Kohei, I will rebase. Should I take out the "Repeat all item labels" checkbox in pivot table creation dialog ?IMO Yes, at least for now.  Our pivot UI is pretty limited, and I don't think we can accommodate that option without some UI redesign.  Also, having a toggle-all option would also mean a bit more work to synchronize it with the individual field settings.But if you feel strongly about having that option there, then I won't be dead set against it.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1The patch looks completely reasonable from the POV of the current state of the code. However, code archaeology suggests that merge commit 67d2af6fac2d9bad52a6b1f6e0cbd1229eb88a42 erroneously removed the call to "ImplUpdate" in MoveItem, since that line is present in BOTH parents of that merge. The "if ( nNewPos < nPos )" seems to be done for the sake of the ImplUpdate, to set the argument it will be called with. It looks reasonable, since the call is made with the default value of bDirect==false, then ImplUpdate updates *all* columns after its first argument (its argument inclusive). So it is essentially called with ::std::min(nPos, nNewPos).So it seems to me that we should rather fix the error in bd24a310be1459510b760b812838cb87923853c5 of using "nPos" instead of "nNewPos" in the second call of ::std::advance (the one before insert), but leave the "if ( nNewPos < nPos )" and reinsert the "ImplUpdate(nPos, ...)".Kendy, I know it is far away, but would you agree with my analysis of your merge commit?Julien, could you try out my suggestion above and test its effects, if the behaviour is good, the bug is still fixed, no other obvious bug is introduced, etc? Thanks in advance.
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1The patch looks completely reasonable from the POV of the current state of the code. However, code archaeology suggests that merge commit 67d2af6fac2d9bad52a6b1f6e0cbd1229eb88a42 erroneously removed the call to "ImplUpdate" in MoveItem, since that line is present in BOTH parents of that merge. The "if ( nNewPos < nPos )" seems to be done for the sake of the ImplUpdate, to set the argument it will be called with. It looks reasonable, since the call is made with the default value of bDirect==false, then ImplUpdate updates *all* columns after its first argument (its argument inclusive). So it is essentially called with ::std::min(nPos, nNewPos).So it seems to me that we should rather fix the error in bd24a310be1459510b760b812838cb87923853c5 of using "nPos" instead of "nNewPos" in the second call of ::std::advance (the one before insert), but leave the "if ( nNewPos < nPos )" and reinsert the "ImplUpdate(nPos, ...)".Kendy, I know it is far away, but would you agree with my analysis of your merge commit?Julien, could you try out my suggestion above and test its effects, if the behaviour is good, the bug is still fixed, no other obvious bug is introduced, etc? Thanks in advance.

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1 Verified+1Looks good to me; I guess we should get some more reviews before merging to -4-4 though; I'd love to hear Eike's thoughts.Clearly the test helps, and my initial worry was in fact bogus as you kindly didn't say =)On the other hand - I'd like to see this re-factored on master - the code makes my eyes bleed - particularly the huge & complex cut/paste evil between the end of the ScHorizontalAttrIterator constructor and the end of 'GetNext' - which are basically the same code: I'd love that shared & split out to some new: "InitForNextRow"I'd also like to move the expensive detection of contiguous spans into that method - so as to simplify the GetNext itself - it seems (to me) crazy to do that handling inside the 'GetNext' loop itself - but perhaps I'm confused. Either way - if we could kill the cut/paste on master I'd be rather happy.

text: Patch Set 1:Yes, it's possible to have an .uno:Something command, and no lc_something.png icon - in that case, only a text is presented.If the icon is or is not in the Galaxy theme is not the definitive answer for the question whether it is active or not - the Galaxy theme is not somehow more exclusive than the others any more.The best is to check the resulting images_*.zip - if the icon (like lc_blah.png) is in eg. in images_human.zip, icon-themes/human/cmd/lc_blah.png should not be removed.In other words, there is another system that takes care of bundling just the existing icons, but I am not sure if it is easy to get the list of the "active" icons in any way :-(
Text: Patch Set 1:Yes, it's possible to have an .uno:Something command, and no lc_something.png icon - in that case, only a text is presented.If the icon is or is not in the Galaxy theme is not the definitive answer for the question whether it is active or not - the Galaxy theme is not somehow more exclusive than the others any more.The best is to check the resulting images_*.zip - if the icon (like lc_blah.png) is in eg. in images_human.zip, icon-themes/human/cmd/lc_blah.png should not be removed.In other words, there is another system that takes care of bundling just the existing icons, but I am not sure if it is easy to get the list of the "active" icons in any way :-(

text: Patch Set 1:Hi Stephan,so, it seems they use ConfigItem to call GetProperties, GetNodeNames, ReplaceSetProperties and PutProperties.All them manages endless Sequences to get/set configuration options. By using directly officecfg we can get and set these values. Also, all these calls to ConfigItem methos are done in one place, so, the initial get and the following set are always done in methods from cfgitem. So we can safely (in theory) to cleanup the ConfigItem inheritance of SmMathConfig.Maybe I can missed something, but it seems to be the actual scenario.
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Stephan,so, it seems they use ConfigItem to call GetProperties, GetNodeNames, ReplaceSetProperties and PutProperties.All them manages endless Sequences to get/set configuration options. By using directly officecfg we can get and set these values. Also, all these calls to ConfigItem methos are done in one place, so, the initial get and the following set are always done in methods from cfgitem. So we can safely (in theory) to cleanup the ConfigItem inheritance of SmMathConfig.Maybe I can missed something, but it seems to be the actual scenario.

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1I think if the "next style" is the same as the current style then you should disable the button. Otherwise you can modify the style in the dialog, e.g. indent, use "edit style" to edit the same style again in another dialog and modify it inconsistently with the still open parent dialog.
Text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1I think if the "next style" is the same as the current style then you should disable the button. Otherwise you can modify the style in the dialog, e.g. indent, use "edit style" to edit the same style again in another dialog and modify it inconsistently with the still open parent dialog.

text: Patch Set 1:Caolan: thought you might be interested in this patch since it's vcl.I think it should be ok since http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/vector/vector/erase/ indicates that even in C++98 erase method of vector returns an iterator.However, I wonder if this patch might have wrong side effects since it concerns vcl and not relationships part only.
Text: Patch Set 1:Caolan: thought you might be interested in this patch since it's vcl.I think it should be ok since http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/vector/vector/erase/ indicates that even in C++98 erase method of vector returns an iterator.However, I wonder if this patch might have wrong side effects since it concerns vcl and not relationships part only.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Calling maItemList.erase(it) indeed invalidates it, we are not authorised to use it any more.However, assigning to it the return value of erase does not match my understanding of the code block that follows the for loop, that is issue a SAL_WARN if the button id to be deleted was not found. Now this SAL_WARN would incorrectly be triggered when the last button (the one that is last in maItemList) is successfully deleted.At first I thought about: * introducing a boolean flag "found" for this information,   which is a bit awkward, especially for an information that   is used only in debug mode:   bool found(false);   for(...)   {       if(...)       {           found=true;           ....       }   }   if(!found)       SAL_WARN(...) * taking more control of the looping than in a "usual" for loop pattern:   for (it = maItemList.begin(); ; ++it)   {       if (it == maItemList.end())       {           SAL_WARN( "vcl.window", "ButtonDialog::RemoveButton(): ButtonId invalid" );           break;       }       else if (it->mnId == nId)       {           ...       }   }but then I got the idea of just replacing the "break" by a "return" since this is the end of the function anyway.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Calling maItemList.erase(it) indeed invalidates it, we are not authorised to use it any more.However, assigning to it the return value of erase does not match my understanding of the code block that follows the for loop, that is issue a SAL_WARN if the button id to be deleted was not found. Now this SAL_WARN would incorrectly be triggered when the last button (the one that is last in maItemList) is successfully deleted.At first I thought about: * introducing a boolean flag "found" for this information,   which is a bit awkward, especially for an information that   is used only in debug mode:   bool found(false);   for(...)   {       if(...)       {           found=true;           ....       }   }   if(!found)       SAL_WARN(...) * taking more control of the looping than in a "usual" for loop pattern:   for (it = maItemList.begin(); ; ++it)   {       if (it == maItemList.end())       {           SAL_WARN( "vcl.window", "ButtonDialog::RemoveButton(): ButtonId invalid" );           break;       }       else if (it->mnId == nId)       {           ...       }   }but then I got the idea of just replacing the "break" by a "return" since this is the end of the function anyway.

text: Patch Set 1:Also, since you are touching this code anyway, you could (but that is optional / up to you) make the SAL_WARN message better. For example:  SAL_WARN( "vcl.window", "ButtonDialog::RemoveButton(): invalid ButtonId: " << nId);  or, if ButtonDialog had a "getId" or "getName" or some such  (which I haven't immediately found):  SAL_WARN( "vcl.window", "ButtonDialog::RemoveButton(): invalid ButtonId: " << nId << " in ButtonDialog '" << getName() << "'" );If you do it, do it in a separate commit.If you want to do that kind of "drive-by" improvements is up to you.
Text: Patch Set 1:Also, since you are touching this code anyway, you could (but that is optional / up to you) make the SAL_WARN message better. For example:  SAL_WARN( "vcl.window", "ButtonDialog::RemoveButton(): invalid ButtonId: " << nId);  or, if ButtonDialog had a "getId" or "getName" or some such  (which I haven't immediately found):  SAL_WARN( "vcl.window", "ButtonDialog::RemoveButton(): invalid ButtonId: " << nId << " in ButtonDialog '" << getName() << "'" );If you do it, do it in a separate commit.If you want to do that kind of "drive-by" improvements is up to you.

text: Patch Set 1:> "This means that a handler can successfully handle a situation in which the content of a file changes while the handler is reading the file."> Does the handler really fulfil that requirement?No, the handler doesn't handle the situation where the file change while it's reading it.But I think crashing the handler is better than forbidding the user to open the file. The handler opens the file in read-only mode so it will not damage it.Currently the only solution to bug #67534 is to completely disable the explorer shell extensions.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2So - it seems to me that with all our (well Caolan's really ;-) hard work on coverity fixing, my hope is that this prop handler should be able to cope with arbitrary broken / truncated / partially written / fuzzed & mangled data streams. Certainly, far better than we did in the past; and where they fail that is a handler bug we can fix separately.So - I'm strongly in favour of a more friendly locking mode; the alternative: of read-only opened files, when someone else is just browsing that directory; or worse - of making everyone's directory browsing slow by needlessly locking things remotely while they browse is pretty horrible =)It seems to fix a key MIMO issue seen in the wild, and is plausible, so I'm in favour =)
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2So - it seems to me that with all our (well Caolan's really ;-) hard work on coverity fixing, my hope is that this prop handler should be able to cope with arbitrary broken / truncated / partially written / fuzzed & mangled data streams. text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1So - the concept looks ok to me; but I'd like to avoid the use of sprintf - and this static sized buffer.We -should- be able to pass our own OStringBuffer into the method - and if we re-use that each time by associating it eg. with the Workbook object - we don't need to keep freeing & allocating that. So we can avoid that cost - and not use fixed size stack buffers and also get the perf. win I think =)
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1So - the concept looks ok to me; but I'd like to avoid the use of sprintf - and this static sized buffer.We -should- be able to pass our own OStringBuffer into the method - and if we re-use that each time by associating it eg. with the Workbook object - we don't need to keep freeing & allocating that. So we can avoid that cost - and not use fixed size stack buffers and also get the perf. win I think =)

text: Patch Set 6:the difference is that "startsWith" makes it very obvious what the code does, whereas "match" is so generic a term that the reader must know by heart the specification of OUString::match or needs to look it up(and the redundant if-check in the inline definition of OUString::startsWith should be optimized away, if that's what you're concerned about)
Text: Patch Set 6:the difference is that "startsWith" makes it very obvious what the code does, whereas "match" is so generic a term that the reader must know by heart the specification of OUString::match or needs to look it up(and the redundant if-check in the inline definition of OUString::startsWith should be optimized away, if that's what you're concerned about)

text: Patch Set 1:That's interesting. I had the impression that LO doesn't read SmartArt, since if I remove the contents of drawing1.xml in the original document, I get a blank page, and if I understand it correctly drawing1.xml is used only for DrawingML. If LO can import SmartArt and produce an editable diagram, why doesn't it do that by default? Unfortunately I don't have a good test document yet. For the bug page, I hacked up a version of drawing1.xml but it contains no SmartArt data.
Text: Patch Set 1:That's interesting. I had the impression that LO doesn't read SmartArt, since if I remove the contents of drawing1.xml in the original document, I get a blank page, and if I understand it correctly drawing1.xml is used only for DrawingML. If LO can import SmartArt and produce an editable diagram, why doesn't it do that by default? Unfortunately I don't have a good test document yet. For the bug page, I hacked up a version of drawing1.xml but it contains no SmartArt data.

text: Patch Set 1:SmartArt has some declarative data and also some pre-rendered drawingML result (since MSO 2010). LO only uses the drawingML result. That's still editable (depending on the setting), but it doesn't mean that you'll get the same editing experience than in MSO, what understands the declarative data as well. E.g. in LO, if the SmartArt has 5 points in a circle, then you can move one of the points, but in MSO, you can add a 6th point to the circle and it'll re-distribute them equally on the circle. In LO, the default is lock-down, so that the user is not encouraged to edit the SmartArt. If it's modified, we can preserve the declarative metadata and write it back to the OOXML file on export.
Text: Patch Set 1:SmartArt has some declarative data and also some pre-rendered drawingML result (since MSO 2010). LO only uses the drawingML result. That's still editable (depending on the setting), but it doesn't mean that you'll get the same editing experience than in MSO, what understands the declarative data as well. E.g. in LO, if the SmartArt has 5 points in a circle, then you can move one of the points, but in MSO, you can add a 6th point to the circle and it'll re-distribute them equally on the circle. In LO, the default is lock-down, so that the user is not encouraged to edit the SmartArt. If it's modified, we can preserve the declarative metadata and write it back to the OOXML file on export.

text: Patch Set 4:the vector is guaranteed to be sorted only to clients of SwpHints; the SwpHints class itself is responsible for guaranteeing that, and inside a SwpHints method the vector may be temporarily not in the proper sort order.of course no STL algorithms that depend on the ordering must be run in such a situation; do you have a concrete example that triggers an assert?
Text: Patch Set 4:the vector is guaranteed to be sorted only to clients of SwpHints; the SwpHints class itself is responsible for guaranteeing that, and inside a SwpHints method the vector may be temporarily not in the proper sort order.of course no STL algorithms that depend on the ordering must be run in such a situation; do you have a concrete example that triggers an assert?

text: Patch Set 4:> of course no STL algorithms that depend on the ordering must be run in such a situation; do you have a concrete example that triggers an assert?Yes. As I said, I have reproduced it. It's not theoretical. Unfortunately, the doc that triggers it is impossible to share (it's private).The assertion happens as a result of calling Delete (line 2853) after entering the loop under "// change all attributes with key i". That loop (line 2862-2871) modifies the items of the sorted_vector. If that large loop in that function has more entries to merge, it hits Delete on line 2853 a second time, which calls GetStartOf, which searches for the SwTxtAttr* via lower_bound in the sorted_vector (which might fail because the items are no longer sorted, but asserts in dbgutil builds).The only downside to my fix is the potential performance hit, but I don't see any obvious fixes that prevents the issue, so correctness first.
Text: Patch Set 4:> of course no STL algorithms that depend on the ordering must be run in such a situation; do you have a concrete example that triggers an assert?Yes. As I said, I have reproduced it. It's not theoretical. Unfortunately, the doc that triggers it is impossible to share (it's private).The assertion happens as a result of calling Delete (line 2853) after entering the loop under "// change all attributes with key i". That loop (line 2862-2871) modifies the items of the sorted_vector. If that large loop in that function has more entries to merge, it hits Delete on line 2853 a second time, which calls GetStartOf, which searches for the SwTxtAttr* via lower_bound in the sorted_vector (which might fail because the items are no longer sorted, but asserts in dbgutil builds).The only downside to my fix is the potential performance hit, but I don't see any obvious fixes that prevents the issue, so correctness first.

text: Patch Set 7:> 5. i'm actually wondering what the "check if deletion actually took place before destroying attribute" nonsense is: perhaps it was a work-around for this bug? clearly Delete() can't fail?My thoughts exactly. Delete() may fail due to unsorted vector, and freeing the item that is still accessible in the vector will certainly not be a good idea.I'd add a comment to this effect for posterity, but not enough confidence to remove the check. Alternatively, Delete could return a bool status to signal deletion and at least make the code cleaner.

text: Patch Set 6: Verified+1 Code-Review+2ok, findings:1. the .DOC files fail on a different assertion, in RstAttrs2. it is possible to trigger the assertion, although   apparently not with libstdc++ _GLIBCXX_DEBUG,   but MSVC asserts3. there is no other modification of text attributes that   impacts sort order after this so we don't need to do   another sort on function exit4. the function should get a MATCH state at most 2 times   while inserting a hint, once "before" and once "after"   inserted hint, so re-sorting twice shouldn't be too   expensive5. i'm actually wondering what the "check if deletion actually took place before destroying attribute" nonsense is: perhaps it was a work-around for this bug? clearly Delete() can't fail?steps to reproduce:1. insert paragraph with some text2. set char style "Strong Emphasis" on 2 disjoint ranges in the paragraph3. insert hyperlink, starting from start of first "Strong Emphasis" range and ending after end of first S.E. range and before the second one4. select from end of first S.E. range to start of second one, set "Strong Emphasis"
Text: Patch Set 6: Verified+1 Code-Review+2ok, findings:1. the .DOC files fail on a different assertion, in RstAttrs2. it is possible to trigger the assertion, although   apparently not with libstdc++ _GLIBCXX_DEBUG,   but MSVC asserts3. there is no other modification of text attributes that   impacts sort order after this so we don't need to do   another sort on function exit4. the function should get a MATCH state at most 2 times   while inserting a hint, once "before" and once "after"   inserted hint, so re-sorting twice shouldn't be too   expensive5. i'm actually wondering what the "check if deletion actually took place before destroying attribute" nonsense is: perhaps it was a work-around for this bug? clearly Delete() can't fail?steps to reproduce:1. insert paragraph with some text2. set char style "Strong Emphasis" on 2 disjoint ranges in the paragraph3. insert hyperlink, starting from start of first "Strong Emphasis" range and ending after end of first S.E. range and before the second one4. select from end of first S.E. range to start of second one, set "Strong Emphasis"
