text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(3 comments)i'm a bit confused here....do we need to export only the top level element table:table in a different namespace?it looks like you want to export table-row / table-column / cell in different namespace too and forgot covered-cell.but why change the namespace of these 3-4 elements and not the paragraphs contained in the cells etc. etc.?changing the namespace of everything inside the table is going to be quite painful, isn't it enough to only change the top-level table element?
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(3 comments)i'm a bit confused here....do we need to export only the top level element table:table in a different namespace?it looks like you want to export table-row / table-column / cell in different namespace too and forgot covered-cell.but why change the namespace of these 3-4 elements and not the paragraphs contained in the cells etc. etc.?changing the namespace of everything inside the table is going to be quite painful, isn't it enough to only change the top-level table element?

text: Patch Set 1:Hi,> do we need to export only the top level element table:table in a different namespace?Just table:table is not enough, as you see in the patch, all the table-related elements have to be in the extension namespace, odfvalidator says so at least.> it looks like you want to export table-row / table-column / cell in different namespace too and forgot covered-cell.Indeed, I'll fix covered-cell.> but why change the namespace of these 3-4 elements and not the paragraphs contained in the cells etc. etc.?The idea is that table-in-shape is a new feature, but text-in-shape is not, so if a reader is not capable of table-in-shape, it can still import the text of the table into the shape. (Slightly related example: old RTF import did the same for nested tables.)> changing the namespace of everything inside the table is going to be quite painful, isn't it enough to only change the top-level table element?I needed the minimal changes to make odfvalidator happy. That means changing the prefix of table:*, but not the content of the tables, which would be indeed painful.I'll fix the rest on master and upload a new revision.
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi,> do we need to export only the top level element table:table in a different namespace?Just table:table is not enough, as you see in the patch, all the table-related elements have to be in the extension namespace, odfvalidator says so at least.> it looks like you want to export table-row / table-column / cell in different namespace too and forgot covered-cell.Indeed, I'll fix covered-cell.> but why change the namespace of these 3-4 elements and not the paragraphs contained in the cells etc. etc.?The idea is that table-in-shape is a new feature, but text-in-shape is not, so if a reader is not capable of table-in-shape, it can still import the text of the table into the shape. (Slightly related example: old RTF import did the same for nested tables.)> changing the namespace of everything inside the table is going to be quite painful, isn't it enough to only change the top-level table element?I needed the minimal changes to make odfvalidator happy. That means changing the prefix of table:*, but not the content of the tables, which would be indeed painful.I'll fix the rest on master and upload a new revision.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1ERROR.TYPE(532) should return a #N/A error like for all expressions passed as argument that are not error. ERROR.TYPE() returns a number only if an error was passed as argument. See also http://docs.oasis-open.org/office/v1.2/os/OpenDocument-v1.2-os-part2.html#ERROR_TYPE

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(2 comments)Despite the build error, when fixed this doesn't work as intended. The function propagates an error instead of returning the corresponding numeric value, e.g. ERROR.TYPE(1/0) returns #DIV/0! It does work however for ERROR.TYPE(#DIV/0!)Note also that in interpr4.cxx in ScInterpreter::Interpret() there is the CASE_OCERRFUNC macro where ocErrorType_MS needs to be added to prevent shortcut on error if functions evaluating an error are used in the expression. Maybe this is already the cause for the ERROR.TYPE(1/0) case.

text: Patch Set 2:Thanks for the review. I confess this was a bit of a "provocation" on my part. I considered "working around" the problem in the form wizard code, but then I decided that especially since the wizard uses only our public API (which any user can use in their scripts), what it does *should* work. If it doesn't, we present our users with a lousy API / experience.Specifically the sequence is something like:// SETUPXControlShape aDateShape = factory.createInstance("com.sun.star.drawing.ControlShape");XControlModel aDateControlModel = factory.createInstance("com.sun.star.form.component.DateField");aDateShape.setControl(aDateControlModel);XControlShape aTimeShape = factory.createInstance("com.sun.star.drawing.ControlShape");XControlModel aTimeControlModel = factory.createInstance("com.sun.star.form.component.TimeField");aTimeShape.setControl(aTimeControlModel);xShapes = factory.createInstance("com.sun.star.drawing.ShapeCollection");xShapes.add(aDateShape);xShapes.add(aTimeShape);someXShapeGrouper.group(xShapes);// NOW, WHAT I EXPECT TO WORKaDateShape.getControl(); // SHOULD NOT RETURN NULL! SHOULD RETURN aDateModel!aTimeShape.getControl(); // SHOULD NOT RETURN NULL! SHOULD RETURN aTimeModel!I guess what I'm trying to say, is that even if this "aggressive" patch creates regressions in Draw/Impress, we should find some way for the above scenario to work, for the sake of the saneness of our public API.
Text: Patch Set 2:Thanks for the review. I confess this was a bit of a "provocation" on my part. I considered "working around" the problem in the form wizard code, but then I decided that especially since the wizard uses only our public API (which any user can use in their scripts), what it does *should* work. If it doesn't, we present our users with a lousy API / experience.Specifically the sequence is something like:// SETUPXControlShape aDateShape = factory.createInstance("com.sun.star.drawing.ControlShape");XControlModel aDateControlModel = factory.createInstance("com.sun.star.form.component.DateField");aDateShape.setControl(aDateControlModel);XControlShape aTimeShape = factory.createInstance("com.sun.star.drawing.ControlShape");XControlModel aTimeControlModel = factory.createInstance("com.sun.star.form.component.TimeField");aTimeShape.setControl(aTimeControlModel);xShapes = factory.createInstance("com.sun.star.drawing.ShapeCollection");xShapes.add(aDateShape);xShapes.add(aTimeShape);someXShapeGrouper.group(xShapes);// NOW, WHAT I EXPECT TO WORKaDateShape.getControl(); // SHOULD NOT RETURN NULL! SHOULD RETURN aDateModel!aTimeShape.getControl(); // SHOULD NOT RETURN NULL! SHOULD RETURN aTimeModel!I guess what I'm trying to say, is that even if this "aggressive" patch creates regressions in Draw/Impress, we should find some way for the above scenario to work, for the sake of the saneness of our public API.

text: Patch Set 2:Regarding backports, you have to propose it, then it either gets rejected or merged during review. So no need to ask, just propose it. :-)
Text: Patch Set 2:Regarding backports, you have to propose it, then it either gets rejected or merged during review. So no need to ask, just propose it. :-)

text: Patch Set 2:My preference is to have the testcase and the fix in a single commit (after all, you should commit when you're done with something, and you're done when you finished the fix and the testcase), but in this case they were separate commits, so no need to bother with backporting the testcase as well.Also, please avoid the cherry-pick button if possible, that would let you propose a change without actually testing it first. We assume that you only propose changes which you already tested locally. If we figure out that you don't do that, you gain bad reputation. :-)
Text: Patch Set 2:My preference is to have the testcase and the fix in a single commit (after all, you should commit when you're done with something, and you're done when you finished the fix and the testcase), but in this case they were separate commits, so no need to bother with backporting the testcase as well.Also, please avoid the cherry-pick button if possible, that would let you propose a change without actually testing it first. We assume that you only propose changes which you already tested locally. If we figure out that you don't do that, you gain bad reputation. :-)

text: Patch Set 1:In the previous code, the zoom scale factor was ONLY saved when the zoom type was percent mode, not page width, full page etc.  I kept that logic intact - as it seems more correct logically.However, Microsoft Office ALWAYS saves the zoom scale factor.  So it could also be correct to do it that way.  That would at least help out any implementations (like LO before this patch) that import zoom percent but not zoom type.In the end, zoom type takes precedence over zoom factor, so I don't think it is important which way we choose, especially since very few people seemed interested in the bug (i.e. no bibisect).
Text: Patch Set 1:In the previous code, the zoom scale factor was ONLY saved when the zoom type was percent mode, not page width, full page etc.  I kept that logic intact - as it seems more correct logically.However, Microsoft Office ALWAYS saves the zoom scale factor.  So it could also be correct to do it that way.  That would at least help out any implementations (like LO before this patch) that import zoom percent but not zoom type.In the end, zoom type takes precedence over zoom factor, so I don't think it is important which way we choose, especially since very few people seemed interested in the bug (i.e. no bibisect).

text: Patch Set 1:Hi,I have gone through your changes. Clustered bar chart supports OUTSIDE label positioning as well. If file containing clustered bar chart with OUTSIDE label position, is RTed then the label position changes to CENTER as it is default. Whereas these changes RT it correctly  http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/oox/source/export/chartexport.cxx#2674So my unit test case is not working on it.
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi,I have gone through your changes. Clustered bar chart supports OUTSIDE label positioning as well. If file containing clustered bar chart with OUTSIDE label position, is RTed then the label position changes to CENTER as it is default. Whereas these changes RT it correctly  http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/oox/source/export/chartexport.cxx#2674So my unit test case is not working on it.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Verified+1I can't think of such situation (which IMHO would be an error anyway), InitDrawLayer() is called on a clipboard document only if drawing objects are to be copied from the source, in which case the secondary pool should already exist at the source.

text: Patch Set 1:Sorry this took so long.  (I had had a quick look at the patch, which looks more complicated on first sight than it actually is, due to the necessary changes to indentation, but then lost sight of it again.)getAllJREInfos (jvmfwk/plugins/sunmajor/pluginlib/util.cxx, called indirectly from jfw_findAndSelectJRE via jfw_plugin_getAllJavaInfos) already searches JAVA_HOME and PATH for JREs, they just don't get priority treatment in the current jfw_findAndSelectJRE.  It would probably be better to not have that search code also in jfw_findAndSelectJRE, but rather transport the information about how a JRE has been found from getAllJREInfos to jfw_findAndSelectJRE, so that the latter can pick the "best" based on that and not only on version numbers.(Also, the plugin architecture in jvmfwk is probably over-architectured, and I would like to get rid of it, not the least to drop all the #ifdef DISABLE_DYNLOADINGs, and to ease maintenance of that code.)
Text: Patch Set 1:Sorry this took so long.  (I had had a quick look at the patch, which looks more complicated on first sight than it actually is, due to the necessary changes to indentation, but then lost sight of it again.)getAllJREInfos (jvmfwk/plugins/sunmajor/pluginlib/util.cxx, called indirectly from jfw_findAndSelectJRE via jfw_plugin_getAllJavaInfos) already searches JAVA_HOME and PATH for JREs, they just don't get priority treatment in the current jfw_findAndSelectJRE.  It would probably be better to not have that search code also in jfw_findAndSelectJRE, but rather transport the information about how a JRE has been found from getAllJREInfos to jfw_findAndSelectJRE, so that the latter can pick the "best" based on that and not only on version numbers.(Also, the plugin architecture in jvmfwk is probably over-architectured, and I would like to get rid of it, not the least to drop all the #ifdef DISABLE_DYNLOADINGs, and to ease maintenance of that code.)

text: Patch Set 1: Verified+1 Code-Review+2(1 comment)this is much better.one subtle problem remains: if there is both an auto-format and char-format (or both an auto-format and hyperlink) on the same text range you will return several pams with items covering that range, and set multiple new font sizes - the last one will win.for auto-format and char-format the thints.cxx code guarantees that they don't overlap i.e. if they cover the same range they must have same start and end position; for hyperlinks there is no such guarantee, hyperlinks may overlap formatting hints.
Text: Patch Set 1: Verified+1 Code-Review+2(1 comment)this is much better.one subtle problem remains: if there is both an auto-format and char-format (or both an auto-format and hyperlink) on the same text range you will return several pams with items covering that range, and set multiple new font sizes - the last one will win.for auto-format and char-format the thints.cxx code guarantees that they don't overlap i.e. if they cover the same range they must have same start and end position; for hyperlinks there is no such guarantee, hyperlinks may overlap formatting hints.

text: Patch Set 1:There can never be any unchecked access beyond the end of the stream, because the readXXX functions throw an exception in that case. That said, I have not decided yet if we should start adding checks like this everywhere or if we should treat the related coverity reports as false positives. I tried to pinpoint this in the model for RVNGInputStream, but either I am doing something wrong, or coverity is not smart enough to recognize it. Maybe I should just disable marking of the read data as tainted...
Text: Patch Set 1:There can never be any unchecked access beyond the end of the stream, because the readXXX functions throw an exception in that case. That said, I have not decided yet if we should start adding checks like this everywhere or if we should treat the related coverity reports as false positives. I tried to pinpoint this in the model for RVNGInputStream, but either I am doing something wrong, or coverity is not smart enough to recognize it. Maybe I should just disable marking of the read data as tainted...

text: Patch Set 1:As IÔÇÖve already mentioned, I donÔÇÖt think itÔÇÖs helpful to use two slots for a single function. The existing ÔÇ£SaveÔÇØ icon already doubles as ÔÇ£Save AsÔÇØ when the document is not saved (a behavior that seems much more intelligent to me than having two icons). Is it really that frequent that people explicitly need ÔÇ£Save AsÔÇØ to change the fileÔÇÖs name or location? IsnÔÇÖt that the file managerÔÇÖs purpose anyway?Also, this seems in contradiction with the mantra that it has been repeated a lot: that youÔÇÖre removing seldom-used buttons to make room for more useful ones. An ever-present ÔÇ£Save AsÔÇØ doesnÔÇÖt seem so useful to me.

text: Patch Set 1:This change introduces a new string for translation (and removes one unused string), so some additional steps are required to make it work in non English LibreOffice. Unfortunately, I don't know what.I know it is bad to introduce a new string in a point release (was it done even once before?), but the other alternative "No Euro converter for Lithuanian litas" is possibly even worse.Euro is introduced in Lithuania on the 1st of January 2015.Without this change Euro converter would be available only in LibreOffice 4.4.0 (Feb 1, 2015). Enterprises usually use a more mature version, lets say 4.4.3 (May 10, 2015).So, without this patch, Euro converter would be useless for 1-4 months after the introduction of Euro in Lithuania.
Text: Patch Set 1:This change introduces a new string for translation (and removes one unused string), so some additional steps are required to make it work in non English LibreOffice. Unfortunately, I don't know what.I know it is bad to introduce a new string in a point release (was it done even once before?), but the other alternative "No Euro converter for Lithuanian litas" is possibly even worse.Euro is introduced in Lithuania on the 1st of January 2015.Without this change Euro converter would be available only in LibreOffice 4.4.0 (Feb 1, 2015). Enterprises usually use a more mature version, lets say 4.4.3 (May 10, 2015).So, without this patch, Euro converter would be useless for 1-4 months after the introduction of Euro in Lithuania.

text: Patch Set 3:I mean, I'll merge the OOXML testcase + the OOXML change in a bit. Not sure about the WW8 part. In general we want testcases in two situations:- if there is a recent fix, so it's a regression fix. in this case the testcase is "good" if it fails withtout the fix- boosting testcase coverage. in this case we want to run lcov before and after the testcase to see if it really improves the coverage.Do I guess right that you added the WW8 testcase to demonstrate that you're adapting writerfilter to the WW8 import? If so, then I'll just merge the patch without the WW8 bits, and we're done.Otherwise, let's do the WW8 test in a separate patch and measure lcov numbers before and after. ;-)

In general we want testcases in two situations:- if there is a recent fix, so it's a regression fix. in this case the testcase is "good" if it fails withtout the fix- boosting testcase coverage. in this case we want to run lcov before and after the testcase to see if it really improves the coverage.Do I guess right that you added the WW8 testcase to demonstrate that you're adapting writerfilter to the WW8 import? If so, then I'll just merge the patch without the WW8 bits, and we're done.Otherwise, let's do the WW8 test in a separate patch and measure lcov numbers before and after. ;-)

text: Patch Set 3:Hi Mikos, I don't understand how export tests were done. That's why I did it in a more conservative way, putting it in import tests.It is my concern that numbering types are not one to one mapping. A sequence like import, export, import lose information by nature. For example there are many cases fallback into NUMBER_LOWER_ZH. However it seems that the patchset for rtfexport can compile ( did it ever make check? ) , It contradict my guess.
Text: Patch Set 3:Hi Mikos, I don't understand how export tests were done. That's why I did it in a more conservative way, putting it in import tests.It is my concern that numbering types are not one to one mapping. A sequence like import, export, import lose information by nature. For example there are many cases fallback into NUMBER_LOWER_ZH. However it seems that the patchset for rtfexport can compile ( did it ever make check? ) , It contradict my guess.

text: Patch Set 3:When designing the framework, we had two basic ideas:- interesting document models are easier to be loaded from some format, than building them from code- checking an in-memory document model is reasonably easy (usually by using the UNO API), at least easier than asserting a written file (think of manually checking a binary .doc result)That's why for export tests, we do an import->export->import sequence. That ensures that the doc. models can be still stored in a file, allows asserting the result using the UNO API, and still export problems are detected. (I'm just re-stating what's in sw/qa/extras/README, just in case for some reason that file is not clear.) Hopefully this makes it clear how export tests are done. :-)Regarding loosing data during import/export: sure, sometimes that's necessary when e.g. our numbering types and MSO's numbering types do not match. In your case, the provided tests passed just fine when also the exporter got included in the chain, that's why I changed that. As long as it passes, it's safe to change, and it ensures that your export improvements won't break in the future silently. ;-)
Text: Patch Set 3:When designing the framework, we had two basic ideas:- interesting document models are easier to be loaded from some format, than building them from code- checking an in-memory document model is reasonably easy (usually by using the UNO API), at least easier than asserting a written file (think of manually checking a binary .doc result)That's why for export tests, we do an import->export->import sequence. That ensures that the doc. models can be still stored in a file, allows asserting the result using the UNO API, and still export problems are detected. (I'm just re-stating what's in sw/qa/extras/README, just in case for some reason that file is not clear.) Hopefully this makes it clear how export tests are done. :-)Regarding loosing data during import/export: sure, sometimes that's necessary when e.g. our numbering types and MSO's numbering types do not match. In your case, the provided tests passed just fine when also the exporter got included in the chain, that's why I changed that. As long as it passes, it's safe to change, and it ensures that your export improvements won't break in the future silently. ;-)

text: Patch Set 3:The fix is not complete. If a child element has set visibility="visible" it has to be shown, even when the parent is hidden. Test the last too test files in https://issues.apache.org/ooo/show_bug.cgi?id=125321.There is likely a second problem, but I cannot test it because of the first one: In contrast to display="none" in case of visible="hidden" the place the element would need, is reserved, similar to "phantom" in Math. In svg this affects the tspan element.
Text: Patch Set 3:The fix is not complete. If a child element has set visibility="visible" it has to be shown, even when the parent is hidden. Test the last too test files in https://issues.apache.org/ooo/show_bug.cgi?id=125321.There is likely a second problem, but I cannot test it because of the first one: In contrast to display="none" in case of visible="hidden" the place the element would need, is reserved, similar to "phantom" in Math. In svg this affects the tspan element.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1> I noticed that the behavior seemed to be the same with translate and lookat in the AerialView. But I could be wrong.The two branch behaves differently. First branch (mbAerialView) moves the camera to the new position and change view to make the camera look at the center of the model (orbit mode invariant).Second branch only moves the camera to the new position, but does not change the direction of the camera view, which means camera will look at a new point (right behavior in walkthrough mode, but wrong in orbit mode).
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1> I noticed that the behavior seemed to be the same with translate and lookat in the AerialView. But I could be wrong.The two branch behaves differently. First branch (mbAerialView) moves the camera to the new position and change view to make the camera look at the center of the model (orbit mode invariant).Second branch only moves the camera to the new position, but does not change the direction of the camera view, which means camera will look at a new point (right behavior in walkthrough mode, but wrong in orbit mode).

text: Patch Set 2:So UPD has been computed as the somewhat silly  10^(floor(log_10(max(minor, 1)))+1)*major + 10*minorever since 74bd1f57b56918a3ef5f27aa2565397a4c6e85e1 (and before that had been manually tracked as something like RSCVERSION=350 in solenv/inc/minor.mk).  This clearly has drawbacks if ever minor > 9.So, instead of carefully mimicking that silly formula via application of OString::number and OString::toInt* to integer literals, I would suggest turning to a more sane formula instead, like  1000*major + 10*minor(Whether it is better or worse to include micro in that formula I don't know.)
Text: Patch Set 2:So UPD has been computed as the somewhat silly  10^(floor(log_10(max(minor, 1)))+1)*major + 10*minorever since 74bd1f57b56918a3ef5f27aa2565397a4c6e85e1 (and before that had been manually tracked as something like RSCVERSION=350 in solenv/inc/minor.mk).  This clearly has drawbacks if ever minor > 9.So, instead of carefully mimicking that silly formula via application of OString::number and OString::toInt* to integer literals, I would suggest turning to a more sane formula instead, like  1000*major + 10*minor(Whether it is better or worse to include micro in that formula I don't know.)

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1On the question of whether it is sufficient to resolve the problem: please test it. Create a query (with an outer join) in design view, and then switch to SQL view. Is the "{ OJ" in lower case? If not, "git grep -w OJ -- connectivity/ dbaccess/" gives this interesting match:dbaccess/source/ui/querydesign/QueryDesignView.cxx:                                            aStr += "{ OJ ";This indiscriminately puts all tokens in lower case; however fdo#84073 is about the "{ }" escapes *only* (which are not in the SQL standard, they are an ODBC / JDBC escape/extension), not the whole SQL standard. I'd rather we changed only the ODBC/JDBC escapes: { oj ... } // outer join { ts .. } // timestamp { d .. } // date { t .. } // time(any other I'm forgetting?)The date/time ones seem to be in (if not in sqlflex.l)connectivity/source/commontools/DateConversion.cxx:                            aRet.appendAscii("{TS '");
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1On the question of whether it is sufficient to resolve the problem: please test it. Create a query (with an outer join) in design view, and then switch to SQL view. I'd rather we changed only the ODBC/JDBC escapes: { oj ... } // outer join { ts .. } // timestamp { d .. } // date { t .. } // time(any other I'm forgetting?)The date/time ones seem to be in (if not in sqlflex.l)connectivity/source/commontools/DateConversion.cxx:                            aRet.appendAscii("{TS '");

text: Patch Set 1:@Robert Antoni Buj i Gelonch:This patch affects _C_ and not _C++_.For C we specifically only support C90 (and not C99 or later) as e.g. MSVC doesn't support newer than C90 (and gcc appears to default to that too), hence it's useful for devs with clang (which doesn't default to C90) to be able to catch potential build problems (i.e. non C90 compliant code) locally.(And incidentally LO is buildable with C++03, and can't use C++11 only features (for now), as we still need to support some older systems.)
Text: Patch Set 1:@Robert Antoni Buj i Gelonch:This patch affects _C_ and not _C++_.For C we specifically only support C90 (and not C99 or later) as e.g. MSVC doesn't support newer than C90 (and gcc appears to default to that too), hence it's useful for devs with clang (which doesn't default to C90) to be able to catch potential build problems (i.e. non C90 compliant code) locally.(And incidentally LO is buildable with C++03, and can't use C++11 only features (for now), as we still need to support some older systems.)

text: Patch Set 2:"I tested it in OS X Yosemite DP2 with -std=gnu11 and it worked well."But what benefit would we have from compiling the (little) C code that we have with -std=gnu11?  AFAIK, we do not actively try to make use of any C99/C11 features where available in any of our C code, anyway.On the contrary, what this patch is about is restricting more capable compilers to the C89 subset (enforced upon us effectively by MSVC), so that developers across different platforms can more easily prevent adding new code violating C89 (which would otherwise break only on platforms they did not test their new code on).
Text: Patch Set 2:"I tested it in OS X Yosemite DP2 with -std=gnu11 and it worked well."But what benefit would we have from compiling the (little) C code that we have with -std=gnu11?  AFAIK, we do not actively try to make use of any C99/C11 features where available in any of our C code, anyway.On the contrary, what this patch is about is restricting more capable compilers to the C89 subset (enforced upon us effectively by MSVC), so that developers across different platforms can more easily prevent adding new code violating C89 (which would otherwise break only on platforms they did not test their new code on).

text: Patch Set 2:If you think that the best option is to force the usage of C89 to everybody, the best is to add the AC_PROG_CC_C89 macro at the top.
Text: Patch Set 2:If you think that the best option is to force the usage of C89 to everybody, the best is to add the AC_PROG_CC_C89 macro at the top.

text: Patch Set 3:Yes -- backport the code, or at least its relevant part, to 4.2. To be able to read, prompt for and use modify password, Impress/Draw code must read the appropriate data from ODF container - ModifyPasswordInfo bits from settings.xml. And since 4.2 Impress/Draw doesn't have that functionality yet (this is only added with my change to UnoDocumentSettings.cxx), it simply ignores the existence of modify password and allows user to edit the document w/o entering one.Otherwise, password protection created in 4.4 and newer will be null and void when opening such document in 4.3 and older
Text: Patch Set 3:Yes -- backport the code, or at least its relevant part, to 4.2. To be able to read, prompt for and use modify password, Impress/Draw code must read the appropriate data from ODF container - ModifyPasswordInfo bits from settings.xml. And since 4.2 Impress/Draw doesn't have that functionality yet (this is only added with my change to UnoDocumentSettings.cxx), it simply ignores the existence of modify password and allows user to edit the document w/o entering one.Otherwise, password protection created in 4.4 and newer will be null and void when opening such document in 4.3 and older

text: Patch Set 3:I wouldn't add such message (warning users that the document they're about to save might not be opened with older versions of %PRODUCT) -- unless there's a couple of precedents of doing it already elsewhere in LibO. I don't know about any ... Such messages, imo, add little value and largely only annoy the users.What certainly should be done is documenting this limitation in release notes.

text: Patch Set 1:"I would suggest to generate an additional three ctors that each take a first argument Throwable cause"That would cause a minor compile-time incompatibility, in that a call  E(null)would now be ambiguous, but arguably such a call had always bordered on beeing illegal (as it sets the UNO css.uno.Exception string Message member to null, and null is not among the java.lang.String values that are valid UNO string representations), is probably rare in practice, only causes a compile-time and not a run-time problem, and is trivially fixed in the source code.  (But technically, it would make the commit an [API CHANGE] again.)
Text: Patch Set 1:"I would suggest to generate an additional three ctors that each take a first argument Throwable cause"That would cause a minor compile-time incompatibility, in that a call  E(null)would now be ambiguous, but arguably such a call had always bordered on beeing illegal (as it sets the UNO css.uno.Exception string Message member to null, and null is not among the java.lang.String values that are valid UNO string representations), is probably rare in practice, only causes a compile-time and not a run-time problem, and is trivially fixed in the source code.  (But technically, it would make the commit an [API CHANGE] again.)

text: Patch Set 5:Ok there are still people who want to keep everything in the context menu, but we can't please everyone.So I've reduced this patch to affect only writer and removed only the things which are accessible in the formatting bar by default (see commit message)
Text: Patch Set 5:Ok there are still people who want to keep everything in the context menu, but we can't please everyone.So I've reduced this patch to affect only writer and removed only the things which are accessible in the formatting bar by default (see commit message)

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1This is nice work, but there are two small problems(1) you can't convert " a == b" to "assertEquals(a,b)" because they do different things - the second form calls the equals method on object a(2) I don't like the exception.expect stuff - it looks too magical, and I don't see how it is possible for you to do an exception test and then some more stuff in the same method. That exception = None stuff isn't doing what you think it's doing.
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1This is nice work, but there are two small problems(1) you can't convert " a == b" to "assertEquals(a,b)" because they do different things - the second form calls the equals method on object a(2) I don't like the exception.expect stuff - it looks too magical, and I don't see how it is possible for you to do an exception test and then some more stuff in the same method. That exception = None stuff isn't doing what you think it's doing.

text: Patch Set 3:"are all clang tinderboxes programmed to fall over on warnings ?"Yes, looks like all tbs that use the plugins also use --enable-werror.  The only good way to get a list of problematic code places is to run the plugin locally."its really non-obvious that -everything- dropped in that directory is un-conditionally compiled & used"The canonic place to put plugins that are not intended to be run unconditionally is the compilerplugins/clang/store/ directory.
Text: Patch Set 3:"are all clang tinderboxes programmed to fall over on warnings ?"Yes, looks like all tbs that use the plugins also use --enable-werror.  The only good way to get a list of problematic code places is to run the plugin locally."its really non-obvious that -everything- dropped in that directory is un-conditionally compiled & used"The canonic place to put plugins that are not intended to be run unconditionally is the compilerplugins/clang/store/ directory.

text: Patch Set 1:Actually this is incompatible with the pre 4.1 behavior (that's right - it's broken since 4.1, and no one ever complained until now). For example, for the edit verb a user could use in a macro both -1 (which is correct) and 65535. Of course we can emulate the old behavior by simply casting back SfxUInt16Item::GetValue() to signed, but I wonder whether it's a good idea to carry this ancient bug (as it seems there's no much user code that depends on it).
Text: Patch Set 1:Actually this is incompatible with the pre 4.1 behavior (that's right - it's broken since 4.1, and no one ever complained until now). For example, for the edit verb a user could use in a macro both -1 (which is correct) and 65535. Of course we can emulate the old behavior by simply casting back SfxUInt16Item::GetValue() to signed, but I wonder whether it's a good idea to carry this ancient bug (as it seems there's no much user code that depends on it).

text: Patch Set 6:Yes, that's what I thought when I first read your patch, but sadly there is also an svx vs sfx2 circular dependency here as well.FmFormShell is part of svx, and svx uses sfx, so sfx can't refer to FmFormShell. Maybe move up IsDesignMode() to SfxShell? And it would be false by default, virtual, and FmFormShell would provide a real implementation.
Text: Patch Set 6:Yes, that's what I thought when I first read your patch, but sadly there is also an svx vs sfx2 circular dependency here as well.FmFormShell is part of svx, and svx uses sfx, so sfx can't refer to FmFormShell. Maybe move up IsDesignMode() to SfxShell? And it would be false by default, virtual, and FmFormShell would provide a real implementation.

text: Patch Set 2:By "a node that is not expandable" is a node without children, if we look at the Styles and Formatting the style Addressee is not the base of any other style and is not expandable in the Hierarchal view. Sorry if I use the word node in an incorrect way. :(The problem is not as big in the sidebar version of the Styles and formatting window as in the one that is brought up by the menu Format -> Styles and Formatting. The only problem in the sidebar version is that if you have the style Addressee selected and press the left arrow it should move to it's parent but it doesn't without this patch.
Text: Patch Set 2:By "a node that is not expandable" is a node without children, if we look at the Styles and Formatting the style Addressee is not the base of any other style and is not expandable in the Hierarchal view. Sorry if I use the word node in an incorrect way. :(The problem is not as big in the sidebar version of the Styles and formatting window as in the one that is brought up by the menu Format -> Styles and Formatting. The only problem in the sidebar version is that if you have the style Addressee selected and press the left arrow it should move to it's parent but it doesn't without this patch.

text: Patch Set 2:> Please don't open the sidebar by default in calc.You are right. Our idea was that only the icons of the sidebar are shown by default in Calc, Draw and maybe also in Writer. But I have not yet figured out how to do this. So it needs to be visible by default, but there should be no pane visible until the user selects one.>  Personally I would leave the Styles and Formatting icon in this toolbar, because if a user decides to _not_ use the sidebar he has no easy click-access to styles and formatting.Our plan was to hide the floating windows and promote the sidebar (the floating windows should be only available in the menu). But even if the sidebar is hidden, you can show the formatting pane by selecting "More" from the styles drop-down.Maybe we can merge this even if it's not perfect yet and then discuss further improvements with UX-Advise. I'll continue to work on this.
Text: Patch Set 2:> Please don't open the sidebar by default in calc.You are right. Our idea was that only the icons of the sidebar are shown by default in Calc, Draw and maybe also in Writer. But I have not yet figured out how to do this. So it needs to be visible by default, but there should be no pane visible until the user selects one.>  Personally I would leave the Styles and Formatting icon in this toolbar, because if a user decides to _not_ use the sidebar he has no easy click-access to styles and formatting.Our plan was to hide the floating windows and promote the sidebar (the floating windows should be only available in the menu). But even if the sidebar is hidden, you can show the formatting pane by selecting "More" from the styles drop-down.Maybe we can merge this even if it's not perfect yet and then discuss further improvements with UX-Advise. I'll continue to work on this.

text: Patch Set 1:Ah, but indeed I build with --enable-debug, so not optimising. Presumably the (bogus) warnings are generated only when the compile is optimising? Perhaps even only when using LTO?Not sure if checking $(MSVC_USE_DEBUG_RUNTIME) is the right thing, isn't it so that we use the debug runtime when --enable-dbgutil was used, and that does not correspond 1:1 to not optimising.

text: Patch Set 1:Those warnings are from tb Win-x86_42, I think it's VS2012. But without --enable-debug. LTO is off for this machine.I think the underlying problem is the definition of SAL_WARN_IF athttp://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/include/sal/log.hxx#304For non-debug "SAL_DETAIL_ENABLE_LOG_WARN" is false then, and "condition" is never reached, so it's unused in this case, maybe that's what MSVC complains about.
Text: Patch Set 1:Those warnings are from tb Win-x86_42, I think it's VS2012. But without --enable-debug. LTO is off for this machine.I think the underlying problem is the definition of SAL_WARN_IF athttp://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/include/sal/log.hxx#304For non-debug "SAL_DETAIL_ENABLE_LOG_WARN" is false then, and "condition" is never reached, so it's unused in this case, maybe that's what MSVC complains about.

text: Patch Set 1:Sure, sure, but the point is that it is (in my not so humble opinion) wrong if the compiler claims that variables are "unused" if they occur only in the right-hand-side of an && expression where the left-hand-side is a false constant. But yeah, we can't do anything about that, so probably we should apply this patch. Except that instead of MSVC_USE_DEBUG_RUNTIME we should check whether optimisation is used.
Text: Patch Set 1:Sure, sure, but the point is that it is (in my not so humble opinion) wrong if the compiler claims that variables are "unused" if they occur only in the right-hand-side of an && expression where the left-hand-side is a false constant. But yeah, we can't do anything about that, so probably we should apply this patch. Except that instead of MSVC_USE_DEBUG_RUNTIME we should check whether optimisation is used.

text: Patch Set 3:package com.mycompany.tests;import java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException;import java.nio.ByteBuffer;import java.util.ArrayList;import java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit;import java.util.logging.Level;import java.util.logging.Logger;import org.openjdk.jmh.annotations.Benchmark;import org.openjdk.jmh.annotations.BenchmarkMode;import org.openjdk.jmh.annotations.Mode;import org.openjdk.jmh.annotations.OutputTimeUnit;import org.openjdk.jmh.annotations.Scope;import org.openjdk.jmh.annotations.State;import org.openjdk.jmh.runner.Runner;import org.openjdk.jmh.runner.RunnerException;import org.openjdk.jmh.runner.options.Options;import org.openjdk.jmh.runner.options.OptionsBuilder;/** * * @author rbuj */@State(Scope.Thread)@BenchmarkMode(Mode.AverageTime)@OutputTimeUnit(TimeUnit.NANOSECONDS)public class DecodeUTF8 {    String query;    public DecodeUTF8() {        this.query = "";        for (int i = 0; i < 500; i++) {            this.query += "%5B";        }    }    @Benchmark    @BenchmarkMode(Mode.All)    @OutputTimeUnit(TimeUnit.MICROSECONDS)    public void v1_decodeUTF8_test() {        try {            String ans = v1_decodeUTF8_function(query);        } catch (Exception ex) {            Logger.getLogger(DecodeUTF8.class.getName()).log(Level.SEVERE, null, ex);        }    }    @Benchmark    @BenchmarkMode(Mode.All)    @OutputTimeUnit(TimeUnit.MICROSECONDS)    public void v2_decodeUTF8_test() {        try {            String ans = v2_decodeUTF8_function(query);        } catch (Exception ex) {            Logger.getLogger(DecodeUTF8.class.getName()).log(Level.SEVERE, null, ex);        }    }    @Benchmark    @BenchmarkMode(Mode.All)    @OutputTimeUnit(TimeUnit.MICROSECONDS)    public void v3_decodeUTF8_test() {        try {            String ans = v3_decodeUTF8_function(query);        } catch (Exception ex) {            Logger.getLogger(DecodeUTF8.class.getName()).log(Level.SEVERE, null, ex);        }    }    private static int hexToInt(int ch)            throws Exception {        int c = Character.toLowerCase((char) ch);        boolean isDigit = ('0' <= c && c <= '9');        boolean isValidChar = ('a' <= c && c <= 'f') || isDigit;        if (!isValidChar) {            throw new Exception(                    "Invalid UTF-8 hex byte '" + c + "'.");        }        return isDigit ? ch - '0' : 10 + ((char) c - 'a') & 0xF;    }    private static String v1_decodeUTF8_function(String s)            throws Exception {        ArrayList<Integer> v = new ArrayList<Integer>();        for (int i = 0; i < s.length(); i++) {            int ch = s.charAt(i);            if (ch == '%') {                int hb = hexToInt(s.charAt(++i));                int lb = hexToInt(s.charAt(++i));                ch = (hb << 4) | lb;            }            v.add(new Integer(ch));        }        int size = v.size();        byte[] bytes = new byte[size];        for (int i = 0; i < size; i++) {            Integer anInt = v.get(i);            bytes[i] = (byte) (anInt.intValue() & 0xFF);        }        try {            return new String(bytes, "UTF-8");        } catch (UnsupportedEncodingException e) {            throw new Exception(                    "Couldn't convert parameter string to UTF-8 string:" + e.getMessage());        }    }    private static String v2_decodeUTF8_function(String s)            throws Exception {        try {            if (s.contains("%")) {                ArrayList<Integer> v = new ArrayList<Integer>();                int length = s.length();                for (int i = 0; i < length; i++) {                    int ch = s.charAt(i);                    if (ch == '%') {                        if (i + 3 > length) {                            throw new Exception(                                    "Incomplete trailing escape (%) pattern");                        }                        try {                            ch = Integer.parseInt(s.substring(i + 1, i + 3), 16);                        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {                            throw new Exception(e.toString());                        }                        if (ch < 0) {                            throw new Exception(                                    "Illegal hex characters in escape (%) pattern - negative value");                        }                        i += 2;                    }                    v.add(new Integer(ch));                }                int size = v.size();                byte[] bytes = new byte[size];                for (int i = 0; i < size; i++) {                    Integer anInt = v.get(i);                    bytes[i] = (byte) (anInt.intValue() & 0xFF);                }                return new String(bytes, "UTF-8");            } else {                return new String(s.getBytes(), "UTF-8");            }        } catch (UnsupportedEncodingException e) {            throw new Exception(                    "Couldn't convert parameter string to UTF-8 string:" + e.getMessage());        }    }    private static String v3_decodeUTF8_function(String s)            throws Exception {        try {            if (s.contains("%")) {                int length = s.length();                ByteBuffer bb = ByteBuffer.allocate(length);                for (int i = 0; i < length; i++) {                    int ch = s.charAt(i);                    if (ch == '%') {                        if (i + 3 > length) {                            throw new Exception(                                    "Incomplete trailing escape (%) pattern");                        }                        try {                            ch = Integer.parseInt(s.substring(i + 1, i + 3), 16);                        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {                            throw new Exception(e.toString());                        }                        if (ch < 0) {                            throw new Exception(                                    "Illegal hex characters in escape (%) pattern - negative value");                        }                        i += 2;                    }                    bb.put((byte) (ch & 0xFF));                }                byte[] bytes = new byte[bb.position()];                System.arraycopy(bb.array(), 0, bytes, 0, bytes.length);                return new String(bytes, "UTF-8");            } else {                return new String(s.getBytes(), "UTF-8");            }        } catch (UnsupportedEncodingException e) {            throw new Exception(                    "Couldn't convert parameter string to UTF-8 string:" + e.getMessage());        }    }    public static void main(String[] args) throws RunnerException {        Options opt = new OptionsBuilder()                .include(".*" + DecodeUTF8.class.getSimpleName() + ".*")                .warmupIterations(5)                .measurementIterations(5)                .forks(1)                .build();        new Runner(opt).run();    }}

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1The comment has nothing to do with concurrency, so CopyOnWriteArrayList is the wrong answer.This is, in fact, the correct Java way to write a loop that needs to delete an object from the collection that it is iterating over.The commented out code could simply be removed.

text: Patch Set 1:Seeing no objections, I'm going to merge this. For the reference, here is the problem this fixes:Create a single form control (like a checkbox) in a Writer document, then in basic, do "xray ThisComponent.DrawPage(0)", and then soffice crashes with (gdb) bt 10 #0  0x00007ffff3b4cd5c in SfxItemSet::Get (this=0x22d2ba0, nWhich=0, bSrchInParent=true) at /home/vmiklos/git/libreoffice/master/svl/source/items/itemset.cxx:1002 #1  0x00007fffd2ecfe3e in SdrObject::GetMergedItem (this=0x22b5a80, nWhich=0) at /home/vmiklos/git/libreoffice/master/svx/source/svdraw/svdobj.cxx:2113 #2  0x00007fffd30aea66 in SvxShape::_getPropertyValue (this=0x2413c58, PropertyName="CharCaseMap") at /home/vmiklos/git/libreoffice/master/svx/source/unodraw/unoshape.cxx:1797 #3  0x00007fffd30ae83c in SvxShape::getPropertyValue (this=0x2413c58, PropertyName="CharCaseMap") at /home/vmiklos/git/libreoffice/master/svx/source/unodraw/unoshape.cxx:1773 #4  0x00007fffd30907ff in SvxShapeControl::getPropertyValue (this=0x2413c50, aPropertyName="CharCaseMap") at /home/vmiklos/git/libreoffice/master/svx/source/unodraw/unoshap2.cxx:898 #5  0x00007fffd73b225a in SwXShape::_getPropAtAggrObj (this=0x23e8b20, _rPropertyName="CharCaseMap") at /home/vmiklos/git/libreoffice/master/sw/source/core/unocore/unodraw.cxx:1753 #6  0x00007fffd73b1b8d in SwXShape::getPropertyValue (this=0x23e8b20, rPropertyName="CharCaseMap") at /home/vmiklos/git/libreoffice/master/sw/source/core/unocore/unodraw.cxx:1701

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1words fail me when describing the evils of image lifecycle management: is it really true that trying to save a non-swapped-in image results in an empty/image / non-save ? simply amazing.More amazing when you consider how much CPU time you can see in the profiles burned loading in and checksumming etc. images just in order to write them out again ;-) [ in their original compressed form of course ] - cf. the performance profiles.OTOH - not loosing images is good; clearly =) Thanks for the fix !
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1words fail me when describing the evils of image lifecycle management: is it really true that trying to save a non-swapped-in image results in an empty/image / non-save ? simply amazing.More amazing when you consider how much CPU time you can see in the profiles burned loading in and checksumming etc. images just in order to write them out again ;-) [ in their original compressed form of course ] - cf. the performance profiles.OTOH - not loosing images is good; clearly =) Thanks for the fix !

text: Patch Set 7:i wonder what is the goal here?it is utterly pointless to build the LO bundled python as "universal" in any way, since the rest of the LO code supports only a single architecture anyway, so there are only downsides, i.e. it is a waste of space.IIRC the only reason why the --enable-universalsdk parameter is used is that it is the _only_ way to get python to build against the SDK, and not random stuff in /usr/include etc; it is somehow tangled up with building universal binaries in python's build system but that is (imho) a deficiency of python's build system.did you see the silly changes to fix that up in external/python3/python-3.3.0-darwin.patch.1?
Text: Patch Set 7:i wonder what is the goal here?it is utterly pointless to build the LO bundled python as "universal" in any way, since the rest of the LO code supports only a single architecture anyway, so there are only downsides, i.e. it is a waste of space.IIRC the only reason why the --enable-universalsdk parameter is used is that it is the _only_ way to get python to build against the SDK, and not random stuff in /usr/include etc; it is somehow tangled up with building universal binaries in python's build system but that is (imho) a deficiency of python's build system.did you see the silly changes to fix that up in external/python3/python-3.3.0-darwin.patch.1?

text: Patch Set 12:ok so 2 things.1/ this patch start to suffer from feature creep.you know have 3 independents changes crammed into it.Let's keep these independent things in independents patches.(the JDK thing is orthogonal to the Python thing, which is orthogonal to the SDK thing)2/ I'm a bit confused by the rapid fire upload of new version.The idea of gerrit is to upload a version when you think it is ready for review... but here you got 7 version in rapid sequence without any review interaction.. and same after version 7...  Is the patch ready for review ? or should I wait for another hour for version n+1 ?iow:In a single patch: do one thing. Upload to gerrit when you think it is ready for review, ie ready, you think, to be merged.Review takes time too.. and every time you upload a new version it essentially invalidate the review done on the previous versionI'm encouraged by your patch.. there are good stuff in there.I'm just trying to adjust the process to make processing these patches easier for all involved :-)
Text: Patch Set 12:ok so 2 things.1/ this patch start to suffer from feature creep.you know have 3 independents changes crammed into it.Let's keep these independent things in independents patches.(the JDK thing is orthogonal to the Python thing, which is orthogonal to the SDK thing)2/ I'm a bit confused by the rapid fire upload of new version.The idea of gerrit is to upload a version when you think it is ready for review... but here you got 7 version in rapid sequence without any review interaction.. and same after version 7...  Is the patch ready for review ? or should I wait for another hour for version n+1 ?iow:In a single patch: do one thing. Upload to gerrit when you think it is ready for review, ie ready, you think, to be merged.Review takes time too.. and every time you upload a new version it essentially invalidate the review done on the previous versionI'm encouraged by your patch.. there are good stuff in there.I'm just trying to adjust the process to make processing these patches easier for all involved :-)

text: Patch Set 1:Miklos: In ww8atr.cxx i have made sure to get the value using GetAuthorField().I have a doubt for authfld.cxxI will undo my changes as you suggested but in SwAuthorityField::ConditionalExpand, GetAuthorField() is called for AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER irrespective of what is passed as eField which i think should be changed.In DocxAttributeOutput::EndField_Impl, ExpandField is called with AUTH_FIELD_TITLE which then calls ConditionalExpand but ConditionalExpand returns OUString as per AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER which is wrong and should be changed.I have the patch ready...Could you please confirm?
Text: Patch Set 1:Miklos: In ww8atr.cxx i have made sure to get the value using GetAuthorField().I have a doubt for authfld.cxxI will undo my changes as you suggested but in SwAuthorityField::ConditionalExpand, GetAuthorField() is called for AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER irrespective of what is passed as eField which i think should be changed.In DocxAttributeOutput::EndField_Impl, ExpandField is called with AUTH_FIELD_TITLE which then calls ConditionalExpand but ConditionalExpand returns OUString as per AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER which is wrong and should be changed.I have the patch ready...Could you please confirm?

text: Patch Set 1:Mkilos:I am making changes in:	 OUString SwAuthorityField::ConditionalExpand(ToxAuthorityField eField) constAs per changes:-sRet += pEntry->GetAuthorField(AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER); will be changed to sRet += pEntry->GetAuthorField(eField);I have calculated the impact of SwAuthorityField::ConditionalExpand:-a)ConditionalExpand is called from OUString SwAuthorityField::Expand() const with argument as AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER so my change in ConditionalExpand will not affect existing behaviour.http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/fields/authfld.cxx#543b)ConditionalExpand is called from OUString SwField::ExpandField(bool const bCached, ToxAuthorityField eField) constwith the argemunt as eField.The eField argument in SwField::ExpandField is a default argument having value AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER only so my change will not affect existing behaviour.http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/fields/fldbas.cxx#397The only possibiliy that is left is what if SwField::ExpandField is called with both the arguments and the second argument is not AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER??I have checked the callers of SwField::ExpandField and came to know that it is called with only one argument and hence second augumrnt will be taken as default so there will not be any issue.The only time SwField::ExpandField is called with two parameters is for Citation only.so i request you to please consider this.Apologies for making you read so much.
Text: OUString SwAuthorityField::ConditionalExpand(ToxAuthorityField eField) constAs per changes:-sRet += pEntry->GetAuthorField(AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER); will be changed to sRet += pEntry->GetAuthorField(eField);I have calculated the impact of SwAuthorityField::ConditionalExpand:-a)ConditionalExpand is called from OUString SwAuthorityField::Expand() const with argument as AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER so my change in ConditionalExpand will not affect existing behaviour.http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/fields/authfld.cxx#543b)ConditionalExpand is called from OUString SwField::ExpandField(bool const bCached, ToxAuthorityField eField) constwith the argemunt as eField.The eField argument in SwField::ExpandField is a default argument having value AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER only so my change will not affect existing behaviour.http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/fields/fldbas.cxx#397The only possibiliy that is left is what if SwField::ExpandField is called with both the arguments and the second argument is not AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER??I have checked the callers of SwField::ExpandField and came to know that it is called with only one argument and hence second augumrnt will be taken as default so there will not be any issue.The only time SwField::ExpandField is called with two parameters is for Citation only.so i request you to please consider this.Apologies for making you read so much."

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1If you add a new uno property, then it should be also documented under offapi. However, I think a bigger problem is that you expose the "has bookmarks" property only to workaround the underlying problem that SwXParagraph::dispose() crashes when it has bookmarks, and it definitely should not.Would it be OK to let SwXParagraph::dispose() remove the bookmarks it has? If so, that could fix the crash. By "has a bookmark", I mean the bookmarks where the start or end position of the bookmark is inside the paragraph.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1If you add a new uno property, then it should be also documented under offapi. However, I think a bigger problem is that you expose the "has bookmarks" property only to workaround the underlying problem that SwXParagraph::dispose() crashes when it has bookmarks, and it definitely should not.Would it be OK to let SwXParagraph::dispose() remove the bookmarks it has? If so, that could fix the crash. By "has a bookmark", I mean the bookmarks where the start or end position of the bookmark is inside the paragraph.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1The main q is if the draw uno api should allow undo. Looking at the writer one it does, so I reckon that's reasonable. And the draw modified thing is hooked off if there is anything in the undo stack.But I think we should honour IsUndoEnabled (especially for e.g. the document load case where undo should be disabled) and I think CreateUndoDeleteObject is the more appropiate undo action rather than CreateUndoRemoveObject.I'll try this myself and see if it works out
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1The main q is if the draw uno api should allow undo. Looking at the writer one it does, so I reckon that's reasonable. And the draw modified thing is hooked off if there is anything in the undo stack.But I think we should honour IsUndoEnabled (especially for e.g. the document load case where undo should be disabled) and I think CreateUndoDeleteObject is the more appropiate undo action rather than CreateUndoRemoveObject.I'll try this myself and see if it works out

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I am sorry - but this is not the right approach in this case :-(As you can see, the class SwpHstry is there only to re-define the destructor so that it iterates over the content, and destructs it.The right solution here is to move the SwpHstry::~SwpHstry()'s functionality to SwHistory::~SwHistory() [ie. that ~SwHistory() does the descruction], and change the type of m_SwpHstry from SwpHstry directly to std::vector<SwHistoryHint*>, and kill the SwHstry class for good.I am sorry for this - the bug 75757 is really a more advanced one, it is not an easy Easy Hack :-(

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1For include files in the stable URE interface (include/salhelper/*), this change breaks the ABI and is wrong.For other "widely seen" include files (i.e., include/*) it could be debatable whether to prefer stability or performance, but is probably OK to prefer performance, given our relatively short build times and high flux anyway.But applying the optimization to trivial assignment ops (e.g., include/vmaccess/virtualmachine.hxx) looks odd.  If done at all, those assignment ops should arguably be better left implicitly declared.  (The rationale for the non-inline definition of all those exception classes' special functions is to avoid proliferation of weak vtables.)  Maybe the best thing would be to fix inlinesimpleaccessmethods.cxx to not trigger on "return *this;".(And, as a nitpick, "methods" is not a term of C++; even if Clang internals happily use it, too.)
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1For include files in the stable URE interface (include/salhelper/*), this change breaks the ABI and is wrong.For other "widely seen" include files (i.e., include/*) it could be debatable whether to prefer stability or performance, but is probably OK to prefer performance, given our relatively short build times and high flux anyway.But applying the optimization to trivial assignment ops (e.g., include/vmaccess/virtualmachine.hxx) looks odd.  If done at all, those assignment ops should arguably be better left implicitly declared.  (The rationale for the non-inline definition of all those exception classes' special functions is to avoid proliferation of weak vtables.)  Maybe the best thing would be to fix inlinesimpleaccessmethods.cxx to not trigger on "return *this;".(And, as a nitpick, "methods" is not a term of C++; even if Clang internals happily use it, too.)

text: Patch Set 2:The commit had to be reverted for now, because SAL_WARN_IF is not available in C code, only in C++.The best approach to revive the patch would probably be to in a first patch convert those files from C to C++ as a prerequisite (which most of the time means just renaming the files to .cxx extension and moving them from gb_Library_add_cobjects to gb_Library_add_exception_objects in sal/Library_sal.mk), and then redo the OSL_ASSERT -> SAL_WARN_IF changes.However, you should always make sure your changes build OK locally before you upload them.  These changes are to Windows-only code, so if you are not developing on Windows, it is probably best to look for another easy hack for now.
Text: Patch Set 2:The commit had to be reverted for now, because SAL_WARN_IF is not available in C code, only in C++.The best approach to revive the patch would probably be to in a first patch convert those files from C to C++ as a prerequisite (which most of the time means just renaming the files to .cxx extension and moving them from gb_Library_add_cobjects to gb_Library_add_exception_objects in sal/Library_sal.mk), and then redo the OSL_ASSERT -> SAL_WARN_IF changes.However, you should always make sure your changes build OK locally before you upload them.  These changes are to Windows-only code, so if you are not developing on Windows, it is probably best to look for another easy hack for now.

text: Patch Set 2:First, thanks for working on this.I am sorry, I could not test the patch easily because I do not longer work on LO and do not have the build environment at hands. So, I just react to the comments.If this patch causes that Draw behaves different way when pasting from Writer and Draw then it is even less intuitive that the previous behavior and I suggest to revert it.IMHO, it should not matter where you paste from. Also all LO appications should handle the pasting the same way.When I think about it, the confusion might be in the definition of selected object. If you select part of text in Writer and paste something, the selected text is overwritten, so writer behaves the same way as Draw.The problem is that in Writer, if no test is selected, the cursor is somewhere between two characters and pasted text is added. No text is selected most of the time when you write a text. You need to do explict action (select the text) to overwrite it.In draw, the last added or edited object is always selected, so most of the time some object is selected. This causes that the last object is overwritten when pasting. You need to do explicit action (deselect the object) to avoid overwriting.To be honest I am not sure how to solve this.PS: I am sorry if I added the comment a wrong way. I am not familiar with the current Gerrint interface. I did not find any way how to replay any existing comment.
Text: Patch Set 2:First, thanks for working on this.I am sorry, I could not test the patch easily because I do not longer work on LO and do not have the build environment at hands. Also all LO appications should handle the pasting the same way.When I think about it, the confusion might be in the definition of selected object. If you select part of text in Writer and paste something, the selected text is overwritten, so writer behaves the same way as Draw.The problem is that in Writer, if no test is selected, the cursor is somewhere between two characters and pasted text is added. No text is selected most of the time when you write a text. You need to do explict action (select the text) to overwrite it.In draw, the last added or edited object is always selected, so most of the time some object is selected. This causes that the last object is overwritten when pasting. You need to do explicit action (deselect the object) to avoid overwriting.To be honest I am not sure how to solve this.PS: I am sorry if I added the comment a wrong way. I am not familiar with the current Gerrint interface. I did not find any way how to replay any existing comment.

text: Patch Set 4:> I think the original intention was to suggest functions from the MRU list first for partial matches; just to say.. we're giving that up by removing the code.Actually we had already given that up when we switched the container used by pFormulaData from whatever it was previously to std::set. ;-)  So, removal of that here won't change it.  I think this code did what was intended only with the old container which was semi-array and semi-associative container...  Anyway, losing that is probably not such a big deal (since it was gone already in the past several releases and nobody seems to have noticed).It's good to know the original intention though.
Text: Patch Set 4:> I think the original intention was to suggest functions from the MRU list first for partial matches; just to say.. we're giving that up by removing the code.Actually we had already given that up when we switched the container used by pFormulaData from whatever it was previously to std::set. ;-)  So, removal of that here won't change it. text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1Please keep OSL_POSTCOND in osl/diagnose.h for now.  I would much prefer to remove all that deprecated functionality of osl/diagnose.h in one single step once all of it is unused in the LO code base, instead of doing a number of piecemeal incompatible API changes there.
Text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1Please keep OSL_POSTCOND in osl/diagnose.h for now.  I would much prefer to remove all that deprecated functionality of osl/diagnose.h in one single step once all of it is unused in the LO code base, instead of doing a number of piecemeal incompatible API changes there.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1osl/diagnose.h is part of the stable URE interface and its contents must generally not be changed incompatibly.  I would prefer it to wait until all of the remaining osl/diagnose.h functionality is no longer used, and only then remove all of osl/diagnose.h wholesale.  (It has been marked deprecated for some time now, so it should be OK to eventually remove it, with a proper "[API CHANGE]" commit message and all.)
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1osl/diagnose.h is part of the stable URE interface and its contents must generally not be changed incompatibly. text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1osl/diagnose.h is part of the stable URE interface and its contents must generally not be changed incompatibly. I would prefer it to wait until all of the remaining osl/diagnose.h functionality is no longer used, and only then remove all of osl/diagnose.h wholesale. (It has been marked deprecated for some time now, so it should be OK to eventually remove it, with a proper "[API CHANGE]" commit message and all.)

text: Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1The use of AC_CHECK_LIB(c, ...) to look for a function in the normal C library that the compiler uses is bogus. (For instance, nothing guarantees that the C library is called "c". ) There is AC_CHECK_FUNCS for that, and it automatically sets the corresponding HAVE_FOO variables, no need to do it explicitly. (The existing use of AC_CHECK_FUNCS in configure.ac is slightly weird in that sense.) Anyway, I don't see how you would make those HAVE_FOO things you add propagate to the compilations?Also, I don't think it can be strictly correct to assume that a non-standard function like me malign, if it happens to exist, would have the semantics the code expects. Better to let the code that explicitly uses it explicitly just for Android be as is, IMHO. (The strictly correct thing would be to actually run a test during the configury to find out what memalign, does, if it exists. But that would be quite overkill, LO is not supposed to be portable to all possible and impossible OSes anyway, and besides, for cross-compilations (like for Android), such tests couldn't be run at configure time anyway.
Text: Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1The use of AC_CHECK_LIB(c, ...) to look for a function in the normal C library that the compiler uses is bogus. (For instance, nothing guarantees that the C library is called "c". ) There is AC_CHECK_FUNCS for that, and it automatically sets the corresponding HAVE_FOO variables, no need to do it explicitly. (The existing use of AC_CHECK_FUNCS in configure.ac is slightly weird in that sense.) Anyway, I don't see how you would make those HAVE_FOO things you add propagate to the compilations?Also, I don't think it can be strictly correct to assume that a non-standard function like me malign, if it happens to exist, would have the semantics the code expects. Better to let the code that explicitly uses it explicitly just for Android be as is, IMHO. (The strictly correct thing would be to actually run a test during the configury to find out what memalign, does, if it exists. But that would be quite overkill, LO is not supposed to be portable to all possible and impossible OSes anyway, and besides, for cross-compilations (like for Android), such tests couldn't be run at configure time anyway.

text: Patch Set 9:The 'idea' when talking about patch designed ot re-introduce backward compat to a deprecated platform is1/ do not break other platform code2/ do no shift the burden on maintenance back onto other platforms3/ keep it clear that whatever hack is needed is for that purpose, so that we can clean it up easily later.
Text: Patch Set 9:The 'idea' when talking about patch designed ot re-introduce backward compat to a deprecated platform is1/ do not break other platform code2/ do no shift the burden on maintenance back onto other platforms3/ keep it clear that whatever hack is needed is for that purpose, so that we can clean it up easily later.

text: Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1I still don't see how you expect HAVE_POSIX_MEMALIGN and HAVE_MEMALIGN to propagate to the compilations. (Of course, you don't notice if/that they don't in your compilations, as you care only for the cases where they are not defined.)The OOo/LO codebase is full of delusions of grandeur and misleading names for various bits and pieces. Don't take the "system abstraction layer" expansion of the "sal" acronym too literally.Of course want it to be easy to remove your code at some point. This codebase is 20 years old now, and I expect (fear?) that it will be around after 20 years still, too. Do even you expect PowerPC Macs and OS X 10.5 to be around any more at that point in time?

(Of course, you don't notice if/that they don't in your compilations, as you care only for the cases where they are not defined.)The OOo/LO codebase is full of delusions of grandeur and misleading names for various bits and pieces. Don't take the "system abstraction layer" expansion of the "sal" acronym too literally.Of course want it to be easy to remove your code at some point. This codebase is 20 years old now, and I expect (fear?) that it will be around after 20 years still, too. Do even you expect PowerPC Macs and OS X 10.5 to be around any more at that point in time?

text: Patch Set 11:It is misleading to claim that the code would "blindly guess" the availability of posix_memalign() (and others). The LibreOffice code is *not* portable to arbitrary platforms. We *know* what it is portable to. We depend on totally machine- and OS-dependent assembler code, for chrissake. We enumerate the platforms it has been ported to in the configure file (and elsewhere). Thus I think it does not make things any worse to not suddenly start pretending we are oh so portable and must do all the autoconf way for this one thing.
Text: Patch Set 11:It is misleading to claim that the code would "blindly guess" the availability of posix_memalign() (and others). The LibreOffice code is *not* portable to arbitrary platforms. We *know* what it is portable to. We depend on totally machine- and OS-dependent assembler code, for chrissake. We enumerate the platforms it has been ported to in the configure file (and elsewhere). Thus I think it does not make things any worse to not suddenly start pretending we are oh so portable and must do all the autoconf way for this one thing.

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1I don't think this is good.  If we offer a general-purpose, low-level rtl_allocateAlignedMemory that promises to return aligned memory, it should not be able to silently return non-aligned memory.  (If you're confident that it is OK for your 10.5 port to silently return non-aligned memory, then please make this conditional exactly on that 10.5 port.)
Text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1I don't think this is good.  If we offer a general-purpose, low-level rtl_allocateAlignedMemory that promises to return aligned memory, it should not be able to silently return non-aligned memory.  (If you're confident that it is OK for your 10.5 port to silently return non-aligned memory, then please make this conditional exactly on that 10.5 port.)

text: Patch Set 3:"can you please suggest solution for Darwin/OSX where are no posix_memalign nor memalign?"  Recent OS X does have posix_memalign, so it apparently only is a problem for the 10.5 port.  As I wrote, "If you're confident that it is OK for your 10.5 port [...], then please make this conditional exactly on that 10.5 port," i.e., I'd suggest using the usual MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED < 1060 instead of a newly introduced HAVE_POSIX_MEMALIGN."Also, don't forget that there're another platforms where posix_memalign is not available."  Which relevant ones are that?  And they potentially offer some similar functionality already that we could use, like in the Android case."When this memory.c has been introduced? Why? For what purpose?"  See git log.
Text: Patch Set 3:"can you please suggest solution for Darwin/OSX where are no posix_memalign nor memalign?"  Recent OS X does have posix_memalign, so it apparently only is a problem for the 10.5 port.  As I wrote, "If you're confident that it is OK for your 10.5 port [...], then please make this conditional exactly on that 10.5 port," i.e., I'd suggest using the usual MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED < 1060 instead of a newly introduced HAVE_POSIX_MEMALIGN."Also, don't forget that there're another platforms where posix_memalign is not available."  Which relevant ones are that?  And they potentially offer some similar functionality already that we could use, like in the Android case."When this memory.c has been introduced? Why? For what purpose?"  See git log.

text: Patch Set 3:doug: "Also, don't forget that there're another platforms where posix_memalign is not available."this is in unx/*Unixes that are not Posix are not really a concern these days.Windows, the usual offender in that field, _has_ a _aligned_mallocso, no none of the supported platform have issues with that..Furthermore, jsut because something is 16 bytes aligned, does not make it conformant to memalign... of course malloc return a value that is addressable so typically at least a multiple of sizeof(void*)but posix_memalign is meant to deal with : I need page-aligned memory and this sort of things.
Text: Patch Set 3:doug: "Also, don't forget that there're another platforms where posix_memalign is not available."this is in unx/*Unixes that are not Posix are not really a concern these days.Windows, the usual offender in that field, _has_ a _aligned_mallocso, no none of the supported platform have issues with that..Furthermore, jsut because something is 16 bytes aligned, does not make it conformant to memalign... of course malloc return a value that is addressable so typically at least a multiple of sizeof(void*)but posix_memalign is meant to deal with : I need page-aligned memory and this sort of things.

text: Patch Set 4:the revised patches were still using the view's dimension as reference for computing the position of the pointer. With the additional spacing elements and weights it might have matched the actual size of the preview image close enough, but on my device with different aspect ration it was still way off. So patch#4 solves this by computing the actual display size of the image - admittedly in a somewhat awkward way. Also get rid of the then unnecessary layouts/views.

text: Patch Set 1:yes i had the same patch a year ago...then i realized that actually the particular bugdoc had regressed in LO and loops again, perhaps for the same reason and perhaps for a different reason.iirc it started looping again before bibisect, so a pain to track down.i'm not sure if reverting a bugfix because some other (potentially unrelated) regression produces the same superficial symptoms is a good idea.the question that i would like answered before merging this is, are there documents _other_ than the particular bugdoc that will loop with this revert but don't loop currently?
