text: Patch Set 1:Two notes:-It seems that the unit test for ISO.CEILING does not work because of a problem with the xlsx file. Cell B10 contains ISO.CEILING(..), where _xlfn.ISO.CEILING(...) is expected. That's why the unit test for this function is still switched off.-I use different help-ids for CEILINg.PRECISE and ISO.CEILING. They could be identical, but then the help-writers must know that both functions share the same help-id.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Looks good to me.BTW, we have a bit of a mess with the grid line options. This particular one is a global gridline option, but we also have a per-sheet grid line show/hide options as well.  To make it more complicated, we've introduced additional gridline option of whether to draw them above or below cell backgrounds which unfortunately was made to the global gridline option.  So, the UI for all these grid line options are currently not ideal.All of this is unrelated to this fix, but I thought I'd mention.At some point I'd like us to get all this mess squared out....
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Looks good to me.BTW, we have a bit of a mess with the grid line options. This particular one is a global gridline option, but we also have a per-sheet grid line show/hide options as well.  To make it more complicated, we've introduced additional gridline option of whether to draw them above or below cell backgrounds which unfortunately was made to the global gridline option.  So, the UI for all these grid line options are currently not ideal.All of this is unrelated to this fix, but I thought I'd mention.At some point I'd like us to get all this mess squared out....

text: Patch Set 1:Hi Kendy,Thanks for the review. I'm still building my understanding on these 'simple' fixes... but may have got it wrong!Agreed, the .uno: ref exists, but doesn't seem to be exposed on the UI side at all? Looking into original issue i#80528 comments and spec, it seems some options had to be left for supporting import filters... Since these are removed from the core Galaxy theme for a few years (so custom themes wouldn't get packed with these icons anyway), I think it's safe to remove...
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Kendy,Thanks for the review. I'm still building my understanding on these 'simple' fixes... but may have got it wrong!Agreed, the .uno: ref exists, but doesn't seem to be exposed on the UI side at all? Looking into original issue i#80528 comments and spec, it seems some options had to be left for supporting import filters... Since these are removed from the core Galaxy theme for a few years (so custom themes wouldn't get packed with these icons anyway), I think it's safe to remove...

text: Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1This isn't going to fly I believe. e.g.pGraphics /*= oldgraphics*/pGraphics = GetGraphics() becomesif (AcquireGraphics())    pGraphics = GetGraphics()so if we couldn't acquire graphics we have pGraphics pointing to the oldone, not NULL, so the expectations of the code have changed and I'm unconvinced that every case is handled correctly. Far simpler and safer would be to just rename GetGraphics to AcquireGraphics, which solves the problem and is safer.Also, one commit for one problem, mixing indendation changes, sal_Bool to bool and extra problems in one patch is making it very hard to unpick what's going on in any given commit.Leave this patch with me a while and I'll turn it into a GetGraphics->AcquireGraphics change and split out some of the additional bits in separate commits.
Text: Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1This isn't going to fly I believe. e.g.pGraphics /*= oldgraphics*/pGraphics = GetGraphics() becomesif (AcquireGraphics())    pGraphics = GetGraphics()so if we couldn't acquire graphics we have pGraphics pointing to the oldone, not NULL, so the expectations of the code have changed and I'm unconvinced that every case is handled correctly. Far simpler and safer would be to just rename GetGraphics to AcquireGraphics, which solves the problem and is safer.Also, one commit for one problem, mixing indendation changes, sal_Bool to bool and extra problems in one patch is making it very hard to unpick what's going on in any given commit.Leave this patch with me a while and I'll turn it into a GetGraphics->AcquireGraphics change and split out some of the additional bits in separate commits.

text: Patch Set 1: Verified-1Thanks for the patch Radu, but unfortunately it doesn't fix the issue.Some lines below your patch you will find this code that sets the proper ATK role for a heading bar to UNO heading role:        roleMap[accessibility::AccessibleRole::HEADING] = registerRole("heading");Actually, if you open a document that contains some heading text, it gets the proper role, but the problem comes when you transform a paragraph into a heading: the role changes paragraph->heading and vice-versa aren't being properly communicated. I'm working on a patch to fix that right now :)

I'm working on a patch to fix that right now :)

text: Patch Set 3:Hi Kendy,> I wonder - do we have to introduce a new flag?Of course. In some case it is useful to differentiate focusing caused by F6 or TAB. e.g. in BackingWindow::GetFocus(), GETFOCUS_F6 + !GETFOCUS_FORWARD -> grab focus to thumbnailview while GETFOCUS_TAB -> nothing> Also about removing if(GETFOCUS_TAB & GetGetFocusFlags()) - what now happens when you click there; won't it lead to extra focusing and unfocusing? Or is that unrelated?Yes, you are right. I will revert this change and will add a more explicit solution which will select item just when it is actually necessary. Unfortunately ImplGrabFocus() can't be used outside vcl, which would be a simple way (e.g. using ImplGrabFocus(GETFOCUS_F6) inside BackingWindow too).> The rest is nitpicking :-) - if we really need GETFOCUS_F6, it should be 0x0800, not 0x1000.Are you sure? I just look these GETFOCUS_ flags are defined in this way leaving out 0x0008, 0x0080 and I thought maybe somewhere these flags are used in a special way (e.g. some special bit operation) which makes it necessary.> PreNotify() should return true's, not 1's.Oh, yes. This is the result of new bool improvements. :)
Text: Patch Set 3:Hi Kendy,> I wonder - do we have to introduce a new flag?Of course. In some case it is useful to differentiate focusing caused by F6 or TAB. e.g. in BackingWindow::GetFocus(), GETFOCUS_F6 + !GETFOCUS_FORWARD -> grab focus to thumbnailview while GETFOCUS_TAB -> nothing> Also about removing if(GETFOCUS_TAB & GetGetFocusFlags()) - what now happens when you click there; won't it lead to extra focusing and unfocusing? Or is that unrelated?Yes, you are right. I will revert this change and will add a more explicit solution which will select item just when it is actually necessary. Unfortunately ImplGrabFocus() can't be used outside vcl, which would be a simple way (e.g. using ImplGrabFocus(GETFOCUS_F6) inside BackingWindow too).> The rest is nitpicking :-) - if we really need GETFOCUS_F6, it should be 0x0800, not 0x1000.Are you sure? I just look these GETFOCUS_ flags are defined in this way leaving out 0x0008, 0x0080 and I thought maybe somewhere these flags are used in a special way (e.g. some special bit operation) which makes it necessary.> PreNotify() should return true's, not 1's.Oh, yes. This is the result of new bool improvements. :)

text: Patch Set 3:>> Also about removing if(GETFOCUS_TAB & GetGetFocusFlags()) - what now happens when you click there; won't it lead to extra focusing and unfocusing? Or is that unrelated?> Yes, you are right. I will revert this change and will add a more explicit solution which will select item just when it is actually necessary. Unfortunately ImplGrabFocus() can't be used outside vcl, which would be a simple way (e.g. using ImplGrabFocus(GETFOCUS_F6) inside BackingWindow too).I was wrong. It seems mouse click doesn't lead to GetFocus() call (maybe that's why there is no a GETFOCUS_MOUSE flag?) so for simplicity I keep at the first version (select first item in all case when GetFocus is called).

text: Patch Set 1:The Excel function PERCENTRANK.EXC complies with ODF1.2, but calc's PERCENTRANK doesn't (missing 3rd optional argument significance).Would this be a good moment to upgrade the current PERCENTRANK function to ODF1.2? Or would this introduce compatibilty problems as with CEILING and FLOOR?
Text: Patch Set 1:The Excel function PERCENTRANK.EXC complies with ODF1.2, but calc's PERCENTRANK doesn't (missing 3rd optional argument significance).Would this be a good moment to upgrade the current PERCENTRANK function to ODF1.2? Or would this introduce compatibilty problems as with CEILING and FLOOR?

text: Patch Set 2:To answer this: > The Excel function PERCENTRANK.EXC complies with ODF1.2, but calc's > PERCENTRANK doesn't (missing 3rd optional argument significance). Would > this be a good moment to upgrade the current PERCENTRANK function to > ODF1.2? Or would this introduce compatibilty problems as with CEILING > and FLOOR?A new optional (!) parameter shouldn't be a problem. Old versions can'tprocess that if given and would return an error, but that's something wehave to live with and is the same as a new function introduced.
Text: Patch Set 2:To answer this: > The Excel function PERCENTRANK.EXC complies with ODF1.2, but calc's > PERCENTRANK doesn't (missing 3rd optional argument significance). Would > this be a good moment to upgrade the current PERCENTRANK function to > ODF1.2? Or would this introduce compatibilty problems as with CEILING > and FLOOR?A new optional (!) parameter shouldn't be a problem. Old versions can'tprocess that if given and would return an error, but that's something wehave to live with and is the same as a new function introduced.

text: Patch Set 2:I did three changes:(1) JobExecutor did not implement XComponent, so would not be notified pre-exit by a component context/service manager dispose, but would only release its resources during atexit, with all the dreaded consequences.  It now implements XComponent (via cppu::WeakComponentImplHelper4, which unfortunately required some more changes, due to framework's ill tendency to roll everything its own).(2) The "Prior to..." comment should only come after the descriptive first sentence in the documentation of theJobExecutor.idl.(3) No idea what that OOo.jcs file is exactly, but it is binary and I at least routinely ignore it when doing any sort of mass changes, so reverted that again.
Text: Patch Set 2:I did three changes:(1) JobExecutor did not implement XComponent, so would not be notified pre-exit by a component context/service manager dispose, but would only release its resources during atexit, with all the dreaded consequences.  It now implements XComponent (via cppu::WeakComponentImplHelper4, which unfortunately required some more changes, due to framework's ill tendency to roll everything its own).(2) The "Prior to..." comment should only come after the descriptive first sentence in the documentation of theJobExecutor.idl.(3) No idea what that OOo.jcs file is exactly, but it is binary and I at least routinely ignore it when doing any sort of mass changes, so reverted that again.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Not sure I agree here. As this macro clearly isn't used anywhere else than in that one source file, why should it be defined in a "public" header in include/vcl? text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergeI still donÔÇÖt see any sense in removing it. It solves a couple of issues: it checks adapter existence before enabling / disabling it instead of checking everywhere, it should help to acquire adapter the proper way on higher platforms [1] instead of duplicating code everywhere. Plus you instantiate property directly but I was trying to init them in constructors only to avoid mess. Null checks is just element of style so I can close my eyes on this part.Anyway my vote seems to be ignored at all. [1]:https://developer.android.com/reference/android/bluetooth/BluetoothAdapter.html
Text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergeI still don脭脟脰t see any sense in removing it. It solves a couple of issues: it checks adapter existence before enabling / disabling it instead of checking everywhere, it should help to acquire adapter the proper way on higher platforms [1] instead of duplicating code everywhere. Plus you instantiate property directly but I was trying to init them in constructors only to avoid mess. Null checks is just element of style so I can close my eyes on this part.Anyway my vote seems to be ignored at all. [1]:https://developer.android.com/reference/android/bluetooth/BluetoothAdapter.html

text: Patch Set 1:> it checks adapter existence before enabling / disabling it > instead of checking everywhere,1st of all that's not true. You're just wrapping the check into a function call, so that decision is just hidden behind a function and still executed everytime, just hidden between two or three levels of indirection. This makes the code harder to understand, harder to get into for newcomers.Newcomers read Android's api to understand what's going on and are thrown off by wrappers that they have to track through different files.2nd enabling/disabling the adapter is only triggered/used once each. So this is far from "everywhere".3rd your (I assume it is yours, since you're defending it so much) code acquires the adapter way more often than the changed code, where once it is acquired, it is stored in the member variable(s). The old code always calls getDefaultAdapter(), take for example the getPairingDeviceName() function.1st time when calling isAvailable, that indirects to getAdapter that in turn calls getDefaultAdapter.2nd time in the check for a device name (uses getAdapter that indirects to getDefaultAdapter3rd time when returning the name.And this for each Bluetooth device that is found. > it should help to acquire adapter the proper way on  > higher platforms [1] instead of duplicating code everywhere.Again you're making it hard for me to take your argumentation seriously. This has been mentioned in the previous comments already. A) There's absolutely no reason to introduce runtime-version checks. This would not only complicate the code, but more importantly doing test on the various codepaths. I would personally object any change that introduces a runtime version check without actual need for it. If docs would say: function will be removed in next version of Android, that would be a different story. But for the foreseeable future, the functionality will remain the same, B) Even when you want to acquire the adapter depending on the version, then *one single public static method* is enough to do this, no need for a whole class that wraps's the BluetoothAdapter's API. Apart from acquiring the actual adapter, there are absolutely no changes in the API. > Plus you instantiate property directlynot sure what you mean with property, I guess calling the actual API on the adapter? Yes, indeed I do it directly, since I believe in KISS - and I cannot think of anything simpler than just calling the function that is properly documented in the API docs, that every Android developer having dealt with BT already knows... >  but I was trying to init them in constructors only to > avoid mess.I absolutely cannot follow where. The Operator-wrapper's constructor is empty. And for launching the activities, you use intents, not constructors. I cannot find any occurrence where you'd pass the adapter in a constructor. (and also don't see a benefit), as it's static and can just be obtained on a if-needed basis. > Null checks is just element of style so I can close my > eyes on this part.I absolutely don't understand this comment either. You have *plenty* of null checks in the operator and in other places of the code, and they are the most straightforward/only way to check whether something is null. It also makes it immediately clear to the person reading the code that whatever is bound to the check won't happen because that adapter is null.  > Anyway my vote seems to be ignored at all.It is not that it is ignored, just that I have a completely different view on this topic. I want the code to be straightforward, easy to understand by people not familiar with it (just like I was before writing this patch. I neither had a take at android development, let alone the remote). I find all those redirections highly irritating. KISS should be the prime goal here. I see no need to split a function that happily fits on my small screen (i.e. less than 30 lines) if the parts that it is split into are not reusable/not used anywhere else.I also see absolutely no point in creating a wrapper to one-line function calls.If the Operator-wrapper would do more stuff that things that can be put into a single 80-column-line, then I'd be happy to keep that functionality, but all it has is a) a "renamed" null-check. A function that just returns the value of a comparison != null.and on top of that it unnecessarily requires the adapter anew. (something that can probably be optimized out by the compiler/the runtime, but still something I consider unnecessary. b) a "enable" function, that just calls the API function of the same name(wrapped along with the useless isAvailable check that you very likely already had checked before even trying to enable the adapter) c) a "disable" function where the same remarks as for the enable function apply, d) the getAdapter wrapper, that does nothing but call the getDefaultAdapter() API function.I see that this is the most debatable, and the one that is the only one that has at least a minimalistic reason to exist.But as written earlier: I see absolutely no reason why want to have runtime version checks if the code happily runs on the newest devices unchanged. After all we even use compatibility/support libraries to support old versions, why would you jeopardize this by explicitly targeting newer versions with such a runtime check?After all all that changes is the way to get a BlueToothAdapter object, nothing else. If newer Android version had a different Bluetooth api, then this would be a completely different story (but then again probably handled by the support libraries, so nothing one would have to deal with manually).And after all: I wrote a patch that fixes stuff. So that's why I in this case value my own opinion higher than yours (cynicism, don't take too seriously). I'm aware that I'm stepping on your toes now, and I'm sorry for that. But I won't change my opinion on this because of that.* my changes fix a couple of bugs* no previous functionality is lost* the wrapper did only most trivial stuffIn my opinion it makes the code much easier to grasp without all that redirection. Quoting from the Zen of Python (that applies here as well): [ÔÇª] Explicit is better than implicit. Simple is better than complex. [ÔÇª] Flat is better than nested. [ÔÇª] Readability counts. [ÔÇª]I hope the long response shows that I'm not simply ignoring your opinion, just that I don't share it.I'd rather add other missing features (like locking screen orientation and adding the "laser-pointer" feature) than arguing about this.

text: Patch Set 1:Thanks for the comment re the telling function names that are no longer preserved - this is true, however in later commits that handling gets revamped anyway, for example instead of all that was-bt-enabled stuff there is then only a member variable "disableBTOnQuit that keeps the state and has a telling name:private static final BluetoothAdapter btAdapter = BluetoothAdapter.getDefaultAdapter();private static boolean disableBTOnQuit = btAdapter != null && !btAdapter.isEnabled();all the other state-saving/retrieval is moot that way, and the disabling of BT reduces toif (isFinishing() && disableBTOnQuit) { btAdapter.disable();}Similar for the setup of the viewpager/the tabs.I only created the split commits because I was asked to provide atomic commits - but that also means I'm touching parts of the code multiple other times in the later patches.

text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergePlease try to provide atomic changes instead of all-in-one commit.First, you are changing minimum SDK version we are not interested in ÔÇö┬áthere is a sweet ICS future, it is more wise to move forward instead of backward. Second, changing target SDK should be supported via build servers to not fail. Third, we are not interested at moment in switching from ABS to ABC because LO Android port uses ABS anyway and, again, this should be supported via build servers. Fourth, SettingsActivity after your change wouldnÔÇÖt have an action bar on pre-Honeycomb versions.I agree with you that ABS ÔåÆ ABC migration makes sense but there is a *really low* percentage of users using Gingerbread. It makes a very little sense for me to swap dependencies for things that just work for platform version which *potentially* could be dropped.

text: Patch Set 1:> Please try to provide atomic changes instead of all-in-one commit.This is an atomic commit. Splitting that up would result in unbuildable project/mix of abs and android support lib. Not what you want.And did you even bother to look at the patch? All those changes are trivial, basically replacing "Sherlock" with "Compat" or similar> First, you are changing minimum SDK version we are not interested in ÔÇö there is a sweet ICS future, it is more wise to move forward instead of backward.Changing the minimum version doesn't impact use of new ICS features at all. That's what the support libraries are for. ActionBarSherlock previously, and the default android support library in the proposal.You fail to mention what ICS features are lost by that, so please elaborate. And of course one doesn't need to lower it - but why artificially limiting the usable devices when there is no reason?> Second, changing target SDK should be supported via build servers to not fail.No idea what you mean by that. Target SDK is the version that is definitely supported, i.e. in this case the version that runs on a device I personally own, did personally test with. But again, no biggie to leave that at present values.> Third, we are not interested at moment in switching from ABS to ABCWho is "we"?> because LO Android port uses ABS anyway and,How is the LO Android port related to the Impress Remote? The remote(s) have already been decoupled translation wise, release-schedule wise, so I fail to see how the remote is bound to the Android port.Again the changes are small, the android support libraries stack up easily to support newer features.You mentioned that newer versions have nice features and you'd rather drop support for older devices: using the android support libs makes that easy. In Fact the ABS one already used the v4 support library itself.> again, this should be supported via build servers.And again no idea what you mean by that. If you mean it should be buildable by ant/using the makefiles and not by using Eclipse, you should see that I also updated the makefile.I didn't bother to add a check whether the v7 support library has been installed on the machine, as it is not built as part of LO anyway, and the error message will be pretty obvious in that case....If you insist, I can also add configure checks. Or do the easy way as with the abs and check it into the repo.> Fourth, SettingsActivity after your change wouldnÔÇÖt have an action bar on pre-Honeycomb versions.It will.> I agree with you that ABS ÔåÆ ABC migration makes sense but there is a *really low* percentage of users using Gingerbread.I didn't change it because I wanted to lower the minimumSDK, that was just the result of the lint check that this is the minimum that the code uses.> It makes a very little sense for me to swap dependencies for things that just work for platform version which *potentially* could be dropped.I don't care about the minimum SDK, so don't fixate on that.  I did swap dependencies for the contrary, to make it easier to extend later with new features. Even the author of the ABS wrote that ABS has done its job, that with the android support lib v7 there is no reason to use ABS anymore. That of course doesn't mean one should swap components, never change a running system yadda,yadda, but the remote is small, the change as a whole is small, so it is (IMHO) a sensible thing to do.You also state on the one-hand pre honeycomb (aka gingerbread) would look different, but on the other hand you're willing to just drop support for gingerbread completely. So I fail to see how this then is a concern regarding this patch.

text: Patch Set 1:In general looks good to me :)The only problems I can see are with the project.properties:1.Presumably we want to bump the target to 17 here?2.Using ${sdk.dir} doesn't work with eclipse -- *maybe* it's worth having a ../v7-appcompat instead, and adding the project to the git repo, but ultimately I suspect we want to migrate from having ant OR eclipse, to using gradle which apparently uses exactly the same build no matter whether you are in an ide or not (but I haven't looked into the details so can't confirm how this works).Sorry, I can't easily quote previous reviews for some reason, but here are my view on the other issues:* API versions:> but there is a *really low* percentage of users using Gingerbreadas discussed on IRC and possibly the ML a few times, we want to support the vast majority of Android devices, that means at least API 10, and nothing wrong with going lower if we don't lose features (see http://developer.android.com/about/dashboards/index.html to see that API 10 is still about 30% of the market)* ABS:Also been discussed on IRC, we specifically want to get rid of ABS, both for the remote and for the main android app in order to reduce complexity & maintenance -- having ABS in the way is somewhat of a blocker for splitting the Impress Remote repo out, or would alternatively result in duplication between repos...Yes, we need to update the build guide, but the new procedure is simply different and not more complicated.* Build servers:- That's up to the tb maintainers to upgrade (same as the previous comment on installing the correct lib), not really an issue -- there is going to be significant change anyway when the repo is split, so worst case the tbs might be disabled for a short time, but they aren't hugely important for the remote.
Text: Patch Set 1:In general looks good to me :)The only problems I can see are with the project.properties:1.Presumably we want to bump the target to 17 here?2.Using ${sdk.dir} doesn't work with eclipse -- *maybe* it's worth having a ../v7-appcompat instead, and adding the project to the git repo, but ultimately I suspect we want to migrate from having ant OR eclipse, to using gradle which apparently uses exactly the same build no matter whether you are in an ide or not (but I haven't looked into the details so can't confirm how this works).Sorry, I can't easily quote previous reviews for some reason, but here are my view on the other issues:* API versions:> but there is a *really low* percentage of users using Gingerbreadas discussed on IRC and possibly the ML a few times, we want to support the vast majority of Android devices, that means at least API 10, and nothing wrong with going lower if we don't lose features (see http://developer.android.com/about/dashboards/index.html to see that API 10 is still about 30% of the market)* ABS:Also been discussed on IRC, we specifically want to get rid of ABS, both for the remote and for the main android app in order to reduce complexity & maintenance -- having ABS in the way is somewhat of a blocker for splitting the Impress Remote repo out, or would alternatively result in duplication between repos...Yes, we need to update the build guide, but the new procedure is simply different and not more complicated.* Build servers:- That's up to the tb maintainers to upgrade (same as the previous comment on installing the correct lib), not really an issue -- there is going to be significant change anyway when the repo is split, so worst case the tbs might be disabled for a short time, but they aren't hugely important for the remote.

text: Patch Set 1:> The only problems I can see are with the project.properties: > 1.Presumably we want to bump the target to 17 here?Eclipse's target version is different from the target in the manifest. Manifest basically that newer versions should enable compatibility mode and not apply for example a new system-theme. While target in properties defines what SDK Eclipse will use / defines the maximum api you can use without getting errors - so if you'd want to add runtime checks for versions > 14, then you'd need to raise the limit. As it currently is, it could even be lowered to minSDK..  > 2.Using ${sdk.dir} doesn't work with eclipse --Yes, but there is no way to know the relative path to the SDK from the build-tree beforehand. Even when checked into the code, then in Ecplipse it will only work when you don't copy stuff to your workdir (as then relative paths are again different).As having a correct path is not enough in Ecplipse, but you have to add the library project as an additional project in Eclipse anyway, I don't consider this a problem. I have to adjust the library reference in the code that uses abs, and also with the one that uses the android support lib. > *maybe* it's worth having a ../v7-appcompat instead, and > adding the project to the git repo,This will make building with ant easier, as you then can skip the python statement to determine the relative path, but would not help /that/ much for Eclipse. You would still have to import both the v7-appcompat as well as the sdremote projects.(in any case: only halfway nice, as it "pollutes" the sourcetree, as opposed to other parts of the LO sourcecode that leave the sourcetree alone, but do all the work in workdir or previously solver)
Text: Patch Set 1:> The only problems I can see are with the project.properties: > 1.Presumably we want to bump the target to 17 here?Eclipse's target version is different from the target in the manifest. Manifest basically that newer versions should enable compatibility mode and not apply for example a new system-theme. While target in properties defines what SDK Eclipse will use / defines the maximum api you can use without getting errors - so if you'd want to add runtime checks for versions > 14, then you'd need to raise the limit. As it currently is, it could even be lowered to minSDK..  > 2.Using ${sdk.dir} doesn't work with eclipse --Yes, but there is no way to know the relative path to the SDK from the build-tree beforehand. Even when checked into the code, then in Ecplipse it will only work when you don't copy stuff to your workdir (as then relative paths are again different).As having a correct path is not enough in Ecplipse, but you have to add the library project as an additional project in Eclipse anyway, I don't consider this a problem. I have to adjust the library reference in the code that uses abs, and also with the one that uses the android support lib. > *maybe* it's worth having a ../v7-appcompat instead, and > adding the project to the git repo,This will make building with ant easier, as you then can skip the python statement to determine the relative path, but would not help /that/ much for Eclipse. You would still have to import both the v7-appcompat as well as the sdremote projects.(in any case: only halfway nice, as it "pollutes" the sourcetree, as opposed to other parts of the LO sourcecode that leave the sourcetree alone, but do all the work in workdir or previously solver)

text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approved> [...] While target in properties defines what SDK Eclipse> will use / defines the maximum api you can use without> getting errorsAhh ok, seems I've misunderstood how they all interact.> [...] As having a correct path is not enough in Ecplipse,> but you have to add the library project as an additional> project in Eclipse anyway, I don't consider this a problem. [...]I agree -- setting up Eclipse requires following the user manual and isn't plug'n'play either way so makes sense to optimise the non-eclipse case etc.Looking into the (or a possible) future, I'm investigating upgrading to the Android Studio / gradle build system which will *massively* simplify things (add "compile "com.android.support:appcompat-v7:18.0.+"" to the dependencies and you are ready to go...), but that's completely separate to this change in any case... That could probably be done in parallel to the current build, but I'll probably send that to the ML once I know more...

text: Patch Set 1:The tablet-layout itself is OK with the 50:50 split, but I kind of disagree with making the font larger also for the small-screen layouts. There doesn't seem to be a reason for this, as you hold the device in your hand to make use of it as a remote, so it is close to your eyes.And the 12sp is actaully rendering the text smaller than default (at least in the preview in eclipse) - sure about that? I'd probably use 22sp for tablets - that would correspond to "large" font size according to http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11590538/dpi-value-of-default-large-medium-and-small-text-views-androidBut I'd leave the size for phones at it's current value (and rather tweak the horizontal padding/spacing to maximize the usable screen-estate)

text: Patch Set 4:Does this "nobody should use" mean it is a programming error to do it? In that case I would add an assert() guaranteed to fail. Otherwise the programming error might well go unnoticed during development unit tests and usage, if the exception is caught and just ignored, or handled silently.

text: Patch Set 1:If program logic guarantees that OOXMLFastTokenHandler::getIdentifier can never be called (which would imply that OOXMLFastTokenHandler instances are only used internally and are never visible to macro/extension code), failing fast via something likeOUString OOXMLFastTokenHandler::getIdentifier(sal_Int32) {  for (;;) { std::abort(); } // avoid "must return a value" warnings}(cf. sal/osl/all/compat.cxx etc.) might be preferable.  Otherwise, throwing some RuntimeException might be preferable over returning "arbitrary" wrong values.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1 Verified+1re: "I've no idea what consequences it may have that glade removed a bunch of properties"The invisible_char_set, use_action_appearance, entry_text_column, id_column properties were removed by glade (and added by an earlier version of glade) and have no effect at all. Seems new glade removes properties that are set to their defaults and all of these are not used by us anyway.The hexpand, vexpand are halign, valign etc are horizontal expand, vertical expand, horizontal align, and vertical align are all deliberate. Expand also implies Shrink for us and that's the meat of the patch.
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1 Verified+1re: "I've no idea what consequences it may have that glade removed a bunch of properties"The invisible_char_set, use_action_appearance, entry_text_column, id_column properties were removed by glade (and added by an earlier version of glade) and have no effect at all. Seems new glade removes properties that are set to their defaults and all of these are not used by us anyway.The hexpand, vexpand are halign, valign etc are horizontal expand, vertical expand, horizontal align, and vertical align are all deliberate. Expand also implies Shrink for us and that's the meat of the patch.

text: Patch Set 2:please be serious.Nowhere does this state it is about dropping support for pre-honeycomb.I say it is OK that instead of "ALL CAPS" they get "All Caps" (or whatever casing the string is actually present in the xml/translations).So if you insist that all-caps for those entries is a must, just have translators provide them in ALL CAPS and you don't see any difference.I personally dislike all-caps, and wouldn't mind also removing that from the styledefinition for newer devices.
Text: Patch Set 2:please be serious.Nowhere does this state it is about dropping support for pre-honeycomb.I say it is OK that instead of "ALL CAPS" they get "All Caps" (or whatever casing the string is actually present in the xml/translations).So if you insist that all-caps for those entries is a must, just have translators provide them in ALL CAPS and you don't see any difference.I personally dislike all-caps, and wouldn't mind also removing that from the styledefinition for newer devices.

text: Patch Set 2:And I say it is not OK ;-) As well it is not OK to keep strings as uppercase text. You can dislike uppercase but is headers style defined in guidelines [1] (and the whole platform uses it). I see no reason to remove things defined by the platform but you personally dislike, plus this custom widget causes no overdraw or other performance drawbacks.[1]: http://developer.android.com/design/style/metrics-grids.html#examples
Text: Patch Set 2:And I say it is not OK ;-) As well it is not OK to keep strings as uppercase text. You can dislike uppercase but is headers style defined in guidelines [1] (and the whole platform uses it). I see no reason to remove things defined by the platform but you personally dislike, plus this custom widget causes no overdraw or other performance drawbacks.[1]: http://developer.android.com/design/style/metrics-grids.html#examples

text: Patch Set 2:> It is a design decision based on idea that in landscape> we have a little vertical space so it makes sense to > show a slide more detailed.What do you mean with "more detailed". The aspect ratio in landscape means that you have lots of dead space left and right in the current/old design. And even has lots of padding around that gives it even less vertical space.Vertical space is limiting the size here, that's true. So if you cannot display a large slide anyway, why not use the empty/unused space in a useful way?Compare the old:http://frupic.frubar.net/shots/30949.jpgand new:http://frupic.frubar.net/shots/30950.jpgwhich one makes better use of the space to show a as-large-as-possible preview slide?And why would anyone even use landscape mode, when that does show less information than portrait?> On other hand there are tablets but tablets support> should be implemented in other scale than just > ÔÇ£use the same everywhereÔÇØ.Tablets are not really the target-devices for the remote. If you need to hold a big/heavy device, you can just step up to the desk... As the previews are low-quality anyway, larger screen will not bring much benefit.
Text: Patch Set 2:> It is a design decision based on idea that in landscape> we have a little vertical space so it makes sense to > show a slide more detailed.What do you mean with "more detailed". The aspect ratio in landscape means that you have lots of dead space left and right in the current/old design. And even has lots of padding around that gives it even less vertical space.Vertical space is limiting the size here, that's true. So if you cannot display a large slide anyway, why not use the empty/unused space in a useful way?Compare the old:http://frupic.frubar.net/shots/30949.jpgand new:http://frupic.frubar.net/shots/30950.jpgwhich one makes better use of the space to show a as-large-as-possible preview slide?And why would anyone even use landscape mode, when that does show less information than portrait?> On other hand there are tablets but tablets support> should be implemented in other scale than just > 脭脟拢use the same everywhere脭脟脴.Tablets are not really the target-devices for the remote. If you need to hold a big/heavy device, you can just step up to the desk... As the previews are low-quality anyway, larger screen will not bring much benefit.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Ah, it's the goal seek dialog, not the solver dialog. Now it makes sense.  Normally, when you commit something that is intended to fix a particular fdo bug, you need to start your commit message with "fdo#xxxx: ...". Otherwise we wouldn't know whether it's associated with a particular bug report or not.So, could you fix your commit message to have it start with the bug number?  Then I'll be happy.  Also, do make sure to send your license statement to the developer mailing list. Thanks.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Ah, it's the goal seek dialog, not the solver dialog. Now it makes sense.  Normally, when you commit something that is intended to fix a particular fdo bug, you need to start your commit message with "fdo#xxxx: ...". Otherwise we wouldn't know whether it's associated with a particular bug report or not.So, could you fix your commit message to have it start with the bug number?  Then I'll be happy.  Also, do make sure to send your license statement to the developer mailing list. Thanks.

text: Patch Set 2:@Markus: It's not enough to just 'allow' the BOM entries. The type detection (supportedByType function) will still fail, because it's based on string comparison, so we must decode the input from UTF-16 first. Is there an easy way to do it (otherwise I'm not sure I really want to deal with it)?
Text: Patch Set 2:@Markus: It's not enough to just 'allow' the BOM entries. The type detection (supportedByType function) will still fail, because it's based on string comparison, so we must decode the input from UTF-16 first. Is there an easy way to do it (otherwise I'm not sure I really want to deal with it)?

text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedOk. Seems this code is really bad. Maybe you have some time to look into it and make it work at least with UTF-16. In theory it is not too complicated. We need to work with OUString instead of OString and detect the encoding before converting from OString to OUString.
Text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedOk. Seems this code is really bad. Maybe you have some time to look into it and make it work at least with UTF-16. In theory it is not too complicated. We need to work with OUString instead of OString and detect the encoding before converting from OString to OUString.

text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedFollowing the bug's description all looks good, after changing the source range the new table data keeps its sorting. However, going to the layout again strangely for the row Phone field's options the "Sort by" list box is greyed out and the Manual radio button is selected. After having changed that to Descending and selected "Count - Phone" it is kept intact even if the range is changed again later, also for multiple times.I think that problem can be addressed in a follow-up change, I'm submitting this one here.
Text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedFollowing the bug's description all looks good, after changing the source range the new table data keeps its sorting. However, going to the layout again strangely for the row Phone field's options the "Sort by" list box is greyed out and the Manual radio button is selected. After having changed that to Descending and selected "Count - Phone" it is kept intact even if the range is changed again later, also for multiple times.I think that problem can be addressed in a follow-up change, I'm submitting this one here.

Text: Patch Set 1:Whilst working on the wiki, I found out that the argument handling for this functiion was not the same as in Excel.This patch fixes that.As CHISQ.DIST is scheduled for version 4.2, this fix should be reviewed for version 4.2 as well.

text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedSo despite requiring the 3rd argument, the difference is that Excel limits the value range. While I see that it makes sense for fDF<1, fX<0 seems to be arbitrary; does it mathematically or precision-wise make sense for fDF>1E10?Anyhow, I'll push this to master and 4-2. For master we should change CHISQDIST and also let that fail for fDF<1.
Text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedSo despite requiring the 3rd argument, the difference is that Excel limits the value range. While I see that it makes sense for fDF<1, fX<0 seems to be arbitrary; does it mathematically or precision-wise make sense for fDF>1E10?Anyhow, I'll push this to master and 4-2. For master we should change CHISQDIST and also let that fail for fDF<1.

text: Patch Set 1:We can't remove the scopencl from the makefile. But we can put it into a conditional that depends on the feature.That would still allow us to make sure that the test works when opencl disabled (basically testing that our fallback is ok) and fix the problem.Can you do that or should I push a patch?
Text: Patch Set 1:We can't remove the scopencl from the makefile. But we can put it into a conditional that depends on the feature.That would still allow us to make sure that the test works when opencl disabled (basically testing that our fallback is ok) and fix the problem.Can you do that or should I push a patch?

text: Patch Set 1:I don't think it's the localised or not version of MSVC that matters, but the system codepage. Apparently MSVC insists that C++ source code is a valid byte sequence in the system codepage, and this UTF-8 comment is not in yours. Or something like that... I guess you don't want to change your system codepage...?
Text: Patch Set 1:I don't think it's the localised or not version of MSVC that matters, but the system codepage. Apparently MSVC insists that C++ source code is a valid byte sequence in the system codepage, and this UTF-8 comment is not in yours. Or something like that... I guess you don't want to change your system codepage...?

text: Patch Set 1:personally i've set up the tarball directory _outside_ the source dir (one level up so it's at the same level as the source dir) so it can be shared by multiple clones with different branches.  not sure if that would be appropriate as a default though."src/" is a horrible default though and this patch is an improvement :)
Text: Patch Set 1:personally i've set up the tarball directory _outside_ the source dir (one level up so it's at the same level as the source dir) so it can be shared by multiple clones with different branches.  not sure if that would be appropriate as a default though."src/" is a horrible default though and this patch is an improvement :)

text: Patch Set 1:I also support this (I think a less awkward position for this button is at the status bar). Removing these buttons from the scrollbar would finally allow LibreOffice to have dissappearing (overlay) scrollbars in OS X as well - no UI elements should be positioned over scrollbars.
Text: Patch Set 1:I also support this (I think a less awkward position for this button is at the status bar). Removing these buttons from the scrollbar would finally allow LibreOffice to have dissappearing (overlay) scrollbars in OS X as well - no UI elements should be positioned over scrollbars.

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedBranchoff is today, I would have hoped to have received a conclusive decision from the UX-advise list on this already, given this. Unfortunately the discussion on this seems to be unconclusive there still.As such I discourteously make a conclusion on this so that we have one:The majority on the list seems to be that the positioning of these buttons in the scrollbar is awkward.Removing them without replacement was considered unhelpful too.We dont have the code to put this in the statusbar.As such I conclude, we do not merge this before branchoff (thus it wont be in 4.2), but right after branchoff in the expectation of the navigation to be recreated in the statusbar for the next release.
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedBranchoff is today, I would have hoped to have received a conclusive decision from the UX-advise list on this already, given this. Unfortunately the discussion on this seems to be unconclusive there still.As such I discourteously make a conclusion on this so that we have one:The majority on the list seems to be that the positioning of these buttons in the scrollbar is awkward.Removing them without replacement was considered unhelpful too.We dont have the code to put this in the statusbar.As such I conclude, we do not merge this before branchoff (thus it wont be in 4.2), but right after branchoff in the expectation of the navigation to be recreated in the statusbar for the next release.

text: Patch Set 1:No, that wouldn't be right. The docu says "If you define NTDDI_VERSION, you must also define _WIN32_WINNT.". So we should use both. Somewhere I read that NTDDI_VERSION was the new approach to overcome all those different macros (esp. because of the former 98/NT difference). But rumor says, that it's not fully supported - as the documentation says, too.For simplicity I would only set _WIN32_WINNT and WINVER. And replace _WIN32_WINDOWS with _WIN32_WINNT .
Text: Patch Set 1:No, that wouldn't be right. The docu says "If you define NTDDI_VERSION, you must also define _WIN32_WINNT.". So we should use both. Somewhere I read that NTDDI_VERSION was the new approach to overcome all those different macros (esp. because of the former 98/NT difference). But rumor says, that it's not fully supported - as the documentation says, too.For simplicity I would only set _WIN32_WINNT and WINVER. And replace _WIN32_WINDOWS with _WIN32_WINNT .

text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedIf I understand correctly, the problem is that:# style has w:line="240"# direct formatting has w:line="320"And instead of handling inheritance when applying the table style as direct formatting, the previous overwrites the later.So I guess the perfect solution would not be just erasing that property, but instead erase it when direct formatting is not present. But that can be done as a follow-up improvement, I guess.
Text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedIf I understand correctly, the problem is that:# style has w:line="240"# direct formatting has w:line="320"And instead of handling inheritance when applying the table style as direct formatting, the previous overwrites the later.So I guess the perfect solution would not be just erasing that property, but instead erase it when direct formatting is not present. But that can be done as a follow-up improvement, I guess.

text: Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveSo - in general in-lining headers like this is fine - assuming that we are just moving these redundant extra headers into others that are included anyway.However - looking at the number counts we do more than this:0       65      slideshow/source/inc/animationfunction.hxx104     6       slideshow/source/inc/eventmultiplexer.hxx28      2       slideshow/source/inc/expressionnode.hxx176     2       slideshow/source/inc/listenercontainer.hxx30      1       slideshow/source/inc/shapeattributelayer.hxx0       61      slideshow/source/inc/shapecursoreventhandler.hxx0       67      slideshow/source/inc/state.hxx0       59      slideshow/source/inc/userpainteventhandler.hxx0       67      slideshow/source/inc/viewrepainthandler.hxxSo - a lot more code ends up in the new headers than is removed from the old ones: where does that come from ?I'm very scared by things like:+class MutexBase+{+public:+    struct Guard : public osl::MutexGuard+    {+        explicit Guard(MutexBase const& rBase) :+            osl::MutexGuard(rBase.maMutex)+        {}+    };+    struct ClearableGuard : public osl::ClearableMutexGuard+    {+        explicit ClearableGuard(MutexBase const& rBase) :+            osl::ClearableMutexGuard(rBase.maMutex)+        {}+    };++    mutable osl::Mutex maMutex;+};Then I noticed that you just forgot to git rm 'listenercontainerimpl.hxx' that has this stuff in it.Quite why we have this 'MutexBase' class I have no idea it looks odd to me - but that's a problem for another commit =)So - anyhow - this is good. There is really not a lot of value using a pimpl pattern for classes that are internal to slideshow anyway, so - this inlining seems rather helpful.Thanks ! will push in a sec.
Text: Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveSo - in general in-lining headers like this is fine - assuming that we are just moving these redundant extra headers into others that are included anyway.However - looking at the number counts we do more than this:0       65      slideshow/source/inc/animationfunction.hxx104     6       slideshow/source/inc/eventmultiplexer.hxx28      2       slideshow/source/inc/expressionnode.hxx176     2       slideshow/source/inc/listenercontainer.hxx30      1       slideshow/source/inc/shapeattributelayer.hxx0       61      slideshow/source/inc/shapecursoreventhandler.hxx0       67      slideshow/source/inc/state.hxx0       59      slideshow/source/inc/userpainteventhandler.hxx0       67      slideshow/source/inc/viewrepainthandler.hxxSo - a lot more code ends up in the new headers than is removed from the old ones: where does that come from ?I'm very scared by things like:+class MutexBase+{+public:+    struct Guard : public osl::MutexGuard+    {+        explicit Guard(MutexBase const& rBase) :+            osl::MutexGuard(rBase.maMutex)+        {}+    };+    struct ClearableGuard : public osl::ClearableMutexGuard+    {+        explicit ClearableGuard(MutexBase const& rBase) :+            osl::ClearableMutexGuard(rBase.maMutex)+        {}+    };++    mutable osl::Mutex maMutex;+};Then I noticed that you just forgot to git rm 'listenercontainerimpl.hxx' that has this stuff in it.Quite why we have this 'MutexBase' class I have no idea it looks odd to me - but that's a problem for another commit =)So - anyhow - this is good. There is really not a lot of value using a pimpl pattern for classes that are internal to slideshow anyway, so - this inlining seems rather helpful.Thanks ! will push in a sec.

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedSorry this remained unreviewed for so long.  I think the include clean-up in the .idl files is a good thing.Although the #include lines in those files are becoming obsolete; only SDK's idlc still uses them, while newer tools ignore them anyway.  Therefore, I think it is not worth it to add the Makefile_idl_compile and include.idl tooling.Anyway, I did not find a license statement from you at <https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/Developers>; can you clarify that first?  I'll push the .idl clean-up part then.
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedSorry this remained unreviewed for so long.  I think the include clean-up in the .idl files is a good thing.Although the #include lines in those files are becoming obsolete; only SDK's idlc still uses them, while newer tools ignore them anyway.  Therefore, I think it is not worth it to add the Makefile_idl_compile and include.idl tooling.Anyway, I did not find a license statement from you at <https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/Developers>; can you clarify that first?  I'll push the .idl clean-up part then.

text: Patch Set 2:Hmmm - the problem is, when loading such a document, the strings getmatched against existing table styles, and then the table design paneselects the right icon for the currently-selected table object.Now, if you change the name, when loading an old doc, Impress willon-demand create a new style (since the name 'turquise' is unknown),and assign a matching icon. So you'll end up with a bunch of dupeentries in that widget.I wonder if this rather cosmetic change is worth that user annoyance?Alternatively, one could of course map the names on import, doubtfulthough if that's worth the hassle ...
Text: Patch Set 2:Hmmm - the problem is, when loading such a document, the strings getmatched against existing table styles, and then the table design paneselects the right icon for the currently-selected table object.Now, if you change the name, when loading an old doc, Impress willon-demand create a new style (since the name 'turquise' is unknown),and assign a matching icon. So you'll end up with a bunch of dupeentries in that widget.I wonder if this rather cosmetic change is worth that user annoyance?Alternatively, one could of course map the names on import, doubtfulthough if that's worth the hassle ...

text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedso it looks like we actually write the name of these table styles into the ODF file...... as table:template-name="turquise" on table:table element.this means that the values will be read from the ODF file anyway so it shouldn't matter what the styles are called internally (that will just affect new files).the only problem i can see is that if you load a document with the old spelling you can see an additional entry in "Table Design" but i think it's not really a problem.
Text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedso it looks like we actually write the name of these table styles into the ODF file...... as table:template-name="turquise" on table:table element.this means that the values will be read from the ODF file anyway so it shouldn't matter what the styles are called internally (that will just affect new files).the only problem i can see is that if you load a document with the old spelling you can see an additional entry in "Table Design" but i think it's not really a problem.

text: Patch Set 1:The SCSTR_COLUMN and SCSTR_ROW strings already contain the "%1" placeholder, apparently that was added to actually allow translations to specify if the column/row should be prepended or appended. sc/source/ui/src/scstring.src has String SCSTR_COLUMN {     Text [ x-comment ] = "%1 is replaced to column letter, such as 'Column A'" ;     Text [ en-US ] = "Column %1" ; };All other places using these strings already correctly substitute the placeholder with the column/row number, this one was just missing. It doesn't break anything unless translations omitted the %1 placeholder, but then it broke in several other places as well.
Text: Patch Set 1:The SCSTR_COLUMN and SCSTR_ROW strings already contain the "%1" placeholder, apparently that was added to actually allow translations to specify if the column/row should be prepended or appended. sc/source/ui/src/scstring.src has String SCSTR_COLUMN {     Text [ x-comment ] = "%1 is replaced to column letter, such as 'Column A'" ;     Text [ en-US ] = "Column %1" ; };All other places using these strings already correctly substitute the placeholder with the column/row number, this one was just missing. It doesn't break anything unless translations omitted the %1 placeholder, but then it broke in several other places as well.

text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approved"All other places using these strings already correctly substitute the placeholder with the column/row number, this one was just missing."Ah, ok, then translations without the placeholder are broken already. Sorry, I didn't consider that. :)
Text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approved"All other places using these strings already correctly substitute the placeholder with the column/row number, this one was just missing."Ah, ok, then translations without the placeholder are broken already. Sorry, I didn't consider that. :)

text: Patch Set 1:Circa 2009 I asked OOo development to let sysadmins disable the new database button, through a configuration parameter (default was to let users create new databases). The main reason is that in many corporations, scattered databases in desktops (such as Access or Base) are conseidered a breach in data security, uncontrollable data leak and poor data management.I beg to let sysadmins to keep installation to prevent the creation of new databases, as its is today.The configuration that hides the New Database from the dialog is here (should be added in main.xcd)----------------%<----------------------- <?xml version="1.0"?><oor:data xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:oor="http://openoffice.org/2001/registry"> <dependency file="main"/> <oor:component-data xmlns:install="http://openoffice.org/2004/installation" oor:name="DataAccess" oor:package="org.openoffice.Office">  <node oor:name="Policies">   <node oor:name="Features">    <node oor:name="Base">     <prop oor:name="CreateLocalDatabase" oor:type="xs:boolean">      <value>false</value>     </prop>    </node>    <node oor:name="Writer">     <prop oor:name="DatabaseFields" oor:type="xs:boolean">      <value>true</value>     </prop>     </node>     <node oor:name="Common">      <prop oor:name="EditDatabaseFromDataSourceView" oor:type="xs:boolean">       <value>true</value>      </prop>    </node>   </node>  </node> </oor:component-data></oor:data>----------------%<-----------------------
Text: Patch Set 1:Circa 2009 I asked OOo development to let sysadmins disable the new database button, through a configuration parameter (default was to let users create new databases). The main reason is that in many corporations, scattered databases in desktops (such as Access or Base) are conseidered a breach in data security, uncontrollable data leak and poor data management.I beg to let sysadmins to keep installation to prevent the creation of new databases, as its is today.The configuration that hides the New Database from the dialog is here (should be added in main.xcd)----------------%<----------------------- <?xml version="1.0"?><oor:data xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:oor="http://openoffice.org/2001/registry"> <dependency file="main"/> <oor:component-data xmlns:install="http://openoffice.org/2004/installation" oor:name="DataAccess" oor:package="org.openoffice.Office">  <node oor:name="Policies">   <node oor:name="Features">    <node oor:name="Base">     <prop oor:name="CreateLocalDatabase" oor:type="xs:boolean">      <value>false</value>     </prop>    </node>    <node oor:name="Writer">     <prop oor:name="DatabaseFields" oor:type="xs:boolean">      <value>true</value>     </prop>     </node>     <node oor:name="Common">      <prop oor:name="EditDatabaseFromDataSourceView" oor:type="xs:boolean">       <value>true</value>      </prop>    </node>   </node>  </node> </oor:component-data></oor:data>----------------%<-----------------------

text: Patch Set 1:Hi Olivier,I believe the "New Database" you are referring to is completely unrelated to the change above -- my change only affects the options when already creating a .odb file (via the "Connect to an Existing Database" option, and even then only when creating a new .odb that is intended to link to a firebird file database. It will in no way affect the first page of the Base Dialog which offers the "Create a New Database", "Open an existing database", "Connect to an existing database" options.In other words it will still be possible to block creation of new .odb files using the previous config options.
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Olivier,I believe the "New Database" you are referring to is completely unrelated to the change above -- my change only affects the options when already creating a .odb file (via the "Connect to an Existing Database" option, and even then only when creating a new .odb that is intended to link to a firebird file database. It will in no way affect the first page of the Base Dialog which offers the "Create a New Database", "Open an existing database", "Connect to an existing database" options.In other words it will still be possible to block creation of new .odb files using the previous config options.

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedAs discussed on IRC, if we change something here, then we probably should go back to what we had in 3.6 (one test is one cppunit test) and handle the two "import" and "export + second import" cases in two subclasses. That way then it would be possible to avoid introducing the ugly DECLARE_OOXML_TEST / RUN_OOXML_TEST macros.I mean such a change causes some pain on backports, so if we do it, I think we should do it properly, not hiding copy&paste behind macros. :-)
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedAs discussed on IRC, if we change something here, then we probably should go back to what we had in 3.6 (one test is one cppunit test) and handle the two "import" and "export + second import" cases in two subclasses. That way then it would be possible to avoid introducing the ugly DECLARE_OOXML_TEST / RUN_OOXML_TEST macros.I mean such a change causes some pain on backports, so if we do it, I think we should do it properly, not hiding copy&paste behind macros. :-)

text: Patch Set 2:I checked the patch and we need to fix the odf export here because of some ugly embedded object handling.I'm still not 100% convinced that this patch is correct but as soon as the test for this patch is working I will accept the patch.I somehow still believe it is an ooxml import bug but apparently the patch works and should at least not affect calc with external data provider.
Text: Patch Set 2:I checked the patch and we need to fix the odf export here because of some ugly embedded object handling.I'm still not 100% convinced that this patch is correct but as soon as the test for this patch is working I will accept the patch.I somehow still believe it is an ooxml import bug but apparently the patch works and should at least not affect calc with external data provider.

text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedMeh, I'm not actually sure about this patch. It doesn't seem right to me. More of a workaround for some other bug elsewhere in the calculation of the initial size of the full comboboxwidget rather than the placement of the subedit within that space. But I won't make the great the enemy of good.
Text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedMeh, I'm not actually sure about this patch. It doesn't seem right to me. But I won't make the great the enemy of good.

text: Patch Set 1:Hmm, not sure I follow, but OK... Without the corresponding script, though, this now means others will not be able to build the MobileLibreOffice app, right?Also, I think the name LO_LDFLAGS is misleading, as it isn't consistent with the other LO_FOO settings in lo.xcconfig(.in), which originate from LO's configury. Some other name would be better, and please don't use "LDFLAGS" in the name as "LDFLAGS" traditionally is used for flags, not a list of libraries.Sorry if this seems like nitpicking, but experience has taught me that code needs to use existing conventions and terminology to be understandable later...
Text: Patch Set 1:Hmm, not sure I follow, but OK... Without the corresponding script, though, this now means others will not be able to build the MobileLibreOffice app, right?Also, I think the name LO_LDFLAGS is misleading, as it isn't consistent with the other LO_FOO settings in lo.xcconfig(.in), which originate from LO's configury. Some other name would be better, and please don't use "LDFLAGS" in the name as "LDFLAGS" traditionally is used for flags, not a list of libraries.Sorry if this seems like nitpicking, but experience has taught me that code needs to use existing conventions and terminology to be understandable later...

text: Patch Set 1:Commit message states, that https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/1164  inadvertently introduced a regression. 2bd856e6 added extensive tests (250 LoC): https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/1164/17/connectivity/qa/connectivity/commontools/FValue_test.cxxThese tests must be extended to cover the bool->string conversion problem that is fixed in this change.

text: Patch Set 3: This need some tweaks before it is mergedCan you please tell me which Office version you use for your tests. Sadly they changed the default values for some properties between different versions.I'll fix it in the patch and push it but try to be as explicit as possible when you fix something in the chart export code.Can you maybe also add test cases to chart2/qa/extras? We have an export test there and while we don't validate the exported files yet, it is planned and will therefore help prevent regressions in this area in the future.
Text: Patch Set 3: This need some tweaks before it is mergedCan you please tell me which Office version you use for your tests. Sadly they changed the default values for some properties between different versions.I'll fix it in the patch and push it but try to be as explicit as possible when you fix something in the chart export code.Can you maybe also add test cases to chart2/qa/extras? We have an export test there and while we don't validate the exported files yet, it is planned and will therefore help prevent regressions in this area in the future.

text: Patch Set 1:@Eike:This is the main part of the total bug fix. This patch works only on start up of Calc, so changing the global setting 'Use English function names' will not be effected immediately. I'm still working on that, but it is possible that I will not succeed in getting that to work. Should I succeed, I will submit that as a separate patch.Any way, the submitted patch will be good for 99% of the time as I expect that the global setting 'Use English function names' is only set once to the user's preference.
Text: Patch Set 1:@Eike:This is the main part of the total bug fix. This patch works only on start up of Calc, so changing the global setting 'Use English function names' will not be effected immediately. I'm still working on that, but it is possible that I will not succeed in getting that to work. Should I succeed, I will submit that as a separate patch.Any way, the submitted patch will be good for 99% of the time as I expect that the global setting 'Use English function names' is only set once to the user's preference.

text: Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveSeems good to me, deadlock-wise; I'd avoid ever using the internal mutex there personally and stop pretending we're multi-threaded, and bin the 'external' lock, and hard-code the Solar mutex etc. ;)I'm curious as to how the         forgetExternalLock();            // this ensures that the lock, which may be already destroyed as part of the derivee,            // is not used anymore        ensureDisposed();works - that is assuming that 'disposing' may get emitted during ensureDisposed (but now without a lock held ?).Then again, my impression with locking issues it that: we can't really make it much worse so ... ;-)
Text: Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveSeems good to me, deadlock-wise; I'd avoid ever using the internal mutex there personally and stop pretending we're multi-threaded, and bin the 'external' lock, and hard-code the Solar mutex etc. ;)I'm curious as to how the         forgetExternalLock();            // this ensures that the lock, which may be already destroyed as part of the derivee,            // is not used anymore        ensureDisposed();works - that is assuming that 'disposing' may get emitted during ensureDisposed (but now without a lock held ?).Then again, my impression with locking issues it that: we can't really make it much worse so ... ;-)

text: Patch Set 1:ensureDisposed() called from dtor shouldn't need a lock -the lock guards m_pImpl, and when we're in dtor alreadythere shouldn't be a way for another thread to access the object.although it looks like revokeClientNotifyDisposing receives a "this" pointer, and if it sends that as Reference to event listeners when called from dtor then that's perhaps a different disaster waiting to happen...
Text: Patch Set 1:ensureDisposed() called from dtor shouldn't need a lock -the lock guards m_pImpl, and when we're in dtor alreadythere shouldn't be a way for another thread to access the object.although it looks like revokeClientNotifyDisposing receives a "this" pointer, and if it sends that as Reference to event listeners when called from dtor then that's perhaps a different disaster waiting to happen...

text: Patch Set 2:Without that change Impress immediately crashes if presentation minimizer wizard is started from the menu. With assertion error, that Michael Stahl committed two days ago. Unfortunately i don't have a link to pastebin.com with the back trace any more. I posted it yesterday on the IRC and Michael suggested to make that change in this file. This solved that problem. In any event i don't know what the original problem with solar mutex is/was and why this line solved it.@Michael can you upload a new version of this change with updated commit message, please?Concerning de-externalization of the presentation minimizer in fdo#61950 it is only related, because it would be a valid test case after migration: it should work again. But currently it doesn't work as extension either ;-)Bur formally you are right, we could remove the mention of this bug from the commit message, create a new bug and link to it, or just let it as is ;-)

text: Patch Set 1:"Sorry, that the patch is big. Important bits are Gallery.mk and CppunitTest.mk, where 'xcsxcu' in CONFIGURATION_LAYERS is changed and 'module' is no more used. I hope something like this is possible.. patches to remove $(OUTDIR)/xml are almost done ;-)"That would mean that the affected modules would now (circularly, at the module level) depend on postprocess, right?  (Not that is necessarily a bad thing to introduce such "false" module-level circular dependencies.)"btw: 'xcsxcu' and 'res' in CONFIGURATION_LAYERS in instsetoo_native/CustomTarget_setup.mk have the same value, is it right ? Otherwise only 'xcsxcu' is now used AFAICS, so possibly also configmgr can be simplified ?"Each of "xcsxcu", "res", and "module" parse slightly different sets of files, cf. configmgr/source/components.cxx.  What you loose with the changes to CppunitTest.mk is to read the localized instdir/*/share/registry/res/*.xcd files, which also include the fallback *-en_US.xcd ones, which might or might not be a problem for (some of) the tests.  But if it turns out to be a problem, we could easily add that afterwards.
Text: Patch Set 1:"Sorry, that the patch is big. Important bits are Gallery.mk and CppunitTest.mk, where 'xcsxcu' in CONFIGURATION_LAYERS is changed and 'module' is no more used. I hope something like this is possible.. patches to remove $(OUTDIR)/xml are almost done ;-)"That would mean that the affected modules would now (circularly, at the module level) depend on postprocess, right?  (Not that is necessarily a bad thing to introduce such "false" module-level circular dependencies.)"btw: 'xcsxcu' and 'res' in CONFIGURATION_LAYERS in instsetoo_native/CustomTarget_setup.mk have the same value, is it right ? Otherwise only 'xcsxcu' is now used AFAICS, so possibly also configmgr can be simplified ?"Each of "xcsxcu", "res", and "module" parse slightly different sets of files, cf. configmgr/source/components.cxx.  What you loose with the changes to CppunitTest.mk is to read the localized instdir/*/share/registry/res/*.xcd files, which also include the fallback *-en_US.xcd ones, which might or might not be a problem for (some of) the tests.  But if it turns out to be a problem, we could easily add that afterwards.

text: Patch Set 5:The vigra::copyImage is not handling copy areas in the same image so the code is checking whether the src and dst are same buffer and directing it to scaleImage which is very slow.The whole concept of pixel accessors is a huge overhead in the case of direct pixel copy (vigra::copyImage is also using pixel accessors).The idea here was to identify when direct memory copy is applicable (when src.size==dst.size && src.format==dst.format) and use direct memory block copy and not pixel wise copy.The result is 100x faster than vigra implementation.This direct copy is also handling the case when the src and dst are same buffer by copy it from bottom to top when needed and using memmove instead of memcpyabout using long or int for iterating i'm not keen on the cross platform details please advice how to do it properly.
Text: Patch Set 5:The vigra::copyImage is not handling copy areas in the same image so the code is checking whether the src and dst are same buffer and directing it to scaleImage which is very slow.The whole concept of pixel accessors is a huge overhead in the case of direct pixel copy (vigra::copyImage is also using pixel accessors).The idea here was to identify when direct memory copy is applicable (when src.size==dst.size && src.format==dst.format) and use direct memory block copy and not pixel wise copy.The result is 100x faster than vigra implementation.This direct copy is also handling the case when the src and dst are same buffer by copy it from bottom to top when needed and using memmove instead of memcpyabout using long or int for iterating i'm not keen on the cross platform details please advice how to do it properly.

text: Patch Set 5:Yep, no beef with the function per se - my verbose comment was more a documentation of why this is a good idea. ;)For the variables - please double-check this, but from the math, sal_Int32 should be sufficient. This is on all of our platforms interchangeable with int, so why not use that.If the original intend of long was 'something bigger than int', then you should use sal_Int64 (I doubt it is needed though).
Text: Patch Set 5:Yep, no beef with the function per se - my verbose comment was more a documentation of why this is a good idea. ;)For the variables - please double-check this, but from the math, sal_Int32 should be sufficient. This is on all of our platforms interchangeable with int, so why not use that.If the original intend of long was 'something bigger than int', then you should use sal_Int64 (I doubt it is needed though).

text: Patch Set 7: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedFound the problem, it wasn't a fencepost error after all, but the problem was with 1- and 4-bit-per-pixel formats, where obviously it doesn't make sense to copy pixels with memmove() (unless one adds complexity by first copying an integral number of bytes and then any remaining bits). I am not sure that is worth it, for now I just added a condition to call the new implDrawBitmapDirect()  only for formats that use an integral number of bytes per pixel.
Text: Patch Set 7: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedFound the problem, it wasn't a fencepost error after all, but the problem was with 1- and 4-bit-per-pixel formats, where obviously it doesn't make sense to copy pixels with memmove() (unless one adds complexity by first copying an integral number of bytes and then any remaining bits). I am not sure that is worth it, for now I just added a condition to call the new implDrawBitmapDirect()  only for formats that use an integral number of bytes per pixel.

text: Patch Set 3:I probably wasn't clear - as you can see, the delta is being used as a value to increase or decrease nNewSize.  Instead, I think we should compute nNewSize directly based on the mouse pointer position - this is what I meant by 'absolute'; ie. 'absolute' in the term that you will do nNewSize = function_of(mouse_pointer_position); not nNewSize = previous_size + nDelta;  Does this make sense, or is there anything else that prevents this?
Text: Patch Set 3:I probably wasn't clear - as you can see, the delta is being used as a value to increase or decrease nNewSize.  Instead, I think we should compute nNewSize directly based on the mouse pointer position - this is what I meant by 'absolute'; ie. 'absolute' in the term that you will do nNewSize = function_of(mouse_pointer_position); not nNewSize = previous_size + nDelta;  Does this make sense, or is there anything else that prevents this?
