text: Patch Set 2:This part is meant for LibreOffice 4.1, too. The reason is to cover the following regression:Until 4.0, one could do: Dim d as Date ' set d in some way aDateControl.DateMax = CDateToIso(d) d = CDateFromIso(aDateControl.Date)That's relatively easy. This patch intends to make possible on 4.1: Dim d as Date ' set d in some way aDateControl.DateMax = CDateToUnoDate(d) d = CDateFromUnoDate(aDateControl.Date)instead of the current more verbose / harder to come up with: Dim d as Date ' set d in some way Dim ud as new "com.sun.star.util.Date" ud.Year = Year(d) ud.Month = Month(d) ud.Day = Day(d) aDateControl.DateMax = ud ud = aDateControl.Date d = DateSerial(ud.Year, ud.Month, ud.Day)
Text: Patch Set 2:This part is meant for LibreOffice 4.1, too. The reason is to cover the following regression:Until 4.0, one could do: Dim d as Date ' set d in some way aDateControl.DateMax = CDateToIso(d) d = CDateFromIso(aDateControl.Date)That's relatively easy. This patch intends to make possible on 4.1: Dim d as Date ' set d in some way aDateControl.DateMax = CDateToUnoDate(d) d = CDateFromUnoDate(aDateControl.Date)instead of the current more verbose / harder to come up with: Dim d as Date ' set d in some way Dim ud as new "com.sun.star.util.Date" ud.Year = Year(d) ud.Month = Month(d) ud.Day = Day(d) aDateControl.DateMax = ud ud = aDateControl.Date d = DateSerial(ud.Year, ud.Month, ud.Day)

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is merged(7 inline comments)Cool, thanks.It feels a bit sluggish to go via creating an XML temp file, but at least that's only done if the relevant winreg key is present, so will not slow down installations that don't use the feature.Also, I wonder whether it would make sense to make the structure of the winreg data already cater for future improvements (e.g., explicitly specify the type of property value, in case in the future types other than xs:string are supported; and "Final"=dword:00000001 smells like it could be used as a bitfield for various flags, see oor:mandatory and maybe oor:op; if it is not, isn't there a boolean data type in winreg? (I have no idea really)).Apart from that, sprinkled a few comments across the patch, many of them minor nits anyway.
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is merged(7 inline comments)Cool, thanks.It feels a bit sluggish to go via creating an XML temp file, but at least that's only done if the relevant winreg key is present, so will not slow down installations that don't use the feature.Also, I wonder whether it would make sense to make the structure of the winreg data already cater for future improvements (e.g., explicitly specify the type of property value, in case in the future types other than xs:string are supported; and "Final"=dword:00000001 smells like it could be used as a bitfield for various flags, see oor:mandatory and maybe oor:op; if it is not, isn't there a boolean data type in winreg? (I have no idea really)).Apart from that, sprinkled a few comments across the patch, many of them minor nits anyway.

text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedlooking back it turns out that dcc05d40c6fdb41a4193072d6b72456d75269ba3 fixed the dereference problem already. Your code to stop duplicating the test is good so I extracted that here. The "else" isn't fully safe because the idea seems to be to try aCommandStr first and if that doesn't work (or was empty in the first place) then try aHelpId so its got to be two if cases one after the other. All fixed up now I think.

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is merged(19 inline comments)This is a lot of nice work. Unfortunately, it needs some improvements, see the inline comments. We need the clean up but we need to keep the readability. And do not break the code ;-)Also we should not change the style too often. Even the comments might create conflicts when merging fixes between branches.I wonder if you do the patch using a script or manually. I think that it is best to do this using some scripts (bash,sed, perl).In each case, I strongly suggest to split such changes into more commits next time. The big patch was wery hard to review (hard to keep concentration, my right hand was aching after going through all the pages). So, you could get faster feedback with a smaller patch. Also, you will be able to do the other parts better after the feedback. Finally, it will help you to keep concentration as well. Note that you even removed two pieces of code by mistake.
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is merged(19 inline comments)This is a lot of nice work. Unfortunately, it needs some improvements, see the inline comments. We need the clean up but we need to keep the readability. And do not break the code ;-)Also we should not change the style too often. Even the comments might create conflicts when merging fixes between branches.I wonder if you do the patch using a script or manually. I think that it is best to do this using some scripts (bash,sed, perl).In each case, I strongly suggest to split such changes into more commits next time. The big patch was wery hard to review (hard to keep concentration, my right hand was aching after going through all the pages). So, you could get faster feedback with a smaller patch. Also, you will be able to do the other parts better after the feedback. Finally, it will help you to keep concentration as well. Note that you even removed two pieces of code by mistake.

text: Patch Set 1:In the initial file, the iterator was invalid after this line:"aSet.erase ( it );" (at least according to http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1636578/iterator-validity-after-erase-call-in-stdset)So I removed the for loop to manage manually the increment of the iterator

text: Patch Set 5:I think I will simply remove the boolean flag, change it from 'unsigned int' to 'signed int' and analyze all the places that use the function to get the value, to make sure I don't corrupt any existing logic.That way - in the entire codebase - '0 or more' will mean a specific page start value, and 'negative value' means no page start value.
Text: Patch Set 5:I think I will simply remove the boolean flag, change it from 'unsigned int' to 'signed int' and analyze all the places that use the function to get the value, to make sure I don't corrupt any existing logic.That way - in the entire codebase - '0 or more' will mean a specific page start value, and 'negative value' means no page start value.

text: Patch Set 3:Well, I cannot argue with the compiler. If it says that it wants a copy constructor, I will have to give it one. :-)I was not aware of that detail of the 98 C++ standard, and it is a bit unintuitive. Why should a copy constructor be called when constructing a temporary object?Anyway, I will check how to tell GCC to be strict about the 98 C++ standard, recompile and resubmit the patch.Is there anything I have to do apart from that, e.g., somehow reverting the commit?
Text: Patch Set 3:Well, I cannot argue with the compiler. If it says that it wants a copy constructor, I will have to give it one. :-)I was not aware of that detail of the 98 C++ standard, and it is a bit unintuitive. Why should a copy constructor be called when constructing a temporary object?Anyway, I will check how to tell GCC to be strict about the 98 C++ standard, recompile and resubmit the patch.Is there anything I have to do apart from that, e.g., somehow reverting the commit?

text: Patch Set 2: This need some tweaks before it is merged* The declaration in uno.h is not necessary; the definition in uno.hxx is enough.* The definition must be in namespace com::sun::star::uno.* For maximum generality, use std::basic_ostream<charT, traits> instead of std::ostream, as in e.g. include/rtl/ustring.hxx.* There is no need for a HANDLE_UNSUPPORTED_TYPE macro.  The type is readily available as a string via Any::getValueTypeName (and it would arguably be a good idea to always include it in the output, like "Any of type T with value V", or for cases where we have no code to print the value just "Any of type T," or something less verbose but containing the same amount of information).* The TypeClass values UNION and ARRAY are unused historic mistakes; and typelib_TypeClass_MAKE_FIXED_SIZE is an artefact of the UNO C++ language binding, not a legal value of UNO enum TypeClass.* Likewise, the TypeClass values TYPEDEF, SERVICE, MODULE, INTERFACE_METHOD, INTERFACE_ATTRIBUTE, UNKNOWN, PROPERTY, CONSTANT, CONSTANTS, and SINGLETON are only used to represent UNOIDL entities unrelated to the UNO type system.  They are never used for values of type Any.* Likewise, a UNO ANY cannot contain a nested ANY (cf. <http://www.openoffice.org/udk/common/man/typesystem.html>).  That is, all cases other than VOID, BOOLEAN, BYTE, SHORT, UNSIGNED_SHORT, LONG, UNSIGNED_LONG, HYPER, UNSIGNED_HYPER, FLOAT, DOUBLE, CHAR, STRING, TYPE, SEQUENCE, ENUM, STRUCT, EXCEPTION, and INTERFACE should be subsumed under  default:    assert(false); // this cannot happen    break;(And whenever I write code that lists all those UNO type system tags, I stick with the above order as given at <http://www.openoffice.org/udk/common/man/typesystem.html>, not the completely stupid and arbitrary one from the TypeClass enum.)* Add @since LibreOffice 4.2.
Text: Patch Set 2: This need some tweaks before it is merged* The declaration in uno.h is not necessary; the definition in uno.hxx is enough.* The definition must be in namespace com::sun::star::uno.* For maximum generality, use std::basic_ostream<charT, traits> instead of std::ostream, as in e.g. include/rtl/ustring.hxx.* There is no need for a HANDLE_UNSUPPORTED_TYPE macro.  The type is readily available as a string via Any::getValueTypeName (and it would arguably be a good idea to always include it in the output, like "Any of type T with value V", or for cases where we have no code to print the value just "Any of type T," or something less verbose but containing the same amount of information).* The TypeClass values UNION and ARRAY are unused historic mistakes; and typelib_TypeClass_MAKE_FIXED_SIZE is an artefact of the UNO C++ language binding, not a legal value of UNO enum TypeClass.* Likewise, the TypeClass values TYPEDEF, SERVICE, MODULE, INTERFACE_METHOD, INTERFACE_ATTRIBUTE, UNKNOWN, PROPERTY, CONSTANT, CONSTANTS, and SINGLETON are only used to represent UNOIDL entities unrelated to the UNO type system.  They are never used for values of type Any.* Likewise, a UNO ANY cannot contain a nested ANY (cf. <http://www.openoffice.org/udk/common/man/typesystem.html>).  That is, all cases other than VOID, BOOLEAN, BYTE, SHORT, UNSIGNED_SHORT, LONG, UNSIGNED_LONG, HYPER, UNSIGNED_HYPER, FLOAT, DOUBLE, CHAR, STRING, TYPE, SEQUENCE, ENUM, STRUCT, EXCEPTION, and INTERFACE should be subsumed under  default:    assert(false); // this cannot happen    break;(And whenever I write code that lists all those UNO type system tags, I stick with the above order as given at <http://www.openoffice.org/udk/common/man/typesystem.html>, not the completely stupid and arbitrary one from the TypeClass enum.)* Add @since LibreOffice 4.2.

text: Patch Set 2:Thanks Norbert.I would like not to rebase at all, if possible, it's always scary to me :)In this case I did it because of Tor's 2nd comment (failing cherry-picking) and because, after that, I also committed a patch that touched some of the involved files (on the same lines).Anyway, I experienced in the past this "rebase required", tried cherry picking on recent master (without clashes), submitting again (failed due to no changes), then just hit "rebase" on gerrit's interface to try to fix the notification I had (even if I don't know if it was really necessary, at this point). Is the latter the right way to proceed?

text: Patch Set 2:@Winfried: > Once this patch has been approved, I will ask for cherry -picking for > version 4.1. >  > But how? Not by submitting the same patch, I presume. (I only know of the > old method: [REVIEW}-message to the mailing list...)The usual way would be to checkout and build the libreoffice-4-1 branch,then once the patch was pushed to master do a git fetch and thengit cherry-pick -x SHA1-of-that-commitresolve possible merge conflicts, build it and then submit the resultingcommit to gerrit for review on the libreoffice-4-1 branch.However, as I'm at this anyway and already have a 4-1 build I'll takea short cut and push the cherry-pick to 4-1 with my sign-off, providedthe patch works and solves the issue ;-)
Text: Patch Set 2:@Winfried: > Once this patch has been approved, I will ask for cherry -picking for > version 4.1. >  > But how? Not by submitting the same patch, I presume. (I only know of the > old method: [REVIEW}-message to the mailing list...)The usual way would be to checkout and build the libreoffice-4-1 branch,then once the patch was pushed to master do a git fetch and thengit cherry-pick -x SHA1-of-that-commitresolve possible merge conflicts, build it and then submit the resultingcommit to gerrit for review on the libreoffice-4-1 branch.However, as I'm at this anyway and already have a 4-1 build I'll takea short cut and push the cherry-pick to 4-1 with my sign-off, providedthe patch works and solves the issue ;-)

text: Patch Set 1:actually i had a look at "ECMA-376 Part 1 3rd edition"(is this the relevant reference?) and it has:<quote>17.18.9ST_DateTime (Standard Date and Time Storage Format)This simple type's contents are a restriction of the W3C XML Schema dateTime datatype.</quote>which is apparently for the word processing part;then there is this about spreadsheets:<quote>18.17.4Dates and TimesEach unique instant in SpreadsheetML time is stored as an ISO 8601-formatted string, which is made up of adate component, a time component, and a timezone component.L.2.16.9.1Date Conversion for Serial ValuesAll date values stored in cells within a SpreadsheetML file are stored in the ISO 8601 format.</quote>yay - a standard with 2 different normative references for date formats!however can't find any reference to http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime  in there - where did the idea come from that that was relevant?

text: Patch Set 1:Side effect?  I'm not sure. The reason why I tried to reduce the amount of virtual methods on this class is to limit the amount of surprises and makes it easier to track who's using what method.  Turning this to a virtual would add that down-side again... Once a method becomes virtual, it also becomes harder to track how it's used, and making it more difficult to debug for all users of this class.The only way to be sure there is no side effect is to test all places where this class is used.... It's hard for me to say just by looking at the code change...
Text: Patch Set 1:Side effect?  I'm not sure. text: Patch Set 1:This is indeed completely non-obvious.  It is the odd entanglement between Window and VCLXWindow life-cycles that makes this work; if PropBrw has already been destroyed by the time that DialogWindowLayout's ~Window calls UnoWrapper::WindowDestroyed, it has apparently already been removed from the datastructures that are walked there to destroy "children created with ::com::sun::star::loader::Java that would otherwise not be destroyed until the garbage collector cleans up."However, if you remove "delete pPropertyBrowser" from ~DialogWindowLayout, things will continue to work, too (~PropBrw will now be called again from UnoWrapper::WindowDestroyed as in the commit msg's backtrace, though of course it will no longer call back into DialogWindowLayout, what was causing the original problem).  So it might even be better to leave the explicit "delete pProperyBrowser" out and rely on this scheme of UnoWrapper::WindowDestroyed cleaning it up---I honestly don't know.
Text: Patch Set 1:This is indeed completely non-obvious.  It is the odd entanglement between Window and VCLXWindow life-cycles that makes this work; if PropBrw has already been destroyed by the time that DialogWindowLayout's ~Window calls UnoWrapper::WindowDestroyed, it has apparently already been removed from the datastructures that are walked there to destroy "children created with ::com::sun::star::loader::Java that would otherwise not be destroyed until the garbage collector cleans up."However, if you remove "delete pPropertyBrowser" from ~DialogWindowLayout, things will continue to work, too (~PropBrw will now be called again from UnoWrapper::WindowDestroyed as in the commit msg's backtrace, though of course it will no longer call back into DialogWindowLayout, what was causing the original problem).  So it might even be better to leave the explicit "delete pProperyBrowser" out and rely on this scheme of UnoWrapper::WindowDestroyed cleaning it up---I honestly don't know.

text: Patch Set 1:In theory yes, but somehow not calling Clear() didn't affect the formats of imported edit texts. I'd tested a variety of combinations.  And Clear() is expensive, so I left it out.Having said that, I'm not against putting Clear() back in, just to be safe.  We could put that right before we call SetText(), to ensure that we don't call Clear() for cells that don't use edit engine.
Text: Patch Set 1:In theory yes, but somehow not calling Clear() didn't affect the formats of imported edit texts. I'd tested a variety of combinations.  And Clear() is expensive, so I left it out.Having said that, I'm not against putting Clear() back in, just to be safe.  We could put that right before we call SetText(), to ensure that we don't call Clear() for cells that don't use edit engine.

text: Patch Set 2: This need some tweaks before it is mergedPatch didn't apply for me, merge conflicts: diff --cc sc/qa/unit/subsequent_export-test.cxx index ed23eee,8b7e225..0000000 --- a/sc/qa/unit/subsequent_export-test.cxx +++ b/sc/qa/unit/subsequent_export-test.cxx @@@ -52,7 -53,7 +53,11 @@@ public       void testDataBarExportODS();       void testDataBarExportXLSX();       void testMiscRowHeightExport(); ++<<<<<<< HEAD  +    void testNamedRangeBugfdo62729(); ++======= +     void testSheetProtectionXLSX(); ++>>>>>>> 6bd9a91... 1st step fix for exporting SheetProtection fdo#64753 is to import correctly          CPPUNIT_TEST_SUITE(ScExportTest);       CPPUNIT_TEST(test); @@@ -64,7 -65,8 +69,12 @@@       CPPUNIT_TEST(testColorScaleExportODS);       CPPUNIT_TEST(testColorScaleExportXLSX);       CPPUNIT_TEST(testMiscRowHeightExport); ++<<<<<<< HEAD  +    CPPUNIT_TEST(testNamedRangeBugfdo62729); ++======= +     CPPUNIT_TEST(testSheetProtectionXLSX); +  ++>>>>>>> 6bd9a91... 1st step fix for exporting SheetProtection fdo#64753 is to import correctly       CPPUNIT_TEST_SUITE_END();      private: @@@ -294,31 -296,31 +304,59 @@@ void ScExportTest::testMiscRowHeightExp       miscRowHeightsTest( aTestValues, SAL_N_ELEMENTS(aTestValues) );   }    ++<<<<<<< HEAD  +  +void ScExportTest::testNamedRangeBugfdo62729()  +{  +    ScDocShellRef xShell = loadDoc("fdo62729.", ODS);  +    CPPUNIT_ASSERT(xShell.Is());  +    ScDocument* pDoc = xShell->GetDocument();  +    CPPUNIT_ASSERT(pDoc);  +  +    ScRangeName* pNames = pDoc->GetRangeName();  +    //should be just a single named range  +    CPPUNIT_ASSERT(pNames->size() == 1 );  +    pDoc->DeleteTab(0);  +    //should be still a single named range  +    CPPUNIT_ASSERT(pNames->size() == 1 );  +    ScDocShellRef xDocSh = saveAndReload(xShell, ODS);  +    xShell->DoClose();  +  +    CPPUNIT_ASSERT(xDocSh.Is());  +    pDoc = xDocSh->GetDocument();  +    CPPUNIT_ASSERT(pDoc);  +  +    pNames = pDoc->GetRangeName();  +    //after reload should still have a named range  +    CPPUNIT_ASSERT(pNames->size() == 1 );  + ++======= + void ScExportTest::testSheetProtectionXLSX() + { +     ScDocShellRef xShell = loadDoc("ProtecteSheet1234Pass.", XLSX); +     CPPUNIT_ASSERT(xShell.Is()); +  +     ScDocShellRef xDocSh = saveAndReload(xShell, XLSX); +     CPPUNIT_ASSERT(xDocSh.Is()); +  +     ScDocument* pDoc = xDocSh->GetDocument(); +     CPPUNIT_ASSERT(pDoc); +     const ScTableProtection* pTabProtect = pDoc->GetTabProtection(0); +     CPPUNIT_ASSERT(pTabProtect); +     if ( pTabProtect ) +     { +         Sequence<sal_Int8> aHash = pTabProtect->getPasswordHash(PASSHASH_XL); +         // check has +         if (aHash.getLength() >= 2) +         { +             CPPUNIT_ASSERT( (sal_uInt8)aHash[0] == 204 ); +             CPPUNIT_ASSERT( (sal_uInt8)aHash[1] == 61 ); +         } +         // we could flesh out this check I guess +         CPPUNIT_ASSERT ( pTabProtect->isOptionEnabled( ScTableProtection::OBJECTS ) ); +         CPPUNIT_ASSERT ( pTabProtect->isOptionEnabled( ScTableProtection::SCENARIOS ) ); +     } ++>>>>>>> 6bd9a91... 1st step fix for exporting SheetProtection fdo#64753 is to import correctly       xDocSh->DoClose();   }

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedWork in progress. This is a quite complex dialog, full of corner conditions1) Widget sizes should be adjusted at will2) The Line preview (CTL_PREVIEW) need to be fixed for correct display3) To test the dialog: Create a spreadsheet with one graphic object and one line chart. 4) Inside the chart, select the data series line object and click "format selection". The icon sub-dialog now appears. In the icon sub-dialog, the menu button allows many choices. The #define scalars for the menu choices had to be adjusted. I have no idea on the scalar  values definition except by looking at the packing of the menuitem (order in packing).The Gallery option shows a long list of graphics objects, not all work, specially png's and svg's. This is a bug, and I wil file it when the patch is committed.5) Selecting the graphic object outside the chart will show arrow styles and corner & caps sub-menus. Adjust listbox sizes at will.6) The previous non-widget dialog had glitches in the enable/disable condition for the arrow styles starts/ends.7) A whishlist: Some GtK widgets (mostly listboxes and spinboxes) should have a label associated, so that Enable/Disable and Show/Hidecan be simplified (like checkboxes and radiobuttons).
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedWork in progress. This is a quite complex dialog, full of corner conditions1) Widget sizes should be adjusted at will2) The Line preview (CTL_PREVIEW) need to be fixed for correct display3) To test the dialog: Create a spreadsheet with one graphic object and one line chart. 4) Inside the chart, select the data series line object and click "format selection". The icon sub-dialog now appears. In the icon sub-dialog, the menu button allows many choices. The #define scalars for the menu choices had to be adjusted. I have no idea on the scalar  values definition except by looking at the packing of the menuitem (order in packing).The Gallery option shows a long list of graphics objects, not all work, specially png's and svg's. This is a bug, and I wil file it when the patch is committed.5) Selecting the graphic object outside the chart will show arrow styles and corner & caps sub-menus. Adjust listbox sizes at will.6) The previous non-widget dialog had glitches in the enable/disable condition for the arrow styles starts/ends.7) A whishlist: Some GtK widgets (mostly listboxes and spinboxes) should have a label associated, so that Enable/Disable and Show/Hidecan be simplified (like checkboxes and radiobuttons).

text: Patch Set 2: This need some tweaks before it is mergedThis looks much better now. The only remaining problem is in SvxXMLListLevelStyleContext_Impl::GetProperties(): you're currently writing uninitialized memory there: at the start, the array size is defined as "cBullet ? 15 : 14", but then later you now unconditionally write the array, so after your change, the size in the bBullet == true case should be unconditionally 15, right?See http://pastebin.com/raw.php?i=jPBnAKLm
Text: Patch Set 2: This need some tweaks before it is mergedThis looks much better now. The only remaining problem is in SvxXMLListLevelStyleContext_Impl::GetProperties(): you're currently writing uninitialized memory there: at the start, the array size is defined as "cBullet ? 15 : 14", but then later you now unconditionally write the array, so after your change, the size in the bBullet == true case should be unconditionally 15, right?See http://pastebin.com/raw.php?i=jPBnAKLm

text: Patch Set 3: This need some tweaks before it is mergedThis still isn't quite right for merging. But now it appears for me without a crash, though a few bits of functionality aren't working yet.I wonder if you are not building with --enable-dbgutil. With --enable-dbgutil you get error messages like "element foo should be a FixedText" and hints like that.I wonder if instead of moving the "optionshelper" code into this cxx if it would be better to duplicate it as a "newoptionshelper" because it seems the other filter dialog uses the old one so when that dialog is converted over as well it might be able to use the new helper
Text: Patch Set 3: This need some tweaks before it is mergedThis still isn't quite right for merging. But now it appears for me without a crash, though a few bits of functionality aren't working yet.I wonder if you are not building with --enable-dbgutil. With --enable-dbgutil you get error messages like "element foo should be a FixedText" and hints like that.I wonder if instead of moving the "optionshelper" code into this cxx if it would be better to duplicate it as a "newoptionshelper" because it seems the other filter dialog uses the old one so when that dialog is converted over as well it might be able to use the new helper

text: Patch Set 1: Fails; This need some tweaks before it is mergedThe filtering works with the patch but I have lost the pivot table when refreshing.Steps to reproduce:1. Open the original test document  "Pivot table with data groups.ods" from  https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=639982. Press right mouse button in the cell [A5] and select    "Refresh"Result: The pivot table is broken. The data are missing. It shows only the titles, so it has 3 rows and 2 columns:      Sum - TimeSpent	Billable      Years	        Total Result      Total ResultResult without the patch: It shows large table with all      non-filtered data.Expoected result: It should show the original table with 8       rows and 7 columnsNote that I do not see this problem when I change the filter in the cell [B3] before doing the refresh. I guess that a pointer is not-initialized correctly during the start or so.Anyway, the new problem is a kind of data loss => we should not push this patch for 4-1-0 in this state.Note that the problem has already been in 4.0. I think that the proper fix could wait for 4.1.1 bugfix release.

text: Patch Set 1:My undersdtanding is that it reverts the code back to the state in 2001, see http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/commit/?id=1903d481790c799a110cda43a436e472ab554aadThere was:--- cut ---- for( sal_Int32 nIdx = 0; nIdx < nCount; nIdx++ )- pState[nIdx] = getPropertyState( pNames[nIdx] );+ if( mpImpl->mpMaster )+ {+ for( sal_Int32 nIdx = 0; nIdx < nCount; nIdx++ )+ pState[nIdx] = getPropertyState( pNames[nIdx] );++ }+ else+ {+ for( sal_Int32 nIdx = 0; nIdx < nCount; nIdx++ )+ pState[nIdx] = getPropertyState( pNames[nIdx] );+ }--- cut ---This change added the if condition but still the same for-cycle was called in both ways.If I am not blind, David did a long cycle back to the pre-2001 code.
Text: Patch Set 1:My undersdtanding is that it reverts the code back to the state in 2001, see http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/commit/?id=1903d481790c799a110cda43a436e472ab554aadThere was:--- cut ---- for( sal_Int32 nIdx = 0; nIdx < nCount; nIdx++ )- pState[nIdx] = getPropertyState( pNames[nIdx] );+ if( mpImpl->mpMaster )+ {+ for( sal_Int32 nIdx = 0; nIdx < nCount; nIdx++ )+ pState[nIdx] = getPropertyState( pNames[nIdx] );++ }+ else+ {+ for( sal_Int32 nIdx = 0; nIdx < nCount; nIdx++ )+ pState[nIdx] = getPropertyState( pNames[nIdx] );+ }--- cut ---This change added the if condition but still the same for-cycle was called in both ways.If I am not blind, David did a long cycle back to the pre-2001 code.

text: Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)Two comments in addition to Eike's comment:* It would be good to give the rationale for this change in the commit message (presumably, to get it in line with the changed UNOIDL struct).* osl_getDateTimeFromTimeValue and osl_getTimeValueFromDateTime in sal/osl/w32/time.c needed no conversion precautions in the past, given that Windows SYSTEMTIME's wYear is a WORD (i.e., same underlying value range as sal_uInt16).  Now, strictly speaking, one would need to check that pDateTime->Year >= 0 before assining it to aSystemTime.wYear in osl_getTimeValueFromDateTime.  However, wYear is documented as "The valid values for this member are 1601 through 30827," so negative pDateTime->Year values would in practice wrap around to wYear >= 32768 > 30827 and SystemTimeToFileTime should return false, so everything should happen to work out fine.
Text: Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)Two comments in addition to Eike's comment:* It would be good to give the rationale for this change in the commit message (presumably, to get it in line with the changed UNOIDL struct).* osl_getDateTimeFromTimeValue and osl_getTimeValueFromDateTime in sal/osl/w32/time.c needed no conversion precautions in the past, given that Windows SYSTEMTIME's wYear is a WORD (i.e., same underlying value range as sal_uInt16).  Now, strictly speaking, one would need to check that pDateTime->Year >= 0 before assining it to aSystemTime.wYear in osl_getTimeValueFromDateTime.  However, wYear is documented as "The valid values for this member are 1601 through 30827," so negative pDateTime->Year values would in practice wrap around to wYear >= 32768 > 30827 and SystemTimeToFileTime should return false, so everything should happen to work out fine.

text: Patch Set 4:Sigh, too late, but I am still not convinced about the usefulness of changes like this.Changing arbitrary comments in module-internal headers to "meet Doxygen standards", huh? Do we even run doxygen on these headers? To more or less repeat my objections in another similar change, what is the point in having Doxygen-handled documents for just some fields in an otherwise totally undocumented class? Who would get any useful information from reading such Doxygen-generated woefully incomplete documentation?Any comments from the change author, please?

text: Patch Set 3: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedLooks good, but the contents of the listboxes got lost. The "stringlists" of old ListBoxes in .src files can be described in .ui as GtkComboBoxText and fill the list into the "items" of that. (There is another more complicated way to do it with GtkComboBox by adding a ComboBox Model to them, but we only need to do that if we need to, e.g. associated data with an entry)
Text: Patch Set 3: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedLooks good, but the contents of the listboxes got lost. The "stringlists" of old ListBoxes in .src files can be described in .ui as GtkComboBoxText and fill the list into the "items" of that. (There is another more complicated way to do it with GtkComboBox by adding a ComboBox Model to them, but we only need to do that if we need to, e.g. associated data with an entry)

text: Patch Set 2:> Heh, I wonder if such table names are supported also by the other functionality, e.g. queries, views. Anyway, this fix allows users to rename them at least ;-)That's up to the database engine. Essentially, you have to understand that "Query" is an SQL command that is stored by LibreOffice in the .odb file. So the "name" of that query is something that is up to LibreOffice, the database engine never sees it. That's why "SELECT * from qryName" will not work, because this will send qryName to the database engine, and it does not know it.As far as queries are concerned, code archeology shows that this special treatment of '/' in query names dates back from a "new feature: hierarchical queries". I have no clue what this feature is :)However, views are a database engine feature. They are an SQL command that is stored by the database engine in the database. Their name is up to the database engine. As such, they are just like tables to LibreOffice: LibreOffice selects, updates, deletes, etc from them directly (as far as supported by the database engine).
Text: Patch Set 2:> Heh, I wonder if such table names are supported also by the other functionality, e.g. queries, views. Anyway, this fix allows users to rename them at least ;-)That's up to the database engine. Essentially, you have to understand that "Query" is an SQL command that is stored by LibreOffice in the .odb file. So the "name" of that query is something that is up to LibreOffice, the database engine never sees it. That's why "SELECT * from qryName" will not work, because this will send qryName to the database engine, and it does not know it.As far as queries are concerned, code archeology shows that this special treatment of '/' in query names dates back from a "new feature: hierarchical queries". I have no clue what this feature is :)However, views are a database engine feature. They are an SQL command that is stored by the database engine in the database. Their name is up to the database engine. As such, they are just like tables to LibreOffice: LibreOffice selects, updates, deletes, etc from them directly (as far as supported by the database engine).

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedAndras is right: the 64bit dlls are copied to solver/bin so that the installer finds them since they are packaged as files, while the 32bit ones are in some mystery MSM thingy and (apparently) don't need to be in solver.confusingly the same find_msvc_x64_dlls function also finds debug dlls (for the build CPU architecture, not necessarily 64bit), which should not be in the installation set; i'm not sure if it's actually necessary to copy these to solver/bin nowadays (AFAIR it was needed for MSVC 2008 but they should actually be installed on the system by MSVC).so clearly there's some need for cleanup here.
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedAndras is right: the 64bit dlls are copied to solver/bin so that the installer finds them since they are packaged as files, while the 32bit ones are in some mystery MSM thingy and (apparently) don't need to be in solver.confusingly the same find_msvc_x64_dlls function also finds debug dlls (for the build CPU architecture, not necessarily 64bit), which should not be in the installation set; i'm not sure if it's actually necessary to copy these to solver/bin nowadays (AFAIR it was needed for MSVC 2008 but they should actually be installed on the system by MSVC).so clearly there's some need for cleanup here.

text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedyes it's rather horrible... another problem with operator>> and operator<< is the reliance on overloading for _binary_ IO - i.e. change the type of a variable or return value somewhere and _maybe_ you've accidentally changed the serialization format.... we'd like to replace the overload mess by explicit Write16/Read16/etc. calls eventuallyhttps://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=56110

text: Patch Set 2:So this script would replace occurrences of e.g.  #include "sal/config.h"with  #include <sal/config.h>The latter is wrong, or at least less portable than the former (and thus the script should never be used to modify the code base).  The <...> form is for standard headers (provided through the compiler), while the "..." form is for arbitrary source files (provided by the compiler's client).  (The use of "header" in the Standard does not necessarily reflect colloquial usage of that term.  The exact mechanisms are implementation-defined in any case, but the <compiler/platform> vs. "client" is the general idea.  And I know that lots of places in the code erroneously use the <sal/config.h> form, but that doesn't mean that it is good; it just never bothered anybody enough in practice to fix it.)
Text: Patch Set 2:So this script would replace occurrences of e.g.  #include "sal/config.h"with  #include <sal/config.h>The latter is wrong, or at least less portable than the former (and thus the script should never be used to modify the code base).  The <...> form is for standard headers (provided through the compiler), while the "..." form is for arbitrary source files (provided by the compiler's client).  (The use of "header" in the Standard does not necessarily reflect colloquial usage of that term.  The exact mechanisms are implementation-defined in any case, but the <compiler/platform> vs. "client" is the general idea.  And I know that lots of places in the code erroneously use the <sal/config.h> form, but that doesn't mean that it is good; it just never bothered anybody enough in practice to fix it.)

text: Patch Set 2:New in patch 2:* Kept OUString concatenation, after verifying that it is considered the best solution* Reverted to local YES/NO temporaries, as suggested* Reverted changes to SvxBrushItem, which required hacks to surrounding code and will be better addressed when the related code will also be updated to O(U)String.Still gives the same error in sc_unoapi when it is executed by plain make check, no error when executed by itself. Any hint on how to solve this? I can upload the log, if necessary. Without this patch, I had two failures in writer. I do not know if all faults are reported at the end of the process or if the checks are stopped as soon as one is found, though.Finally, the patch touches some files in sc: impact on Kohei Yoshida's work should be evaluated before committing.
Text: Patch Set 2:New in patch 2:* Kept OUString concatenation, after verifying that it is considered the best solution* Reverted to local YES/NO temporaries, as suggested* Reverted changes to SvxBrushItem, which required hacks to surrounding code and will be better addressed when the related code will also be updated to O(U)String.Still gives the same error in sc_unoapi when it is executed by plain make check, no error when executed by itself. Any hint on how to solve this? I can upload the log, if necessary. Without this patch, I had two failures in writer. I do not know if all faults are reported at the end of the process or if the checks are stopped as soon as one is found, though.Finally, the patch touches some files in sc: impact on Kohei Yoshida's work should be evaluated before committing.

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedIf you want to turn Automatic and AutoSize into one string, I would rather go for AutoSize instead. Rationale: Automatic is too generic, while AutoSize also mentions that the automatism affects size here.Also, help explicitly talks about "AutoSize feature", so removing that would be confusing:https://help.libreoffice.org/Writer/Inserting,_Editing,_and_Linking_Text_FramesRenaming it to "Automatic feature" would be confusing as well.
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedIf you want to turn Automatic and AutoSize into one string, I would rather go for AutoSize instead. Rationale: Automatic is too generic, while AutoSize also mentions that the automatism affects size here.Also, help explicitly talks about "AutoSize feature", so removing that would be confusing:https://help.libreoffice.org/Writer/Inserting,_Editing,_and_Linking_Text_FramesRenaming it to "Automatic feature" would be confusing as well.

Text: Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveThis bombs Windows tinderbox: http://tinderbox.libreoffice.org/cgi-bin/gunzip.cgi?tree=MASTER&brief-log=1370625602.29405#11958 There will need to be some casting to disambiguate. text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is merged(1 inline comment)This looks like it changes the operation from thread-safe to thread-unsafe. For a well-known example of this issue, see e.g. the difference between strtok and strtok_r in libc. Unless access to the ShapeList is always mutex'ed (wich I don't see as being the case), this is unsafe.There are several alternatives how to proceed to make traversing the list linear:1) Just use getList() and iterate over that2) implement the C++/STL iterator concept for ShapeList and use that in calling code instead of getNextShape
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is merged(1 inline comment)This looks like it changes the operation from thread-safe to thread-unsafe. For a well-known example of this issue, see e.g. the difference between strtok and strtok_r in libc. Unless access to the ShapeList is always mutex'ed (wich I don't see as being the case), this is unsafe.There are several alternatives how to proceed to make traversing the list linear:1) Just use getList() and iterate over that2) implement the C++/STL iterator concept for ShapeList and use that in calling code instead of getNextShape

text: Patch Set 2:Are you sure there will never be two intermixed accesses to the same ShapeList? Internal iterators are rather fragile and easily break in mysterious ways in such cases.

text: Patch Set 1:Yes, I used the mechanism that the existing code used. The unicode/uchar.h header explicitly marks each UBLOCK as being stable since a particular version. Which is how the versions were derived. e.g: UBLOCK_MANDAIC Stable: ICU 4.6
Text: Patch Set 1:Yes, I used the mechanism that the existing code used. The unicode/uchar.h header explicitly marks each UBLOCK as being stable since a particular version. Which is how the versions were derived. e.g: UBLOCK_MANDAIC Stable: ICU 4.6

text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedThe change makes sense and looks safe. It basically affects just the reportbuilder stuff that was clearly broken and works now.I have doubled checked also the older related bugs: fdo#60910, fdo#56980 and they are still fixed.Thanks a lot for chasing this nasty problem.Just a small nitpicking. I personally try to avoid boolean variables with negative names. The logic is harder to read because "True" value means that something is actually disabled and vice versa. It gets even verse if you use it in some logic expression, especially with negation '!' ;-)Anyway, great work.
Text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedThe change makes sense and looks safe. It basically affects just the reportbuilder stuff that was clearly broken and works now.I have doubled checked also the older related bugs: fdo#60910, fdo#56980 and they are still fixed.Thanks a lot for chasing this nasty problem.Just a small nitpicking. I personally try to avoid boolean variables with negative names. The logic is harder to read because "True" value means that something is actually disabled and vice versa. It gets even verse if you use it in some logic expression, especially with negation '!' ;-)Anyway, great work.

text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergeunfortunately there's a substantial problem here - Fedora ships jpeg 6 and the maintainer has publicly stated that packaging jpeg 8 will not happen:http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.linux.redhat.fedora.devel/173253http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.linux.redhat.fedora.devel/173299so we should not have a hard dependency on any features that are not in jpeg 6.
Text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergeunfortunately there's a substantial problem here - Fedora ships jpeg 6 and the maintainer has publicly stated that packaging jpeg 8 will not happen:http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.linux.redhat.fedora.devel/173253http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.linux.redhat.fedora.devel/173299so we should not have a hard dependency on any features that are not in jpeg 6.

text: Patch Set 2:Michael, if you download the vanilla libjpeg fom here http://www.ijg.org/files/ you don't have JERR_BAD_CROP_SPEC in jpeg6b but you have it in jpeg7. Then from a user point of view JERR_BAD_CROP_SPEC means nothing and i'd prefer suggest a version that to force one download and grep source code. I think fedora (and other distros i suppose) have patched versions?
Text: Patch Set 2:Michael, if you download the vanilla libjpeg fom here http://www.ijg.org/files/ you don't have JERR_BAD_CROP_SPEC in jpeg6b but you have it in jpeg7. Then from a user point of view JERR_BAD_CROP_SPEC means nothing and i'd prefer suggest a version that to force one download and grep source code. I think fedora (and other distros i suppose) have patched versions?

Text: Patch Set 2:FYI his had to be reverted ( I suppose I should have done that through gerrit ) somehow I thought it probably would be smart enough to see the change was revert so now this change is marked as merged ( but clearly not anymore )Any the problem with this patch is that 'incend' ( a global array ) points to parts of the allocated pIncEnv so it can't be freed :-(

text: Patch Set 4:I am not really happy about the commit message. Reading it, it is hard to understand what effect the patch actually has. Please don't use passive voice. Write simple, imperative statements describing what effect the patch has.If you need to refer to the behaviour of code before the patch, be explicit, as in "Foo previously did bar", not "The way it works now". (Saying how something works "now" is ambiguous, does it mean "now, after this patch" or "now, before this patch".)Instead of "saving to docx is fixed", say "fix saving to docx". (But does the patch really fix saving to docx in general, was that broken? Or do you mean compared to a previous version of the patch? In that case, no need to mention it, once this goes into git, any iterations ("patch sets") it had in gerrit is irrelevant.
Text: Patch Set 4:I am not really happy about the commit message. Reading it, it is hard to understand what effect the patch actually has. Please don't use passive voice. Write simple, imperative statements describing what effect the patch has.If you need to refer to the behaviour of code before the patch, be explicit, as in "Foo previously did bar", not "The way it works now". (Saying how something works "now" is ambiguous, does it mean "now, after this patch" or "now, before this patch".)Instead of "saving to docx is fixed", say "fix saving to docx". (But does the patch really fix saving to docx in general, was that broken? Or do you mean compared to a previous version of the patch? In that case, no need to mention it, once this goes into git, any iterations ("patch sets") it had in gerrit is irrelevant.

text: Patch Set 4:Sure. And sorry for nitpicking about the commit message...

text: Patch Set 1:I'm not 100% sure, which is why I didn't push direct :-)Initializing a Mutext should include a memory barrier, which would provide make sure the code was seeing a fairly recent view of the data, if it was executing multi-threaded on a multi-core CPU.But it provides no actual exclusion, so it's weak protection at best.I say either delete it or implement it properly (I'm happy to do either).
Text: Patch Set 1:I'm not 100% sure, which is why I didn't push direct :-)Initializing a Mutext should include a memory barrier, which would provide make sure the code was seeing a fairly recent view of the data, if it was executing multi-threaded on a multi-core CPU.But it provides no actual exclusion, so it's weak protection at best.I say either delete it or implement it properly (I'm happy to do either).

text: Patch Set 1:The commit comment is confusing. Does the comment describe the behaviour after the commi, or the behaviour before the commit?If this change makes "freezing" (whatever that is) mark a spreadsheet as unsaved, then the commit comment could in my humble opinion simply say so, "Mark spreadsheet as unsaved when freezing it"Is the "freeze" term well-known enough among Calc hackers? If not, maybe some more lines describing what that is would be appropriate.

text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedI'll do the code adaptation on these. For the .ui itself, if you want a help button on the left of a buttonbox then start with a normal button box, put in ok, cancel and help buttons and then on the help button use packing->secondary and that will make it appear on other side of the dialog.
Text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedI'll do the code adaptation on these. For the .ui itself, if you want a help button on the left of a buttonbox then start with a normal button box, put in ok, cancel and help buttons and then on the help button use packing->secondary and that will make it appear on other side of the dialog.

text: Patch Set 1:This mostly works but there are serious issues with combining marks (only Arabic was tested); somewhere else in the code assumption (that are clearly wrong) are mad about how glyphs gets positioned, which seems to be specific to the way ICU LE reports glyph positions.There is a huge performance improvement for complex text layout when using HarfBuzz, see files from fdo#63656.
Text: Patch Set 1:This mostly works but there are serious issues with combining marks (only Arabic was tested); somewhere else in the code assumption (that are clearly wrong) are mad about how glyphs gets positioned, which seems to be specific to the way ICU LE reports glyph positions.There is a huge performance improvement for complex text layout when using HarfBuzz, see files from fdo#63656.

Text: Patch Set 1:include <algorithm> is correct.However, as is this may (didn't try) fail to compile on Windows because MSVC defines min/max macros in <windows.h>, was this already build tested on Windows?If it breaks, to solve, our header files that include <windows.h> should   #define NOMINMAX #include <windows.h>or also define NOMINMAX before including any of Windows specific header files that may in turn include <windows.h>

text: Patch Set 2:Hi Eike, I was unable to reply on the thread of the inline comments so I preferred to write those things here:If I don't make the changes in sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx, then on doing 'make' I get an error :/home/elixir/libo/sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx: In static member function ÔÇÿstatic void ScXMLConverter::GetStringFromFunction(rtl::OUString&, ScSubTotalFunc, bool)ÔÇÖ:/home/elixir/libo/sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx:145:11: error: enumeration value ÔÇÿSUBTOTAL_FUNC_SELECTION_COUNTÔÇÖ not handled in switch [-Werror=switch]cc1plus: all warnings being treated as errors .with --enable-werror [ I enabled this, since warnings are no good and mac crashes with warnings is what I've learnt through irc conversations ].So handling ÔÇÿSUBTOTAL_FUNC_SELECTION_COUNTÔÇÖ in switch became necessary.The rest of xml file changes follow this change.And definitely I shall take care of indentation. :)I small doubt: Should the hidden rows be counted in 'Selection count', i.e. if the row was hidden, its value should be added or not?ThanksPrashant
Text: Patch Set 2:Hi Eike, I was unable to reply on the thread of the inline comments so I preferred to write those things here:If I don't make the changes in sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx, then on doing 'make' I get an error :/home/elixir/libo/sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx: In static member function 脭脟每static void ScXMLConverter::GetStringFromFunction(rtl::OUString&, ScSubTotalFunc, bool)脭脟脰:/home/elixir/libo/sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx:145:11: error: enumeration value 脭脟每SUBTOTAL_FUNC_SELECTION_COUNT脭脟脰 not handled in switch [-Werror=switch]cc1plus: all warnings being treated as errors .with --enable-werror [ I enabled this, since warnings are no good and mac crashes with warnings is what I've learnt through irc conversations ].So handling 脭脟每SUBTOTAL_FUNC_SELECTION_COUNT脭脟脰 in switch became necessary.The rest of xml file changes follow this change.And definitely I shall take care of indentation. :)I small doubt: Should the hidden rows be counted in 'Selection count', i.e. if the row was hidden, its value should be added or not?ThanksPrashant

text: Patch Set 2:> If I don't make the changes in sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx, then on doing 'make' I get an error :As discussed on IRC, handle that with an empty case statement.> And definitely I shall take care of indentation. :)Good :-)> I small doubt: Should the hidden rows be counted in 'Selection count', i.e. if the row was hidden, its value should be added or not?Good question.. I think they should be treated the same as for the otherfunction cases so that Count2 and SelectionCount deliver the same resultif all selected cells are filled with data.
Text: Patch Set 2:> If I don't make the changes in sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx, then on doing 'make' I get an error :As discussed on IRC, handle that with an empty case statement.> And definitely I shall take care of indentation. :)Good :-)> I small doubt: Should the hidden rows be counted in 'Selection count', i.e. if the row was hidden, its value should be added or not?Good question.. I think they should be treated the same as for the otherfunction cases so that Count2 and SelectionCount deliver the same resultif all selected cells are filled with data.

text: Patch Set 6: This need some tweaks before it is mergedI rebased the patch to current master to apply, in the mean time sc/inc/globstr.hrc got additional entries added. Also changed the overly long one-line comment to a more readable comment preceding the code line. Please avoid lines longer than 120 characters if possible.Please update your patch with this one.Other than that it looks good so far, there's just one little annoyance:If from a selection one cell is removed with Ctrl+LeftClick the count is not updated, it looks as if the current cell cursor position is always counted, even if a selection not including that position exists. This is not the case with for example the CountA function for which the count is correctly decremented by one.Could you please look into that?

This is not the case with for example the CountA function for which the count is correctly decremented by one.Could you please look into that?

text: Patch Set 1:This patch fixed the conditional style handling of tables if importing docx files. As described in: http://social.msdn.microsoft.com/Forums/en-US/os_openXML-ecma/thread/1febafab-67d7-4a26-ac51-fec69a39c2fe/The cnfStyle doesn't have a function and should not be used to determine the table style, instead the tblLook property has to be used.I fixed this, I added a bugdoc that contains a table without cnfStyle Properties, this file looks bad in LO, but good in Word.As a side effect, now also the table corner styles are imported properly.Best regards,Sven
Text: Patch Set 1:This patch fixed the conditional style handling of tables if importing docx files. As described in: http://social.msdn.microsoft.com/Forums/en-US/os_openXML-ecma/thread/1febafab-67d7-4a26-ac51-fec69a39c2fe/The cnfStyle doesn't have a function and should not be used to determine the table style, instead the tblLook property has to be used.I fixed this, I added a bugdoc that contains a table without cnfStyle Properties, this file looks bad in LO, but good in Word.As a side effect, now also the table corner styles are imported properly.Best regards,Sven

text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approveduploaded a new patch set just to rebase on dtardon's makefile renaming, nothing changed here.a) For aligning things the trick is to have *another* size group with the labels in it, that way they all request the same size and it works out as expected.Well, it should, it appears I have a small bug in how that works. It seems that margins should be part of the request, but I'm adding those on after the request, not as part of the request. But we can workaround that by putting a one element box around the elements with margins and put those boxes into the size group instead. That way it works now, and will continue to work after I change the request+margin logic.b) The tristates are a pain, I thought they would be very rare elements. Catch is that they are always set to "state unknown" on .ui load, while in .src load they default to "state nocheck". So, yeah, to be super sure that the logic is unchanged its best to set them explicitly in .cxx to "state nocheck". I'll do that in a follow up patch.c) As an aside, the accessibility relation between the checkbox and the numeric field can be retained in the .ui with label-for/label-by under the a11y tab of glade (wheelchair icon). If it was a label and a numeric field then the mnemonic_widget relationship would add a default accessibility label-for/label-by relationship which is why the other "Start at" element doesn't need or have that.
Text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approveduploaded a new patch set just to rebase on dtardon's makefile renaming, nothing changed here.a) For aligning things the trick is to have *another* size group with the labels in it, that way they all request the same size and it works out as expected.Well, it should, it appears I have a small bug in how that works. It seems that margins should be part of the request, but I'm adding those on after the request, not as part of the request. But we can workaround that by putting a one element box around the elements with margins and put those boxes into the size group instead. That way it works now, and will continue to work after I change the request+margin logic.b) The tristates are a pain, I thought they would be very rare elements. Catch is that they are always set to "state unknown" on .ui load, while in .src load they default to "state nocheck". So, yeah, to be super sure that the logic is unchanged its best to set them explicitly in .cxx to "state nocheck". I'll do that in a follow up patch.c) As an aside, the accessibility relation between the checkbox and the numeric field can be retained in the .ui with label-for/label-by under the a11y tab of glade (wheelchair icon). If it was a label and a numeric field then the mnemonic_widget relationship would add a default accessibility label-for/label-by relationship which is why the other "Start at" element doesn't need or have that.

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedIn general I like the idea, but any reason you use #ifdef and command line arguments, instead of #if and config_host/ for this purpose? See ab7ac5884c5a824999b58d2a800cae64cb8e359a for an example on how to add a new entry to config_host/.That makes the commandline shorter (more readable) and with #if, there is a build-time check if the necessary .h was included or not.
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedIn general I like the idea, but any reason you use #ifdef and command line arguments, instead of #if and config_host/ for this purpose? See ab7ac5884c5a824999b58d2a800cae64cb8e359a for an example on how to add a new entry to config_host/.That makes the commandline shorter (more readable) and with #if, there is a build-time check if the necessary .h was included or not.

text: Patch Set 4:This code looks like it concerns the query design UI.If that function is called each time the user changes something in there, then the field name/formula (aField string in the code) can definitely be empty, since the user can type anything. Whether that is a valid choice, and whether we catch that "user error" earlier is another question. In other words: it may or may not be that in the case of an empty aField, that codepath is not taken at all. Given the situation, I'd rather not rely on aField's non-emptyness (too much).But from a semantic point of view, the issue is moot anyway, since that test should be aField == "*"and not aField.beginsWith("*")I'm changing that in master.
Text: Patch Set 4:This code looks like it concerns the query design UI.If that function is called each time the user changes something in there, then the field name/formula (aField string in the code) can definitely be empty, since the user can type anything. Whether that is a valid choice, and whether we catch that "user error" earlier is another question. In other words: it may or may not be that in the case of an empty aField, that codepath is not taken at all. Given the situation, I'd rather not rely on aField's non-emptyness (too much).But from a semantic point of view, the issue is moot anyway, since that test should be aField == "*"and not aField.beginsWith("*")I'm changing that in master.

text: Patch Set 2:"Maybe there should be a check for length before accessing the element at operator[] as the comment describes @param"I'm not sure patch set 2 is actually an improvement.  Adding a check for a condition without knowing whether the condition can actually ever not hold is a slippery slope down "defensive programming" that leads to unmaintainable code.  ("What /are/ the invariants of that code?" people will start to ask, seeing a mixture of redundant and non-redundant checks.)Given that the original code did not check for validity of accessing index 0, that could either mean that it was sloppy and "cleverly" relied on the fact that both String and OUString are null-terminated, so accessing index 0 is always valid technically (and the check for '*' guaranteed to fail for the empty string), or that there's an invariant enforcing aField to be non-empty anyway.Only in the first case would patch set 2 be an improvement.  In the latter case, the correct fix would rather be an assert(!aField.isEmpty()).Maybe Lionel can shed some light on this?
Text: Patch Set 2:"Maybe there should be a check for length before accessing the element at operator[] as the comment describes @param"I'm not sure patch set 2 is actually an improvement.  Adding a check for a condition without knowing whether the condition can actually ever not hold is a slippery slope down "defensive programming" that leads to unmaintainable code.  ("What /are/ the invariants of that code?" people will start to ask, seeing a mixture of redundant and non-redundant checks.)Given that the original code did not check for validity of accessing index 0, that could either mean that it was sloppy and "cleverly" relied on the fact that both String and OUString are null-terminated, so accessing index 0 is always valid technically (and the check for '*' guaranteed to fail for the empty string), or that there's an invariant enforcing aField to be non-empty anyway.Only in the first case would patch set 2 be an improvement.  In the latter case, the correct fix would rather be an assert(!aField.isEmpty()).Maybe Lionel can shed some light on this?

text: Patch Set 2:Ricardo: Ah it was not meant that Patchset1 is not good. Only some loud thinking about GetChar()/operator[] and what happens if that accesses an index greater the string len.Stephan: I set you as reviewer to get an opinion, if it's a possible problem if operator[] accesses an index out of range. If yes, then maybe a check for that should be in the operator[] method. Or am I wrong?
Text: Patch Set 2:Ricardo: Ah it was not meant that Patchset1 is not good. Only some loud thinking about GetChar()/operator[] and what happens if that accesses an index greater the string len.Stephan: I set you as reviewer to get an opinion, if it's a possible problem if operator[] accesses an index out of range. If yes, then maybe a check for that should be in the operator[] method. Or am I wrong?

text: Patch Set 2:"I set you as reviewer to get an opinion, if it's a possible problem if operator[] accesses an index out of range. If yes, then maybe a check for that should be in the operator[] method. Or am I wrong?"Yes, rtl::O[U]String::operator[] -- with documented prerequisite "index must be non-negative and less than length" -- should contain an assert(index >= 0 && index < getLength());  I'll take care of that.However, esp. in code that got converted from tools' String to OUString (where String::CharAt remains silent about its prerequisites), there may be "clever" code that relies on s[s.getLength()] returning null.  That code would now be caught (in --enable-debug builds) at runtime due to the assert, and can be fixed to be less clever and more explicit.(Though that does not necessarily pertain to the code in SelectionBrowseBox.cxx, where it is still unclear whether aField can legitimately be empty.)
Text: Patch Set 2:"I set you as reviewer to get an opinion, if it's a possible problem if operator[] accesses an index out of range. If yes, then maybe a check for that should be in the operator[] method. Or am I wrong?"Yes, rtl::O[U]String::operator[] -- with documented prerequisite "index must be non-negative and less than length" -- should contain an assert(index >= 0 && index < getLength());  I'll take care of that.However, esp. in code that got converted from tools' String to OUString (where String::CharAt remains silent about its prerequisites), there may be "clever" code that relies on s[s.getLength()] returning null.  That code would now be caught (in --enable-debug builds) at runtime due to the assert, and can be fixed to be less clever and more explicit.(Though that does not necessarily pertain to the code in SelectionBrowseBox.cxx, where it is still unclear whether aField can legitimately be empty.)

text: Patch Set 5:Ok, it seems there's agreement to not copy header files and point into the UnpackedTarball ike you did, so we're clean from that side.BUT, please undo all the renaming of patches from icu4c to icu5c, that is not some version number in the name, but it is "ICU for C" as opposed to "ICU for Java" that also exists, icu4c is a term used by upstream.
Text: Patch Set 5:Ok, it seems there's agreement to not copy header files and point into the UnpackedTarball ike you did, so we're clean from that side.BUT, please undo all the renaming of patches from icu4c to icu5c, that is not some version number in the name, but it is "ICU for C" as opposed to "ICU for Java" that also exists, icu4c is a term used by upstream.

text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedI think that the code should be:if( pStk || ( eType == CurrPtCurrMk ) )By other words, we almost always need to have a valid pStk. The only exception is when eType == CurrPtCurrMk because then we do not use pStk.I think that this was even the original idea but it was not realized correctly. BTW: The problem has been there since the original import in 2000 :-)
Text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedI think that the code should be:if( pStk || ( eType == CurrPtCurrMk ) )By other words, we almost always need to have a valid pStk. text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedI have put back "band" instead of "bar". I know that it is not English word but it is used in the method and class names. I think that it is better to use this word and be consistent. The word "bar: would create another naming scheme and confusion ;-)Also I removed the added words "table" and "(inside cells)". I think that I know what you meant and it was kind of correct. But it was not a complete English sentence and the meaning was hard to understand. I think that less is sometimes more ;-)Finally, I left the "eventually" word. In the given context,  it sounds better to me than "maybe" or "possibly". Well, I am not a native speaker, so I might be wrong.Anywyay, I am pushing it now. Thank you both for translation and review.
Text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedI have put back "band" instead of "bar". I know that it is not English word but it is used in the method and class names. I think that it is better to use this word and be consistent. The word "bar: would create another naming scheme and confusion ;-)Also I removed the added words "table" and "(inside cells)". I think that I know what you meant and it was kind of correct. But it was not a complete English sentence and the meaning was hard to understand. I think that less is sometimes more ;-)Finally, I left the "eventually" word. In the given context,  it sounds better to me than "maybe" or "possibly". Well, I am not a native speaker, so I might be wrong.Anywyay, I am pushing it now. Thank you both for translation and review.

text: Patch Set 8:If the code says "OKButton" then the button has to be a stock gtk-ok button and if a "CancelButton" it has to be a stock gtk-cancel button. If they are not stock buttons they have to be PushButtons in the code.So I'll change the .ui for the cancel button to be a stock gtk-cancel and the code for the ok button (because it says "Create" and not "OK") to be a PushButton
Text: Patch Set 8:If the code says "OKButton" then the button has to be a stock gtk-ok button and if a "CancelButton" it has to be a stock gtk-cancel button. If they are not stock buttons they have to be PushButtons in the code.So I'll change the .ui for the cancel button to be a stock gtk-cancel and the code for the ok button (because it says "Create" and not "OK") to be a PushButton

text: Patch Set 2:I think the two load options should be set to not expand vertically, looks a bit silly.The warning could go under the dropdown that it applies to now that nothing has to be manually moved in the code.odfwarning never seems to appear but maybe that's a wider/theme bug
Text: Patch Set 2:I think the two load options should be set to not expand vertically, looks a bit silly.The warning could go under the dropdown that it applies to now that nothing has to be manually moved in the code.odfwarning never seems to appear but maybe that's a wider/theme bug

text: Patch Set 2:> I think the two load options should be set to not expand vertically, looks a bit silly.The reason I did it this way was because otherwise the width of the combo box would change dynamically depending on the current selection, and I wanted to avoid that. I guess I could have set the width to a fixed value, but I wanted the GUI toolkit to do the sizing, feels more flexible.> The warning could go under the dropdown that it applies to now that nothing has to be manually moved in the code.I put it in the end because it was there in the original code, and because otherwise I would have to leave an empty row there, or have everything under it move down when it appears. I thought I should try to keep all the GUI elements static, and not jump around when a user changes something, to avoid confusion.> odfwarning never seems to appear but maybe that's a wider/theme bugIt did appear for me under Linux Mint 14 MATE, what OS are you on?
Text: Patch Set 2:> I think the two load options should be set to not expand vertically, looks a bit silly.The reason I did it this way was because otherwise the width of the combo box would change dynamically depending on the current selection, and I wanted to avoid that. I guess I could have set the width to a fixed value, but I wanted the GUI toolkit to do the sizing, feels more flexible.> The warning could go under the dropdown that it applies to now that nothing has to be manually moved in the code.I put it in the end because it was there in the original code, and because otherwise I would have to leave an empty row there, or have everything under it move down when it appears. I thought I should try to keep all the GUI elements static, and not jump around when a user changes something, to avoid confusion.> odfwarning never seems to appear but maybe that's a wider/theme bugIt did appear for me under Linux Mint 14 MATE, what OS are you on?

text: Patch Set 2:> The reason I did it this way was because otherwise the width of the combo box would change dynamically depending on the current selection, and I wanted to avoid that.You could set Vertical Alignment to 'start' on the grid but that seems to break the text wrap...> or have everything under it move down when it appears.I think that's quite a good property for a warning but I'm not a UX guy so whatev :D
Text: Patch Set 2:> The reason I did it this way was because otherwise the width of the combo box would change dynamically depending on the current selection, and I wanted to avoid that.You could set Vertical Alignment to 'start' on the grid but that seems to break the text wrap...> or have everything under it move down when it appears.I think that's quite a good property for a warning but I'm not a UX guy so whatev :D

text: Patch Set 2:Just for the record: I am against this change. It removes <1500 lines of makefile code, but at the price of making the resulting makefile much less readable. It is not like there were any rapid development in bridges (resulting in the need to update many makefiles at the same time), so I do not see any problem with copy-pasted makefiles.
Text: Patch Set 2:Just for the record: I am against this change. It removes <1500 lines of makefile code, but at the price of making the resulting makefile much less readable. It is not like there were any rapid development in bridges (resulting in the need to update many makefiles at the same time), so I do not see any problem with copy-pasted makefiles.

text: Patch Set 1:(messed up when pushing the patches, they don't depend on each other, so ignore the "depends on")To answer your comments:"So we have unit test for it: FValueTest::test_Bool() What do you mean by failing checks? That test fails?"Exactly that one, and test_uInt8 & test_uInt16. Log without fix:[ CUT ] connectivity_commontoolssrc_Bool: 1trg_Bool: 1trg_Bool: 0src_salInt8: 127trg_salInt8: 127trg_salInt8: 127src_saluInt8: 255trg_saluInt8: 255trg_saluInt8: 0src_salInt16: -10001trg_salInt16: -10001src_saluInt16: 10001trg_saluInt16: 10001src_salInt32: -10000001trg_salInt32: -10000001src_saluInt32: 100000001trg_saluInt32: 100000001src_salInt64: -1000000000000000001trg_salInt64: -1000000000000000001src_saluInt64: 10000000000000000001trg_saluInt64: 10000000000000000001src_float: 1.234trg_float: 1.234src_double: 1.23457trg_double: 1.23457/Volumes/Build/compile.noindex/master/connectivity/qa/connectivity/commontools/FValue_test.cxx:89: AssertionTest name: connectivity::commontools::FValueTest::test_Boolassertion failed- Expression: src_Bool == trg_Bool- bool conversion from Any didn't work/Volumes/Build/compile.noindex/master/connectivity/qa/connectivity/commontools/FValue_test.cxx:131: AssertionTest name: connectivity::commontools::FValueTest::test_uInt8assertion failed- Expression: src_saluInt8 == trg_saluInt8- sal_uInt8 conversion from Any didn't work/Volumes/Build/compile.noindex/master/connectivity/qa/connectivity/commontools/FValue_test.cxx:169: AssertionTest name: connectivity::commontools::FValueTest::test_uInt16assertion failed- Expression: src_saluInt16 == trg_saluInt16- sal_uInt16 conversion from Any didn't workFailures !!!Run: 11   Failure total: 3   Failures: 3   Errors: 0###########"Why tinderboxes are green then?"Because there currently is no PPC/BigEndian tinderbox out there. The Mac OSX 10.4/PPC one has been inactive and I'm currently setting it up again witth Mac OSX 10.5. And before reporting to tinderbox server again, I want to make sure that it builds, hence the set of patches.###########"s/sal_Int23/sal_Int32"Yes, typo in the commit-message. Tell me whether I should abandon this one and file a separate one (because of the bogus "depends on") or whether an iteration of this one is enough (I wouldn't mind if you'd fix that typo either).

text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedThanks, fixes the crash.@Kohei:Looking at the code, it should not be necessary to iterate over positions that bear no cells as there is no text to set the width dirty for. That is also what the previous version using ScColumnIterator did. ScColumnTextWidthIterator IMHO should take care of that.
Text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedThanks, fixes the crash.@Kohei:Looking at the code, it should not be necessary to iterate over positions that bear no cells as there is no text to set the width dirty for. That is also what the previous version using ScColumnIterator did. ScColumnTextWidthIterator IMHO should take care of that.

text: Patch Set 3:Where did you find that we are interested in patches that only remove rtl:: prefix? While we won't reject such changes if they have been already done as a part of another work, it's a completely mechanical change that can be automated and doing it this way is just a waste of your time.
Text: Patch Set 3:Where did you find that we are interested in patches that only remove rtl:: prefix? While we won't reject such changes if they have been already done as a part of another work, it's a completely mechanical change that can be automated and doing it this way is just a waste of your time.

text: Patch Set 1:Maintain the references is error prone. Actually the catalog already contains a few errors, like indistinguishable control titles (e.g. "Preview Pane"). That's why I prefer a machine doing the job of keeping the list up-to-date. Actually I've also discussed automatic generation of widget groups with Tristan, but that would require even more changes to Glade, and it would take its time until all such change in Glade propagates to all LibreOffice hackers.
Text: Patch Set 1:Maintain the references is error prone. Actually the catalog already contains a few errors, like indistinguishable control titles (e.g. "Preview Pane"). That's why I prefer a machine doing the job of keeping the list up-to-date. Actually I've also discussed automatic generation of widget groups with Tristan, but that would require even more changes to Glade, and it would take its time until all such change in Glade propagates to all LibreOffice hackers.

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedYou also do a lot of rtl::OUString -> OUString changes in the same commit. That is not a good idea. Do just one thing in each commit. The removal of the rtl:: prefix from uses of rtl::OUString is supposed to be done *programmatically* at some suitable point in time (using a Clang plug-in), I think, it is just too much pointless tedious work to do it manually.
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedYou also do a lot of rtl::OUString -> OUString changes in the same commit. That is not a good idea. Do just one thing in each commit. The removal of the rtl:: prefix from uses of rtl::OUString is supposed to be done *programmatically* at some suitable point in time (using a Clang plug-in), I think, it is just too much pointless tedious work to do it manually.

text: Patch Set 6:>This is not enough, it did not work before either! You need to use also --enable-python=system :-)>Really we don't want people to build with python 2 ;-)Or that's really messy ;-) and definitely doesn't comply with the rule of least surprise:i have:  --with-system-libsi have python 2.7 up and running on the system i do not have python 3.3 (only 3.2)i do pass PYTHON_FLAGS aboveand it still pick up the wrong python.i would suggest to support python 2.7 as the first class citizen without all that noise above (i. e. without CFLAG & LIBS):if --with-system-libs passed and no other python options provided then try to pick up the best system python or fail:try system-python 3.3try system-python 2.7FAIL unless internal python option override the global --with-system-libs provided.How that sounds?
Text: Patch Set 6:>This is not enough, it did not work before either! You need to use also --enable-python=system :-)>Really we don't want people to build with python 2 ;-)Or that's really messy ;-) and definitely doesn't comply with the rule of least surprise:i have:  --with-system-libsi have python 2.7 up and running on the system i do not have python 3.3 (only 3.2)i do pass PYTHON_FLAGS aboveand it still pick up the wrong python.i would suggest to support python 2.7 as the first class citizen without all that noise above (i. e. without CFLAG & LIBS):if --with-system-libs passed and no other python options provided then try to pick up the best system python or fail:try system-python 3.3try system-python 2.7FAIL unless internal python option override the global --with-system-libs provided.How that sounds?
