text: Patch Set 4:Too late now, but I must say that from the point of view of somebody who has to debug code, anonymous namespaces are a bit (but just a little bit) more painful than plain old "static" functions. Much more and harder to type in gdb something like "b '(anonymous namespace)::foobar'" than "b foobar". IMHO there is nothing wrong with static methods...
Text: Patch Set 4:Too late now, but I must say that from the point of view of somebody who has to debug code, anonymous namespaces are a bit (but just a little bit) more painful than plain old "static" functions. Much more and harder to type in gdb something like "b '(anonymous namespace)::foobar'" than "b foobar". IMHO there is nothing wrong with static methods...

text: Patch Set 2:Normally with this patch, all method marked static are now in an anonymous namespace (static method is deprecated in c++98 if I remember well), so visibility doesn't change, except if I did a mistake.

text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedLooks good, and works for the use cases. So I'll push this.Minor nits: I'm not mad about the use of vector::at with values guaranteed to be inside the vector bounds, I mean those can't ever throw.I also worry that the existing use of IsAutoCorrectChar in SvxAutoCorrect::AutoCorrect will do something unexpected with the addition of - in there. But I can't think of a real world case where it might matter. Which means I should figure out how to get a regression test in there to collect known edge cases.
Text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedLooks good, and works for the use cases. So I'll push this.Minor nits: I'm not mad about the use of vector::at with values guaranteed to be inside the vector bounds, I mean those can't ever throw.I also worry that the existing use of IsAutoCorrectChar in SvxAutoCorrect::AutoCorrect will do something unexpected with the addition of - in there. But I can't think of a real world case where it might matter. Which means I should figure out how to get a regression test in there to collect known edge cases.

Will it work with this change?Also, I don't know the impact on scripting/java/org/openoffice/netbeans/editor/OOo.jcb

text: Patch Set 1:See c91b8d3251e3a8ad14e1b143af182c937bf6e5cb for what is necessary to correctly import the original test file from fdo#60083I also attached to the bug report a set of the test documents that I used which show some of the stuff that my commit fixes. Sadly there are way to many corner cases still open and both the chart and the chart2 UNO API are involved in importing.

text: Patch Set 1:String gets converted to OUString and vice versa by the compiler.I did not modify the method signatures on purpose to avoid rippling effects where changing the signature means breaking other places that require fixing etc.Of course I intend to change the method signatures you outlined over time, but the changes I did here are for readability/performance when it comes to building OUString.Do you still give a -1 to this change after my explanations?Can I apply your suggestions in my next commit?I can bring back the previous readability for sc/source/ui/dbgui/sortkeydlg.cxx if you require it.
Text: Patch Set 1:String gets converted to OUString and vice versa by the compiler.I did not modify the method signatures on purpose to avoid rippling effects where changing the signature means breaking other places that require fixing etc.Of course I intend to change the method signatures you outlined over time, but the changes I did here are for readability/performance when it comes to building OUString.Do you still give a -1 to this change after my explanations?Can I apply your suggestions in my next commit?I can bring back the previous readability for sc/source/ui/dbgui/sortkeydlg.cxx if you require it.

text: Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this(2 inline comments)As I see these comments dont point to real problems, but I have noticed two other one. 1. In SQL view, users can use 0*[0-9]* numbers and with changing view these numbers will be 'transported' to the LimitBox, which cant contain such numbers.2. During initialization the default 'All' value is not sent to OQueryController. So when the content of LimitBox is not changed, the SQL statement will contain a 'LIMIT' keyword without value which cause syntax error (m_sLimit is empty by default).So need some improvement.
Text: Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this(2 inline comments)As I see these comments dont point to real problems, but I have noticed two other one. 1. In SQL view, users can use 0*[0-9]* numbers and with changing view these numbers will be 'transported' to the LimitBox, which cant contain such numbers.2. During initialization the default 'All' value is not sent to OQueryController. So when the content of LimitBox is not changed, the SQL statement will contain a 'LIMIT' keyword without value which cause syntax error (m_sLimit is empty by default).So need some improvement.

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedHi,Even if this is a workaround, I think it makes sense, as fixing up OLE objects inside tables is a harder issue. But killing OLE objects completely is too much. Could you please change the patch to disable OLE objects only inside tables? you can check for m_pCurrentBuffer, if it's not null, we are inside a table (or similar complex container).Also, a testcase is missing, see here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/qa/extras/Or if that sounds too complicated, I can create the testcase for you after the patch itself is correct.Thanks,Miklos
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedHi,Even if this is a workaround, I think it makes sense, as fixing up OLE objects inside tables is a harder issue. But killing OLE objects completely is too much. Could you please change the patch to disable OLE objects only inside tables? you can check for m_pCurrentBuffer, if it's not null, we are inside a table (or similar complex container).Also, a testcase is missing, see here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/qa/extras/Or if that sounds too complicated, I can create the testcase for you after the patch itself is correct.Thanks,Miklos

text: Patch Set 3:> "I didn't look through the diff, just a small request about terminology: Could we please call them "bundled" or "third-party" modules, not "external"? (Because "external" means external, right, and if they were external then they wouldn't be there but somewhere outside;)"today they are called "external" in several gbuild class files solenv/gbuild/External*, various functions like gb_LinkTarget_use_external, gb_Jar_use_external, and also in RepositoryExternal.mk, so your complaint is a little bit late i'm afraid.also, they _may_ actually be external, in case you use --with-system-libs, so the name isn't entirely wrong.
Text: Patch Set 3:> "I didn't look through the diff, just a small request about terminology: Could we please call them "bundled" or "third-party" modules, not "external"? (Because "external" means external, right, and if they were external then they wouldn't be there but somewhere outside;)"today they are called "external" in several gbuild class files solenv/gbuild/External*, various functions like gb_LinkTarget_use_external, gb_Jar_use_external, and also in RepositoryExternal.mk, so your complaint is a little bit late i'm afraid.also, they _may_ actually be external, in case you use --with-system-libs, so the name isn't entirely wrong.

text: Patch Set 2:> I don't get why m_pBroadcaster is a pointer with NULL checks when there seems to be no way it cannot be non-NULL. Presumably a reference would be sufficient there.Right, reference would be just fine. It is just that at one point I thought it would be necessary to handle SFX_DYING hint, in which case the pointer would be cleared, avoiding use of a dead object in destructor. It turned out this is not really needed, but I forgot (or was too lazy; your pick :-) to change the pointer into a reference.
Text: Patch Set 2:> I don't get why m_pBroadcaster is a pointer with NULL checks when there seems to be no way it cannot be non-NULL. Presumably a reference would be sufficient there.Right, reference would be just fine. It is just that at one point I thought it would be necessary to handle SFX_DYING hint, in which case the pointer would be cleared, avoiding use of a dead object in destructor. It turned out this is not really needed, but I forgot (or was too lazy; your pick :-) to change the pointer into a reference.

text: Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this(5 inline comments)See my inline comments.  BTW, if the change I'm asking for is hard to understand, let me know maybe I can do the change this time.We'll still have to solve the problem of not generating multiple undo steps for this single action, though. With this change, hiding multiple sheets would create multiple undo steps, one per sheet.  But we want that to be just a single undo step.

text: Patch Set 9:Just a minor nit: Please don't refer to git commits using their gerrit Change-Ids in the commit comment. That just makes it harder to search for the commits using git commands. To git, the Change-Id is just a part of the comment. Instead use the git commit identifiers.Or am I misunderstanding, does git in fact understand Change-Ids?
Text: Patch Set 9:Just a minor nit: Please don't refer to git commits using their gerrit Change-Ids in the commit comment. That just makes it harder to search for the commits using git commands. To git, the Change-Id is just a part of the comment. Instead use the git commit identifiers.Or am I misunderstanding, does git in fact understand Change-Ids?

text: Patch Set 1:Note that in order to approve this patch, I think the following steps are necessary:1) Somebody needs to have an Apple code-signing certificate in their keychain. Or maybe a certificate issued by some other entity would also work, or a self-signed one, I don't know. (I only have experience of handling Apple-provided ones in Xcode.)2) And then do a full "normal" (Intel) release build of the 4-0 branch3) And then somebody (else) needs to try the produced dmg on machines running 10.4, 10.5 and 10.6 and check that the app runs fine, that the signed binary doesn't cause problems in an older dynamic linker which doesn't know what the signature stuff inserted into the binary means.Alternatively, if somebody can find a definitive reference that promises signed binaries will work also on 10.[456], I guess we should trust that...(For 10.7 and 10.7 I think it is safe to assume the signing won't cause trouble, and for 10.8 where Gatekeeper is checking for signatures, I have already verified that signing indeed helps to get rid of the scary warning about "unidentified developer".)
Text: Patch Set 1:Note that in order to approve this patch, I think the following steps are necessary:1) Somebody needs to have an Apple code-signing certificate in their keychain. Or maybe a certificate issued by some other entity would also work, or a self-signed one, I don't know. (I only have experience of handling Apple-provided ones in Xcode.)2) And then do a full "normal" (Intel) release build of the 4-0 branch3) And then somebody (else) needs to try the produced dmg on machines running 10.4, 10.5 and 10.6 and check that the app runs fine, that the signed binary doesn't cause problems in an older dynamic linker which doesn't know what the signature stuff inserted into the binary means.Alternatively, if somebody can find a definitive reference that promises signed binaries will work also on 10.[456], I guess we should trust that...(For 10.7 and 10.7 I think it is safe to assume the signing won't cause trouble, and for 10.8 where Gatekeeper is checking for signatures, I have already verified that signing indeed helps to get rid of the scary warning about "unidentified developer".)

text: Patch Set 1:Thanks for your supportive message.I try to concentrate on calc and so be able to use what I found out earlier (if indeed I could only remember it).The intersect-check has been changed and works fine, the FindAreaPos is a dead-end (if that's proper English). It stops at hidden columns/rows and continues until it finds a non-empty cell. Imagine a sheet with some data in row 1 and some in row 2 and you wanting to cut row 2 and paste+shift down above row 1. FindAreaPos will check (MAXROW-2)*MAXCOL cells, where only MAXCOL cells need to be checked. But I started looking around in the code and found ScDocument::IsEmptyBlock() and that looks promising. Still building though (slow machine at my work) and I want to test it before submitting the new patch set.
Text: Patch Set 1:Thanks for your supportive message.I try to concentrate on calc and so be able to use what I found out earlier (if indeed I could only remember it).The intersect-check has been changed and works fine, the FindAreaPos is a dead-end (if that's proper English). It stops at hidden columns/rows and continues until it finds a non-empty cell. Imagine a sheet with some data in row 1 and some in row 2 and you wanting to cut row 2 and paste+shift down above row 1. FindAreaPos will check (MAXROW-2)*MAXCOL cells, where only MAXCOL cells need to be checked. But I started looking around in the code and found ScDocument::IsEmptyBlock() and that looks promising. Still building though (slow machine at my work) and I want to test it before submitting the new patch set.

text: Patch Set 1:That is not what I was meaning.RegQueryValueEx can change the value in 'size', so it makes sense to me to explicitly assign it before each call. There is no reason to have the first one different from the others.See comments below.static void add_NS_keys( HKEY hKey, PluginLocationMap & rPlugins ){    TCHAR value[MAX_PATH];    DWORD dwType, size;    // 4.7    size = sizeof(value);                                          <---- size is reseted before calling RegQueryValueEx    if (::RegQueryValueEx(        hKey, _T("Plugins Directory"), NULL, &dwType,        (LPBYTE)value, &size ) == ERROR_SUCCESS &&                 <---- size can be changed        (dwType == REG_SZ || dwType == REG_EXPAND_SZ))    {        addPluginsFromPath( value, rPlugins );    }    // 6    size = sizeof(value);                                          <---- size is reseted before calling RegQueryValueEx    if (::RegQueryValueEx(        hKey, _T("Install Directory"), NULL, &dwType,        (LPBYTE)value, &size ) == ERROR_SUCCESS &&                 <---- size can be changed        (dwType == REG_SZ || dwType == REG_EXPAND_SZ))    {        int n = size / sizeof (TCHAR);        if ('\\' != value[ n -2 ])        {            value[ n -1 ] = '\\';            value[ n ] = 0;        }        addPluginsFromPath( ::lstrcat( value, _T("Plugins") ), rPlugins );    }    size = sizeof(value);                                          <---- size is reseted before calling RegQueryValueEx    if (::RegQueryValueEx(        hKey, _T("Plugins"), NULL, &dwType,        (LPBYTE)value, &size ) == ERROR_SUCCESS &&                 <---- size can be changed        (dwType == REG_SZ || dwType == REG_EXPAND_SZ))    {        addPluginsFromPath( value, rPlugins );    }}
Text: Patch Set 1:That is not what I was meaning.RegQueryValueEx can change the value in 'size', so it makes sense to me to explicitly assign it before each call. There is no reason to have the first one different from the others.See comments below.static void add_NS_keys( HKEY hKey, PluginLocationMap & rPlugins ){    TCHAR value[MAX_PATH];    DWORD dwType, size;    // 4.7    size = sizeof(value);                                          <---- size is reseted before calling RegQueryValueEx    if (::RegQueryValueEx(        hKey, _T("Plugins Directory"), NULL, &dwType,        (LPBYTE)value, &size ) == ERROR_SUCCESS &&                 <---- size can be changed        (dwType == REG_SZ || dwType == REG_EXPAND_SZ))    {        addPluginsFromPath( value, rPlugins );    }    // 6    size = sizeof(value);                                          <---- size is reseted before calling RegQueryValueEx    if (::RegQueryValueEx(        hKey, _T("Install Directory"), NULL, &dwType,        (LPBYTE)value, &size ) == ERROR_SUCCESS &&                 <---- size can be changed        (dwType == REG_SZ || dwType == REG_EXPAND_SZ))    {        int n = size / sizeof (TCHAR);        if ('\\' != value[ n -2 ])        {            value[ n -1 ] = '\\';            value[ n ] = 0;        }        addPluginsFromPath( ::lstrcat( value, _T("Plugins") ), rPlugins );    }    size = sizeof(value);                                          <---- size is reseted before calling RegQueryValueEx    if (::RegQueryValueEx(        hKey, _T("Plugins"), NULL, &dwType,        (LPBYTE)value, &size ) == ERROR_SUCCESS &&                 <---- size can be changed        (dwType == REG_SZ || dwType == REG_EXPAND_SZ))    {        addPluginsFromPath( value, rPlugins );    }}

Text: Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)I'm working on a revised patch.So far I have a quetion regarding simply pushing a double argument, see inline comment.Also, I realised that I forgot to make group and decimal separator case independent, e.g. "gs" as group separator should also treat "GS" as a group separator since calcformulas are case independent as fas as I know. I will change this too.

text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedI tested the patch and it did not work. I have fixed the following problems:   + added extra [] because one level was eaten by autoconf   + fixed "brand_files" to match with "brand_vars"   + use "test" instead of "[]" to avoid bashism   + use "source" instead of the incomplete and non-working      "read" command call   + removed the extra spacesIt works for me now => pushingIt was a good change. Just, please, do some testing before pushing changes next time.

Text: Patch Set 2:poking this a bit more it looks something is wrong here:the old code (when not SYSTEM_MYSQL_CPPCONN) didload the mysqlconn library at runtime viaosl_loadModuleRelative, using CPPCONN_LIBas the filename..but with the conversion, the mysqlcppconn libraryis not built at all, and of course the extensiondoes not contain the library; instead a staticlibrary is built in module mysqlcppconn, whichdoes seem unhelpful.

text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedGreat, code converted correctly. Some small nits...ObjectNameDialog:  - Lets make dialogs resizeable unless there's a reason not to. The old ones weren't resizeable because of the lack-of-layout defect.   - some pixel size-requests on edit-boxes, maybe worried about its default size? So I set a "width in chars" on the edit box to make it wide enough, that way we don't have to worry about measuring things in pixelsObjectTitleNameDialog   - Lets make it resizeable, as above.  - The original had a scrollbar, so added a scrolledwindow to it with always vertically scroll  - For the textview to give it a default height, rather than using pixels I let it take its width by expand to the above edit widget width  - For its height, added a non-translated text buffer with 5 blank lines and tweaked the ctor to set that as its permanent height request  - GtkTextView maps to class VclMultiLineEdit instead of MultiLineEdit. This is a sort of bizarre impossible to know about corner case. But they should be equivalent, so I just changed MultiLineEdit to VclMultiLineEditNameDialog:  - width requests as above  - set name_entry as the mnemonic widget of name_entryMessBox:  - I set the label to be vertically centered for the resizeable caseI've been keeping things as one dialog per .ui file, which as a side effect allows no name collisions between various "ok" buttons being called "ok", etc, so I split them up like that.
Text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedGreat, code converted correctly. Some small nits...ObjectNameDialog:  - Lets make dialogs resizeable unless there's a reason not to. The old ones weren't resizeable because of the lack-of-layout defect.   - some pixel size-requests on edit-boxes, maybe worried about its default size? So I set a "width in chars" on the edit box to make it wide enough, that way we don't have to worry about measuring things in pixelsObjectTitleNameDialog   - Lets make it resizeable, as above.  - The original had a scrollbar, so added a scrolledwindow to it with always vertically scroll  - For the textview to give it a default height, rather than using pixels I let it take its width by expand to the above edit widget width  - For its height, added a non-translated text buffer with 5 blank lines and tweaked the ctor to set that as its permanent height request  - GtkTextView maps to class VclMultiLineEdit instead of MultiLineEdit. This is a sort of bizarre impossible to know about corner case. But they should be equivalent, so I just changed MultiLineEdit to VclMultiLineEditNameDialog:  - width requests as above  - set name_entry as the mnemonic widget of name_entryMessBox:  - I set the label to be vertically centered for the resizeable caseI've been keeping things as one dialog per .ui file, which as a side effect allows no name collisions between various "ok" buttons being called "ok", etc, so I split them up like that.

text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisHmm, I am not sure that I like this change. It does not create the formatting entry without any explanation. You were able to edit the unused formatting and add the range later in the past.For example, imagine that you define some formatting, forget to define the range, and press the "Add" button. You will not know why the entry was not created. You will need to select everything again and again until you find why it does not work :-)IMHO, the best solution would be to preffil the range with the current selected cell(s). For example, the DataPilot or Chart is created from the current selection by default as well.Hmm, the prefil would be annoying if you lose some older formatting  in the selected cells. In this case, I would prefer to leave the behavior as is and fix it with the error dialog for 4.1. IMHO, the behavior is more annoying with the patch than without it.BTW: I really like the conditional formatting. It is very cool and useful feature. Thanks a lot for the hard work in this area.
Text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisHmm, I am not sure that I like this change. It does not create the formatting entry without any explanation. You were able to edit the unused formatting and add the range later in the past.For example, imagine that you define some formatting, forget to define the range, and press the "Add" button. You will not know why the entry was not created. You will need to select everything again and again until you find why it does not work :-)IMHO, the best solution would be to preffil the range with the current selected cell(s). For example, the DataPilot or Chart is created from the current selection by default as well.Hmm, the prefil would be annoying if you lose some older formatting  in the selected cells. In this case, I would prefer to leave the behavior as is and fix it with the error dialog for 4.1. IMHO, the behavior is more annoying with the patch than without it.BTW: I really like the conditional formatting. It is very cool and useful feature. Thanks a lot for the hard work in this area.

text: Patch Set 1:The reason why this change is a good thing is that being able to define conditional formats without ranges and later storing them in ScConditionalFormatList may result in crashes.Calc core always assumes non-empty conditional format ranges because they have to be kept in sync with the cell attribute storage. Inside ScConditionalFormatList::UpdateReference we will additionally delete ScConditionalFormat instances with an empty range. I also added a check to xmlcondformat.cxx that removes all conditional formats that are imported without a range to prevent a crash.The idea is to add for 4.1 an error dialog that makes clear that you either have to define a range or use Cancel. This is however not possible in 4-0 because of the string-freeze.
Text: Patch Set 1:The reason why this change is a good thing is that being able to define conditional formats without ranges and later storing them in ScConditionalFormatList may result in crashes.Calc core always assumes non-empty conditional format ranges because they have to be kept in sync with the cell attribute storage. Inside ScConditionalFormatList::UpdateReference we will additionally delete ScConditionalFormat instances with an empty range. I also added a check to xmlcondformat.cxx that removes all conditional formats that are imported without a range to prevent a crash.The idea is to add for 4.1 an error dialog that makes clear that you either have to define a range or use Cancel. This is however not possible in 4-0 because of the string-freeze.

text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedLooks ok, thanks for the patch.If you're going to do more similar changes, it'd be safer to check that the type in the cast is one of the sal_Int* types, I expect it's unlikely there would be a cast with sal_Char or sal_Bool, but if it were, changing that to number() would be incorrect.Also a small stylistic detail: Something like 'rtl::OUString::valueOf(static_cast<sal_Int32>(50))' can be actually further simplified to just "50".
Text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedLooks ok, thanks for the patch.If you're going to do more similar changes, it'd be safer to check that the type in the cast is one of the sal_Int* types, I expect it's unlikely there would be a cast with sal_Char or sal_Bool, but if it were, changing that to number() would be incorrect.Also a small stylistic detail: Something like 'rtl::OUString::valueOf(static_cast<sal_Int32>(50))' can be actually further simplified to just "50".

text: Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisI'm working with toolbars in these days and I'm worked with Findbar too. So I have some idea to this patch.I think it is unneeded to make a new class for this function. The FindbarDispatcher class enables us to catch and work up messages which is belong to findbar, like 'vnd.sun.star.findbar:FocusToFindbar'. (see dispatch method) So i think it would be better to use this method instead of a new class which has only one useful method and a lot of garnish.It's not a point, but I think the code of "hide findbar" can be extract to a function to avoid code duplicates.
Text: Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisI'm working with toolbars in these days and I'm worked with Findbar too. So I have some idea to this patch.I think it is unneeded to make a new class for this function. The FindbarDispatcher class enables us to catch and work up messages which is belong to findbar, like 'vnd.sun.star.findbar:FocusToFindbar'. (see dispatch method) So i think it would be better to use this method instead of a new class which has only one useful method and a lot of garnish.It's not a point, but I think the code of "hide findbar" can be extract to a function to avoid code duplicates.

text: Patch Set 2:oops did not notice Markus' comment:"It requires some more thinking if sal_Bool is implicitly converted to sal_uInt16 or SfxPoolItem to SfxItemSet."AFAIK SfxPoolItem does not convert implicitly to SfxItemSet (which Which-Ranges would it have then? sounds like a bad idea in any case), but sal_Bool is just a "unsigned char" which converts automatically to sal_uInt16 "unsigned short", causing the problem.
Text: Patch Set 2:oops did not notice Markus' comment:"It requires some more thinking if sal_Bool is implicitly converted to sal_uInt16 or SfxPoolItem to SfxItemSet."AFAIK SfxPoolItem does not convert implicitly to SfxItemSet (which Which-Ranges would it have then? sounds like a bad idea in any case), but sal_Bool is just a "unsigned char" which converts automatically to sal_uInt16 "unsigned short", causing the problem.

text: Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisRemoving functions from sal.map strictly speaking requires bumping SONAME, and that is too disruptive a change for merely getting rid of those deprecated functions.Like what has been done for osl/semaphor.h, please:* do remove rtl/memory.h and rtl/source/memory.cxx,* but keep sal.map intact and add aborting stubs for the removed functions to sal/osl/all/compat.cxx* add a section to <http://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/LibreOffice4> for incompatible changes in LO 4.1, and add the removal of rtl/memory.h there* Prefix the commit message with "API CHANGE:"
Text: Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisRemoving functions from sal.map strictly speaking requires bumping SONAME, and that is too disruptive a change for merely getting rid of those deprecated functions.Like what has been done for osl/semaphor.h, please:* do remove rtl/memory.h and rtl/source/memory.cxx,* but keep sal.map intact and add aborting stubs for the removed functions to sal/osl/all/compat.cxx* add a section to <http://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/LibreOffice4> for incompatible changes in LO 4.1, and add the removal of rtl/memory.h there* Prefix the commit message with "API CHANGE:"

text: Patch Set 1:Wouldn't it be better to keep throwing a PropertyVetoException from setSize, but let setHeight/Width translate that into a WrappedTargetRuntimeException?  That way, other clients of setSize would not be affected.Also, constructing an instance of Reference<XInterface> from *this confuses me -- not sure why it works here and if all compilers will accept it.  The standard idiom there is static_cast<cppu::OWeakObject*>(this).
Text: Patch Set 1:Wouldn't it be better to keep throwing a PropertyVetoException from setSize, but let setHeight/Width translate that into a WrappedTargetRuntimeException?  That way, other clients of setSize would not be affected.Also, constructing an instance of Reference<XInterface> from *this confuses me -- not sure why it works here and if all compilers will accept it.  The standard idiom there is static_cast<cppu::OWeakObject*>(this).

text: Patch Set 2:> Wouldn't it be better to keep throwing a PropertyVetoException from setSizeYes, fair point. Corrected that.> but let setHeight/Width translate that into a WrappedTargetRuntimeException?No, throwing a WrappedTargetRuntimeException still leads to a crash.> Also, constructing an instance of Reference<XInterface> from *this confuses me -- not sure why it works here and if all compilers will accept it. The standard idiom there is static_cast<cppu::OWeakObject*>(this).Other places in the code definitely do it from *this, but indeed far fewer than with the static_cast<cppu::OWeakObject*>. I must have seen only the "bad" examples before...

text: Patch Set 2: Do not submit(2 inline comments)With this patch there would be two independent ways to control whether -g is used, the other being ENABLE_DEBUGINFO_FOR, and moreover this breaks the other way, i.e. the selective debuginfo feature.It also might be a good idea to reconsider the "symbols" name, unless you want to repeatedly explain it to people who for some reason keep getting confused by all this stuff over and over again (it's a lot of fun I can assure you, and "debug" vs "debug symbols" is just asking for it).It possibly might make sense to fold --enable-symbols and --enable-selective-debuginfo in one option and functionality.Finally, I suggest the commit message just says that the option is back in order to avoid having to specify -g or similar manually, instead of the long list of claims you copied from the ML, as a number of those claims are questionable or just plain incorrect.
Text: Patch Set 2: Do not submit(2 inline comments)With this patch there would be two independent ways to control whether -g is used, the other being ENABLE_DEBUGINFO_FOR, and moreover this breaks the other way, i.e. the selective debuginfo feature.It also might be a good idea to reconsider the "symbols" name, unless you want to repeatedly explain it to people who for some reason keep getting confused by all this stuff over and over again (it's a lot of fun I can assure you, and "debug" vs "debug symbols" is just asking for it).It possibly might make sense to fold --enable-symbols and --enable-selective-debuginfo in one option and functionality.Finally, I suggest the commit message just says that the option is back in order to avoid having to specify -g or similar manually, instead of the long list of claims you copied from the ML, as a number of those claims are questionable or just plain incorrect.

text: Patch Set 2:I was not questioning symmetrical, balanced and clearly visible braces, I was talking about the braces around single commands that only add visual clutter. And that is why it is a matter of taste. As this is not "your" code (it is not, is it, you wouldn't be asking for review otherwise, or would you?), with this approach the next person to do a random modification to this code could very well revert all those back, and so forth. And that's why people shouldn't do "cleanups" to their taste of code they otherwise do not work on.As for the changed sal::static_int_cast, either put that back to make it visible the conversion is taking place, or you can remove the C-style cast altogether, as the C-style cast serves no purpose there at all.
Text: Patch Set 2:I was not questioning symmetrical, balanced and clearly visible braces, I was talking about the braces around single commands that only add visual clutter. And that is why it is a matter of taste. As this is not "your" code (it is not, is it, you wouldn't be asking for review otherwise, or would you?), with this approach the next person to do a random modification to this code could very well revert all those back, and so forth. And that's why people shouldn't do "cleanups" to their taste of code they otherwise do not work on.As for the changed sal::static_int_cast, either put that back to make it visible the conversion is taking place, or you can remove the C-style cast altogether, as the C-style cast serves no purpose there at all.

text: Patch Set 1:Also system boost supports it, there is no reason why it should not do so.You only have to use the header with the standard enabled in cxxflags, and if you don't it warns on you like this:                 from /usr/include/boost/unordered_map.hpp:16,                 from conftest.cpp:69:/usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu/4.6.3/include/g++-v4/bits/c++0x_warning.h:32:2: error: #error This file requires compiler and library support for the upcoming ISO C++ standard, C++0x. This support is currently experimental, and must be enabled with the -std=c++0x or -std=gnu++0x compiler options.
Text: Patch Set 1:Also system boost supports it, there is no reason why it should not do so.You only have to use the header with the standard enabled in cxxflags, and if you don't it warns on you like this:                 from /usr/include/boost/unordered_map.hpp:16,                 from conftest.cpp:69:/usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu/4.6.3/include/g++-v4/bits/c++0x_warning.h:32:2: error: #error This file requires compiler and library support for the upcoming ISO C++ standard, C++0x. This support is currently experimental, and must be enabled with the -std=c++0x or -std=gnu++0x compiler options.

text: Patch Set 1:So why not drop the check (and all mention of HAVE_BOOST_UNORDERD_MAP in configure.ac) completely?  A system boost will hopefully have an unordered_map.hpp that works just fine with the compiler switches that will be used during the build -- and otherwise, we'll get a compile-time error at least anyway.
Text: Patch Set 1:So why not drop the check (and all mention of HAVE_BOOST_UNORDERD_MAP in configure.ac) completely?  A system boost will hopefully have an unordered_map.hpp that works just fine with the compiler switches that will be used during the build -- and otherwise, we'll get a compile-time error at least anyway.

text: Patch Set 1:Stephan's idea sounds good to me. In general, I think we occasionally try too hard to figure out at configure time if compilation will fail later. Sure, it can save some hour(s) of waiting before the compilation then fails, but it adds a lot of complexity to the configure.ac, with corresponding possibilities that the check is wrong anyway, either gives a false positive or false negative.
Text: Patch Set 1:Stephan's idea sounds good to me. In general, I think we occasionally try too hard to figure out at configure time if compilation will fail later. Sure, it can save some hour(s) of waiting before the compilation then fails, but it adds a lot of complexity to the configure.ac, with corresponding possibilities that the check is wrong anyway, either gives a false positive or false negative.

text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this* Setting MALLOC_PERTURB_ to zero reportedly (<http://udrepper.livejournal.com/11429.html>) disables it, so we should make sure $rndbyte is never zero.* Trying   dd if=/dev/urandom bs=1 count=1 2>/dev/null | od -tu1 | cut -s -d " " -f2does not always produce a number for me, as od outputs the 1-to-3-digit number right aligned, so cut -f2 sometimes hits "nothing" in between leading spaces.* I personally never --enable-linkoo, so it would be cool if we could put this somewhere where everybody can benefit (though I have no good idea where that would be; maybe its time to split program/ooenv in two, things that are useful for all developer runs, like MALLOC_CHECK_=2, and things specific to linkoo, like fiddling with LD_LIBRARY_PATH).
Text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this* Setting MALLOC_PERTURB_ to zero reportedly (<http://udrepper.livejournal.com/11429.html>) disables it, so we should make sure $rndbyte is never zero.* Trying   dd if=/dev/urandom bs=1 count=1 2>/dev/null | od -tu1 | cut -s -d " " -f2does not always produce a number for me, as od outputs the 1-to-3-digit number right aligned, so cut -f2 sometimes hits "nothing" in between leading spaces.* I personally never --enable-linkoo, so it would be cool if we could put this somewhere where everybody can benefit (though I have no good idea where that would be; maybe its time to split program/ooenv in two, things that are useful for all developer runs, like MALLOC_CHECK_=2, and things specific to linkoo, like fiddling with LD_LIBRARY_PATH).

text: Patch Set 1:discussing this with sberg, I agree that this change _should_ do no difference as otherwise the ::boost::unordered_map<>::erase(iterator, iterator) interface is useless.But it does: without this change and only with a std::list->std::deque replacement in vcl to evade possible C++11-ABI poisoning, LibreOffice crashes after some ~10 iterations of xmluno_api -- with the patch it:- ran 140 iterations once and then crashed on a different stacktrace- ran 250 iterations without any issueReverting the patch, I get:- the fdo#51324 stacktrace after 7 iterations- the fdo#51324 stacktrace after 1 iteration- the fdo#51324 stacktrace after 1 iteration- the fdo#51324 stacktrace after 6 iterationAs the change should not hurt a nonbroken boost::unordered_map implementation, might heal (or evade) a broken boost::unordered_map implementation and is more readable, I suggest to cherry-pick this to libreoffice-3-6
Text: Patch Set 1:discussing this with sberg, I agree that this change _should_ do no difference as otherwise the ::boost::unordered_map<>::erase(iterator, iterator) interface is useless.But it does: without this change and only with a std::list->std::deque replacement in vcl to evade possible C++11-ABI poisoning, LibreOffice crashes after some ~10 iterations of xmluno_api -- with the patch it:- ran 140 iterations once and then crashed on a different stacktrace- ran 250 iterations without any issueReverting the patch, I get:- the fdo#51324 stacktrace after 7 iterations- the fdo#51324 stacktrace after 1 iteration- the fdo#51324 stacktrace after 1 iteration- the fdo#51324 stacktrace after 6 iterationAs the change should not hurt a nonbroken boost::unordered_map implementation, might heal (or evade) a broken boost::unordered_map implementation and is more readable, I suggest to cherry-pick this to libreoffice-3-6

So, I prefer this safer way -- rolling back to the equivalent of SearchAscii().Also, I'm a bit reluctant between indexOfAsciiL() >= 0 and != -1, which means "not found". Which is better?This should be pushed to -3-6 branch as well. Thanks :-)

text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisIndeed, good catch, and the patch seems to be correct.But instead of all the indexOfAsciiL() with ugly and error prone hard coded length argument we now can benefit from the new internal::ConstCharArrayDetector indexOf() template, see sal/inc/rtl/ustring.hxx just before the indexOfAsciiL() declaration.So, instead ofaFilterName.indexOfAsciiL("impress8", 8)we can simply writeaFilterName.indexOf("impress8")It would be great if you could submit a new patch using that easier to read and maintain method.And yes, using >=0 is perfectly valid and fine.
Text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisIndeed, good catch, and the patch seems to be correct.But instead of all the indexOfAsciiL() with ugly and error prone hard coded length argument we now can benefit from the new internal::ConstCharArrayDetector indexOf() template, see sal/inc/rtl/ustring.hxx just before the indexOfAsciiL() declaration.So, instead ofaFilterName.indexOfAsciiL("impress8", 8)we can simply writeaFilterName.indexOf("impress8")It would be great if you could submit a new patch using that easier to read and maintain method.And yes, using >=0 is perfectly valid and fine.

text: Patch Set 1:I will try to fix the memory leaks and upload a new patch. I agree that an empty static string wouldn't be elegant (although thats basically how it worked before with tools/string), so I will try to change the call sites, which should be possible as most other getString methods (including one in the same object, with other parameters) return by value.
Text: Patch Set 1:I will try to fix the memory leaks and upload a new patch. I agree that an empty static string wouldn't be elegant (although thats basically how it worked before with tools/string), so I will try to change the call sites, which should be possible as most other getString methods (including one in the same object, with other parameters) return by value.

text: Patch Set 1: No score"_might_ break things if included code is in some evil way depending on earlier includes in the list."Which btw. should not happen if all header files declare their define guards (ifdef ME_H) etc. correctly... Agree that this might make problems - but those would be code smells as well and I will then take care of them - iff those ever happen.On the other hand, having the includes sorted helps a lot for getting a quick overview and might also help identifying unused or deprecated includes...See also <http://google-styleguide.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/cppguide.xml?showone=Names_and_Order_of_Includes#Names_and_Order_of_Includes>

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1(1 comment)Why not replace EMPTY with 0,0,INT_MAX,INT,MAX and let the remaining algorithm merge it? I'm not sure I understand why we need all these special cases (too much code to handle special cases when the default merging be enough).In fact, I think it'd be better if we remove EMPTY from Core and replace it with 0,0,INT_MAX,INT_MAX or something like that. We'd have a consistent message format, and easier numbers to parse and merge with others. Miklos, what do you think?
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1(1 comment)Why not replace EMPTY with 0,0,INT_MAX,INT,MAX and let the remaining algorithm merge it? I'm not sure I understand why we need all these special cases (too much code to handle special cases when the default merging be enough).In fact, I think it'd be better if we remove EMPTY from Core and replace it with 0,0,INT_MAX,INT_MAX or something like that. We'd have a consistent message format, and easier numbers to parse and merge with others. Miklos, what do you think?

text: Patch Set 2:As mentioned earlier, there is some value EMPTY provides (easier to debug, easier to drop all tiles). The immediate problem that needs fixing is that when reading EMPTY into 4 ints, they are left uninitialized, and then passed as Rectangle ctor arguments. That needs fixing.Then I have no problem if it's decided that EMPTY causes more problems than it solves, and get rid of it in a separate commit (though where do you draw that "max" line? Does INT_MAX cover the bottom of a very large Writer document that has lots of pages in a single part?)Also, I think this should be done on master, and then cherry-picked to cp-5.1, not the other way around.
Text: Patch Set 2:As mentioned earlier, there is some value EMPTY provides (easier to debug, easier to drop all tiles). The immediate problem that needs fixing is that when reading EMPTY into 4 ints, they are left uninitialized, and then passed as Rectangle ctor arguments. That needs fixing.Then I have no problem if it's decided that EMPTY causes more problems than it solves, and get rid of it in a separate commit (though where do you draw that "max" line? Does INT_MAX cover the bottom of a very large Writer document that has lots of pages in a single part?)Also, I think this should be done on master, and then cherry-picked to cp-5.1, not the other way around.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)The idea to merge the two threads (callback handler and tile rendering) is reasonable, but we should discuss the approach.The starvation you noticed happens because you are using the tile-queue, which is designed for... well, yes, tiles! :)It reorders the messages such that it renders tiles in large blocks first. So with heavy typing the callback messages always end up getting overtaken by tiles, which the queue explicitly favors, thereby starving callback events.So this is one problem with the current implementation. I think the tiles should have its own queue, and callbacks a separate one. The thread that pumps them would process one callback, then one tile-rendering.Another issue with combining these threads is that there will be reduction in performance. This is because before and after rendering a tile there is significant work being done that does *not* execute with the Solar lock. This code (mostly encoding to PNG) is CPU intensive and can run in parallel to other code (even to other rendering calls).Finally, I have submitted my patch (342125b8ea) to fix the missing tiles issue. Should be easier to read than describe it here (it's only +27, -6). It comes with detailed commit log too. So this approach is mostly an optimization to reduce the thread-count, but, as mentioned, we need multiple threads because we have opportunity to parallelize, and merging them will reduce performance (unless benchmark proves otherwise, of course).
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)The idea to merge the two threads (callback handler and tile rendering) is reasonable, but we should discuss the approach.The starvation you noticed happens because you are using the tile-queue, which is designed for... well, yes, tiles! :)It reorders the messages such that it renders tiles in large blocks first. So with heavy typing the callback messages always end up getting overtaken by tiles, which the queue explicitly favors, thereby starving callback events.So this is one problem with the current implementation. I think the tiles should have its own queue, and callbacks a separate one. The thread that pumps them would process one callback, then one tile-rendering.Another issue with combining these threads is that there will be reduction in performance. This is because before and after rendering a tile there is significant work being done that does *not* execute with the Solar lock. This code (mostly encoding to PNG) is CPU intensive and can run in parallel to other code (even to other rendering calls).Finally, I have submitted my patch (342125b8ea) to fix the missing tiles issue. Should be easier to read than describe it here (it's only +27, -6). It comes with detailed commit log too. So this approach is mostly an optimization to reduce the thread-count, but, as mentioned, we need multiple threads because we have opportunity to parallelize, and merging them will reduce performance (unless benchmark proves otherwise, of course).

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-2Hmm, I wonder if this can ever work, so marking this -2 for now -- not because the code provided so far is bad per se.Here are a few things noticed:- The original image is set when inserting the image, so when inserting an image, saving and reloading, it one cant "reset"- this doesnt do undo and might well confuse/crash the undo stack (e.g. when doing multiple actions, and then undoing them on a different state)- storing the image on the writer shell doesnt work with multiple images: e.g. insert two images, modify the first, reset the first => first image then duplicates the secondBut before taking this further I think we need to take a step back and clarify what is actually needed/wanted here and if we can provide it: I dont think we want to inflate files by storing both the original and the modified images (people might also find it surprising that their original image contents are "leaked"). Also I think most file formats currently dont support this. Finally, for big documents with lots of big images, this would possibly duplicate memory usage.So for now, I would suggest to discuss what is actually wanted and if it realistically can be provided without confusing users too much.

Also I think most file formats currently dont support this. Finally, for big documents with lots of big images, this would possibly duplicate memory usage.So for now, I would suggest to discuss what is actually wanted and if it realistically can be provided without confusing users too much.

text: Patch Set 1:> -1 for 2x: include + forward declares in AccessibleControlShape.hxxOops, those forward declares shouldn't be there. Thanks for catching that :) > for discussion: > stuff from hpp files is api which hardly changes. > to reduce bloat, includes and forward declarations in hpp files > should not appear in regular hxx headers againI prefer not doing this since I think that headers should directly include everything they need, except private headers and some other cases. It's easier to do that instead of keeping track of the includes and forward declarations that each .hpp file has already, especially since there's so many of them, and I don't think that files should rely on that, regardless of how often the API changes. Leaving those includes and forward declarations in also allows someone reading that file later to know everything that it depends on more easily. If a file relies on an include or forward declaration that isn't already in that file, iwyu considers that as an error and will suggest to place it back in. That would make reading its output harder if I decided to rely on any includes present in .hpp files.Also, GCC and Clang can perform what is called the 'multiple-include optimization' as described here: https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/cppinternals/Guard-Macros.html and http://clang.llvm.org/docs/InternalsManual.html#the-multipleincludeopt-class...and thus, at least for those compilers, removing an include because it's already in an included .hpp file may have no measurable effect on build time.

Thanks for catching that :) > for discussion: > stuff from hpp files is api which hardly changes. > to reduce bloat, includes and forward declarations in hpp files > should not appear in regular hxx headers againI prefer not doing this since I think that headers should directly include everything they need, except private headers and some other cases. It's easier to do that instead of keeping track of the includes and forward declarations that each .hpp file has already, especially since there's so many of them, and I don't think that files should rely on that, regardless of how often the API changes. Leaving those includes and forward declarations in also allows someone reading that file later to know everything that it depends on more easily. If a file relies on an include or forward declaration that isn't already in that file, iwyu considers that as an error and will suggest to place it back in. That would make reading its output harder if I decided to rely on any includes present in .hpp files.Also, GCC and Clang can perform what is called the 'multiple-include optimization' as described here: https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/cppinternals/Guard-Macros.html and http://clang.llvm.org/docs/InternalsManual.html#the-multipleincludeopt-class...and thus, at least for those compilers, removing an include because it's already in an included .hpp file may have no measurable effect on build time.

text: Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1I have to *strongly* disagree. LibreOffice is unique in its definition of "offset" - anyone coming from Microsoft Word or another program is going to expect the behavior I outlined. The old behavior lends no benefit to the user whatsoever, whereas the new behavior does.Also, the "current" way of "starting on a custom page" is extremely difficult for many users to understand and implement, and is somewhat unreliable in its nature. The main problem is that you wind up with a new empty page at the start of your document.It's a basic principle of software design: if many users are confused, that doesn't mean the documentation needs to be updated, it means the design needs to be updated.Thus, I vote that since the old behavior adds no value to LibreOffice, this patch be reconsidered. Otherwise, a very clear user-oriented case for the old behavior should be made.

The old behavior lends no benefit to the user whatsoever, whereas the new behavior does.Also, the "current" way of "starting on a custom page" is extremely difficult for many users to understand and implement, and is somewhat unreliable in its nature. The main problem is that you wind up with a new empty page at the start of your document.It's a basic principle of software design: if many users are confused, that doesn't mean the documentation needs to be updated, it means the design needs to be updated.Thus, I vote that since the old behavior adds no value to LibreOffice, this patch be reconsidered. Otherwise, a very clear user-oriented case for the old behavior should be made.

text: Patch Set 6:I would be all right with dropping this feature, in favor of implementing a considerably easier-to-use "start page on" feature.However, we have to face the fact that a huge number of users rely on offset for exactly what this feature allowed, and we have even documented the workaround to achieve the exact same end as what I've described. Thus, before I could abandon this, we would need to:- Change or remove the UI for setting the "offset". It appears to be used exclusively for what is was not designed for, and not for whatever theoretical use it was designed for. Removing the UI for offset doesn't eliminate the feature, but it prevents its rampant (apparent) misuse.- Remove the "workaround" documented to force offset page numbers to overrun the end of the document. Since this is contrary to intended use, we shouldn't be telling users to use offset this way.- Make the means of "starting on" a page number VERY VERY clear.All that said, I don't believe it is wise to abandon this revision until all of those changes are made. This problem has been heavily reported and wholly unaddressed for nearly a decade. This fix isn't ideal, but it is considerably closer to expected behavior than the current behavior. Thus, we need to either provide the expected behavior, or adapt this to match how everyone uses it.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(2 comments)Checking each cell of the entire selection is clearly unnecessary and a huge performance bottleneck.If two or three rows of a column selection are of string type then maybe the first row is not a column header. Similar for a row selection.Things are different if more than one column or row is selected and a cell type of the alleged header row/column is not of string type, then likely it's not a header row/column. Maybe a check of the second row/column would be appropriate if the first row/column was detected to contain only string cells, if also the second row/column contains only string cells then it is uncertain. If it contains at least one non-string cell then likely the first row/column contains headers.Please also see again my comments at https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=91305#c13 and https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=91305#c15

text: Patch Set 3:(1 comment)Good that you look for both .fbk and .fdb and that you give .fbk priority.Will this silently "upgrade" an .odb that has an .fdb to one that has a .fbk on the next save? Not that I necessarily oppose it, just to be clear.

text: Patch Set 7:> Saving an opened file:> When the user saves the file, there is a .fbk file> stored in the odb. The driver checks for the fbk> first, and then (if not found) it looks for an fdb.> Should the old .fbk file be removed in the second case?> I think if we want to remove the old file,> there should be an extra check to be sure the> .fbk file works successfully.You mean "the old *fdb*" I suppose. On the one hand,letting old cruft lie around is not good, and lettingthe old fdb in place will also lead to an .odb thatopens a different database (with different data) dependingon which version of LibreOffice opens the file...On the other hand, you are right, risk of data loss if we screw up and the fbk is not functional.On the balance of it, I'd say "people should make backups, remove the old fdb". Ideally, we would make a popup that warns people about this "silent upgrade", too.> Anyway I don't think it will be a common happening,> because it works only with fb 3.0 fdb files,> and the update comes in the same time.This part of the code will indeed be useless as longas we bundle Firebird 3.0 because it cannot openFirebird 2.5 .fdb files. However, since the FB devs planthat a future 3.x release will be able to open Firebird 2.5.fdb files, my plan was to already have the right logic (code)in place in LibreOffice so that (hopefully soon), when weupgrade our bundled Firebird, it will just fall in place :)

text: Patch Set 37: Code-Review-1> These *.d files are dependencies normally generated with the -MMD > option of gcc. On Windows, because of the lack of gcc, I copy these > files from external (modified a bit with sed).You are asking the wrong question and giving a wrong answer. Given your patch set 36 where you've added generated header dependency files to GIT, I'm even don't know where to start with the explanation why it's wrong thing to do.What the problem are you trying to solve in the last sane patch set 35 of this change?sed failure, trying to substitute stuff in generated .d files, that should be generated by gcc with -MMD option. Check this Paul's explanation on auto-dependency generation in GNU make + gcc combination: [1]. One important thing to understand though, in LO build tool chain, we are abusing the gcc with gcc-wrapper machinery on Windows, to not mess around with all those MSVC project files and having only one integration tool chain for external libraries. That why, as you noticed -MMD cannot be understood by the cl.exe that get invoked by gcc-wrapper in the end.So the correct question to ask on patch set 35 is *not* where and how to get those .d files, but of course why they are needed in the first place and how to disable all this header tracking feature altogether on windows platform.After you are asking the right question, you should already have the 99% of the answer to this question: Before this change, compilation worked on windows platform for FB 2.5 with the same approach. What was changed? Firebord upgrade? Fine. But why it's related?When you invoke the make with -d option, to see what is actually going on, it's telling you that "sed ... wildcard ..." is get invoked. Why and from where?grepping on "wilcard" line in FB 3 source code, reveals the lines in question in make.rules. Comparing this file with FB 2.5, reveals that there weren't any sed invokation there.So the missing 3 lines in patch 35 to solve sed missing *.d failures in FB 3 are these deleted 3 lines in make.rules (at least on windows platform): [2].* [1] http://make.mad-scientist.net/papers/advanced-auto-dependency-generation* [2] http://paste.openstack.org/show/534815

Text: Patch Set 41:> I don't know yet the source of this error. >  > The first error is: > - syntax error : missing ';' before 'constant' >  > I thought maybe the problem lies on a missing header, so I wrote > out the included files with -showIncludes and I think winnt.h, > which is required for 'LARGE_INTEGER' is included properly: > http://pastebin.com/KLpSV2cGSee: [1] where the definition of LARGE_INTEGER from winnt.h is included. The content of the structure depends on MIDL_PASS being set or not. Add pre-processor directove to the compiler parameter: [2] to investigate where and why it's set.* [1] http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3606902/cant-make-sense-of-large-integer-struct* [2] http://stackoverflow.com/questions/277258/how-do-i-see-a-c-c-source-file-after-preprocessing-in-visual-studio/277362#277362

Text: Patch Set 1:yes that's it!unfortunately it exposes a bug in the sidebar code: if the writer's sidebar is open, then it doesn't really go away when the Math panel is activated - if you move the cursor over the math panel, the writer sidebar widgets are drawn.this also was the case before but one wouldn't move the cursor on the right side because there's nothing there to click on :-/

text: Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1I took a sample why this (and likely also the other changes) fails the build: csch.fods in row 14 (and also others, but that one fails for me) compares floating point values using =equal. Please use an appropriate rounding instead, i.e. in this case even =ROUND(A14,14)=ROUND(B14,14) would do, but usually rounding to 12 decimals ROUND(...,12) should be fine, always depends on the expected number of course.You can also see the underlying difference error with =RAWSUBTRACT(B14,A14), in fact you can also use RAWSUBTRACT to check for error instead of rounding, e.g. =ABS(RAWSUBTRACT(B14,A14))<F14 where F14 could contain 1e-12
Text: Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1I took a sample why this (and likely also the other changes) fails the build: csch.fods in row 14 (and also others, but that one fails for me) compares floating point values using =equal. Please use an appropriate rounding instead, i.e. in this case even =ROUND(A14,14)=ROUND(B14,14) would do, but usually rounding to 12 decimals ROUND(...,12) should be fine, always depends on the expected number of course.You can also see the underlying difference error with =RAWSUBTRACT(B14,A14), in fact you can also use RAWSUBTRACT to check for error instead of rounding, e.g. =ABS(RAWSUBTRACT(B14,A14))<F14 where F14 could contain 1e-12

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1(7 comments)Thanks for the hard work, sorry this took so long:There is a lot of trickiness here. Some suggestions(1) break off the XPolyPolygon changes into a separate patch, that'll be easy to review and commit(2) I think we're going to need some const casting around Resize() - probably making Resize() const to avoid unnecessary copying.
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1(7 comments)Thanks for the hard work, sorry this took so long:There is a lot of trickiness here. Some suggestions(1) break off the XPolyPolygon changes into a separate patch, that'll be easy to review and commit(2) I think we're going to need some const casting around Resize() - probably making Resize() const to avoid unnecessary copying.

text: Patch Set 2:Looks good in general, I just worry about changing the layout of existing ODP documents.Suggestion: have a look at settings.xml, how they are parsed on import. Add a new setting next to e.g. EmbedFonts, named something like AnchoredTextOverflow, which would be false in the code, but set to true when creating a new document. (Optionally the PPT/PPTX import can set this flag as well.) This way the layout of existing documents would not change, but new and imported-from-PPT/PPTX documents would have the expected, better layout.At least this is how I did changes do the Writer layout in the past. ;-)
Text: Patch Set 2:Looks good in general, I just worry about changing the layout of existing ODP documents.Suggestion: have a look at settings.xml, how they are parsed on import. Add a new setting next to e.g. EmbedFonts, named something like AnchoredTextOverflow, which would be false in the code, but set to true when creating a new document. (Optionally the PPT/PPTX import can set this flag as well.) This way the layout of existing documents would not change, but new and imported-from-PPT/PPTX documents would have the expected, better layout.At least this is how I did changes do the Writer layout in the past. ;-)

text: Patch Set 3:Caolan, honestly, I do not think this is the right way to go...I do not think that it is good to 'hack' the animatedBitmapExPreparator - which is a by purpose isolated piece of tooling - into parts. It's purpose is to provide all frames of a GIF in one run.The GIF itself is shown and/or played or not. If just shown, the 1st frame will be needed, if played the whole stack will be needed to do so (all extra actions to create on-demand here will just let it stuck in the 1st loop). If not shown, all the stack can be flushed.There may be the case that only the start frame is needed (screenshot/preview), than this should be optimized. The 1st frame of the GIF is available using simple steps, maybe added to the tooling.So I see no value in on-demand creating *single frames* of the stack, besides that I do not see code to flush it if not used. It will just use the same amount of mem when the GIF is shown and played once.My approch would be to create (a) the 1st frame on-demand, (b) the whole stack on-demand if played (not at load time), and (c) find a way to flush the whole stack if not used (timer/usage based, or the owner getting invisible, there are possibilities). The step (a) would already solve the too-much-mem-after-load problem, the others would make it smart.
Text: Patch Set 3:Caolan, honestly, I do not think this is the right way to go...I do not think that it is good to 'hack' the animatedBitmapExPreparator - which is a by purpose isolated piece of tooling - into parts. It's purpose is to provide all frames of a GIF in one run.The GIF itself is shown and/or played or not. If just shown, the 1st frame will be needed, if played the whole stack will be needed to do so (all extra actions to create on-demand here will just let it stuck in the 1st loop). If not shown, all the stack can be flushed.There may be the case that only the start frame is needed (screenshot/preview), than this should be optimized. The 1st frame of the GIF is available using simple steps, maybe added to the tooling.So I see no value in on-demand creating *single frames* of the stack, besides that I do not see code to flush it if not used. It will just use the same amount of mem when the GIF is shown and played once.My approch would be to create (a) the 1st frame on-demand, (b) the whole stack on-demand if played (not at load time), and (c) find a way to flush the whole stack if not used (timer/usage based, or the owner getting invisible, there are possibilities). The step (a) would already solve the too-much-mem-after-load problem, the others would make it smart.

text: Patch Set 3:> Caolan, honestly, I do not think this is the right way to go...This is essentially the same thing as the earlier prototype which seemed acceptable. The frames are still created on demand. Its just that in practice I see that on playback sometimes frames are skipped due to timing issues, in which case we need to occasionally "catch up" the missing ones. i.e. play 0, 1, 3, 4 skipping 2. so frame 3 renders 2 into the virtualdevice as well as 3 to get the right final bitmap. > If just shown, the > 1st frame will be needed, if played the whole stack will be needed > to do so (all extra actions to create on-demand here will just let > it stuck in the 1st loop). If not shown, all the stack can be > flushed.I think we're getting hung up on the first frame, the first frame gets requested occasionally during the playback of the animated gif (by the preview I think) so it seemed natural to treat that one separately by caching it so as not not affect the shared virtual devices in use by playback of the active sequence. > So I see no value in on-demand creating *single frames* of the > stack, besides that I do not see code to flush it if not used. It > will just use the same amount of mem when the GIF is shown and > played once.As the animation is played each frame is requested in sequence and each frame bitmap is generated and returned, rendered, and forgotten about, so (ignoring the first frame cache) there is only one bitmap in memory at a time. > My approch would be to create (b) the whole stack on-demand if played (not at load time)What I want to avoid though is 382 simultaneous 1920 x 1080 bitmaps. Its not so much an issue of lingering bitmaps, but the pile of them getting created together and the attempt here creates, uses and destroys them in sequence during the animation.
Text: Patch Set 3:> Caolan, honestly, I do not think this is the right way to go...This is essentially the same thing as the earlier prototype which seemed acceptable. The frames are still created on demand. Its just that in practice I see that on playback sometimes frames are skipped due to timing issues, in which case we need to occasionally "catch up" the missing ones. i.e. play 0, 1, 3, 4 skipping 2. so frame 3 renders 2 into the virtualdevice as well as 3 to get the right final bitmap. > If just shown, the > 1st frame will be needed, if played the whole stack will be needed > to do so (all extra actions to create on-demand here will just let > it stuck in the 1st loop). If not shown, all the stack can be > flushed.I think we're getting hung up on the first frame, the first frame gets requested occasionally during the playback of the animated gif (by the preview I think) so it seemed natural to treat that one separately by caching it so as not not affect the shared virtual devices in use by playback of the active sequence. > So I see no value in on-demand creating *single frames* of the > stack, besides that I do not see code to flush it if not used. It > will just use the same amount of mem when the GIF is shown and > played once.As the animation is played each frame is requested in sequence and each frame bitmap is generated and returned, rendered, and forgotten about, so (ignoring the first frame cache) there is only one bitmap in memory at a time. > My approch would be to create (b) the whole stack on-demand if played (not at load time)What I want to avoid though is 382 simultaneous 1920 x 1080 bitmaps. Its not so much an issue of lingering bitmaps, but the pile of them getting created together and the attempt here creates, uses and destroys them in sequence during the animation.

text: Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1I have looked into this (via https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/25999 )It appears that you cannot use unique_ptr for pImpl in this instance.When reset() is called on pImpl, pImpl contains a SfxSlotPool whose destructor indirectly reads this pImpl (that has been reset) (undefined behaviour of std::unique_ptr reset() )I recommend that this patch is abandoned, unless you want to attempt to fix the spaghetti
Text: Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1I have looked into this (via https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/25999 )It appears that you cannot use unique_ptr for pImpl in this instance.When reset() is called on pImpl, pImpl contains a SfxSlotPool whose destructor indirectly reads this pImpl (that has been reset) (undefined behaviour of std::unique_ptr reset() )I recommend that this patch is abandoned, unless you want to attempt to fix the spaghetti

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2Why do you think this is necessary?  css::uno::DisposedException is derived from css::uno::RuntimeException (which can be thrown from every UNO interface method).  (Also, the definition of getPreferredVisualRepresentation in offapi/com/sun/star/embed/XVisualObject.idl does not redundantly mention DisposedException, either; that would be a mild argument in favour of redundantly adding it here, too.)
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2Why do you think this is necessary?  css::uno::DisposedException is derived from css::uno::RuntimeException (which can be thrown from every UNO interface method).  (Also, the definition of getPreferredVisualRepresentation in offapi/com/sun/star/embed/XVisualObject.idl does not redundantly mention DisposedException, either; that would be a mild argument in favour of redundantly adding it here, too.)

text: Patch Set 1:> Why do you think this is necessary?  css::uno::DisposedException is > derived from css::uno::RuntimeException (which can be thrown from > every UNO interface method).  (Also, the definition of > getPreferredVisualRepresentation in offapi/com/sun/star/embed/XVisualObject.idl > does not redundantly mention DisposedException, either; that would > be a mild argument in favour of redundantly adding it here, too.)Hi, Stephan!Actually, I was not sure it was the right thing to do, because of the inheritance from css::uno::RuntimeException.But then I checked out css::lang::IllegalArgumentException and it turned out it derives also from css::uno::RuntimeException.You can verify it here: workdir/UnoApiHeadersTarget/udkapi/normal/com/sun/star/lang/IllegalArgumentException.hdlSo I thought that we should list all exceptions
Text: Patch Set 1:> Why do you think this is necessary?  css::uno::DisposedException is > derived from css::uno::RuntimeException (which can be thrown from > every UNO interface method).  (Also, the definition of > getPreferredVisualRepresentation in offapi/com/sun/star/embed/XVisualObject.idl > does not redundantly mention DisposedException, either; that would > be a mild argument in favour of redundantly adding it here, too.)Hi, Stephan!Actually, I was not sure it was the right thing to do, because of the inheritance from css::uno::RuntimeException.But then I checked out css::lang::IllegalArgumentException and it turned out it derives also from css::uno::RuntimeException.You can verify it here: workdir/UnoApiHeadersTarget/udkapi/normal/com/sun/star/lang/IllegalArgumentException.hdlSo I thought that we should list all exceptions

text: Patch Set 1:> IllegalArgumentException is a special case - when most of the IDL > files were written it derived from Exception, not RuntimeException; > it was changed to derive from RuntimeException in 2012.Indeed, that's another reason why IllegalArgumentException tends to redundantly show up in UNOIDL raises/C++ throw clauses.However, there are also other examples of redundantly specified runtime exceptions, e.g., css.resource.XResourceBundleLoader.loadBundle explicitly raising css.resource.MissingResourceException.  Lets just be forgiving and close our eyes when a C++ function redundantly mentions a RuntimeException-derived exception in its throws clause because the corresponding UNOIDL method specified it, too.  But don't needlessly add further redundant exceptions to such C++ functions.
Text: Patch Set 1:> IllegalArgumentException is a special case - when most of the IDL > files were written it derived from Exception, not RuntimeException; > it was changed to derive from RuntimeException in 2012.Indeed, that's another reason why IllegalArgumentException tends to redundantly show up in UNOIDL raises/C++ throw clauses.However, there are also other examples of redundantly specified runtime exceptions, e.g., css.resource.XResourceBundleLoader.loadBundle explicitly raising css.resource.MissingResourceException.  Lets just be forgiving and close our eyes when a C++ function redundantly mentions a RuntimeException-derived exception in its throws clause because the corresponding UNOIDL method specified it, too.  But don't needlessly add further redundant exceptions to such C++ functions.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2IMHO in this case the whole class SwVectorModifyBase doesnt make sense at all and should be killed. It is only used five times:- as a base for SwGrfFormatColls and as a base for SwTextFormatColls with DestructorPolicy KeepElements- as a base for SwFrameFormats, SwCharFormats and SwSectionFormats with DestructorPolicy FreeElementsWith DestructorPolicy KeepElements there is no magic in this class AFAICS -- so SwGrfFormatColls and SwTextFormatColls only use the wrapper functions from SwVectorModifyBase.With DestructorPolicy FreeElements, there is magic happening on destruction, but I dont think that the inheriting wrapper is a good choice to implement this. E.g. a unique_ptr with a custom deleter is likely a better choice.So IMHO the way forward would be to:1/ Make SwGrfFormatColls, SwTextFormatColls directly use a plain std::vector instead of the SwVectorModifyBase -- that should be simple enough2/ In a follow up patch do the same for the other clients using a unique_ptr with a custom deleterPatches should be minimal and small, so start with just one class per patch (e.g. SwGrfFormatColls).
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2IMHO in this case the whole class SwVectorModifyBase doesnt make sense at all and should be killed. It is only used five times:- as a base for SwGrfFormatColls and as a base for SwTextFormatColls with DestructorPolicy KeepElements- as a base for SwFrameFormats, SwCharFormats and SwSectionFormats with DestructorPolicy FreeElementsWith DestructorPolicy KeepElements there is no magic in this class AFAICS -- so SwGrfFormatColls and SwTextFormatColls only use the wrapper functions from SwVectorModifyBase.With DestructorPolicy FreeElements, there is magic happening on destruction, but I dont think that the inheriting wrapper is a good choice to implement this. E.g. a unique_ptr with a custom deleter is likely a better choice.So IMHO the way forward would be to:1/ Make SwGrfFormatColls, SwTextFormatColls directly use a plain std::vector instead of the SwVectorModifyBase -- that should be simple enough2/ In a follow up patch do the same for the other clients using a unique_ptr with a custom deleterPatches should be minimal and small, so start with just one class per patch (e.g. SwGrfFormatColls).

E.g. a unique_ptr with a custom deleter > is likely a better choice. >  > So IMHO the way forward would be to: > 1/ Make SwGrfFormatColls, SwTextFormatColls directly use a plain > std::vector instead of the SwVectorModifyBase -- that should be > simple enough > 2/ In a follow up patch do the same for the other clients using a > unique_ptr with a custom deleter >  > Patches should be minimal and small, so start with just one class > per patch (e.g. SwGrfFormatColls).Thank you for the review.I will definitely look into your suggestions and code review and will work accordingly.I will try my best.
