text: Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1You are still ignoring two points in my previous comments without indicating why.* The patch makes m_aCurToken.aText as written by user, which changes the behaviour of NextToken()* Why not improve SmParser::GetTokenTableEntry() instead of exposing the map?Are you sure that specifying the eqFunc function with OUStringHash does notdegrate performance of finding a key?Usual implementation, such as libstdc++, of std::unordered_map is based on a hashtable;I am even afraid if OUStringHash can distribute the canonical-form key into differentbuckets in the hashtable from the one for the lower/mixed-case key, so it would missthe correct entry.
Text: Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1You are still ignoring two points in my previous comments without indicating why.* The patch makes m_aCurToken.aText as written by user, which changes the behaviour of NextToken()* Why not improve SmParser::GetTokenTableEntry() instead of exposing the map?Are you sure that specifying the eqFunc function with OUStringHash does notdegrate performance of finding a key?Usual implementation, such as libstdc++, of std::unordered_map is based on a hashtable;I am even afraid if OUStringHash can distribute the canonical-form key into differentbuckets in the hashtable from the one for the lower/mixed-case key, so it would missthe correct entry.

text: Patch Set 2:in patch set 2, when you fixed a merge conflict, you did solve it the wrong way. You did remove the part I added and was the cause for the merge-conflict.Now there have been again changes to the themes.xml in the meantime for the android:tint for https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/24119/ - so themes.xml again has changes that your patch  would "throw away" -What should happen with stuff that was added to a file that is deleted in this changeset is something that gerrit/git cannot decide automatically.So when solving the conflict, make sure to copy all the additions from themes.xml that were done in the meantime (the logo statement and now the android:tint) to styles.xml
Text: Patch Set 2:in patch set 2, when you fixed a merge conflict, you did solve it the wrong way. You did remove the part I added and was the cause for the merge-conflict.Now there have been again changes to the themes.xml in the meantime for the android:tint for https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/24119/ - so themes.xml again has changes that your patch  would "throw away" -What should happen with stuff that was added to a file that is deleted in this changeset is something that gerrit/git cannot decide automatically.So when solving the conflict, make sure to copy all the additions from themes.xml that were done in the meantime (the logo statement and now the android:tint) to styles.xml

text: Patch Set 1:I don't really mind either way - as there are only "two and a half" theme statements, we can merge it into styles.xml (android projects themselves still use themes.xml) - would make sense to have them separate if we intended to use different themes based on android version (but we don't).But I'd rather put the global theme definition at the top :-)(And if you're up to another cleanup task: all the blurps about apache stuff in the licence is a mistake actually, impress remote was created in 2013 GSoC, long time after the split and never was part of OOo code/has no Apache inheritance)
Text: Patch Set 1:I don't really mind either way - as there are only "two and a half" theme statements, we can merge it into styles.xml (android projects themselves still use themes.xml) - would make sense to have them separate if we intended to use different themes based on android version (but we don't).But I'd rather put the global theme definition at the top :-)(And if you're up to another cleanup task: all the blurps about apache stuff in the licence is a mistake actually, impress remote was created in 2013 GSoC, long time after the split and never was part of OOo code/has no Apache inheritance)

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Nice idea, but it makes Calc crash as soon one wants to pull a handle (the ones in the corners of a range) with the mouse to enlarge a range. This also when an existing formula is edited where the ranges are already highlighted and one of them is pulled.I also dislike that the RangeFinder is initialized on each and every single keystroke, regardless whether something actually has to be redrawn or newly drawn or not, effectively clearing all ranges and displaying all again even on input of function names, operators and the like.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Nice idea, but it makes Calc crash as soon one wants to pull a handle (the ones in the corners of a range) with the mouse to enlarge a range. This also when an existing formula is edited where the ranges are already highlighted and one of them is pulled.I also dislike that the RangeFinder is initialized on each and every single keystroke, regardless whether something actually has to be redrawn or newly drawn or not, effectively clearing all ranges and displaying all again even on input of function names, operators and the like.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2To confirm Norbert's input. I would expect such cosmetic changes to fix potential nano-aggressions ;-) to be done in the course of existing significant work to the code-base. This then avoids conflict and argument over ~irrelevances like this. "Lifecycle" is an industry standard term here encompasing creation & destruction, life & death of objects =) FWIW - the new naming is rather less clear to me.Nevertheless - if someone who is actively working on really substantial functional improvement in this area feels strongly about this, they are at liberty to change it as part of their work of course =)I'd really like to avoid us as a project getting dragged into this.Please consider abandoning your patch =)
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2To confirm Norbert's input. I would expect such cosmetic changes to fix potential nano-aggressions ;-) to be done in the course of existing significant work to the code-base. This then avoids conflict and argument over ~irrelevances like this. "Lifecycle" is an industry standard term here encompasing creation & destruction, life & death of objects =) FWIW - the new naming is rather less clear to me.Nevertheless - if someone who is actively working on really substantial functional improvement in this area feels strongly about this, they are at liberty to change it as part of their work of course =)I'd really like to avoid us as a project getting dragged into this.Please consider abandoning your patch =)

text: Patch Set 1:The first line of the commit message should say what the commit does. It is not strictly necessary or useful to tell what parts of the code a commit touches in the commit message, because one can trivially see that in the 'git log' output anyway (by using the --stat option). Sure, I know that many of my esteemed colleagues feel the need to mention it anyway. But in this case, listing several directories on the first line of the message is not helpful. You can here just use the bug title, "Remove conditionals depending on OSL_DEBUG_LEVEL > 1", it works fine (in this case; that is not always the case).
Text: Patch Set 1:The first line of the commit message should say what the commit does. It is not strictly necessary or useful to tell what parts of the code a commit touches in the commit message, because one can trivially see that in the 'git log' output anyway (by using the --stat option). Sure, I know that many of my esteemed colleagues feel the need to mention it anyway. But in this case, listing several directories on the first line of the message is not helpful. You can here just use the bug title, "Remove conditionals depending on OSL_DEBUG_LEVEL > 1", it works fine (in this case; that is not always the case).

text: Patch Set 1:In general, I am personally not that convinced that adding such #ifdef DEBUG_FOO_BAR is that useful. There is a large risk that the code inside those will bit-rot anyway sooner or later. And if this code at some stage needs debugging, it is questionable whether the specific optional debug code that was perhaps useful some time ago will still be useful, or whether one will need to write more complicated or complete debugging code anyway. I would just remove it. But I am not insisting.

I would just remove it. But I am not insisting.

text: Patch Set 1:Maybe describe what you want to do (not how you want to do) in the commit message. :-)EXTENDED_TIME is a Writer field type, Writer field types are exposed as different service names in the UNO API. What is the intention of using setPropertyValue() to set the field type, when you already specified the field type when you created the instance by specifying its service name? If the name set by setPropertyValue() is the same as the one you used at construction time, then it's redundant. If it's something else -- then just create a new field instance, don't try to change an existing one.
Text: Patch Set 1:Maybe describe what you want to do (not how you want to do) in the commit message. :-)EXTENDED_TIME is a Writer field type, Writer field types are exposed as different service names in the UNO API. What is the intention of using setPropertyValue() to set the field type, when you already specified the field type when you created the instance by specifying its service name? If the name set by setPropertyValue() is the same as the one you used at construction time, then it's redundant. If it's something else -- then just create a new field instance, don't try to change an existing one.

text: Patch Set 1: -Code-Review> EXTENDED_TIME is a Writer field type, Writer field types are > exposed as different service names in the UNO API. What is the > intention of using setPropertyValue() to set the field type, when > you already specified the field type when you created the instance > by specifying its service name? If the name set by > setPropertyValue() is the same as the one you used at construction > time, then it's redundant. If it's something else -- then just > create a new field instance, don't try to change an existing one.But then UnknownPropertyException and IllegalArgumentException are thrown when we do a getPropertyValue() and this certainly indicates we aren't setting the properties correctly.Isn't this case similar with : From UserDataType <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/ExtendedUser.idl#48> and UserDataPart<http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/UserDataPart.idl>, I could notice similarities with the present case. Except that the fields are related to corresponding XML fields and are set here <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/xmloff/source/text/txtfldi.cxx#630>

text: Patch Set 1:Apologies for the delay. I had an exam.So here's the summary : Firstly, coming to the problem - We have a test document from which two things weren't rendering properly in Writer.1) Some content within a frame. The relevant data from the test document's 'content.xml' is - <draw:frame draw:name="Rahmen1" draw:style-name="fr1" svg:x="70.8379179942pt" svg:y="127.5592761pt" text:anchor-type="page" text:anchor-page-number="1" draw:z-index="2" svg:width="212.5421004884pt" svg:height="14.0882133826pt">    <draw:text-box fo:min-height="0.01pt">     <text:p text:style-name="P2"><text:s/><text:span text:style-name="T1">ÔÇó</text:span><text:s/><text:span text:style-name="T2"><text:sender-street>Steinmetzstra├ƒe 57</text:sender-street></text:span><text:span text:style-name="T2"/><text:span text:style-name="T1">ÔÇó</text:span><text:s/><text:span text:style-name="T2"><text:sender-postal-code>10783</text:sender-postal-code></text:span><text:span text:style-name="T2"/><text:span text:style-name="T2"><text:sender-city>Berlin</text:sender-city></text:span></text:p>    </draw:text-box>   </draw:frame>2) A bookmark within a frame wasn't showing up in the Navigation bar (The text was showing in the frame, but the bookmark wasn't showing in the Navigation bar). The relevant XML from 'content.xml' : <draw:frame draw:name="Rahmen4" draw:style-name="fr2" svg:x="70.8379179942pt" svg:y="289.1627056658pt" text:anchor-type="page" text:anchor-page-number="1" draw:z-index="6" svg:width="496.0638515pt" svg:height="14.0882133826pt">    <draw:text-box fo:min-height="0.01pt">     <text:p text:style-name="P5"><text:bookmark text:name="Bezugszeichen"/><text:tab text:tab-ref="1"/>7. Oktober 2005<text:tab text:tab-ref="2"/><text:tab text:tab-ref="3"/><text:span><text:date style:data-style-name="N1"/></text:span></text:p>    </draw:text-box>   </draw:frame>Now coming to seeing which exceptions were thrown : (Breakpoint at SvxFieldData::Create() from editeng/source/items/flditem.cxx)1)   When 2) from above was removed from 'content.xml' and 1) was kept, these were thrown : - throw beans::UnknownPropertyException( "Unknown property: " + rPropertyName, static_cast < cppu::OWeakObject * > ( this ) );line 2322 from unofield.cxx (This unofield.cxx is from module sw)- throw lang::IllegalArgumentException(); line 1942 from unotext.cxx (module editeng)The second exception looks to be thrown because the first in thrown.And the above two get repeated 3 times for a total of 6 exceptions thrown.This is probably because there are three sender fields - 'sender-city', 'sender-postal-code' and 'sender-street' in the content.xml2)   When 1) from above was removed from 'content.xml' and 2) was kept : - throw lang::IllegalArgumentException(); line 1942 from unotext.cxx (module editeng)- throw beans::UnknownPropertyException( "Unknown property: " + rPropertyName, static_cast < cppu::OWeakObject * > ( this ) );line 2322 from unofield.cxx (This unofield.cxx is from module sw)- throw lang::IllegalArgumentException(); line 1942 from unotext.cxx (module editeng)in the given order.When the original 'content.xml' was used as is, 1) was followed by 2)Since these exceptions were thrown from the call in this line'aAny = xPropSet->getPropertyValue(UNO_TC_PROP_TEXTFIELD_TYPE);' in editeng/source/items/flditem.cxx, it is clear that the properties of the type UNO_TC_PROP_TEXTFIELD_TYPE are not filled.From looking below in the above code, we can identify the properties as the ones in :<http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/Type.idl>So we have to set the appropriate properties as indicated in the bug description.And for part 1) of the problem, looks like the properties have to be set in XMLSenderFieldImportContext::PrepareField() from xmloff/source/text/txtfldi.cxxSince we are going to do a getPropertyValue() later, that's the reason I think a call to setPropertyValue() is required. (Miklos - this might be a part answer to your comment)The below explanation is only concerning the Sender Fields and not related to the Bookmark problem.Now looking at the what else is happening in XMLSenderFieldImportContext, we haveaAny <<= nSubType;rPropSet->setPropertyValue(sPropertyFieldSubType, aAny);where nSubType is from UserDataPart - offapi/com/sun/star/text/UserDataPart.idlNow XMLSenderField is of type "ExtendedUser" which is defined in offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/ExtendedUser.idl'UserDataType' is already present here.The association between 'UserDataType' and 'UserDataPart' is exactly like what I want to create between 'TextFieldType' (which I have defined) and 'Type' from Type.idl mentioned above.So I looked into all the places where changes need to be made.1) The first one is of course in ExtendedUser.idl2) Then there is adding the corresponding entry to offapi/type_reference/offapi.idl. (This was because other entries in ExtendedUser.idl had been declared here too)3)Adding ' #define UNO_NAME_TEXT_FIELD_TYPE "TextFieldType" ' to sw/inc/unoprnms.hxx is the most doubtful step where I don't know whether I'm right. Some entries from include/editeng/unonames.hxx have entries in sw/inc/unoprnms.hxx. Some of them are "CurrentPresentation", "IsDate", etc. So I thought "TextFieldType" needed to be in sw/inc/unoprnms.hxx as UNO_NAME_TEXT_FIELD_TYPE so that it can be used in sw/source/core/unocore/unomap.cxx. I haven't looked into adding anything to unomap.cxx yet.4) Then adding "const OUString sPropertyFieldSubType1;" to xmloff/inc/txtfldi.hxx is just an emulation of "const OUString sPropertyFieldSubType;".5) Similar is the case of adding "const sal_Char sAPI_text_field_type[]           = "TextFieldType";" to txtfldi.cxx. (A direct emulation of "const sal_Char sAPI_user_data_type[]            = "UserDataType";"Of course, the relevant header files have been added to txtfldi.cxxNow looks like we shoudn't add anything to 'XMLSenderFieldImportContext::StartElement' in txtfldi.cxx as the properties from UserDataPart have been extended as XML Tokens (const short NAME from UserDataPart.idl is used as XML_TOK_TEXT_SENDER_NAME)  and are being used there. At the moment, the properties from Type.idl are not used as XML Tokens. Again I would need help with the decision here as to whether to extend as XML Tokens or not.Finally in XMLSenderFieldImportContext::PrepareField(),using namespace textfield;aAny <<= Type::EXTENDED_TIME;rPropSet->setPropertyValue(sPropertyFieldSubType1, aAny);is what is supposed to be done.Since I've mentioned '[optional, property]long TextFieldType;' as optional in <opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/ExtendedUser.idl>, I might need a boolean to indicate when 'setPropertyValue()' must be called for each of the fields from <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/Type.idl> in here <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/xmloff/source/text/txtfldi.cxx#706>. I don't think we need to call it for all 15 properties all the time. How do I use the boolean variable - like for example - how do I use it to indicate when to set EXTENDED_TIME and when not to..?And there's one more thing:I think we may need to call this setPropertyValue() <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/editeng/source/uno/unofield.cxx#675> instead of the one currently being called <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/unocore/unofield.cxx#2152> which is throwing up an Unknown Property Exception at <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/unocore/unofield.cxx#2165> One is sw's implementation while the other is editeng's implementation. Moggi was of the opinion that the setPropertyValue() from editeng couldn't be called here. But the current one is unable to support that property (UNO_TC_PROP_TEXTFIELD_TYPE). How would it be possible to proceed? I'm influenced by this comment <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/Type.idl#19> when I say the above.There might be some changes required to xmloff/source/text/txtflde.cxx too.I might have forgotten some bits and pieces, but I guess this is the whole summary in general.So please give some pointers on how to proceed. Please also tell me if there are other files I need to look into.

text: Patch Set 1:OK, so what is your goal? I see the following possibilities:1) You want to extend LO's document model, field implementation etc to handle the extra field markup produced by KWord or2) You just want to make sure that the document can be imported without editeng's UNO code throwing, i.e. minimize data-loss.Do I see correctly that you currently go after 2)?
Text: Patch Set 1:OK, so what is your goal? I see the following possibilities:1) You want to extend LO's document model, field implementation etc to handle the extra field markup produced by KWord or2) You just want to make sure that the document can be imported without editeng's UNO code throwing, i.e. minimize data-loss.Do I see correctly that you currently go after 2)?

text: Patch Set 1:> OK, so what is your goal? I see the following possibilities: >  > 1) You want to extend LO's document model, field implementation etc > to handle the extra field markup produced by KWordI would like to go after the first one since someone might file a bug report for that in the future and since its an enhancement request in Apache's OO, we might as well have it here.But again, I guess this is Kendy's decision.
Text: Patch Set 1:> OK, so what is your goal? I see the following possibilities: >  > 1) You want to extend LO's document model, field implementation etc > to handle the extra field markup produced by KWordI would like to go after the first one since someone might file a bug report for that in the future and since its an enhancement request in Apache's OO, we might as well have it here.But again, I guess this is Kendy's decision.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-136270776a68c0cd0f472ebd7124c93d7936caf04 is an example on how to add a new property to a Writer field. In case the field is in shape text, then you want to do something like that in editeng, since editeng providers the shape text. The idea is that there is a C++ class that internally stores the new member, and then there is an UNO API wrapper class that exposes that in the API.I.e. no change to xmloff yet, and no change to offapi/type_reference. If you need to change the later to not break the build, that means you tried to change the API in an incompatible way, that's a no-go.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-136270776a68c0cd0f472ebd7124c93d7936caf04 is an example on how to add a new property to a Writer field. In case the field is in shape text, then you want to do something like that in editeng, since editeng providers the shape text. The idea is that there is a C++ class that internally stores the new member, and then there is an UNO API wrapper class that exposes that in the API.I.e. no change to xmloff yet, and no change to offapi/type_reference. If you need to change the later to not break the build, that means you tried to change the API in an incompatible way, that's a no-go.

I'm reworking the icons as we speak. Mostly because they're incorrect size now (new Action Bar is taller), and they're Holo gray instead of Material white. text: Patch Set 2:I wanted to use orange because it was previously used, and also because we're working with Impress (and not the whole Libre Office suite), so I think we should still use orange. However, if we think of it as an "extension of the whole suite", and not take into account that it works with Impress only, it should then be green. HOWEVER, if we plan to materialize the Viewer/Editor app, it would also have green color, and maybe we should distinct the two. Also, if we switch it to green, we'd need a new icon (I'm working on it, as soon as I get CorelDraw working on Linux). Also, consider that this (blue) accent doesn't have much contrast between green and it.P.S. should I abandon this change now? I will abandon it, and you "resurrect it" (lol) if you think that we need it, but I guess we basically moved all the useful changes to your commit.
Text: Patch Set 2:I wanted to use orange because it was previously used, and also because we're working with Impress (and not the whole Libre Office suite), so I think we should still use orange. However, if we think of it as an "extension of the whole suite", and not take into account that it works with Impress only, it should then be green. HOWEVER, if we plan to materialize the Viewer/Editor app, it would also have green color, and maybe we should distinct the two. Also, if we switch it to green, we'd need a new icon (I'm working on it, as soon as I get CorelDraw working on Linux). Also, consider that this (blue) accent doesn't have much contrast between green and it.P.S. should I abandon this change now? I will abandon it, and you "resurrect it" (lol) if you think that we need it, but I guess we basically moved all the useful changes to your commit.

text: Patch Set 1:Hi Pasqual, thanks for having a look.The BitmapRead/WriteAccess methods do assert in debug, but nonetheless then execute with out-of-bound values, esp. in product version this is often the cause of immediate crashes. I have seen/fixed quite some in that area. 'Reasonably sure' is not adequate for BitmapWriteAccess from my experience. If you are just reasonably sure, I would suggest to encapsulate with if(...) statements which guarantee the in-bound access.
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Pasqual, thanks for having a look.The BitmapRead/WriteAccess methods do assert in debug, but nonetheless then execute with out-of-bound values, esp. in product version this is often the cause of immediate crashes. I have seen/fixed quite some in that area. 'Reasonably sure' is not adequate for BitmapWriteAccess from my experience. If you are just reasonably sure, I would suggest to encapsulate with if(...) statements which guarantee the in-bound access.

Text: Patch Set 1:this needs further looking into. e.g.2428e1164b5f38da9fc2f24c5bb478e548f54a6fadded "|| ANDROID" back to some cases with a non-telling commit messge-if the adaptations were for the newly introduced HAVE_FEATURE_OPENGL, then why wasn't configure.ac adjusted instead of adding || ANDROID special cases? and was the || ANDROID really needed on thte HAVE_FEATURE_DESKTOP lines or was it just going overboard? text: Patch Set 1:Is this necessary after 2428e1164b5f38da9fc2f24c5bb478e548f54a6f?Christian, sorry about the brief commit message. I was a bit upset that the headless patch was merged even though the ESC asked the author not to merge it in its current form. The opengl situation on our Android port is a bit unclear. On one hand, we disable opengl in configure, OTOH it seems we build most of the opengl code in vcl. My commit just restored that status quo, fixing the build. I also verified that the build result actually works. :-)Given that at the end Android uses cairo to render the tiles, the opengl code is not useful on Android. However, probably it's a good idea to not work on removing it from the Android binary till it's not clear if those opengl #ifdefs will go away or not in the long run. (Currently we have those ifdefs, but it's possible they will be reverted, it's not clear yet.)
Text: Patch Set 1:Is this necessary after 2428e1164b5f38da9fc2f24c5bb478e548f54a6f?Christian, sorry about the brief commit message. I was a bit upset that the headless patch was merged even though the ESC asked the author not to merge it in its current form. The opengl situation on our Android port is a bit unclear. On one hand, we disable opengl in configure, OTOH it seems we build most of the opengl code in vcl. My commit just restored that status quo, fixing the build. I also verified that the build result actually works. :-)Given that at the end Android uses cairo to render the tiles, the opengl code is not useful on Android. However, probably it's a good idea to not work on removing it from the Android binary till it's not clear if those opengl #ifdefs will go away or not in the long run. (Currently we have those ifdefs, but it's possible they will be reverted, it's not clear yet.)

text: Patch Set 1:It seems to me that this patch is trying to do something else than what is meant in tdf#45789.Your code does something when saving the report definition. At the time of saving the report definition, it is not possible to know what data will go in there (only at report *execution* time), so I don't see how your code can do the right thing for tdf#45789, whose purpose is to set the row height to what is needed FOR THE DATA FILLED IN.Conceptually, the work is "simpler" as far as the report execution engine is concerned; it just needs to set the "this row needs to have automatic height" bit on the table row(s) in the odt output and *writer* will compute the correct row height. No need of computation of row heights in report builder.On the other hand, it requires some work in the Report Builder UI to add a user-settable property there in order to allow the user to choose whether the row should, or should not, have automatic height.
Text: Patch Set 1:It seems to me that this patch is trying to do something else than what is meant in tdf#45789.Your code does something when saving the report definition. At the time of saving the report definition, it is not possible to know what data will go in there (only at report *execution* time), so I don't see how your code can do the right thing for tdf#45789, whose purpose is to set the row height to what is needed FOR THE DATA FILLED IN.Conceptually, the work is "simpler" as far as the report execution engine is concerned; it just needs to set the "this row needs to have automatic height" bit on the table row(s) in the odt output and *writer* will compute the correct row height. No need of computation of row heights in report builder.On the other hand, it requires some work in the Report Builder UI to add a user-settable property there in order to allow the user to choose whether the row should, or should not, have automatic height.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1It isn't completely clear to me why (cf. <https://groups.google.com/a/isocpp.org/forum/#!topic/std-discussion/oyLCkCUKpfU> "Linkage of: namespace { extern "C" { void f() {} } }"), but compilers do require the "static" on functions in extern "C" { ... } blocks, even within unnamed namespaces.You can use compat::isInExternCContext (compilerplugins/clang/compat.hxx) to filter them out in your plugin.A naive grep showed that your various "tdf#97966 Drop 'static' keywords" changes drop it from such extern "C" functions at least in  cppu/source/uno/lbenv.cxx  pyuno/source/module/pyuno_module.cxx  sax/source/expatwrap/sax_expat.cxx  stoc/source/javavm/javavm.cxx  stoc/source/proxy_factory/proxyfac.cxx  toolkit/source/awt/vclxtoolkit.cxx(And you deliberately left in some such "static" that the current plugin would warn about in module sax, as dropping "static" there would lead to linker errors?)  But there may be more cases that my naive grep missed, so to be safe please redo all the changes with the updated plugin.

text: Patch Set 1:Just a small nit-pick, but it is good to get this right from the beginning: Commit messages should be in present tense, and as close to normal prose as possible. I.e. here, a much better commit message would be:tdf#97966: Remove 'static' keywordsNo need to put a number in the message even if you have several that do similar things; nothing says they will be accepted in the same order anyway, and even if several commits have the same  message, git log --stat will tell those curious what parts of the source code were affected.
Text: Patch Set 1:Just a small nit-pick, but it is good to get this right from the beginning: Commit messages should be in present tense, and as close to normal prose as possible. I.e. here, a much better commit message would be:tdf#97966: Remove 'static' keywordsNo need to put a number in the message even if you have several that do similar things; nothing says they will be accepted in the same order anyway, and even if several commits have the same  message, git log --stat will tell those curious what parts of the source code were affected.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2(2 comments)So I think you are still not really understanding what you are doing.The typenames are horrible. Why create typedefs when you are never using them. Const and non-const member functions are completely random and don't even conform to the ones that are available in std::vector.Please learn a bit more C++ before working on LibreOffice. This is normally a trivial easy hack and should be easy to solve if you have a decent understanding of C++. Having this decent knowledge is required for most if not all LibreOffice C++ tasks.

text: Patch Set 1:(1 comment)So this is going to be an ugly one.We are now hitting a limitation of the current test framework. Currently all our tests don't have access to the UI configuration as it breaks the tests. Now I don't remember why I went the way of pointing the ui path to the user profile but it still seems to be necessary. Back when I wrote that code there were however no UI files so it was still so that the whole UI should have worked. Now with the UI files this is no longer true and pointing the UI config path to a place that does not the UI files causes an exception and later a crash.I will need some time to get back into the details of the configuration management during the tests.
Text: Patch Set 1:(1 comment)So this is going to be an ugly one.We are now hitting a limitation of the current test framework. Currently all our tests don't have access to the UI configuration as it breaks the tests. Now I don't remember why I went the way of pointing the ui path to the user profile but it still seems to be necessary. Back when I wrote that code there were however no UI files so it was still so that the whole UI should have worked. Now with the UI files this is no longer true and pointing the UI config path to a place that does not the UI files causes an exception and later a crash.I will need some time to get back into the details of the configuration management during the tests.

Text: Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1(1 comment)Not directly affecting this change, as it is a problem even now: All accesses to m_pDocument (and possibly to other private vars too) must be locked. Otherwise we have a problem if the current document is destroyed/changed and there is still a task running in another thread.

text: Patch Set 3:OK, it looks like this change cannot be merged because the preceding commit has not been merged.And for some reason the preceding commit is not showing up in gerrit as  an independant change, so I can't review it easily.I would suggest that(a) you abandon this change(b) you rollup your two commits into one commit and push it to gerrit(c) you should use capitalised names like "True" and "False" for the constants - at the moment the build is failing on windows because TRUE and FALSE are defined to be 1 and 0 by some other header file.Ask on IRC if you need help with doing (b).I would do something like - start with a clean workspace- git apply 9fff09de2719bee84fce6872afe7016e955ee631- git apply 358f0a90668b4273424c2b8772e4d7ca4b04947a- .. make necessary changes...- git commit

text: Patch Set 4:sc/source/core/data/column.cxxLine 1134 => FixedLine 1140 => Fixedsc/source/core/data/column3.cxxLine 1595I would prefer to keep the modification for the following reasons. std::each is really slower than the code i propose. According to valgrind it saves a lot of events. I also made some profiling (summing the execution time of the call to this code for a full execution of SubTotal) on the two versions of the methods with the tests files i added (200 lines, 2000 then 20000) and i have the following results :200 lines std::each is 7,92% slower2000 lines std::each is 4,73% slower20000 lines std::each is 12,18% slowerCould you please give me more information on the problem it creates ? Is the StartListenersHandler declared the wrong way ? Line 2622 => FixedI reverted to the original code. You are right, the code is doing the same, and is not related to the formula performance.
Text: Patch Set 4:sc/source/core/data/column.cxxLine 1134 => FixedLine 1140 => Fixedsc/source/core/data/column3.cxxLine 1595I would prefer to keep the modification for the following reasons. std::each is really slower than the code i propose. According to valgrind it saves a lot of events. I also made some profiling (summing the execution time of the call to this code for a full execution of SubTotal) on the two versions of the methods with the tests files i added (200 lines, 2000 then 20000) and i have the following results :200 lines std::each is 7,92% slower2000 lines std::each is 4,73% slower20000 lines std::each is 12,18% slowerCould you please give me more information on the problem it creates ? Is the StartListenersHandler declared the wrong way ? Line 2622 => FixedI reverted to the original code. You are right, the code is doing the same, and is not related to the formula performance.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(14 comments)First, thanks for the overall performance improvement, the numbers you gave in your mail were quite promising.For my nitpicks see the inline comments ;-)I have one concern though, that we somewhere might miss to set the mbMayHaveFormula flag if there is a formula cell added to the column, which at the end would lead to wrong calculations. Can we somehow make sure that it *always* gets set if a formula cell is present?
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(14 comments)First, thanks for the overall performance improvement, the numbers you gave in your mail were quite promising.For my nitpicks see the inline comments ;-)I have one concern though, that we somewhere might miss to set the mbMayHaveFormula flag if there is a formula cell added to the column, which at the end would lead to wrong calculations. Can we somehow make sure that it *always* gets set if a formula cell is present?

text: Patch Set 5:I'm not sure how you get your numbers. Maybe you are not using a release build.In a release build using the 200 row test case the ScColumn::StartListeners method is responsible for about 7% of the whole calculation time. Nearly none of that is related to std::for_each and nearly everything is related to the expensive calls in that method.
Text: Patch Set 5:I'm not sure how you get your numbers. Maybe you are not using a release build.In a release build using the 200 row test case the ScColumn::StartListeners method is responsible for about 7% of the whole calculation time. Nearly none of that is related to std::for_each and nearly everything is related to the expensive calls in that method.

text: Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1@William:Reading now that the initial performance improvement numbers you gave (in your mail back then) were obtained with a dbgutil build, they were certainly misleading. I tend to believe that the actual improvement in a standard/release build would be much less and would not justify this change, and introducing a still possible risk that presence of a formula cell would go undetected and lead to wrong calculations is a no-go for me.
Text: Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1@William:Reading now that the initial performance improvement numbers you gave (in your mail back then) were obtained with a dbgutil build, they were certainly misleading. I tend to believe that the actual improvement in a standard/release build would be much less and would not justify this change, and introducing a still possible risk that presence of a formula cell would go undetected and lead to wrong calculations is a no-go for me.

text: Patch Set 5:@EikeI fully understand that if the gain is not sufficient, stability prevails. Honestly i am no longer sure if my builds were debug or not... The information i posted were misleading because i switched to debug when i created the performance unit test. I do not remember my september builds.I am currently running a performance test with today's version and release build (./autogen.sh --without-java --without-help --without-myspell-dicts) using the different test case i used, and my original test file. So far the execution ratio is about 1.43 with the 2,000 lines file and about 1,35 with the 5,000 lines file.The performance test with the original file will take hours... so i propose to wait until tomorrow, then i will post more results and tests case you need. So far i have processed about 17% and the current line ratio is about x2. It is a current value, not an average. Average on the first 17% is close to 1.45 but should raise.
Text: Patch Set 5:@EikeI fully understand that if the gain is not sufficient, stability prevails. Honestly i am no longer sure if my builds were debug or not... The information i posted were misleading because i switched to debug when i created the performance unit test. I do not remember my september builds.I am currently running a performance test with today's version and release build (./autogen.sh --without-java --without-help --without-myspell-dicts) using the different test case i used, and my original test file. So far the execution ratio is about 1.43 with the 2,000 lines file and about 1,35 with the 5,000 lines file.The performance test with the original file will take hours... so i propose to wait until tomorrow, then i will post more results and tests case you need. So far i have processed about 17% and the current line ratio is about x2. It is a current value, not an average. Average on the first 17% is close to 1.45 but should raise.

text: Patch Set 5:Hey William,so what I propose is that we take the performance tests that have been pushed already to master and start from a purely algorithmic perspective.I had a short discussion with Eike and Kohei and reading the patch and looking at the results of the performance test I feel that we can easily win much more by doing some algorithm improvements to the subtotal code.If you look at the current callgrind output we are basically inserting n rows and execute the same operations in the code for each inserted row. Most of these operations however are not necessary for n-1 iterations as the only valid update happens in the last iteration. Examples for that are starting and stopping listeners, updating references.Not all of these places are easy to refactor but I think all in all we can find an incremental approach moving to this goal. If you are interested in that let us move the discussion to the mailing list.The huge advantage of that approach is that the code will be simpler and more robust (the boolean flag is easy to forget in the future in some new code path) and will give the same speed up for columns with formula cells as well.
Text: Patch Set 5:Hey William,so what I propose is that we take the performance tests that have been pushed already to master and start from a purely algorithmic perspective.I had a short discussion with Eike and Kohei and reading the patch and looking at the results of the performance test I feel that we can easily win much more by doing some algorithm improvements to the subtotal code.If you look at the current callgrind output we are basically inserting n rows and execute the same operations in the code for each inserted row. Most of these operations however are not necessary for n-1 iterations as the only valid update happens in the last iteration. Examples for that are starting and stopping listeners, updating references.Not all of these places are easy to refactor but I think all in all we can find an incremental approach moving to this goal. If you are interested in that let us move the discussion to the mailing list.The huge advantage of that approach is that the code will be simpler and more robust (the boolean flag is easy to forget in the future in some new code path) and will give the same speed up for columns with formula cells as well.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1Patch is ok to me, but I do miss a test case. Whenever a patch has improving performance as goal, it should have a test case so we get notified if we later loose the performance gained.

text: Patch Set 4:BTW: my original problem is the mail merge dialog from "File => Print", which lets the user select a directory to generate the MM documents in. I was just looking for a way to fix my "local path => file URL" problem and accidentally stumbled over a lot of places with the identical code.And I don't know how many places would actually die with a non-file URL to begin with, so the current code may already be wrong, when it accepts any valid URL (me guesses a file URL with the wrong system notation is accepted and would also produce interesting results).

text: Patch Set 4:So looking at 1d1fd4d2b6ee1db407a8f16dee84900b4f0ff5b2's use of TryUrlFromSystemPathAsString in the SwMailMergeDlg InsertPathHdl (sw/source/ui/envelp/mailmrge.cxx).  The original content of m_pPathED/sPath is either known to be a URL (pModOpt->GetMailingPath(), aPathOpt.GetWorkPath(), xFP->getDirectory()), in which case it is unfortunate that that information was thrown away in the first place.  Or it is some text the user created in m_pPathED.  There is already code in SwMailMergeDlg::ExecQryShell to interpret m_pPathED as a URL, using URIHelper::SmartRel2Abs (so also handling relative paths).  I would stick to that code here, too.It is very rare for the smart-parsing INetURLObject ctor to create an instance with INetProtocol::NotValid, so the  if (INetProtocol::NotValid == aProtocol)in TryUrlFromSystemPathAsString will rarely hit, so when called with bFromURL=false, it will typically return an empty string.  I have no idea what 1d1fd4d2b6ee1db407a8f16dee84900b4f0ff5b2's use of TryUrlFromSystemPathAsString (with bFromURL=false) in SwDBManager::ExecuteFormLetter (sw/source/uibase/dbui/dbmgr.cxx) is supposed to do.Generally, regarding smart parsing, I would not worry too much about FSYS_DETECT being too liberal in accepting foreign filesystem notations---the input it would thus accept would hardly be anything a user could reasonably intend to be something meaningful that should be interpreted differently.  And if there should be any real problems there (but I'm not aware of any), we could probably replace that FSYS_* enumeration with code that just smart-parses the syntax of the given platform.  (A more useful addition to INetURLObject's smart-parsing functionality would likely be a static factory function that, unlike the smart-parsing INetURLObject ctor, does not require the caller to specify a "smart scheme."  That would also address the need of adding an INetProtocol::DEFAULT value.)

The original content of m_pPathED/sPath is either known to be a URL (pModOpt->GetMailingPath(), aPathOpt.GetWorkPath(), xFP->getDirectory()), in which case it is unfortunate that that information was thrown away in the first place. I have no idea what 1d1fd4d2b6ee1db407a8f16dee84900b4f0ff5b2's use of TryUrlFromSystemPathAsString (with bFromURL=false) in SwDBManager::ExecuteFormLetter (sw/source/uibase/dbui/dbmgr.cxx) is supposed to do.Generally, regarding smart parsing, I would not worry too much about FSYS_DETECT being too liberal in accepting foreign filesystem notations---the input it would thus accept would hardly be anything a user could reasonably intend to be something meaningful that should be interpreted differently.  And if there should be any real problems there (but I'm not aware of any), we could probably replace that FSYS_* enumeration with code that just smart-parses the syntax of the given platform. That would also address the need of adding an INetProtocol::DEFAULT value.)

text: Patch Set 3:Is this producing better results than using the existing INetURLObject "smart parsing" functionality?  (I suspect that many, if not all, of the places you identified are using their cumbersome ways out of ignorance of the existing functionality.)

text: Patch Set 6:Thanks for looking at the code and your patience :-)I actually changed the MM dialog to always return a valid URL, so all the hacks in dbmgr.cxx are gone, and a single line of INetURLObject::TryUrlFromSystemPathAsString sw/source/ui/envelp/mailmrge.cxx in 8c511dc1bc285c312c6d98c876a103915853ffc9 remains.My alternative solution is 58fb4ec04eee05de26f1ca3b580ec0d5e6fec1a2, which uses URIHelper::SmartRel2Abs, as you suggested, and gets rid of my use of  INetURLObject::TryUrlFromSystemPathAsString.And I've simplified the embarrassingly wrong code in INetURLObject::TryUrlFromSystemPathAsString - sig :-( > Generally, regarding smart parsing, I would not worry too much about FSYS_DETECT being too liberal in accepting foreign filesystem notations---the input it would thus accept would hardly be anything a user could reasonably intend to be something meaningful that should be interpreted differently.  And if there should be any real problems there (but I'm not aware of any), we could probably replace that FSYS_* enumeration with code that just smart-parses the syntax of the given platform.  (A more useful addition to INetURLObject's smart-parsing functionality would likely be a static factory function that, unlike the smart-parsing INetURLObject ctor, does not require the caller to specify a "smart scheme."  That would also address the need of adding an INetProtocol::DEFAULT value.)I just added the DEFAULT for convenience, as a some functions defaulted to Http.So what about all the duplicated code? Should this become an easy hack to inspect all the code pointers and convert it to more appropriate code, whatever that is?

text: Patch Set 6:> So what about all the duplicated code? Should this become an easy > hack to inspect all the code pointers and convert it to more > appropriate code, whatever that is?Yes, I think it's better to use the existing smart-parsing functionality of INetURLObject (or adapt it slightly if necessary), than to add yet another function to it.  INetURLObject is a mess with a long history, and it already has too much functionality to make it easy to pick the right function to call.  Let's not add to that. ;)

Should this become an easy > hack to inspect all the code pointers and convert it to more > appropriate code, whatever that is?Yes, I think it's better to use the existing smart-parsing functionality of INetURLObject (or adapt it slightly if necessary), than to add yet another function to it. text: Patch Set 1:I guess the underlying problem is rather a confusion what abs overload from the standard headers should be used (and libstdc++'s struggle with getting that right).  I suggest to #include <cstdlib> and use std::abs.
Text: Patch Set 1:I guess the underlying problem is rather a confusion what abs overload from the standard headers should be used (and libstdc++'s struggle with getting that right).  I suggest to #include <cstdlib> and use std::abs.

text: Patch Set 1:> it's not just my setup. try this code:Yeah, <https://gcc.gnu.org/ml/libstdc++/2016-02/msg00001.html> "Rationale for cmath's std::abs(short) -> double."  Though I don't understand why that issue happens to crop up for your (reportedly Fedora Rawhide) scenario now, when the original code appears to work for everybody else (incl. a recent trunk GCC 6 build of mine done last weak, incl. GCC 6's libstdc++, on Fedora 22).

text: Patch Set 1:When discussed? Yesterday, I got mail from Jan. Jan support me on this. What should I do in this situation?**************HiThanks a lot for the picture.I just had a discussion with a couple of other people. Please start working at the bug you asked about (45904), but there are a couple of BIG BUTs:- please save all the calc (sc) to last- please make your commit message "converted java test to python"- do NOT refer to the bug in the commit.Background for this, is that we have one person who feels strongly about C++, while the rest of us just want it converted....Your work is really apriciated, and fact is that it will not be done for C++.Looking forward to blog about your camp, keep up the motivation. Please tell the others, that we are all proud of your work.There is at the moment an efford ongoing to organize a formal hackathon (hackfest) in turkey. I will follow up on that in the weeks to come.Keep hacking and having fun.rgdsjan i.****************

text: Patch Set 1:> Background for this, is that we have one person who feels strongly > about C++, while the rest of us just want it converted....I can understand that Markus is annoyed by this message. Really, this is not the way we should work. If core maintainers have a strong opinion about something at least discuss things and don't message behind their back.Also I prefer C++ tests because they can be easier debugged and stepped through if something fails, though maybe I'm not as a hardliner as Markus on this ground and I would not oppose additional tests that use Python.What I would like to see is not blindly convert all already existing and running Java tests to Python, which except getting rid of more Java doesn't gain us much at the moment, but instead pick the ones that are commented out because they fail (if they fail because of some Java peculiarity). Those maybe could be implement in Python and made work, so we would benefit from additional tests. In particular the ones that are commented out in sc/qa/unoapi/sc_*.sce > It was discussed at FOSDEM (sunday evening).By whom?

text: Patch Set 1:> I can understand that Markus is annoyed by this message.I too can understand that. That is part of a private email I wrote to explain, why we did not want it "just" to happen, and the sentence is taken out of context. The context was that I explained we all want C++, but since there are no C++ developers working on this, an intermidiate step through python is not bad. > but instead pick > the ones that are commented out because they fail (if they fail > because of some Java peculiarity). Those maybe could be implement > in Python and made work, so we would benefit from additional tests. > In particular the ones that are commented out in sc/qa/unoapi/sc_*.sceGood suggestion, hereby passed on. > By whom?I was seriously in doubt, when asked if we could do python instead of C++. I did not agree with "instead", but could live with "until converted to C++". Being in doubt I asked Thorsten and Bj├Ârn for advice before replying. I asked Kadertarlan, to do all other tests first and wait with calc until last...giving a chance to discuss it more, but unfortunately the order was reversed.I have NO intention of doing anything secret or behind anybodys back, but I also do not see it as wrong if someone want to write Python tests and replace the java as long as it does not prevent other future developers from making a C++ version.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)1) This doesn't compile!2) Your code does something when saving the report definition. At the time of saving the report definition, it is not possible to know what data will go in there (only at report *execution* time), so I don't see how your code can do the right thing for tdf#45789, whose purpose is to set the row height to what is needed FOR THE DATA FILLED IN.Conceptually, the work is "simpler" as far as the report execution engine is concerned; it just needs to set the "this row needs to have automatic height" bit and *writer* will compute the correct row height. No need of computation of row heights in report builder.But it does need some work in the Report Builder UI to allow the user to choose whether the row should, or should not, be allowed to adjust automatic height.

text: Patch Set 1:Hi Katarina,i have made a other fix for that problem, can you look to https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/20971/I has set the patch to abandon, while i found the reason patch, but when this patch not right, then my other fix (20971) resolved the CRASH.
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Katarina,i have made a other fix for that problem, can you look to https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/20971/I has set the patch to abandon, while i found the reason patch, but when this patch not right, then my other fix (20971) resolved the CRASH.

text: Patch Set 1:> I has set the patch to abandon, while i found the reason patch, but > when this patch not right, then my other fix (20971) resolved the > CRASH.The other patch is a better approach, but you need to somehow untangle those messy parent-child window relationships further.As you can see in Window::ImplInit, mpBorderWindow is a parent of this window. Moreover, mpClientWindow member variable of mpBorderWindow points to this window too. So by doing mpBorderWindow.disposeAndClear(), we're effectively ending up calling dispose() on this window recursively. Or so it seems.Unfortunately, I've no immediate remedy or creative idea how to fix the issue once and for all, without causing regressions. Maybe have a look at Window::SetBorderStyle, that makes some attempt to break the window relationship in a way.
Text: Patch Set 1:> I has set the patch to abandon, while i found the reason patch, but > when this patch not right, then my other fix (20971) resolved the > CRASH.The other patch is a better approach, but you need to somehow untangle those messy parent-child window relationships further.As you can see in Window::ImplInit, mpBorderWindow is a parent of this window. Moreover, mpClientWindow member variable of mpBorderWindow points to this window too. So by doing mpBorderWindow.disposeAndClear(), we're effectively ending up calling dispose() on this window recursively. Or so it seems.Unfortunately, I've no immediate remedy or creative idea how to fix the issue once and for all, without causing regressions. Maybe have a look at Window::SetBorderStyle, that makes some attempt to break the window relationship in a way.

text: Patch Set 1:The patch from Caol├ín produce the crash, the reason is with this "m_pParent.clear()", then the refcounter=1 from the class SvxColorWindow_Impl, before the line "mpWindowImpl->mpBorderWindow.disposeAndClear()" and after there, the "this-pointer" is deleted, and then crash. I have not found where the mistake is happen, when the Floating change to Floating-Dialog in FloatingWindow::ImplEndPopupMode, but maybe is in this method the problem?I have no more ideas we could be solved the crash, but of my opinion we must solve the crash, crashes are very ugly.

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2(2 comments)The bug is the result of the functionality added incommit 138d29aa09417eba4d15ade4c9f4dab2620b6326"support fast MM printing in non-single-file mode only for CUPS"The point of this commit was to skip the expensive concat'ing of the ODT document and let the CUPS backend concat the multiple jobs from MM printing into a single job of multiple PS files.This has actually a lot of inherited problems, as all printing options, which effect multiple pages (reverse, n-up, empty pages) won't be applied to the overall document, but just the single jobs.This patch actually works, because it uses a merged document again, instead of a concat'ed print job of multiple documents, so it simply reverts to the functionality before the patch and is the same as commenting the line:// bCheckSingleFile_ = !psp::PrinterInfoManager::get().supportsBatchPrint();Actually it's even worse, because it manually splits the merged document into single page jobs again, which will be concated by the CUPS backend again.
Text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2(2 comments)The bug is the result of the functionality added incommit 138d29aa09417eba4d15ade4c9f4dab2620b6326"support fast MM printing in non-single-file mode only for CUPS"The point of this commit was to skip the expensive concat'ing of the ODT document and let the CUPS backend concat the multiple jobs from MM printing into a single job of multiple PS files.This has actually a lot of inherited problems, as all printing options, which effect multiple pages (reverse, n-up, empty pages) won't be applied to the overall document, but just the single jobs.This patch actually works, because it uses a merged document again, instead of a concat'ed print job of multiple documents, so it simply reverts to the functionality before the patch and is the same as commenting the line:// bCheckSingleFile_ = !psp::PrinterInfoManager::get().supportsBatchPrint();Actually it's even worse, because it manually splits the merged document into single page jobs again, which will be concated by the CUPS backend again.

I know it's hard to reduce copy'n'pasta code when the difference between the two methods is only in small details. But now when something needs to be changed in shared parts of the code, it has to be changed in two different places, that's a nightmare for maintenance.

text: Patch Set 1:Well, for me this is the desired result:1. A simple button (i.e. with ToolBoxItemBits::DROPDOWNONLY bits) should show the current color of the selected text/object.2. A split button (i.e. with ToolBoxItemBits::DROPDOWN bits) should initially show some common color, and later the last used one, for easy re-applying it on another text/object.3. All buttons of the same kind (simple vs split), and that are representing the same text attribute, should be synced, and show the same color, regardless whether they are on the toolbar or on the sidebar.This means that if we have .uno:Color on both the toolbar and the sidebar, and *both* are split buttons, they need to be synced - but with the last used color, not with the current one (i.e. if you move the cursor to a text with a different color, it shouldn't affect the button). That's why SvxColorToolBoxControl::StateChanged has the check for bSidebarType, so split buttons won't be updated with the current color, but keep the last used one. This bSidebarType is simply used for distinguish between simple and split buttons, allowing them to share the same code, it's just poorly named (because most of the buttons in the sidebar are simple buttons - except the ones from the text panel, and all the toolbar buttons are split ones).Now, this scenario of syncing split buttons is not yet implemented (and already reported in tdf#82438). The problem is that the last used color is stored inside PaletteManager, and we have separate instance of it for each visible button. This causes also that the last used color resets after closing and re-opening the toolbar (because SvxColorToolboxControl instances are destroyed together with the toolbar) - see tdf#61868, tdf#71413, tdf#72991, tdf#83789.One possible solution is to turn PaletteManager into a singleton, so we'll have only one instance, and could manage all visible buttons from there. That way we could also sync the "recent colors" palette between all visible pickers, and maybe also the currently chosen main palette. Right now each visible button has its own instance of all these settings. Even worse - right now each instance has its own list of all palettes and their colors, thus wasting resources. Such kind of things surely should be managed in a centralized way.
Text: Patch Set 1:Well, for me this is the desired result:1. A simple button (i.e. with ToolBoxItemBits::DROPDOWNONLY bits) should show the current color of the selected text/object.2. A split button (i.e. with ToolBoxItemBits::DROPDOWN bits) should initially show some common color, and later the last used one, for easy re-applying it on another text/object.3. All buttons of the same kind (simple vs split), and that are representing the same text attribute, should be synced, and show the same color, regardless whether they are on the toolbar or on the sidebar.This means that if we have .uno:Color on both the toolbar and the sidebar, and *both* are split buttons, they need to be synced - but with the last used color, not with the current one (i.e. if you move the cursor to a text with a different color, it shouldn't affect the button). That's why SvxColorToolBoxControl::StateChanged has the check for bSidebarType, so split buttons won't be updated with the current color, but keep the last used one. This bSidebarType is simply used for distinguish between simple and split buttons, allowing them to share the same code, it's just poorly named (because most of the buttons in the sidebar are simple buttons - except the ones from the text panel, and all the toolbar buttons are split ones).Now, this scenario of syncing split buttons is not yet implemented (and already reported in tdf#82438). The problem is that the last used color is stored inside PaletteManager, and we have separate instance of it for each visible button. This causes also that the last used color resets after closing and re-opening the toolbar (because SvxColorToolboxControl instances are destroyed together with the toolbar) - see tdf#61868, tdf#71413, tdf#72991, tdf#83789.One possible solution is to turn PaletteManager into a singleton, so we'll have only one instance, and could manage all visible buttons from there. That way we could also sync the "recent colors" palette between all visible pickers, and maybe also the currently chosen main palette. Right now each visible button has its own instance of all these settings. Even worse - right now each instance has its own list of all palettes and their colors, thus wasting resources. Such kind of things surely should be managed in a centralized way.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2I think probably we need to ask this patch to be abandoned, though it is good work and I'd like to acknowledge Bryan's efforts in doing it :-)It was pointed out to me the other day that ActiveX controls can still be used outside of IE. ActiveX, after all, is just a wrapper around COM. Unlike the NPAPI support which is removed entirely and only supports a few browsers, until all of COM is removed by Microsoft (very unlikely) we probably need to keep this.

Anyobjections to removing?i don't think that a LO browser plugin is a terribly good idea, so noobjection to removing that.AFAICT this would just be removing embedding LO into IE.however, isn't it the case that ActiveX components may not be used justfrom IE, but from any Win32 application?that sounds like a potentially more useful embedding use-case, similarto "officebean" and "LibreOfficeKit", but for developers that arefamiliar with Win32 APIs.(or would that be something else that also happens to be called"ActiveX" but is not actually implemented by LO's so_activex library?)

text: Patch Set 1:> Then maybe we should always enable the save button, even if no > modifications are done.In this case we should change the bits of this button dynamically to DROPDOWNONLY when the main command is disabled, otherwise the setting "Allow to save document..." from Tools->Options...->LibreOffice->General would have no visible effect.A note about implementation:Recently I unified several menu-based buttons to use the same class in framework/source/uielement/popuptoolbarcontroller.cxx, which can be controlled by a values from Controller.xcu. We can add additional value there to indicate buttons that should not be disabled. It can be separated by a semicolon, the same way I did in framework/source/uielement/subtoolbarcontroller.cxx.On the other hand, I'm not sure that such scheme is useful in other cases, so it might be better to simply derive from PopupMenuToolbarController a dedicated class for the save button.
Text: Patch Set 1:> Then maybe we should always enable the save button, even if no > modifications are done.In this case we should change the bits of this button dynamically to DROPDOWNONLY when the main command is disabled, otherwise the setting "Allow to save document..." from Tools->Options...->LibreOffice->General would have no visible effect.A note about implementation:Recently I unified several menu-based buttons to use the same class in framework/source/uielement/popuptoolbarcontroller.cxx, which can be controlled by a values from Controller.xcu. We can add additional value there to indicate buttons that should not be disabled. It can be separated by a semicolon, the same way I did in framework/source/uielement/subtoolbarcontroller.cxx.On the other hand, I'm not sure that such scheme is useful in other cases, so it might be better to simply derive from PopupMenuToolbarController a dedicated class for the save button.

text: Patch Set 1:> In this case we should change the bits of this button dynamically to DROPDOWNONLY when the main command is disabled, otherwise the setting "Allow to save document..." from Tools->Options...->LibreOffice->General would have no visible effect.Like the idea. Do you have time to prepare a patch? Would be good to have this before the freeze tonight.Note that we already have a toolbar controller for the save button (framework/source/uielementsaveasmenucontroller). It's just wrongly named.I would add the functionality there.
Text: Patch Set 1:> In this case we should change the bits of this button dynamically to DROPDOWNONLY when the main command is disabled, otherwise the setting "Allow to save document..." from Tools->Options...->LibreOffice->General would have no visible effect.Like the idea. Do you have time to prepare a patch? Would be good to have this before the freeze tonight.Note that we already have a toolbar controller for the save button (framework/source/uielementsaveasmenucontroller). It's just wrongly named.I would add the functionality there.

text: Patch Set 1:> Like the idea. Do you have time to prepare a patch? Would be good > to have this before the freeze tonight.I will try. Unfortunately my free time today is highly limited... > Note that we already have a toolbar controller for the save button > (framework/source/uielementsaveasmenucontroller).It's a *menu* controller, you can't use it on toolbar as-is. So what we're doing right now is to wrap it in a generic toolbar controller in popuptoolbarcontroller.cxx. This way it's possible to create toolbar buttons from *any* menu controller - so menus can be shared between menubar/toolbar.
Text: Patch Set 1:> Like the idea. Do you have time to prepare a patch? Would be good > to have this before the freeze tonight.I will try. Unfortunately my free time today is highly limited... > Note that we already have a toolbar controller for the save button > (framework/source/uielementsaveasmenucontroller).It's a *menu* controller, you can't use it on toolbar as-is. So what we're doing right now is to wrap it in a generic toolbar controller in popuptoolbarcontroller.cxx. This way it's possible to create toolbar buttons from *any* menu controller - so menus can be shared between menubar/toolbar.

text: Patch Set 2:> : error C2039: '_tstring' : is not a member of 'std' >  > You should not define functions in the reserved std namespace.no, the problem is that msiprop.hxx is included too early, it needs to be included after the #ifdef UNICODE #define _tstring ... block, and after #include <string>.this whole _tstring nonsense is obsolete anyway, we should always have UNICODE defined on Win32, since DOS-based Windowses are no longer supported.  see also https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=72606
Text: Patch Set 2:> : error C2039: '_tstring' : is not a member of 'std' >  > You should not define functions in the reserved std namespace.no, the problem is that msiprop.hxx is included too early, it needs to be included after the #ifdef UNICODE #define _tstring ... block, and after #include <string>.this whole _tstring nonsense is obsolete anyway, we should always have UNICODE defined on Win32, since DOS-based Windowses are no longer supported.  see also https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=72606

text: Patch Set 3:Using a test file with unescaped path:http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum un'altra copia.odtOpen it navigating the webdav server folders and opening it, the escaped path received by ucp.webdav content is:http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un%27altra%20copia.odtand this is the path used for the lock and to store it locally.When I try to save it, a PUT operation has instead a path ofhttp://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un'altra%20copia.odtFormed internally where the last fragment is formed with NeonUri::unescape(rURL),during the ucp.webdav internal procedure that lead to PUT.This leads to a collision with the former lock acquired withhttp://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un%27altra%20copia.odtAt the server they are the same, but the for the lock store they are not (NeonLockStore::findByUri usesneon functions to check that).Apparently if I open the file directly, without navigating the webdav folder structure the escaped path received by ucp.webdav content is instead:http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un'altra%20copia.odtthat doesn't cause problems.I needed a unique escape path representation at the DAVResourceAccess level.Probably the NeonUri::unescape(rURL) can be substitued by some other more correct unescape method.What's your suggestion?Adding method to NeonUri ? Or is there some helper function in LO that does a clean job?
Text: Patch Set 3:Using a test file with unescaped path:http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum un'altra copia.odtOpen it navigating the webdav server folders and opening it, the escaped path received by ucp.webdav content is:http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un%27altra%20copia.odtand this is the path used for the lock and to store it locally.When I try to save it, a PUT operation has instead a path ofhttp://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un'altra%20copia.odtFormed internally where the last fragment is formed with NeonUri::unescape(rURL),during the ucp.webdav internal procedure that lead to PUT.This leads to a collision with the former lock acquired withhttp://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un%27altra%20copia.odtAt the server they are the same, but the for the lock store they are not (NeonLockStore::findByUri usesneon functions to check that).Apparently if I open the file directly, without navigating the webdav folder structure the escaped path received by ucp.webdav content is instead:http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un'altra%20copia.odtthat doesn't cause problems.I needed a unique escape path representation at the DAVResourceAccess level.Probably the NeonUri::unescape(rURL) can be substitued by some other more correct unescape method.What's your suggestion?Adding method to NeonUri ? Or is there some helper function in LO that does a clean job?

text: Patch Set 5:(1 comment)"What's your suggestion? Adding method to NeonUri ? Or is there some helper function in LO that does a clean job?"The best solution is probably to use INetURLObject's inherent normalization here to get rid of variation in "harmless" escapes in URLs passed to the UCP; something like:  INetURLObject obj(aURL);  if (obj.HasError()) {    SAL_WARN("ucb.ucp.webdav", "bad URL <" << aURL << ">");    return aURL;  }  return obj.GetMainURL(INetURLObject::NO_DECODE);
Text: Patch Set 5:(1 comment)"What's your suggestion? Adding method to NeonUri ? Or is there some helper function in LO that does a clean job?"The best solution is probably to use INetURLObject's inherent normalization here to get rid of variation in "harmless" escapes in URLs passed to the UCP; something like:  INetURLObject obj(aURL);  if (obj.HasError()) {    SAL_WARN("ucb.ucp.webdav", "bad URL <" << aURL << ">");    return aURL;  }  return obj.GetMainURL(INetURLObject::NO_DECODE);

text: Patch Set 5:>  > INetURLObject obj(aURL); > if (obj.HasError()) { >     SAL_WARN("ucb.ucp.webdav", "bad URL <" << aURL << ">"); >     return aURL; > } > return obj.GetMainURL(INetURLObject::NO_DECODE);used something similar to normalize URL:    INetURLObject aInURLObj( aURL );    if ( aInURLObj.HasError() ) {        SAL_WARN( "ucb.ucp.webdav", "The URL <" << aURL << "> has errors!" );         return aURL;     }    OUString aDecodedURL( aInURLObj.GetMainURL( INetURLObject::DECODE_WITH_CHARSET ) );    INetURLObject aNormalizedURLObj( aDecodedURL );     return aNormalizedURLObj.GetMainURL( INetURLObject::NO_DECODE );but then I ran into another problem: regression to a old OOo issue: ooo#81690, solved here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/ucb/source/ucp/inc/urihelper.hxx#70I decided to solve the problem another way: normalize the URL used internally in LO to store and check the lock held, with a chunk of code similar to the above.Testing it now, looks promising.I'll let you know..
Text: Patch Set 5:>  > INetURLObject obj(aURL); > if (obj.HasError()) { >     SAL_WARN("ucb.ucp.webdav", "bad URL <" << aURL << ">"); >     return aURL; > } > return obj.GetMainURL(INetURLObject::NO_DECODE);used something similar to normalize URL:    INetURLObject aInURLObj( aURL );    if ( aInURLObj.HasError() ) {        SAL_WARN( "ucb.ucp.webdav", "The URL <" << aURL << "> has errors!" );         return aURL;     }    OUString aDecodedURL( aInURLObj.GetMainURL( INetURLObject::DECODE_WITH_CHARSET ) );    INetURLObject aNormalizedURLObj( aDecodedURL );     return aNormalizedURLObj.GetMainURL( INetURLObject::NO_DECODE );but then I ran into another problem: regression to a old OOo issue: ooo#81690, solved here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/ucb/source/ucp/inc/urihelper.hxx#70I decided to solve the problem another way: normalize the URL used internally in LO to store and check the lock held, with a chunk of code similar to the above.Testing it now, looks promising.I'll let you know..

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Basically not a bad approach, but it should be done more modular, e.g. create a primitive class hich has gradient stops and decomposes to the already existing FillGradientPrimitive2D, so nothing has to change there (safe) and the new classes will extend the functionality in the sende of primitives (as intended). This would also avoid the from my POV unacceptable double definition of StartColor/EndColor.In general it can be done to extend all 'classic' gradients to gradient stops (modular), but is questionable - evtl. implementing the SVG gradient definitions and using these if needed would be superiour. This can also be done using primitives and a decomposition, so all renderers would be capable of crunching these.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Basically not a bad approach, but it should be done more modular, e.g. create a primitive class hich has gradient stops and decomposes to the already existing FillGradientPrimitive2D, so nothing has to change there (safe) and the new classes will extend the functionality in the sende of primitives (as intended). This would also avoid the from my POV unacceptable double definition of StartColor/EndColor.In general it can be done to extend all 'classic' gradients to gradient stops (modular), but is questionable - evtl. implementing the SVG gradient definitions and using these if needed would be superiour. This can also be done using primitives and a decomposition, so all renderers would be capable of crunching these.

text: Patch Set 1:(1 comment)"otherwise assertion failure occurs on data write":  You mean the  assert(pBuf && "Possibly Reallocate failed");in SvMemoryStream::PutData (tools/source/stream/stream.cxx) (which was changed form a DBG_ASSERT to an assert in 5ace3f3b4f2f916d8b2acab1b5cc0fe2a5a19dee)?Do you know a scenario where a TempFile::GetStream creates such an SvMemoryStream with eMode containing WRITE bit?  It is unclear to me whether the intent is to have a growable stream to write into in that case, or rather an effectively immutable zero-length stream for which writing will fail with SVSTREAM_OUTOFMEMORY (and in which case the assert would need fixing).In either case, if eMode does not contain WRITE bit in call to TempFile::GetStream, it is probably fine to still return a  new SvMemoryStream( NULL, 0, eMode );
Text: Patch Set 1:(1 comment)"otherwise assertion failure occurs on data write":  You mean the  assert(pBuf && "Possibly Reallocate failed");in SvMemoryStream::PutData (tools/source/stream/stream.cxx) (which was changed form a DBG_ASSERT to an assert in 5ace3f3b4f2f916d8b2acab1b5cc0fe2a5a19dee)?Do you know a scenario where a TempFile::GetStream creates such an SvMemoryStream with eMode containing WRITE bit?  It is unclear to me whether the intent is to have a growable stream to write into in that case, or rather an effectively immutable zero-length stream for which writing will fail with SVSTREAM_OUTOFMEMORY (and in which case the assert would need fixing).In either case, if eMode does not contain WRITE bit in call to TempFile::GetStream, it is probably fine to still return a  new SvMemoryStream( NULL, 0, eMode );
