text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1It is still confusing, what the purpose of this changes is. In the current linear gradient implementation a gradient exists independent of a shape. Therefore "diagonal" makes no sense. To get the same behavior as the gradient in MS, where a "45┬░" linear gradient is indeed diagonal for every rectangle, a new kind of gradient is needed. This can be the svg:linearGradient as used in ODF1.2. That would not need any private attribute.If this is only about a restriction in the UI, I think it should be discussed with the design-group. If the UI gives similar buttons as MS, this will arouse expectations, which currently cannot be hold.

This can be the svg:linearGradient as used in ODF1.2. That would not need any private attribute.If this is only about a restriction in the UI, I think it should be discussed with the design-group. If the UI gives similar buttons as MS, this will arouse expectations, which currently cannot be hold.

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1OK - I've read the patch more carefully now...The comment "/// XStatusListener" is totally misleading.  Normally it means that the method implements XStatusListener UNO service, which scared me a lot, one has to be very careful introducing this :-) Having read it more carefully, it is not the case here luckily.Generally, please do not mix style changes with functional changes in the patches like this, then it looks like a much more complex change than it really is :-)  Of course it is OK to change the style of the actual lines you are touching, but when you do that for lines around too, it just makes the patch less readable.Also it is good to add comments to the places you are fixing / implementing - at least one line summary of purpose of a class is much appreciated.So I'd suggest the following: Split to more patches, where1) 1st patch turns ButtonStatusListener into VclStatusListener template liketemplate <class T> VclStatusListenerthat gets the widget as the template parameter, and calls its statusChanged() method.  In the toolbar code, the instantiation would look like mpStatusListener  = new WindowStatusListener<ToolBox>(this, ".uno:ImageOrientation");2) 2nd that actually implements the functionality for the toolbar.3) [optionally] some style clenaup arnoud, but better to avoid doing much of that.Also - is this all that was necessary to be done to fix the problem in the sidebar, or is an additional patch anticipated?Thank you for your work on this! :-) - and sorry about my initial reaction, the stylistic changes + the wrong comment triggered a warning light in my mind ;-)
Text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1OK - I've read the patch more carefully now...The comment "/// XStatusListener" is totally misleading.  Normally it means that the method implements XStatusListener UNO service, which scared me a lot, one has to be very careful introducing this :-) Having read it more carefully, it is not the case here luckily.Generally, please do not mix style changes with functional changes in the patches like this, then it looks like a much more complex change than it really is :-)  Of course it is OK to change the style of the actual lines you are touching, but when you do that for lines around too, it just makes the patch less readable.Also it is good to add comments to the places you are fixing / implementing - at least one line summary of purpose of a class is much appreciated.So I'd suggest the following: Split to more patches, where1) 1st patch turns ButtonStatusListener into VclStatusListener template liketemplate <class T> VclStatusListenerthat gets the widget as the template parameter, and calls its statusChanged() method.  In the toolbar code, the instantiation would look like mpStatusListener  = new WindowStatusListener<ToolBox>(this, ".uno:ImageOrientation");2) 2nd that actually implements the functionality for the toolbar.3) [optionally] some style clenaup arnoud, but better to avoid doing much of that.Also - is this all that was necessary to be done to fix the problem in the sidebar, or is an additional patch anticipated?Thank you for your work on this! :-) - and sorry about my initial reaction, the stylistic changes + the wrong comment triggered a warning light in my mind ;-)

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1(1 comment)I just marked an obvious bug, which I found while trying to grasp the patch and before I gave up.I'll just add some obvious stuff for you to fix in preparation for the real review of your patchset.1. Please remove all the "unneeded" whitespace changes in the filesTo give you an impression I applied your patch and diff'ed it with different options:$ git diff --stat sw sw/inc/dbmgr.hxx                |  136 ÔÇª sw/source/uibase/dbui/dbmgr.cxx | 1727 ÔÇª 2 files changed, 1156 insertions(+), 707 deletions(-)$ git diff -B -b -w --stat sw sw/inc/dbmgr.hxx                |   98 ÔÇª sw/source/uibase/dbui/dbmgr.cxx | 1319 ÔÇª 2 files changed, 933 insertions(+), 484 deletions(-)or 118079 vs 82753 byte - hmm1.1 Space in actual linesLike-uno::Reference< sdbcx::XColumnsSupplier > xColsSupp( pParam->xResultSet, uno::UNO_QUERY );+uno::Reference<sdbcx::XColumnsSupplier > xColsSupp( pParam->xResultSet, uno::UNO_QUERY );or even -// calls from the calculator may add a connection with an invalid commandtype+// calls from the calculator may add a connection with an invalid command typeIf you think these are worthwhile, move them into an extra patch or include them in other spitted patches.1.2. Please remove all "multiple-empty rows chunks"You added multiple empty lines, where one would be sufficient. This happens in functions and between them.2. Please split the refactoring into multiple patchesThe ToNextRecord is the most obvious one but there is more.The whole refactoring is basically not reviewable, as it's too much in a single patch.There is a reason why Gerrit marks this patches size as red.3. Actually set a meaningful subjectProbably start the whole series with "MM: Refactor ToNextRecord"The refactoring actually has no reference to the bug and is independent, so you don't need the bug-id prefix.4. Think about inline'ing the small functionsThere are GetRowSupplier and GetColumnSupplier, which are just called once and just contain two lines of code.5. Introduce a mail merge state struct to reduce function arguments and stack sizeI literally needed to gasp for air when I saw:+void SwDBManager::MergeSingleFiles(SwDoc *pWorkDoc, SwWrtShell &rWorkShell, SwWrtShell *pTargetShell, SwDoc *pTargetDoc,+                                   SfxObjectShellLock &xWorkDocSh, SfxObjectShellRef xTargetDocShell,+                                   bool bPageStylesWithHeaderFooter, bool bSynchronizedDoc,+                                   OUString &sModifiedStartingPageDesc, OUString &sStartingPageDesc, sal_Int32 nDocNo,+                                   long nStartRow, sal_uInt16 nStartingPageNo, int &targetDocPageCount, const bool bMergeShell,+                                   const SwMergeDescriptor& rMergeDescriptor, sal_Int32 nMaxDumpDocs)This is ridiculousÔÇªAs Katarina already suggested, create a mail merge status structure, i.e. name it SwMergeState (and have a look at SwMergeDescriptor), and pass it around. Probably it would make sense to add the SwMergeDescriptor as a const member to the new mail merge state type.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Although these bugs are fixed, I find that I don't totally understand how outline is designed in OOXML, and not sure if the assumption that there is only one numbering rule for outline is valid. On the other hand, current assumption that outline is defined by its name "Heading 1" .. "Heading 9" is really wrong, not to mention exporting filter generate names that varies with UI setting. I'm not so sure whether I'm doing it right. I want to solicit comment or suggesting for this.

text: Patch Set 8:> Can you please try if it is possible to normalize the url's before > calling the neon API instead?I already tried in this proposed change:https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/18147/But I did poorly, as Stephan pointed out there.This is a description of the original cause, mainly from c/18147/Using a test file having an unescaped path of:<http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum un'altra copia.odt>Navigating the webdav server folders using the LO native filepicker and opening the file, the already escaped path received by ucb.ucp.webdav.content is:<http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un%27altra%20copia.odt>and this is the path used for the lock method and to store it locally (in neon managed lockstore).When I try to save it, a PUT operation has instead a path of<http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un'altra%20copia.odt>Formed internally where the last segment (the file name) is formed with NeonUri::unescape(rURL),during the ucp.webdav internal procedure that lead to PUT.This leads to a collision with the former lock acquired with<http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un%27altra%20copia.odt>At the server end they are the same, but the for the lock store they are not (NeonLockStore::findByUri usesneon functions to check that).Apparently if I open the file directly, without navigating the webdav folder structure the escaped path received by ucb.ucp.webdav.content is instead:<http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un'altra%20copia.odt>that doesn't cause problems.IMHO a unique way of escaping the path should be provided by the clients of ucb.ucp.webdav.I discovedered thet at the ucb.ucp.webdav level is a bad idea to unescape a path and then escape it again, simply because the client application (e.g. framework) should have escaped it according to some rule ucb doesn't know anythinf about.I'll investigate the problem further, though.Starting from LO native file picker, I wonder why the path is not encoded in a unique way.
Text: Patch Set 8:> Can you please try if it is possible to normalize the url's before > calling the neon API instead?I already tried in this proposed change:https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/18147/But I did poorly, as Stephan pointed out there.This is a description of the original cause, mainly from c/18147/Using a test file having an unescaped path of:<http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum un'altra copia.odt>Navigating the webdav server folders using the LO native filepicker and opening the file, the already escaped path received by ucb.ucp.webdav.content is:<http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un%27altra%20copia.odt>and this is the path used for the lock method and to store it locally (in neon managed lockstore).When I try to save it, a PUT operation has instead a path of<http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un'altra%20copia.odt>Formed internally where the last segment (the file name) is formed with NeonUri::unescape(rURL),during the ucp.webdav internal procedure that lead to PUT.This leads to a collision with the former lock acquired with<http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un%27altra%20copia.odt>At the server end they are the same, but the for the lock store they are not (NeonLockStore::findByUri usesneon functions to check that).Apparently if I open the file directly, without navigating the webdav folder structure the escaped path received by ucb.ucp.webdav.content is instead:<http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un'altra%20copia.odt>that doesn't cause problems.IMHO a unique way of escaping the path should be framework) should have escaped it according to some rule ucb doesn't know anythinf about.I'll investigate the problem further, though.Starting from LO native file picker, I wonder why the path is not encoded in a unique way.

text: AbandonedAfter some check of the native file picker operation, I discovered the reason for the behaviour I observed depends from the WebDAV server in use.It seems that some among them don't implement correctly the escaping of the collection property, e.g. the file name.For the time being I'll abandon this change.A simple work-around can be used to open the file: use the full unescaped file path directly with the full path in the native filepicker dialog box.
Text: AbandonedAfter some check of the native file picker operation, I discovered the reason for the behaviour I observed depends from the WebDAV server in use.It seems that some among them don't implement correctly the escaping of the collection property, e.g. the file name.For the time being I'll abandon this change.A simple work-around can be used to open the file: use the full unescaped file path directly with the full path in the native filepicker dialog box.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2Was this change unintentionally uploaded? You previous change, has compile errors, check the link from our Continuous Integration (CI) server: [1]. Every single commit must be sane: it must compile and all tests should succeed.Instead of trying to fix you previous change by creating new commits, and uploading new gerrit changes, you should amend your original commit, and abandon this change.To amend your previous commit, just use `git commit --amend` and make sure to preserve the original Change-Id in the commit message. When you upload new version of your commit to gerrit, by issuing `git push HEAD:refs/for/master` command, gerrit would create new patch set for the same change and not create a new change.* [1] http://ci.libreoffice.org/job/lo_gerrit_master/5712/Gerrit=Gerrit,Platform=Linux/console

text: Patch Set 1:Do you have any source that says this is a good thing to do? Static local variables add extra code, as the initialization must happen exactly once, when the definition is encountered for the first time. And the variables must be deinitialized in reverse order.
Text: Patch Set 1:Do you have any source that says this is a good thing to do? Static local variables add extra code, as the initialization must happen exactly once, when the definition is encountered for the first time. And the variables must be deinitialized in reverse order.

text: Patch Set 1:TThank you for your points.My intention was as follows: a static local constant is constructed only once, and only when the execution enters its scope; so it may be possible to reduce the overhead if either its function is not called at all or is called many times.But I finally understand our compilers are smart enough not to allocate any storage of integer/float constants (with e.g. g++'s -O1 or bigger). So let's abandon this patch.
Text: Patch Set 1:TThank you for your points.My intention was as follows: a static local constant is constructed only once, and only when the execution enters its scope; so it may be possible to reduce the overhead if either its function is not called at all or is called many times.But I finally understand our compilers are smart enough not to allocate any storage of integer/float constants (with e.g. g++'s -O1 or bigger). So let's abandon this patch.

text: Patch Set 15: Code-Review-2These four have deliberately been left out of compbase.hxx and implbase.hxx:For one, ImplHelper should unlikely ever be a better choice than WeakImplHelper, so all its existing uses are probably confused and should use WeakImplHelper instead.For another, aggregation (involving WeakAggImplHelper, AggImplInheritanceHelper, and WeakAggComponentHelper) is known broken in general and should not be used.  (There are some existing uses that are hard to replace with better code, though.)
Text: Patch Set 15: Code-Review-2These four have deliberately been left out of compbase.hxx and implbase.hxx:For one, ImplHelper should unlikely ever be a better choice than WeakImplHelper, so all its existing uses are probably confused and should use WeakImplHelper instead.For another, aggregation (involving WeakAggImplHelper, AggImplInheritanceHelper, and WeakAggComponentHelper) is known broken in general and should not be used.  (There are some existing uses that are hard to replace with better code, though.)

I haven't figured out what is causing the INVALID CONTENT event to be placed on the stack.Based on the way the data is laid out, it appears that nothing is different between page 1 and page 2 that would trigger the event in one case and not the other.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2Anyway, this patch does *not* make sense in general, for other languages. One of the several bugs open against the transition list UI explains it well. Even if in English, sorting the list keeps related transitions sequential (like Uncover Down, Uncover Left, Uncover Right), that might not be true for other languages, so a simple sort would make the list even less usable. text: Patch Set 1:The reason why 8 doesn't seem to be enough is that just in Writer internally (see the RES_MSG enum in sw/inc/hintids.hxx) we have 39 signals, and that does not include shared code, Calc and Draw/Impress. So I would like to keep the possibility to add from these to the widget as/when necessary, without breaking ABI.If we limit the number of new possibilities to 8, the last signal will be a "something happened" one, and we'll stuff everything else into that -- sounds like a bad outcome.Maybe let's wait with this till there is a user for which not having the function pointers is really a hard problem.
Text: Patch Set 1:The reason why 8 doesn't seem to be enough is that just in Writer internally (see the RES_MSG enum in sw/inc/hintids.hxx) we have 39 signals, and that does not include shared code, Calc and Draw/Impress. So I would like to keep the possibility to add from these to the widget as/when necessary, without breaking ABI.If we limit the number of new possibilities to 8, the last signal will be a "something happened" one, and we'll stuff everything else into that -- sounds like a bad outcome.Maybe let's wait with this till there is a user for which not having the function pointers is really a hard problem.

text: Patch Set 1:> Do we really want to save the mixed behavior to configuration > without the possibility to say "this document only" which we have > in master?Hm, if the user wants to have it like that ? I thought (and you more-less confirmed that) for this code path to be actually taken, the user has to go to the relevant Tools > Options dialog and save the config ... It then feels somehow inconsistent that the other 4 options (same as formula syntax, CalcA1, ExcelA1, ExcelR1C1) can be saved as a global value and this one can't. But I don't feel strongly either way. It was mostly LHM guys who wanted this.

It was mostly LHM guys who wanted this.For the "we have many mixed mode documents" case, understood.Do they actually plan to switch to 5.0.x at some point?I'm also quite unbiased on this, so if we want it in we can.

They've lots of legacy documents where mixed mode is an useful thing to have.However I'm abandoning this one (we can always resurrect it, if needed), as it is totally unclear if "this document only" switch is going to stay in master or if it will be replaced with something else as LHM is not very happy with it anymore.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1This patch obviously does not what is mentioned in the commit message.The second question is what is the use-case of adding the line to a test declaration. I understand the advantage of having a line in an assert macro as there might be several in one test case but for the the CPPUNIT_TEST_FAIL this would mean that you just get a pointer to the declaration. You get the sme with a quick git grep or even opening the source file and looking at the declaration of the tests.It would be the same as printing the source line of the test declaration in a CPPUNIT_TEST macro instead of the source line of the assert that failed.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1This patch obviously does not what is mentioned in the commit message.The second question is what is the use-case of adding the line to a test declaration. I understand the advantage of having a line in an assert macro as there might be several in one test case but for the the CPPUNIT_TEST_FAIL this would mean that you just get a pointer to the declaration. You get the sme with a quick git grep or even opening the source file and looking at the declaration of the tests.It would be the same as printing the source line of the test declaration in a CPPUNIT_TEST macro instead of the source line of the assert that failed.

text: Patch Set 1:> This patch obviously does not what is mentioned in the commit message.Well it adds the source position of the test declaration.I don't understand why you think the commit message is wrong?> The second question is what is the use-case of adding the line to a> test declaration. I understand the advantage of having a line in an> assert macro as there might be several in one test case but for> the CPPUNIT_TEST_FAIL this would mean that you just get a pointer to> the declaration. You get the same with a quick git grep or even> opening the source file and looking at the declaration of the tests.Since the test fails, if it passes, there is nothing else to point to, except for the declaration, where the test is declared as "fail if pass".For CPPUNIT_TEST you can obviously point to the failling assertion, which isn't possible in the non-failing fail case.I'm not going to fight for it. I'm myself not sure, if it makes much sense, as it probably would make more sense to point to the implementation, but that's impossible.

text: Patch Set 1:The msbuild tasks are already running in parallel with other stuff (at least in ideal case). So this could actually degrade performance, as in the worst case, msbuild would spawn N processes alongside N-1 processes already run by make. And it would be even worse if more of the msbuild tasks were running in parallel...
Text: Patch Set 1:The msbuild tasks are already running in parallel with other stuff (at least in ideal case). And it would be even worse if more of the msbuild tasks were running in parallel...

And it would be even > worse if more of the msbuild tasks were running in parallel...Yes, that's a possible worst-case scenario. But from observation, I noticed that cpu utilization is low during external project builds and peaks during the LO code build.Is it possible to get more accurate numbers from the build machines with this enabled (and compare to when it wasn't) ?

text: Patch Set 1:IMHO a much better way to improve CPU utilization, without overcommitting, would be to relax the dependencies on external projects a bit. A dependency of a library on external project is typically added by calling gb_LinkTarget_use_external_project; the current impl. delays building of any source file of the library until the external project is done, which is not necessary unless the external project generates a (public) header during build. This could be changed to depend only on the unpacked tarball and only the link target itself on the external project, possibly with a second argument forcing all to depend on the full external project (I do not know if this would be actually needed. A test build would show.)
Text: Patch Set 1:IMHO a much better way to improve CPU utilization, without overcommitting, would be to relax the dependencies on external projects a bit. A dependency of a library on external project is typically added by calling gb_LinkTarget_use_external_project; the current impl. delays building of any source file of the library until the external project is done, which is not necessary unless the external project generates a (public) header during build. This could be changed to depend only on the unpacked tarball and only the link target itself on the external project, possibly with a second argument forcing all to depend on the full external project (I do not know if this would be actually needed. A test build would show.)

text: Patch Set 2:Thinking a bit about it I'm not sure if that works without problems.Some cases that seem like they are causing issues (beside the undo handling):* protected cell ranges* array formulas* formulas in general (here you'd be able to argue that it is not an issue)* edit engine cellsSo I think there are a few more issues with that code than is obvious in the beginning. At least the array formula and the protected cell problem are serious problems that need to be handled before that patch can be merged. Also I'd like to see the undo being handled correctly.
Text: Patch Set 2:Thinking a bit about it I'm not sure if that works without problems.Some cases that seem like they are causing issues (beside the undo handling):* protected cell ranges* array formulas* formulas in general (here you'd be able to argue that it is not an issue)* edit engine cellsSo I think there are a few more issues with that code than is obvious in the beginning. At least the array formula and the protected cell problem are serious problems that need to be handled before that patch can be merged. Also I'd like to see the undo being handled correctly.

text: Patch Set 2:Hi Markus,I updated my test spreadsheet to include your extra tests conditions.  It seems like EnterData() already handles the items you were concerned about.protected cell ranges:  "Protected cells cannot be modified" pops up when it tries to change the protected cell.  It continues and finishes the whole range, skipping only the protected cells.array formulas: "You cannot change only part of an array".edit engine cells:  not sure what you are referring to here.  If you mean that the cursor is in a single cell (or in the top view), then this Execute() function doesn't seem to be called in that circumstance. Did you notice that I updated the code to treat everything as a single Undo?  I copied the code I found in cells1.cxx.  Is there still more that you think needs to be done?  I used the string "multiple.operations" since it seems to fit well.  This function is obscure enough that it does not warrant a translation requirement for a string something like undo "Unicode Notation Toggle".
Text: Patch Set 2:Hi Markus,I updated my test spreadsheet to include your extra tests conditions.  It seems like EnterData() already handles the items you were concerned about.protected cell ranges:  "Protected cells cannot be modified" pops up when it tries to change the protected cell.  It continues and finishes the whole range, skipping only the protected cells.array formulas: "You cannot change only part of an array".edit engine cells:  not sure what you are referring to here.  If you mean that the cursor is in a single cell (or in the top view), then this Execute() function doesn't seem to be called in that circumstance. Did you notice that I updated the code to treat everything as a single Undo?  I copied the code I found in cells1.cxx.  Is there still more that you think needs to be done?  I used the string "multiple.operations" since it seems to fit well.  This function is obscure enough that it does not warrant a translation requirement for a string something like undo "Unicode Notation Toggle".

text: Patch Set 4:I don't agree. All the conditions should be handled in this method. Relying on the EnterData checks is a bad idea as we might want to replace EnterData later with direct calls into ScDocument if the indirection proves to be a performance problem (quite likely).

text: Patch Set 2:So this patch set completely removes oosplash, which apparently does some other things besides the splash screen, and calling soffice.bin directly isn't supported today. At most (using a stopwatch) we're talking about 1 second improvement.  This testing was done using --nologo, so code change cleanup isn't counted in that. (out of approx 8 second startup time.  Firefox is around 10 seconds btw) >*before* we even think about removing any splash screens we should remove that horrible quick-starter thing.Why?

text: Patch Set 2:> Wherever the code stored an iterator in an object field, I did not convert it> from list to vector.> And wherever it stored the end() iterator in a local variable, I made it> compare against .end() directly.> I think that covers the differences in semantics.I don't think so. The iterator validity difference between list andvector is, that deleting a list element only invalidates iteratorspointing to that element and no other iterators, whereas in a vector alliterators are invalidated whenever memory is (automatically or perreserve()) reallocated, or during insertion and deletion all iteratorspointing behind the insertion or deletion point.So actually you have to check also if iterators are remembered, forexample during a loop, and inspect deletion and insertion operationswhile these are held, or calls to reserve().
Text: Patch Set 2:> Wherever the code stored an iterator in an object field, I did not convert it> from list to vector.> And wherever it stored the end() iterator in a local variable, I made it> compare against .end() directly.> I think that covers the differences in semantics.I don't think so. The iterator validity difference between list andvector is, that deleting a list element only invalidates iteratorspointing to that element and no other iterators, whereas in a vector alliterators are invalidated whenever memory is (automatically or perreserve()) reallocated, or during insertion and deletion all iteratorspointing behind the insertion or deletion point.So actually you have to check also if iterators are remembered, forexample during a loop, and inspect deletion and insertion operationswhile these are held, or calls to reserve().

text: Patch Set 1:> are you sure that none of those uses of std::list rely on e.g. the semantics regarding iterator invalidation, which are different from those of std::vector?Wherever the code stored an iterator in an object field, I did not convert it from list to vector.And wherever it stored the end() iterator in a local variable, I made it compare against .end() directly.I think that covers the differences in semantics.
Text: Patch Set 1:> are you sure that none of those uses of std::list rely on e.g. the semantics regarding iterator invalidation, which are different from those of std::vector?Wherever the code stored an iterator in an object field, I did not convert it from list to vector.And wherever it stored the end() iterator in a local variable, I made it compare against .end() directly.I think that covers the differences in semantics.

Text: Patch Set 1:I'm unhappy about the default constructor which does not represent a OpenGL resource.I understand that it is necessary to implement the change which is why I'm not happy with the general change.Additionally I think you should still use a mp prefix as the object is still a (smart) pointer.

text: Patch Set 1:(1 comment)So, the class behaves exactly as it is supposed to. It is a wrapper around the OpenGL texture resource.As mentioned it is meant to be a non-copyable wrapper around the OpenGL texture. In general the better approach that would make more sense is to find a way to get rid of the constructor with the empty parameters for OpenGLTexture. That would remove the need for this patch.In it's current form this patch will cause crashes left and right as we are going to double delete the underlying OpenGL resource.

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2OK, I think I found the actual issue here. Our OpenSymbol font has the wrong (swapped) glyphs for U+03C6 and U+03D5. This change was introduced in https://bz.apache.org/ooo/show_bug.cgi?id=105084 (see the attached document there). Given this is a relatively recent change (relative to the age of star office), I think the proper fix here is to swap the glyphs again  (and for the epsilon and varepsilon as well, because the change is wrong for the same reason) and keep using symbol names that are compatible with the rest of the math world.
Text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2OK, I think I found the actual issue here. Our OpenSymbol font has the wrong (swapped) glyphs for U+03C6 and U+03D5. This change was introduced in https://bz.apache.org/ooo/show_bug.cgi?id=105084 (see the attached document there). Given this is a relatively recent change (relative to the age of star office), I think the proper fix here is to swap the glyphs again  (and for the epsilon and varepsilon as well, because the change is wrong for the same reason) and keep using symbol names that are compatible with the rest of the math world.

text: Patch Set 2:OK, here is what I found:Loading .pro.user files doesn't work even in earlier versions. To make Qt Creator load the .pro.user file, you must go to ~/.config/QtProject/qtcreator/profiles.xml and copy the profile ID from there to the "ProjectExplorer.ProjectConfiguration.Id" key in the .pro.user file. This situation is unfortunate, but that's what we have right now.(Note that Qt creator will still create the .pro.user.3.2-pre1 file, but it's just a backup of the old file, and is not actually used, so it can be removed safely.)
Text: Patch Set 2:OK, here is what I found:Loading .pro.user files doesn't work even in earlier versions. To make Qt Creator load the .pro.user file, you must go to ~/.config/QtProject/qtcreator/profiles.xml and copy the profile ID from there to the "ProjectExplorer.ProjectConfiguration.Id" key in the .pro.user file. This situation is unfortunate, but that's what we have right now.(Note that Qt creator will still create the .pro.user.3.2-pre1 file, but it's just a backup of the old file, and is not actually used, so it can be removed safely.)

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Having dug deeper into this I think the change is wrong. The block of SetEditEngine() starting at line 1012 with if(bGrowCentered){} else if(bGrowToLeft){} else{} does not correspond to the block of EditGrowX() starting at line 1172 with if(bGrowCentered){} else if(bGrowBackwards){} else{}, but instead to the block starting at line 1260, which also is if(bGrowCentered){} else if(bGrowToLeft){} else{}. These blocks calculate the visual area, independent of the logical direction.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Having dug deeper into this I think the change is wrong. The block of SetEditEngine() starting at line 1012 with if(bGrowCentered){} else if(bGrowToLeft){} else{} does not correspond to the block of EditGrowX() starting at line 1172 with if(bGrowCentered){} else if(bGrowBackwards){} else{}, but instead to the block starting at line 1260, which also is if(bGrowCentered){} else if(bGrowToLeft){} else{}. These blocks calculate the visual area, independent of the logical direction.

text: Patch Set 4:*I uploaded the 4th patch because when you give me -1 on patch 3 there are an error in my code I checked it and fixed it.*This bug is a simple hack which I found it in the simple hacks list " https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/Easy_Hacks/lists/by_Difficulty#Easy_Hacks_for_Beginners " Bug 89756*Here is someone also solved the same bug but she didn't fix all files which are mentioned in the Bug, so I fixed the rest " https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/14903/ "*Generally prefix bit better than postfix beacuse the compiler, upon seeing i++, creates a temporary object to hold the original value of i so that after the increment completes the original value of i can be returned.  A temporary is not required when compiling ++i since the value returned by the increment operation is the value i has after the increment has completed.  This means that i++ requires more memory and runs more slowly than ++i

text: Patch Set 4:We certainly don't want to sacrifice readability for imagined speed benefits not proved by profiling. Premature optimisation is evil. Prefix increment or decrement is OK for simple variables, and especially in for loops, where using it is kinda an idiom. But something like --aCrsrSt.m_pCrsr->GetMark()->nContentis horrible.I hope I am not alone having this opinion...

text: Patch Set 4:Thank you Markus, Caol├ín!Actually, this patch turned out to be not enough. It does fix the specific bug, but currently, there are too many problems with ScPostIt/SdrCaptionObj lifetime management that need to be addressed in a consistent fasion, so currently I'm preparing a draft specification for discussion of what changes are planned and why they are needed. That spec does describe why currently deletion of the object in real document (when, e.g. the ScPostIt was deleted by user) crashes the Undo/Redo operation (where only pointers to now-deleted object are stored). That's why I don't update this patch (it should probably be abandoned for now?).Thank you for notes/correstions, and excuse me for not explaining the silence; I should have noted that earlier.
Text: Patch Set 4:Thank you Markus, Caol鈹溍璶!Actually, this patch turned out to be not enough. It does fix the specific bug, but currently, there are too many problems with ScPostIt/SdrCaptionObj lifetime management that need to be addressed in a consistent fasion, so currently I'm preparing a draft specification for discussion of what changes are planned and why they are needed. That spec does describe why currently deletion of the object in real document (when, e.g. the ScPostIt was deleted by user) crashes the Undo/Redo operation (where only pointers to now-deleted object are stored). That's why I don't update this patch (it should probably be abandoned for now?).Thank you for notes/correstions, and excuse me for not explaining the silence; I should have noted that earlier.

text: Patch Set 1:AddGraphicObject() has two kind of usages, which is not a good solution, but anyway..:So first usage when adding a full graphic object (with data), loaded from a file for example. In this case the code generates the graphic ID based on this object (apID). Checks the cache and create a new cache object or add a reference to an existing one. So it means actually adding an object to the cache.Second usage when "adding" an empty graphic object using an own ID (pID, this is used by save). This actually means getting the graphic object from the cache by ID. In this case the method fill the empty graphic object with the data what is found in the cache (if found).Yeap, it must be some side effect if this patch improve the situation.It can break things very badly, for me svtools_graphic test is crashes with this patch.
Text: Patch Set 1:AddGraphicObject() has two kind of usages, which is not a good solution, but anyway..:So first usage when adding a full graphic object (with data), loaded from a file for example. In this case the code generates the graphic ID based on this object (apID). Checks the cache and create a new cache object or add a reference to an existing one. So it means actually adding an object to the cache.Second usage when "adding" an empty graphic object using an own ID (pID, this is used by save). This actually means getting the graphic object from the cache by ID. In this case the method fill the empty graphic object with the data what is found in the cache (if found).Yeap, it must be some side effect if this patch improve the situation.It can break things very badly, for me svtools_graphic test is crashes with this patch.

But - I honestly have some trouble understanding the purpose and the meaning of the original bug, more specifically what usability improvement is a fix of it supposed to bring :-| After addressing the inline comment (about the placement of the new method) I'm gonna give you a greenie, but only +1 instead of +2. I'd like someone else to approve, because as I said, I can't really wrap my head around the bug report

text: Patch Set 1:Sorry for not following the git commit format. I'll correct it and pay attention next time. I believe the bug itself means to make it more convenient for users to type a new value in a dialog. If the value is not selected when opening a new dialog, users will have to select it first and then change the value. And unfortunately I failed to notice that MetricField is derived from SpinBox, which is derived from Edit. I only noticed that MetricField is derived from MetricFormatter, then NumericFormatter, then FormatterBase, finally from FormatterBase and it has a member variable: Edit* mpField. So I just put the method there. I should've be more careful.
Text: Patch Set 1:Sorry for not following the git commit format. I'll correct it and pay attention next time. I believe the bug itself means to make it more convenient for users to type a new value in a dialog. If the value is not selected when opening a new dialog, users will have to select it first and then change the value. And unfortunately I failed to notice that MetricField is derived from SpinBox, which is derived from Edit. I only noticed that MetricField is derived from MetricFormatter, then NumericFormatter, then FormatterBase, finally from FormatterBase and it has a member variable: Edit* mpField. So I just put the method there. I should've be more careful.

text: Patch Set 1:There's a "feature" that even soffice instances of different LO versions hand off command lines among each other (to only have a single instance really running), if they share the same user profile.  This change could apparently break that, and  the consequences of two soffice instances working on the same user profile in parallel are probably rather bad.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1(6 comments)Ok. Looking deeper into it there are a number of issues.As mentioned please follow the coding style used in the existing code.Secondly throwing a const char* is a horrible idea. If there is really a need for an exception (I'm not sure that we really want an exception there) use a real object.And finally there are so many changes that are unrelated to the things mentioned in your commit message that it is quite difficult to see what is going on. Please try to create small and self-contained changes that can easily be reviewed.

Please try to create small and self-contained changes that can easily be reviewed.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2The assumptions behind this patch are wrong. This only works if every single part of the export goes through StartRecord/EndRecord calls. We have some features that don't use that and need the STREAM_SEEK_TO_END in the beginning of the StartRecord.

text: Patch Set 2:The analysis add-in LCM function uses the GCD function to create it's result.  If GCD_ADD must go then LCM_ADD should as well: it has at least as many error issues as GCD.  All of these (Gcd, Lcm, Mod, &?; built-in or add-in) use doubles for input and output values.  The IEEE double has a precision limit of some 50+ bits which is the mantissa width and hence it is the MS limit and an absolute 'natural' limit of precision in LO as well.
Text: Patch Set 2:The analysis add-in LCM function uses the GCD function to create it's result.  If GCD_ADD must go then LCM_ADD should as well: it has at least as many error issues as GCD.  All of these (Gcd, Lcm, Mod, &?; built-in or add-in) use doubles for input and output values.  The IEEE double has a precision limit of some 50+ bits which is the mantissa width and hence it is the MS limit and an absolute 'natural' limit of precision in LO as well.

text: Patch Set 1:Additional patch, entered separately on purpose as it handles a different aspect of the F-distribution "madness".The fact that there exists a UI function name FDIST which is _not_ the same as the ODFF function FDIST bothers me somewhat.The UI FDIST is remained for users who are used to using it, but I removed the publication of it. The identical UI F.DIST.RT is published, supposed to be the 'official' UI name and reflects clearly the difference with UI F.DIST (which is ODFF FDIST).Madness is not a bad term here ;-)
Text: Patch Set 1:Additional patch, entered separately on purpose as it handles a different aspect of the F-distribution "madness".The fact that there exists a UI function name FDIST which is _not_ the same as the ODFF function FDIST bothers me somewhat.The UI FDIST is remained for users who are used to using it, but I removed the publication of it. The identical UI F.DIST.RT is published, supposed to be the 'official' UI name and reflects clearly the difference with UI F.DIST (which is ODFF FDIST).Madness is not a bad term here ;-)

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I was thinking back and forth on this. I don't like the approach of just hiding a long available function. Users don't know about ODFF anyway. Furthermore, if we only advertise F.DIST.RT that will currently be saved as COM.MICROSOFT.F.DIST.RT in ODFF instead of LEGACY.FDIST, which I find rather unfortunate.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I was thinking back and forth on this. I don't like the approach of just hiding a long available function. Users don't know about ODFF anyway. Furthermore, if we only advertise F.DIST.RT that will currently be saved as COM.MICROSOFT.F.DIST.RT in ODFF instead of LEGACY.FDIST, which I find rather unfortunate.

text: Patch Set 1:I understand -and share- your reservations. But the confusion between UI FDIST and ODFF FDIST is something I would like to avoid, or at least minimise.OTOH, no bug report has been created yet, so to keep gerrit lean, I'll abandon this patch.
Text: Patch Set 1:I understand -and share- your reservations. But the confusion between UI FDIST and ODFF FDIST is something I would like to avoid, or at least minimise.OTOH, no bug report has been created yet, so to keep gerrit lean, I'll abandon this patch.

text: Patch Set 3:I think this is the wrong approach.  Instead of "manual" acquire/releaseSolarMutex functionality, you want to use SolarMutexGuard (or, if need be, SolarMutexReleaser) wherever possible.  As long as there should indeed be still demand for manual acquire/release functionality, keep using the functions provided by the Application class.
Text: Patch Set 3:I think this is the wrong approach.  Instead of "manual" acquire/releaseSolarMutex functionality, you want to use SolarMutexGuard (or, if need be, SolarMutexReleaser) wherever possible.  As long as there should indeed be still demand for manual acquire/release functionality, keep using the functions provided by the Application class.

text: Patch Set 4:@Markus Mohrhard : I thought so. I also tried to contact developers on IRC dev chat. From there I got reply that it happens many times that people revert old change. If no UT is available then I can go ahead.Second thing is, I followed code flow for shape rotation, In this case it sets shape rotation value when it reads it from XML but later it changes it to 0. That is what I found wrong. Shape rotation is big regression and we should have caught it at that time itself. Since I don't have access to bug for which this change was made and no UT is available thats why I reverted this change and added proper UT for Shape Rotation.
Text: Patch Set 4:@Markus Mohrhard : I thought so. I also tried to contact developers on IRC dev chat. From there I got reply that it happens many times that people revert old change. If no UT is available then I can go ahead.Second thing is, I followed code flow for shape rotation, In this case it sets shape rotation value when it reads it from XML but later it changes it to 0. That is what I found wrong. Shape rotation is big regression and we should have caught it at that time itself. Since I don't have access to bug for which this change was made and no UT is available thats why I reverted this change and added proper UT for Shape Rotation.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1So, as-is this compiles ... and crashes/asserts for now -- at least with a debug build.There have been some attempts to use unique_ptrs or scoped_ptrs on SwUnoCrsr -- however, as these are kept as naked pointer in SwUnoCrsrTbl too, which mindlessly deletes everything it still finds around on ~SwDoc, the ownership of these is a terrible mess.I'd suggest to use the blunt device of a shared_ptr as a starting point (and a weak_ptr in SwUnoCrsrTbl) to get somewhat sensible ownership of these in the mid-term.In the long run, the users of the SwUnoCrsrTbl should likely be listeners to all the SwUnoCrsrs (registered right in CreateUnoCrsr) and thus removing the need for having a SwUnoCrsrTbl in the first place. But that is still way off.So, as an intermediate step: using shared_ptrs.@mst, caolan: opinions? is this worth finalizing this?
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1So, as-is this compiles ... and crashes/asserts for now -- at least with a debug build.There have been some attempts to use unique_ptrs or scoped_ptrs on SwUnoCrsr -- however, as these are kept as naked pointer in SwUnoCrsrTbl too, which mindlessly deletes everything it still finds around on ~SwDoc, the ownership of these is a terrible mess.I'd suggest to use the blunt device of a shared_ptr as a starting point (and a weak_ptr in SwUnoCrsrTbl) to get somewhat sensible ownership of these in the mid-term.In the long run, the users of the SwUnoCrsrTbl should likely be listeners to all the SwUnoCrsrs (registered right in CreateUnoCrsr) and thus removing the need for having a SwUnoCrsrTbl in the first place. But that is still way off.So, as an intermediate step: using shared_ptrs.@mst, caolan: opinions? is this worth finalizing this?

text: Patch Set 1:> do we really need this? i.e. are there any unique_ptr<SwUnoCrsr> or > scoped_ptr<SwUnoCrsr> that are not on the stack but on the heap?various other UNO wrappers objects have them as members, quite a few as plain naked pointers. > do you clear the dead weak_ptr from the SwUnoCrsrTbl at some point? > any UNO call will create at least 3 new instances, so we should > release the memory at some point.Sure. For a start we should do that from ~SwUnoCrsr as it was done before -- that hardly will make it worse.

For a start we should do that from ~SwUnoCrsr as it was done before -- that hardly will make it worse.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1This pampers over a symptom, but the real problem is still there. A nonexistent file listed in a filelist is something that is not expected to happen at all, as it is gbuild (IOW, make) that creates the filelists, _after it copied the files_.But if all you want is to avoid a perl error, it would be much better to change the log calls above to die calls.
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1This pampers over a symptom, but the real problem is still there. A nonexistent file listed in a filelist is something that is not expected to happen at all, as it is gbuild (IOW, make) that creates the filelists, _after it copied the files_.But if all you want is to avoid a perl error, it would be much better to change the log calls above to die calls.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1See my general comments at <https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=86784#c2>.That said, if choosing this approach, please do not introduce an old-style properties-only UNO service here.  Keep it simple, add a bootstrap() overload that takes a String[] argument, say, allowing precise control over what arguments are passed (in addition to the --accept argument, and probably also in addition to the --nologo, --nodefault, --nolockcheck arguments, as discussed).
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1See my general comments at <https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=86784#c2>.That said, if choosing this approach, please do not introduce an old-style properties-only UNO service here.  Keep it simple, add a bootstrap() overload that takes a String[] argument, say, allowing precise control over what arguments are passed (in addition to the --accept argument, and probably also in addition to the --nologo, --nodefault, --nolockcheck arguments, as discussed).

text: Patch Set 1:answered in fdo#86784.regarding your suggestion to have not .idl file --> no objections.regarding your suggestion to accept String[] instead of PropertyValue[]: In general I want to use the defaults from the simplified bootstrapping, but just be able to switch off (or override) particular options. If the defaults in simplified bootstrapping in future will be changed for an option that is not explicitely overridden, I want to benifit from these changes, so that I don't need to adjust my client code. I want to keep the client code as stupid as possible regarding how to start soffice. Any suggestion how this can be achieved with a String[] approach?
Text: Patch Set 1:answered in fdo#86784.regarding your suggestion to have not .idl file --> no objections.regarding your suggestion to accept String[] instead of PropertyValue[]: In general I want to use the defaults from the simplified bootstrapping, but just be able to switch off (or override) particular options. If the defaults in simplified bootstrapping in future will be changed for an option that is not explicitely overridden, I want to benifit from these changes, so that I don't need to adjust my client code. I want to keep the client code as stupid as possible regarding how to start soffice. Any suggestion how this can be achieved with a String[] approach?

text: Patch Set 6:My main concern was that if hidden data was removed so far, then the default should be still removing, and only after using the option should it be possible that such previously removed hidden data is still mailed out.I'm not sure how the changed .xcu is supposed to work; probably then the config setting is "nil" by default, and you just don't handle the situation when extracting a bool from the setting fails.All in all, please do what Tor suggested to using the new configmgr API to read the setting, and also I think<prop oor:name="..." oor:type="xs:boolean" oor:nillable="false">would be better in the .xcs file, then you would have to provide an explicit default in the .xcu file:<prop oor:name="..." oor:type="xs:boolean">  <value>true</value></prop>That would ensure that no hidden content gets mailed out after an innocent upgrade.
Text: Patch Set 6:My main concern was that if hidden data was removed so far, then the default should be still removing, and only after using the option should it be possible that such previously removed hidden data is still mailed out.I'm not sure how the changed .xcu is supposed to work; probably then the config setting is "nil" by default, and you just don't handle the situation when extracting a bool from the setting fails.All in all, please do what Tor suggested to using the new configmgr API to read the setting, and also I think<prop oor:name="..." oor:type="xs:boolean" oor:nillable="false">would be better in the .xcs file, then you would have to provide an explicit default in the .xcu file:<prop oor:name="..." oor:type="xs:boolean">  <value>true</value></prop>That would ensure that no hidden content gets mailed out after an innocent upgrade.

text: Patch Set 6:* when making the prop non-nillable, the default needs to go directly into the xcs, not the xcu* one benefit of making props non-nillable is that the "new-style" code to access them becomes simpler, as a nillable prop is modelled by a boost::optional, and esp. for bool props C++ bool vs. boost::optional<bool> is error-prone* I don't think the ExternalMailer group is a good place for this prop; the prop is about how to dress up a document for sending, not about how to send a mail

text: Patch Set 1:Hmm, right. It's also possible to adapt the names in .ui files in CustomTarget makefiles or somewhere. It's funny I did not realize that. Is it considered better? Should I do that instead?Anyhow, I think it could be useful to have dynamic getLibraryName function in code somewhere to replace SVLIBRARY, -DFOO_DLL_NAME and other similarities.It's not always possible to replace with static defines. E.g. in vcl/unx/generic/plugadapt/salplug.cxx we have dynamic strings.
Text: Patch Set 1:Hmm, right. It's also possible to adapt the names in .ui files in CustomTarget makefiles or somewhere. It's funny I did not realize that. Is it considered better? Should I do that instead?Anyhow, I think it could be useful to have dynamic getLibraryName function in code somewhere to replace SVLIBRARY, -DFOO_DLL_NAME and other similarities.It's not always possible to replace with static defines. E.g. in vcl/unx/generic/plugadapt/salplug.cxx we have dynamic strings.

text: Patch Set 6:My bad, sorry about that (I read the bugzilla comments without actually trying and poking at the code) ...But actually, the fix for this will be even more straightforward. The position of last selected slide is already saved into ODF, it is "SelectedPage" property, you can find it in settings.xml. Looks e.g. like this: <config:config-item config:name="SelectedPage" config:type="short">2</config:config-item>So, there is no need for you to create an extra setting in UnoDocumentSettings for that, you now only have to figure out why is this setting not used then the document is being loaded (hint: frmview.cxx, look for "sUNO_View_SelectedPage")
Text: Patch Set 6:My bad, sorry about that (I read the bugzilla comments without actually trying and poking at the code) ...But actually, the fix for this will be even more straightforward. The position of last selected slide is already saved into ODF, it is "SelectedPage" property, you can find it in settings.xml. Looks e.g. like this: <config:config-item config:name="SelectedPage" config:type="short">2</config:config-item>So, there is no need for you to create an extra setting in UnoDocumentSettings for that, you now only have to figure out why is this setting not used then the document is being loaded (hint: frmview.cxx, look for "sUNO_View_SelectedPage")

text: Patch Set 6:I still don't like introducing a new document-wide UNO setting when we already have a setting in ODF format doing exactly the same ...Anyway, I did some git archaeology and found out that this "Impress always opens on 1st slide" is an artificial restriction imposed by a design document + OOo feature request from 2005 (https://bz.apache.org/ooo/show_bug.cgi?id=50902)Moreover, keyboard accelerator listed therein (Shift-F5) that was supposed to be used to jump to the last edited slide (the one saved as SelectedPage) no longer works, since it is used for different purpose now (start a slideshow from current slide)So I think this restriction (always open on 1st slide, unless the presentation is an embedded OLE object) can nowadays be removed and that should be the way to fix this issue. I.e. removing this 'if ...( SFX_CREATE_MODE_EMBEDDED == pDoc->GetDocSh()->GetCreateMode()' condition when reading SelectedPage setting ... unless it crashes Impress or cause other nasties ...Anyway, I'm adding Thorsten to Cc: to get a second opinion on that ...
Text: Patch Set 6:I still don't like introducing a new document-wide UNO setting when we already have a setting in ODF format doing exactly the same ...Anyway, I did some git archaeology and found out that this "Impress always opens on 1st slide" is an artificial restriction imposed by a design document + OOo feature request from 2005 (https://bz.apache.org/ooo/show_bug.cgi?id=50902)Moreover, keyboard accelerator listed therein (Shift-F5) that was supposed to be used to jump to the last edited slide (the one saved as SelectedPage) no longer works, since it is used for different purpose now (start a slideshow from current slide)So I think this restriction (always open on 1st slide, unless the presentation is an embedded OLE object) can nowadays be removed and that should be the way to fix this issue. I.e. removing this 'if ...( SFX_CREATE_MODE_EMBEDDED == pDoc->GetDocSh()->GetCreateMode()' condition when reading SelectedPage setting ... unless it crashes Impress or cause other nasties ...Anyway, I'm adding Thorsten to Cc: to get a second opinion on that ...

text: Patch Set 5:The changes are being saved to the odp file when the file is saved because AFAIK,  UNO document settings are written again when we save the document.In settings.xml of the odp file:You can find<config:config-item config:name="CurrentPage" config:type="short">2</config:config-item>And if you modify document again and save at some other slide then, it would be modified:<config:config-item config:name="CurrentPage" config:type="short">4</config:config-item>Also the code in frmview.cxx  loads the current page while loading the document. (pDrawDoc->GetCurrentPage() )Can you please cherry-pick and try. I don't think we need that import and export code as mentioned in comment 3 on the bug page.Thanks for the letting me know about the variable naming, will fix that.
Text: Patch Set 5:The changes are being saved to the odp file when the file is saved because AFAIK,  UNO document settings are written again when we save the document.In settings.xml of the odp file:You can find<config:config-item config:name="CurrentPage" config:type="short">2</config:config-item>And if you modify document again and save at some other slide then, it would be modified:<config:config-item config:name="CurrentPage" config:type="short">4</config:config-item>Also the code in frmview.cxx  loads the current page while loading the document. (pDrawDoc->GetCurrentPage() )Can you please cherry-pick and try. I don't think we need that import and export code as mentioned in comment 3 on the bug page.Thanks for the letting me know about the variable naming, will fix that.

text: Patch Set 1:A workaround around these kind of code pieces might be to define another scope, and then define SolarMutexReleaser aReleaser; inside it.But I was wondering if we can have any other workaround around this without the need of defining the scope.And, yeah, I agree this approach is false. I just blindly used SolarMutexClearableGuard after reading the suggestions from the bug comment; just read the svapp.hxx, and it seems it won't serve the purpose as you mentioned.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Hi G├íbor, thank you for your time spent improving LibreOffice! We appreciate it a lot.Unfortunately this patch conflicts both with a commit I made three days ago [1] and with another Gerrit change set [2]. In other circumstances I would have asked you to just rebase your patch (so that it merges cleanly) but in this case there is another person doing the same work, so instead I would ask you (if you want, of course) to hack towards solving another issue [3].Thank you a bunch, and sorry for the inconvenience! [1]: http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/commit/?id=6a3c5af4eb96d03110fcbc856c6920bfcf4063c7[2]: https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/14795/[3]: https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Design/Blueprints and https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/EasyHacks
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Hi G鈹溍璪or, thank you for your time spent improving LibreOffice! We appreciate it a lot.Unfortunately this patch conflicts both with a commit I made three days ago [1] and with another Gerrit change set [2]. In other circumstances I would have asked you to just rebase your patch (so that it merges cleanly) but in this case there is another person doing the same work, so instead I would ask you (if you want, of course) to hack towards solving another issue [3].Thank you a bunch, and sorry for the inconvenience! text: Patch Set 1:Hi Adolfo,Actually, I did a mistake at [1], I had a too old checkout... that's alright. About the other person working on the same issue, he emailed me about it today. He just took it away from me, knowing I'm working on it. Can show in private if necessary. (I bet we both need one bug fix for GSoC.)Otherwise, his patch is useless. He changed outInvish.cxx, (so did I,) but that isn't the point that needed change. The visible page numberings are at SlsSlotManager.cxx and drviewsa.cxx, which do actually the same work, but first one takes effect when the Slides Manager (on the left side) is active, and drviewsa.cxx when the slide editor itself is active. I didn't manage to find the UI where the code in outInvish.cxx takes effect. I changed those as well, so my patch is working properly, unlike his. Despite all those, I'm ready to fix another bug if necessary.Thanks,dobragab
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Adolfo,Actually, I did a mistake at [1], I had a too old checkout... that's alright. About the other person working on the same issue, he emailed me about it today. He just took it away from me, knowing I'm working on it. Can show in private if necessary. (I bet we both need one bug fix for GSoC.)Otherwise, his patch is useless. He changed outInvish.cxx, (so did I,) but that isn't the point that needed change. The visible page numberings are at SlsSlotManager.cxx and drviewsa.cxx, which do actually the same work, but first one takes effect when the Slides Manager (on the left side) is active, and drviewsa.cxx when the slide editor itself is active. I didn't manage to find the UI where the code in outInvish.cxx takes effect. I changed those as well, so my patch is working properly, unlike his. Despite all those, I'm ready to fix another bug if necessary.Thanks,dobragab

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2To answer your question about how many icons are missing in Galaxy:Since the beginning of LibreOffice, contributors have been adding unfitting icons to Galaxy so that their features work in that theme as well as in Tango. Yes, a hideous approach. We are able to stop doing that now that weÔÇÖve modified LibreOffice to stop considering Galaxy as the ÔÇ£parentÔÇØ theme from which the rest is derived from.The default usage of Tango was also, back in 2010, a highlighted feature which helped to distinguish the newly released fork from OOo. The decision was made, among other reasons perhaps, on the basis that it was a more malleable icon theme (with sources available and compatible with our license) which we could modify to suit our needs. This is still a big advantage that would be lost if we switched to Galaxy in the platform with the most of our user base. Another big disadvantage is that it would make obsolete most, if not all, volunteer-writen guides.

We are able to stop doing that now that we脭脟脰ve modified LibreOffice to stop considering Galaxy as the 脭脟拢parent脭脟脴 theme from which the rest is derived from.The default usage of Tango was also, back in 2010, a highlighted feature which helped to distinguish the newly released fork from OOo. The decision was made, among other reasons perhaps, on the basis that it was a more malleable icon theme (with sources available and compatible with our license) which we could modify to suit our needs. This is still a big advantage that would be lost if we switched to Galaxy in the platform with the most of our user base. Another big disadvantage is that it would make obsolete most, if not all, volunteer-writen guides.

text: Patch Set 1:Adolfo, how do I bring this to ESC?Also, I understand that the UX team doesn't want to maintain a theme without sources, but I wonder how many icons this theme currently lacks or will lack in the near future? From the first impression, this theme still looks perfectly complete, but even if it lacks 10 or so icons, perhaps it's not such a big problem and these could be drawn without having the sources for current ones? Perhaps this way the source base could be built incrementally?

If you select new style we open the dialog to create a new style. It should never be selected in itself as that will break conditional formats horribly.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2That patch is not a good idea in this form (I'm not sure it is in any form).The "New Style" entry is special as it is not a valid style in itself. If you select new style we open the dialog to create a new style. It should never be selected in itself as that will break conditional formats horribly.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2(3 comments)I just had a quick look at this mailmerge.py ... not pretty.BTW: you can drop the resolves from the commit message - just start with tdf#63388.Now for your patch.Normally one should try (in this order of preference): 1. StartTLS: SMTP + EHLO, check for STARTTLS and establish TLS (normally on port 25 or 587) 2. SSL/TLS: SMTP_S_ without STARTTLS (normally on port 465). This should directly start encrypted (SMTP_SSL)! 3. Insecure: SMTP (as 1.)The ports are just the well known ports, but servers can run on any.In the case of the SSL setting from LO, I would just probe 1 and 2 and skip 3. But feel free to update the GUI and add StartTLS.To be technically clear without probing one would need all three options: Insecure, Ssl and StartTLS.And note there is also the POP3 and IMAP code in this file, which should be unified in handling the connection setup. I'm not sure this is actually used. At the end all protocols offer the same three options.Anyway - you don't need to fix these too ;-)OTOH I'm unable to really test this. I'm just familiar with the LO C++ MM code, not the Python email handling backend.Currently a good read: https://www.fastmail.com/help/technical/ssltlsstarttls.htmlHope this comment doesn't shock you too much ;-)

This should directly start encrypted (SMTP_SSL)! 3. Insecure: SMTP (as 1.)The ports are just the well known ports, but servers can run on any.In the case of the SSL setting from LO, I would just probe 1 and 2 and skip 3. But feel free to update the GUI and add StartTLS.To be technically clear without probing one would need all three options: Insecure, Ssl and StartTLS.And note there is also the POP3 and IMAP code in this file, which should be unified in handling the connection setup. I'm not sure this is actually used. At the end all protocols offer the same three options.Anyway - you don't need to fix these too ;-)OTOH I'm unable to really test this. text: Patch Set 2:(2 comments)it is disappointing to see this GCC version (4.9.2?, at least that's the one with which I observe the same) report these false -Werror=maybe-unitialized only at -Og, not at -O0 nor at -O2if it is only a handful of such warnings, silencing them via redundantly initializing variables to "random" values may be acceptable (and see the comments for even better fixes for some), but if it turns out to be more, it might indicate that -Og is not really useful yet and needs fixing in GCC first

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2Yes, what Michael said is true. SdrPage's shapes are always sorted internally by z-order, which is always a consecutive sequence from 0 to N-1. But: 1/ This is an impl. detail of SdrPage. 2/ Even if it were not, it does not follow that any impl. of css::draw::XShapes must do that too, so relying on it in the export code is wrong.
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2Yes, what Michael said is true. SdrPage's shapes are always sorted internally by z-order, which is always a consecutive sequence from 0 to N-1. But: 1/ This is an impl. detail of SdrPage. 2/ Even if it were not, it does not follow that any impl. of css::draw::XShapes must do that too, so relying on it in the export code is wrong.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1sorry but i think that with the "brute force of removing each include one by one" approach there is a significant risk that you introduce more problems than are solved:1. we want each header file to be "complete" in the sense that it would build successfully as a compilation unit on its own; it should not depend on some other header being included before it into a source file to provide the types it uses, it should either include a header that declares the needed type, or contain a "forward declaration" of it.2. removing an include from a source file because there is another include in the source file that transitively brings in the needed include is also undesirable: some time later somebody will refactor the code and reomve soem include that is no longer directly needed and then it turns out that there are a lot of errors that need fixing because the source file was relying on indirectly included files.3. it's also too easy to remove platform dependent or configuration dependent include this way; some of the code is behind some #ifdef.  Ok, this is a more general problem and you have to be aware of it whatever approach you use.  best to build with --enable-dbgutil to get all the debug code built.an obvious example of the problem is the 	accessibility/inc/pch/precompiled_acc.hxx which is quite empty after the patch; the PCH is an exception anyway since putting more stuff into it may actually speed things up...it's probably much easier to use the include-what-you-use tool to remove the unnecessary includes because that tool will not suggest removing headers that declare types that are actually used, thus should prevent the problems 1 and 2.in my experience the tool is still not perfect though and you still have to manually review the add/remove advice it prints out.
Text: accessibility/inc/pch/precompiled_acc.hxx which is quite empty after the patch; the PCH is an exception anyway since putting more stuff into it may actually speed things up...it's probably much easier to use the include-what-you-use tool to remove the unnecessary includes because that tool will not suggest removing headers that declare types that are actually used, thus should prevent the problems 1 and 2.in my experience the tool is still not perfect though and you still have to manually review the add/remove advice it prints out."

text: Patch Set 4:Well look at it in context....the original returned a int, which is expected for a GetError() were one would expect the possibility of different kind of error. it turned out that it always returned so far 0 or 1... text: Patch Set 1:Hi Adolfo, I am not an expert on fonts, but what I can be sure is that those two "'" are very different.Please compare these two:http://suokunlong.cn/tmp/libreoffice/whatsthis.pnghttp://suokunlong.cn/tmp/libreoffice/dontsave.pngThere is no extra space after the "'" in "What's This";but there is extra space after the "DonÔÇÖt save".Maybe this has sth to do with the "full-width" and "half-width" character issue?This may not be a problem after localization, but my concern is not for the Chinese users, but rather for English UI. Maybe I should file a bug report on bugzilla and let someone else test and confirm?
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Adolfo, I am not an expert on fonts, but what I can be sure is that those two "'" are very different.Please compare these two:http://suokunlong.cn/tmp/libreoffice/whatsthis.pnghttp://suokunlong.cn/tmp/libreoffice/dontsave.pngThere is no extra space after the "'" in "What's This";but there is extra space after the "Don脭脟脰t save".Maybe this has sth to do with the "full-width" and "half-width" character issue?This may not be a problem after localization, but my concern is not for the Chinese users, but rather for English UI. Maybe I should file a bug report on bugzilla and let someone else test and confirm?

text: Patch Set 1:> my concern is not for the Chinese users, but rather for English UI.This issue is not present in English-language environments because the Segoe UI font is used there. This is actually a Windows issue, because it is not falling back to Segoe UI when starting a program in English when your UI font is YaHei, JhengHei or Meiryo.> Maybe I should file a bug report on bugzilla and let someone else test and confirm?Sadly we have no control over such font issues. Microsoft owns a kind of bug tracker called Microsoft Connect, perhaps they already know about this. Also, they usually update the UI fonts when a new Windows version comes out. It would be interesting to try to reproduce the issue in Windows 8.1 or 10.
Text: Patch Set 1:> my concern is not for the Chinese users, but rather for English UI.This issue is not present in English-language environments because the Segoe UI font is used there. This is actually a Windows issue, because it is not falling back to Segoe UI when starting a program in English when your UI font is YaHei, JhengHei or Meiryo.> Maybe I should file a bug report on bugzilla and let someone else test and confirm?Sadly we have no control over such font issues. Microsoft owns a kind of bug tracker called Microsoft Connect, perhaps they already know about this. Also, they usually update the UI fonts when a new Windows version comes out. It would be interesting to try to reproduce the issue in Windows 8.1 or 10.

Please have a look how the sw/qa/extras/ooxmlexport/data/table-floating-margins.docx document looks like originally ("original"), how it got roundtripped before your patch ("old") and with your patch ("new").As you can see, in the original and old cases, there is no text above the table and there is one line of text after the table. text: Patch Set 1:http://people.freedesktop.org/~vmiklos/2014/gerrit11013.docx is a reproducer. It has two VML shapes, one in the background, one is not. If you change the z-index of the background one to positive and open it, it won't be in the background, either.So I'm sure that if you unconditionally put any shape with a z-index into background, that's incorrect. I also guess that negative z-index means background, even if it's not in the spec.
Text: Patch Set 1:http://people.freedesktop.org/~vmiklos/2014/gerrit11013.docx is a reproducer. It has two VML shapes, one in the background, one is not. If you change the z-index of the background one to positive and open it, it won't be in the background, either.So I'm sure that if you unconditionally put any shape with a z-index into background, that's incorrect. I also guess that negative z-index means background, even if it's not in the spec.
