text: Patch Set 2:Thanks for your review, David.First of all, i was wrong in the commit message. I should have written 'GetDenominator()==0'About if it is necessary or not.. i think that it is not immediately necessary.I identify three usages of invalid fractions:a) the fraction is created with Fraction(long nNum, long nDen). This allow create a fraction with zero denominator.b) the fraction is created with Fraction(double dVal). This allow the creation of invalid fraction if dVal is out of a long range, in which case the numerator is set to zero and the denominator is set to -1.c) if at least one of the operands in an operation is invalid, or if the result of an operation with valid operands is out of a long range, the result is an invalid fraction with numerator set to zero and denominator set to -1.In some pieces of the code i see conditions using GetDenominator()==0, which are false if we check against invalid fraction due "overflow" (cases b) and c)), but true against GetDenominator()==1.In my previous commit, 2ce0aededea43231d91a0955fc0676120dcc4f13, i missed the case 'divide by zero' or 'zero denominator'. In that commit we catch a division by zero when initialize a Fraction as an invalid value due "overflow".I think that we can do the following:a) revert the commit 2ce0aededea43231d91a0955fc0676120dcc4f13 and try a best effort in rewrite the Fraction classb) add two invalid cases in the Fraction implementation rewrite: "overflow" and "divide by zero", then we can rewrite the conditions such "GetDenominator()==0" as "IsDivideByZero()" (this patch)c) rewrite the conditions such "GetDenominator()==0" as "!IsValid()", but that can modify the usage of Fraction values, due that in some cases, in the if block of GetDenominator()==0 i'm see usages of GetNumerator(). An example is include/svx/svdtrans.hxx in ResizePoint: if (xFact.GetDenominator()==0) xFact=Fraction(xFact.GetNumerator(),1); // DivZero abfangenI'm waiting for your commentsGreetings
Text: Patch Set 2:Thanks for your review, David.First of all, i was wrong in the commit message. I should have written 'GetDenominator()==0'About if it is necessary or not.. i think that it is not immediately necessary.I identify three usages of invalid fractions:a) the fraction is created with Fraction(long nNum, long nDen). This allow create a fraction with zero denominator.b) the fraction is created with Fraction(double dVal). This allow the creation of invalid fraction if dVal is out of a long range, in which case the numerator is set to zero and the denominator is set to -1.c) if at least one of the operands in an operation is invalid, or if the result of an operation with valid operands is out of a long range, the result is an invalid fraction with numerator set to zero and denominator set to -1.In some pieces of the code i see conditions using GetDenominator()==0, which are false if we check against invalid fraction due "overflow" (cases b) and c)), but true against GetDenominator()==1.In my previous commit, 2ce0aededea43231d91a0955fc0676120dcc4f13, i missed the case 'divide by zero' or 'zero denominator'. In that commit we catch a division by zero when initialize a Fraction as an invalid value due "overflow".I think that we can do the following:a) revert the commit 2ce0aededea43231d91a0955fc0676120dcc4f13 and try a best effort in rewrite the Fraction classb) add two invalid cases in the Fraction implementation rewrite: "overflow" and "divide by zero", then we can rewrite the conditions such "GetDenominator()==0" as "IsDivideByZero()" (this patch)c) rewrite the conditions such "GetDenominator()==0" as "!IsValid()", but that can modify the usage of Fraction values, due that in some cases, in the if block of GetDenominator()==0 i'm see usages of GetNumerator(). An example is include/svx/svdtrans.hxx in ResizePoint: if (xFact.GetDenominator()==0) xFact=Fraction(xFact.GetNumerator(),1); // DivZero abfangenI'm waiting for your commentsGreetings

text: Patch Set 2:The include/svx/svdtrans.hxx example is not very convincing to me. IMHO the a/0 -> a/1 change just replaces one meaningless value by another meaningless value. It would be equally good (or bad) to use 1/1... Also, this code does not handle the overflow case .
Text: Patch Set 2:The include/svx/svdtrans.hxx example is not very convincing to me. IMHO the a/0 -> a/1 change just replaces one meaningless value by another meaningless value. It would be equally good (or bad) to use 1/1... Also, this code does not handle the overflow case .

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1This is definitely not the right fix, though perhaps you are in the right area.Compare the new dialog code with the one from the 4.2 branch.  When the backend is not a sheet, we are not supposed to update the source range.  The source range should be disabled and remain empty.  The new code tries to update it regardless, which causes the crash.That's my theory.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1This is definitely not the right fix, though perhaps you are in the right area.Compare the new dialog code with the one from the 4.2 branch.  When the backend is not a sheet, we are not supposed to update the source range.  The source range should be disabled and remain empty.  The new code tries to update it regardless, which causes the crash.That's my theory.

text: Patch Set 2:We use bool instead of int on purpose in C++, as it e.g. generally results in more valuable compiler diagnostics, so I would not want to loose that here.Whether this include file, when included into an Objective C++ compilation unit, violates some Objective C++ standard, or just breaks some specific GCC-based toolchain, is unclear to me.  AFAIK there is no such thing as a precise Objective C++ standard?

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1So, Markus and I had the same discussion years ago.  The reason why we still keep auto_ptr there was 2 things: 1) make the code exception safe, and 2) ptr_set requires auto_ptr to be passed to be truly exception safe.  2) is a loose requirement and you can also pass a raw pointer to ptr_set (as you noticed).  But your current change is a step backward in terms of 1).The best strategy for this use case is to use o3tl::heap_ptr to replace auto_ptr, and call heap_ptr's release() when passing it to ptr_set.  Then the code remains exception safe and we can get rid of auto_ptr.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1So, Markus and I had the same discussion years ago.  The reason why we still keep auto_ptr there was 2 things: 1) make the code exception safe, and 2) ptr_set requires auto_ptr to be passed to be truly exception safe.  2) is a loose requirement and you can also pass a raw pointer to ptr_set (as you noticed).  But your current change is a step backward in terms of 1).The best strategy for this use case is to use o3tl::heap_ptr to replace auto_ptr, and call heap_ptr's release() when passing it to ptr_set.  Then the code remains exception safe and we can get rid of auto_ptr.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2I don't really like that solution, as it would codify in the stable URE interface that on non-Windows wchar_t is 32-bit and represents UTF-32 code units, which need not hold in general.  (Also, include files that are part of the stable URE interface must not depend on Boost, but that would be a minor issue to fix.)  I would rather prefer to find a different fix for the underlying problem, and continue discussion by mail.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2I don't really like that solution, as it would codify in the stable URE interface that on non-Windows wchar_t is 32-bit and represents UTF-32 code units, which need not hold in general.  (Also, include files that are part of the stable URE interface must not depend on Boost, but that would be a minor issue to fix.)  I would rather prefer to find a different fix for the underlying problem, and continue discussion by mail.

text: Patch Set 1:> codify in UR that on non-Windows wchar_t is 32-bit and represents UTF-32 code unitsWell, that's an implementation "bug". When LibreOffice is ported to a platform where it is not the case, the implementation can be updated for this platform. Or we could implement this function in a more portable way, for example using iconv (but polishing the code to fix the memory leak and all that):static iconv_t cnv = iconv_open("UTF-16", "WCHAR_T");sal_Unicode *buf=calloc(len, 2*sizeof(sal_Unicode))size_t cnvlen =  sizeof(2*sal_Unicode*len)const size_t cps = iconv(cnv, &str, &len, &buf, &cnvlen)rtl_uStringbuffer_insert( &pData, &nCapacity, getLength(), buf, cps );I actually think implementing this feature in a robust way it would be a service to C++ extensions (even if it does not get used much within LibreOffice).As far as the needs of connectivity/odbc are concerned, I'm happy with the solution suggested by email.
Text: Patch Set 1:> codify in UR that on non-Windows wchar_t is 32-bit and represents UTF-32 code unitsWell, that's an implementation "bug". When LibreOffice is ported to a platform where it is not the case, the implementation can be updated for this platform. Or we could implement this function in a more portable way, for example using iconv (but polishing the code to fix the memory leak and all that):static iconv_t cnv = iconv_open("UTF-16", "WCHAR_T");sal_Unicode *buf=calloc(len, 2*sizeof(sal_Unicode))size_t cnvlen =  sizeof(2*sal_Unicode*len)const size_t cps = iconv(cnv, &str, &len, &buf, &cnvlen)rtl_uStringbuffer_insert( &pData, &nCapacity, getLength(), buf, cps );I actually think implementing this feature in a robust way it would be a service to C++ extensions (even if it does not get used much within LibreOffice).As far as the needs of connectivity/odbc are concerned, I'm happy with the solution suggested by email.

text: Patch Set 1:Not by mistake - as per the previous comment, "The unit tests are only intended as a quick hack micro-benchmark"and I didn't intend that that file would be merged, but that it would help demonstrate to a reviewer what the intended effect of the main patch was. The "tests" don't have any assertions, I just hijacked the test infrastructure to wedge in a benchmark.And, as stated in the later comment, I'm "Looking for more expert feedback" but didn't have a specific person in mind to CC: a draft to.If someone could tell me if I'm barking up the right tree or not, I could possibly make a proper test of the form "doing this for Chinese text should take < N times the time for English text" to guard against a regression - although a test of that form would be somewhat subject to the vaguaries of scheduling.
Text: Patch Set 1:Not by mistake - as per the previous comment, "The unit tests are only intended as a quick hack micro-benchmark"and I didn't intend that that file would be merged, but that it would help demonstrate to a reviewer what the intended effect of the main patch was. text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2Sorry, but this is not even a fix.  Making the search dialog not appear for Replace All would be a regression.  This is just an attempt to make the problem go away by disabling a feature.

text: Patch Set 2:The right first step to analyze the problem is to run callgrind and profile it.  That should give us a better idea of where the hot spot is & give us a clue of what the right fix should look like.
Text: Patch Set 2:The right first step to analyze the problem is to run callgrind and profile it.  That should give us a better idea of where the hot spot is & give us a clue of what the right fix should look like.

text: Patch Set 2:Also, we need to figure out whether the poor performance of find all and replace all are related to each other, or they have different hot spots.  Once again running callgrind in both use cases should shed some light.  Once you get the callgrind data, please gzip it (or bzip2 it) and post it to the bug so that we can take a look.  Thanks.
Text: Patch Set 2:Also, we need to figure out whether the poor performance of find all and replace all are related to each other, or they have different hot spots.  Once again running callgrind in both use cases should shed some light.  Once you get the callgrind data, please gzip it (or bzip2 it) and post it to the bug so that we can take a look.  Thanks.

text: Patch Set 2:Hi Seyeong, I have a totally unrelated comment: in order to associate patches with bug reports, we use this syntax in the first line of the commit message: fdo#12345 (replace that with the actual bug number). That way, when a patch of yours gets merged, a bot will automatically notify the correspondent bug report. You may want to update your commit message. Thanks and sorry for the nitpick!

text: Patch Set 3:Is there any reason for this? Have you actually talked with a libreoffice developer about reformatting java code or is this just your personal preference? I particularly dislike the folding of { to preceding line: IMHO { on a separate line helps to spot the beginning of the block if the function declaration (or if condition) is multi-line.I have nothing about small cleanups in general, but complete change of coding style in a single source file seems pretty much pointless. If there is a consensus that we should change coding style (or, rather, to start using one .-), it should be done globally, or at least for whole modules at a time. And it should be discussed on the mailing list.
Text: Patch Set 3:Is there any reason for this? Have you actually talked with a libreoffice developer about reformatting java code or is this just your personal preference? I particularly dislike the folding of { to preceding line: IMHO { on a separate line helps to spot the beginning of the block if the function declaration (or if condition) is multi-line.I have nothing about small cleanups in general, but complete change of coding style in a single source file seems pretty much pointless. If there is a consensus that we should change coding style (or, rather, to start using one .-), it should be done globally, or at least for whole modules at a time. And it should be discussed on the mailing list.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)Hi Yogesh, thanks for looking into this.I was worried about the change to wrtw8sty.cxx so I had a bit of a look at the bug myself to understand it better.  I found two different issues which contribute:- the import from docx appears to have a bug which is at play here: when I open the docx in LibreOffice I see that the first page footer has wrong spacing. This affects the export code which tries to join chained page styles into a single word section if they match.  The import bug means that they do not match, so it will try to export this as two different word sections.- however some code recently added to ww8/ww8atr.cxx in a31fbb53dba7 prevents the output of a new section at the page break in this case, as the paragraph on the first page is empty             if( isTextNodeEmpty )                bNewPageDesc = false;So I think these are the two issues that need to be addressed, rather than the change proposed in this item.  Fixing either one of them will solve the reported issue for this document, but it would be great to fix both.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)Hi Yogesh, thanks for looking into this.I was worried about the change to wrtw8sty.cxx so I had a bit of a look at the bug myself to understand it better.  I found two different issues which contribute:- the import from docx appears to have a bug which is at play here: when I open the docx in LibreOffice I see that the first page footer has wrong spacing. This affects the export code which tries to join chained page styles into a single word section if they match.  The import bug means that they do not match, so it will try to export this as two different word sections.- however some code recently added to ww8/ww8atr.cxx in a31fbb53dba7 prevents the output of a new section at the page break in this case, as the paragraph on the first page is empty             if( isTextNodeEmpty )                bNewPageDesc = false;So I think these are the two issues that need to be addressed, rather than the change proposed in this item.  Fixing either one of them will solve the reported issue for this document, but it would be great to fix both.

text: Patch Set 1:Markus,I have not looked at xls, nor at specific binary filter routines, but at the code in general.I have two reasons:1. the pre-patched code consists of a mix of sal_uInt8 and sal_uInt16;2. from previous bug fixes I remember the advise to use size_t for size() types.If it is important to ascertain that the size does not exceed the xls limit, either all types should be sal_uInt8 or a specific check should be added. I would prefer the last option and not 'count' on overflow errors.Finally, as I don't want to mix this change with the fdo40835 patch, I submitted this as a separate patch.

I would prefer the last option and not 'count' on overflow errors.Finally, as I don't want to mix this change with the fdo40835 patch, I submitted this as a separate patch.

text: Patch Set 1:No, files generated by MS Office 2010 does not  contain ';' instead they contain ':' , but user can  change the hyperlink address.If the hyperlink contains ';', MS Office 2010 is not able to open that link.i.e the hyperlink gets broken.however, MS Office is able to open .docx.But without my changes, I get an error dialog which tells that roundtrip file is corrupted & MS Office 2010 is not able to open that document.So, in order to get rid of this corruption & successfully open the roundtrip docx in MS Office 2010 this change has been proposed.
Text: Patch Set 1:No, files generated by MS Office 2010 does not  contain ';' instead they contain ':' , but user can  change the hyperlink address.If the hyperlink contains ';', MS Office 2010 is not able to open that link.i.e the hyperlink gets broken.however, MS Office is able to open .docx.But without my changes, I get an error dialog which tells that roundtrip file is corrupted & MS Office 2010 is not able to open that document.So, in order to get rid of this corruption & successfully open the roundtrip docx in MS Office 2010 this change has been proposed.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I see.The root problem on the LO side is that INetURLObject eagerly normalizes URLs, so something passed in as <file:///c;/...> gets passed out again as <file:///c%3B/...>.  Fixing this is quite a task, but eventually should be addressed.The problem with the proposed patch is that while it fixes this single problem, it may break others.  That aMustEncodeMap is used centrally in INetURLObject for all the different URI schemas, and ";" does have syntactical significance within path segments in general (e.g., in ftp URLs).  Also, would the odd behavior of MS Office 2010 be restricted to ";" vs. "%3B", or are there further characters that would need "fixing?"Also, how severe is this problem in practice?  What is the user's intent in making the URL dysfunctional by replacing ":" with ";"---is it about the user inadvertently introducing a typo?In short, I see no better fix than eventually tackling the root problem as described above.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I see.The root problem on the LO side is that INetURLObject eagerly normalizes URLs, so something passed in as <file:///c;/...> gets passed out again as <file:///c%3B/...>.  Fixing this is quite a task, but eventually should be addressed.The problem with the proposed patch is that while it fixes this single problem, it may break others.  That aMustEncodeMap is used centrally in INetURLObject for all the different URI schemas, and ";" does have syntactical significance within path segments in general (e.g., in ftp URLs).  Also, would the odd behavior of MS Office 2010 be restricted to ";" vs. "%3B", or are there further characters that would need "fixing?"Also, how severe is this problem in practice?  What is the user's intent in making the URL dysfunctional by replacing ":" with ";"---is it about the user inadvertently introducing a typo?In short, I see no better fix than eventually tackling the root problem as described above.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1Not ready yet, but now you should see something. The problem is that adding non-layout widgets as children to a dialog makes it snap into non-layout mode (for backwards compatibility) and so it breaks. If you --enable-dbgutil then you get the warning messages about this.So I mapped GtkSpinner to Throbber and converted that over for you and added a custom widget for the other case. (You can extends its "Init" to get the extra stuff it needs in there that used to go in via the ctor)
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1Not ready yet, but now you should see something. The problem is that adding non-layout widgets as children to a dialog makes it snap into non-layout mode (for backwards compatibility) and so it breaks. If you --enable-dbgutil then you get the warning messages about this.So I mapped GtkSpinner to Throbber and converted that over for you and added a custom widget for the other case. (You can extends its "Init" to get the extra stuff it needs in there that used to go in via the ctor)

You have add the bits from .component file into slideshow then too.Please uncomment+//    IMPLEMENTATION_ENTRY( TargetPropertiesCreator ),and make it work.I'd like to write unit test for this to catch such problems.And thanks for working on this, maybe there will be other possibilities to help in this area soon.
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedFirst: Please do not remove comments in such to-be-reviewed commit.Why it fails: you have removed animations/source/animcore/animcore from gb_CppunitTest_use_components, but forgot to add the new (sd) component, where you moved the code.And: For some reason you have moved something into slideshow/ too.Why is that ? text: Patch Set 2:The tests are not the right place to improve our python examples. Tests have to be maintained and should be as close to the tested code as possible. Obviously putting two additional layers between your test code and the tested code won't help in this case.I'm always happy to see more tests and despite my reluctance to more Python tests I can accept them for API tests but I'm not happy with them if we use them to test internal calc code through UNO. Actually I would be unhappy with the test as well if it would be written in C++ and use UNO to test against this problem.

text: AbandonedI'm going to pull this... I've misunderstood how the SalGraphics interface is working. GetGraphics returns a NULL if the graphics instance is being used, it pulls back the graphics instance if it released and blocks it from reuse, otherwise if there is NO graphics device at all (either released or blocked) then it creates the graphics device and then returns the newly created graphics.
Text: AbandonedI'm going to pull this... I've misunderstood how the SalGraphics interface is working. GetGraphics returns a NULL if the graphics instance is being used, it pulls back the graphics instance if it released and blocks it from reuse, otherwise if there is NO graphics device at all (either released or blocked) then it creates the graphics device and then returns the newly created graphics.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I am afraid this is not exactly what we should be doing here.  The DataChanged() is a kind of fallback in case we were subclassing Application; so that the subclass can implement its own DataChanged() and react accordingly.  [In general, please be careful when changing signature of a virtual function, as when it changes in a superclass, but not in the subclasses, it usually leads to situations that the code in subclasses is not called any more.]The VCLEVENT_APPLICATION_DATACHANGED broadcast is kind of unrelated here, it is broadcasting to the others, does not affect the application itself.I am tempted to abandon your change, sorry for that :-( - unless you think nobody is actually using or going to use the Application's DataChanged(), and in that case we should just remove it from Application for good?
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I am afraid this is not exactly what we should be doing here.  The DataChanged() is a kind of fallback in case we were subclassing Application; so that the subclass can implement its own DataChanged() and react accordingly.  [In general, please be careful when changing signature of a virtual function, as when it changes in a superclass, but not in the subclasses, it usually leads to situations that the code in subclasses is not called any more.]The VCLEVENT_APPLICATION_DATACHANGED broadcast is kind of unrelated here, it is broadcasting to the others, does not affect the application itself.I am tempted to abandon your change, sorry for that :-( - unless you think nobody is actually using or going to use the Application's DataChanged(), and in that case we should just remove it from Application for good?

text: AbandonedI am sorry, but prefer not to do this :-)  The caller of PostUserEvent is notified when the call hasn't succeeed, because in that case the PostUserEvent returns 0, so it is responsibility of the caller to judge if it was an error situation, or not - too much SAL_WARN's in not-so-much-error cases can lead to programmers actually ignoring what it is trying to tell them :-)
Text: AbandonedI am sorry, but prefer not to do this :-)  The caller of PostUserEvent is notified when the call hasn't succeeed, because in that case the PostUserEvent returns 0, so it is responsibility of the caller to judge if it was an error situation, or not - too much SAL_WARN's in not-so-much-error cases can lead to programmers actually ignoring what it is trying to tell them :-)

text: Patch Set 1:hi, now I need some help with git. So I submitted the patch via Gerrit. How can I bring it to a state in which I can fix the spelling mistakes.
Text: Patch Set 1:hi, now I need some help with git. So I submitted the patch via Gerrit. How can I bring it to a state in which I can fix the spelling mistakes.

text: Patch Set 1:Looking good - to readd it to this change, you need to run:git rebase -iThis will take you into your favourite text editor. Take the latter change (the last line) and where it says "pick" change this to "s". This "squashes" the commit into the previous commit. Save and exit the editor. At this point, you might be taken into another editor session, remove all the comments (and Gerrit changeset ID) from the commit you just squashed. Then save and exit again. It should rebase the changes into the first commit with the first commit message. Then push the change to gerrit again as you did last time.
Text: Patch Set 1:Looking good - to readd it to this change, you need to run:git rebase -iThis will take you into your favourite text editor. Take the latter change (the last line) and where it says "pick" change this to "s". This "squashes" the commit into the previous commit. Save and exit the editor. At this point, you might be taken into another editor session, remove all the comments (and Gerrit changeset ID) from the commit you just squashed. Then save and exit again. It should rebase the changes into the first commit with the first commit message. Then push the change to gerrit again as you did last time.

text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergePlease try to provide atomic changes instead of all-in-one commit.We decided to interact with Bluetooth without userÔÇÖs interaction at all. Yes, AndroidÔÇÖs guide insists on showing a dialog but in such case this dialog should be shown on *every* launch which is *extremely* annoying. The concept of ÔÇ£work and auto-do things without touching any buttons or dialogsÔÇØ is a lot better for everyone.BluetoothOperator is a layer of abstraction. For example, on Jelly Bean the BluetoothAdapter instance should be acquired the other way if you read the comment. Using your solution means replace simple call *everywhere* with something like ÔÇ£if (Build.VERSION >= JELLY_BEAN) then ... else ...ÔÇØ. Makes a little sense for me. Another layer of abstraction actually helps readability this way.I cannot review other things because the commit is really huge. Can you consider opening an issue on Bugzilla first we discuss your problems with Bluetooth first and then fixing them instead of ÔÇ£recode everythingÔÇØ?
Text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergePlease try to provide atomic changes instead of all-in-one commit.We decided to interact with Bluetooth without user脭脟脰s interaction at all. Yes, Android脭脟脰s guide insists on showing a dialog but in such case this dialog should be shown on *every* launch which is *extremely* annoying. The concept of 脭脟拢work and auto-do things without touching any buttons or dialogs脭脟脴 is a lot better for everyone.BluetoothOperator is a layer of abstraction. For example, on Jelly Bean the BluetoothAdapter instance should be acquired the other way if you read the comment. Using your solution means replace simple call *everywhere* with something like 脭脟拢if (Build.VERSION >= JELLY_BEAN) then ... else ...脭脟脴. Makes a little sense for me. Another layer of abstraction actually helps readability this way.I cannot review other things because the commit is really huge. Can you consider opening an issue on Bugzilla first we discuss your problems with Bluetooth first and then fixing them instead of 脭脟拢recode everything脭脟脴?

text: Patch Set 1:> Please try to provide atomic changes instead of all-in-one commit.I can try to split it up, but of course only if there is a chance to get the changes in (honestly: without major changes in the way BT is handled, I'd not recommend the remote to anyone)> in such case this dialog should be shown on *every* launch No, only when BT wasn't enabled already. And how often do you launch the Remote, how often do you give a talk? Once a day? Once a Week? Once a Month or even just one year at a conference?> which is *extremely* annoying.I started and used the remote for testing quite a bit, and I think hitting OK is neither extremely annoying, nor very timeconsuming.> The concept of ÔÇ£work and auto-do things without touching any buttons or dialogsÔÇØ is a lot better for everyone./That/ was a good one. The current remote* doesn't list bonded devices, I have to set the computer to be visible just to use the remote.ÔåÆ this involves more steps and clicks than just hitting "OK" directly after launching the remote (only if BT wasn't already enabled.* frequently enough kills my BT, so I have to reboot the phone to be able to turn on bluetooth again. Now /that/ is annoying.> BluetoothOperator is a layer of abstraction. For example, on Jelly Bean the BluetoothAdapter instance should be acquired the other way if you read the comment.That is only a concern once the API is completely removed and a check is needed. Until then, no problem to get rid offunciton do_stuff { return do_this(); }function do_this { reutrn call_something_else(); }function call_something_else { return A != B }> Another layer of abstraction actually helps readability this way.Having to traverse multiple files and even then multiple one-line-functions to track back a simple boolean comparison doesn't help readability at all. I find it highly annoying and irritating, like artificially obscuring what the code does by hiding it under a long chain of function calls.functions that are only called by one single other method, with no chances of being reused.You mention that aquiring the bt adapter might require version checks, but honestly: Before you use different api by checking the runtime version, you rather keep using the deprecated version that works flawlessly. > I cannot review other things because the commit is really huge.It just looks large, the changes themselves are small.> Can you consider opening an issue on Bugzilla first we discuss your problems with Bluetooth first and then fixing them instead of ÔÇ£recode everythingÔÇØ?The problems are:* not showing known (bonded) devices, forcing the user to make the computer visible* forcing a discovery on every start, on every use, that is useless for most users, as they usually use the same devices. So they are known, and after initial pairing set to   hidden, so even the search would not show result.* even doing the recovery in an endless loop* killing the BT connection when rotating the screenProbably the last one in combination with the automatically started discovery is what puts my BT adapter in a non-working state where I cannot enable it anymore and have to reboot the device.

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1Sorry, I tried to fix this up, but still doesn't work for me.Please rebase your patch against newer master, writeVMLTextFrame() got moved to DocxSdrExport, so if you want to write your two new bool variables, then you'll have to pass them as a reference to that method. text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is merged(25 inline comments)Apart from the various inline comments I have some general remarks.First, it would be good if the commit message contained what was changed and why.Second, this change breaks border handling. With the outer border now applied to the adjacent cells, applying another border to such adjacent cell effectively overwrites the outer border of the previous border. Removing the border from such cell effectively removes the outer border of the previous range.Third, the Undo handling looks dubious to me.But, I'll leave all to Moggi now ;-)
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is merged(25 inline comments)Apart from the various inline comments I have some general remarks.First, it would be good if the commit message contained what was changed and why.Second, this change breaks border handling. With the outer border now applied to the adjacent cells, applying another border to such adjacent cell effectively overwrites the outer border of the previous border. Removing the border from such cell effectively removes the outer border of the previous range.Third, the Undo handling looks dubious to me.But, I'll leave all to Moggi now ;-)

text: Patch Set 2:Patch set 2 is 'work in progress', well not so much progress at the moment ;)Notes:1. _ODF functions are saved as _ODF. FormulaCompiler::CreateStringFromToken() is not only called when saving to file, so using that function to rename _ODF functions, will rename them in the UI as well (and behave like non-_ODF function).2. when reading file, FormulaCompiler::Factor() also renames functions in qa and unit tests, giving unwanted and unjust exceptions.3. I changed behaviour of CEILING and FLOOR as I found out that CEILING(1.3;;) was accepted by MustHaveParamCount( nParamCount, 2, 3 ) in ScCeiling() resp. ScFloor(). Now empty is not translated to 0 (when this setting is enabled), but I think this should be done as preparation for the ODF1.2 compliant CEILING/FLOOR functions.
Text: Patch Set 2:Patch set 2 is 'work in progress', well not so much progress at the moment ;)Notes:1. _ODF functions are saved as _ODF. FormulaCompiler::CreateStringFromToken() is not only called when saving to file, so using that function to rename _ODF functions, will rename them in the UI as well (and behave like non-_ODF function).2. when reading file, FormulaCompiler::Factor() also renames functions in qa and unit tests, giving unwanted and unjust exceptions.3. I changed behaviour of CEILING and FLOOR as I found out that CEILING(1.3;;) was accepted by MustHaveParamCount( nParamCount, 2, 3 ) in ScCeiling() resp. ScFloor(). Now empty is not translated to 0 (when this setting is enabled), but I think this should be done as preparation for the ODF1.2 compliant CEILING/FLOOR functions.

text: Patch Set 2: This need some tweaks before it is mergedAs mentioned on the mailing list, introducing *_ODF functions in the file formats is not the way to go.Btw, you can submit draft code for gerrit review by pushing it to refs/drafts/master instead of refs/publish/master, so git push logerrit HEAD:refs/drafts/masteror if you're using the logerrit script ./logerrit submit-draftThe difference of draft is, that only the reviewer(s) you add will see the change, others don't. May be better than just having WIP in the summary and no one accidentally reviews and pushes it, though the chance with these changes here would be rare ;-)
Text: Patch Set 2: This need some tweaks before it is mergedAs mentioned on the mailing list, introducing *_ODF functions in the file formats is not the way to go.Btw, you can submit draft code for gerrit review by pushing it to refs/drafts/master instead of refs/publish/master, so git push logerrit HEAD:refs/drafts/masteror if you're using the logerrit script ./logerrit submit-draftThe difference of draft is, that only the reviewer(s) you add will see the change, others don't. May be better than just having WIP in the summary and no one accidentally reviews and pushes it, though the chance with these changes here would be rare ;-)

text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergethe static library was used until commit 45504f9ba8de2a4372193910b2cb9405f1ea896awhich is a complete mystery to me.removing the static library will probably cause the launcher object to be built as dependency of any of N Executables in desktop and that is generally an unhealthy situation; if the Executables used gb_Executable_add_exception_objects instead of the creative hack to workaround the check then gbuild would even refuse to build this.probably it would be best to revert that commit and then see what if anything actually breaks.
Text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergethe static library was used until commit 45504f9ba8de2a4372193910b2cb9405f1ea896awhich is a complete mystery to me.removing the static library will probably cause the launcher object to be built as dependency of any of N Executables in desktop and that is generally an unhealthy situation; if the Executables used gb_Executable_add_exception_objects instead of the creative hack to workaround the check then gbuild would even refuse to build this.probably it would be best to revert that commit and then see what if anything actually breaks.

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedWhile the code looks ok from a first glance (I didn't verify yet) it will not solve the problem. The IANA language tag registry does not define default scripts for languages, it only defines suppress-script for a few. For all other languages you'd still not get the script. See instdir/share/liblangtag/language-subtag-registry.xmlFurthermore, we avoid at all costs to pull in liblangtag if not necessary (hence all the internal handling of known tags in canonicalize()) because (despite that the rsc resource compiler can't use liblangtag) it needs a significant amount of time to initialize its data, which at startup would add ~10% of startup time. If VCL needed liblangtag already just to display some glyphs that would be a heavy drawback.My suggestion to solve this would be to add an extra default script field in i18nlangtag/source/isolang/isolang.cxx to aImplIsoLangEntries and aImplBcp47CountryEntries and change the lang::Locale returns of MsLangId::Conversion::*() methods to a struct of Locale and additionally a Script field. They are used only internally by LanguageTag and not part of a public API so that would be no problem. Of course doing so would need quite some changes and finding all default scripts for all known locales would be a lot of investigation work.
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedWhile the code looks ok from a first glance (I didn't verify yet) it will not solve the problem. The IANA language tag registry does not define default scripts for languages, it only defines suppress-script for a few. For all other languages you'd still not get the script. See instdir/share/liblangtag/language-subtag-registry.xmlFurthermore, we avoid at all costs to pull in liblangtag if not necessary (hence all the internal handling of known tags in canonicalize()) because (despite that the rsc resource compiler can't use liblangtag) it needs a significant amount of time to initialize its data, which at startup would add ~10% of startup time. If VCL needed liblangtag already just to display some glyphs that would be a heavy drawback.My suggestion to solve this would be to add an extra default script field in i18nlangtag/source/isolang/isolang.cxx to aImplIsoLangEntries and aImplBcp47CountryEntries and change the lang::Locale returns of MsLangId::Conversion::*() methods to a struct of Locale and additionally a Script field. They are used only internally by LanguageTag and not part of a public API so that would be no problem. Of course doing so would need quite some changes and finding all default scripts for all known locales would be a lot of investigation work.

text: Patch Set 1:"BUT, as it appears in include/sal/config.h it is also part of the SDK and extensions use it, so I guess we can't completely eliminate it and at least {osl,sal,rtl} need to live on with it. Or?"I would not mind changing include/sal/config.h to use _WIN32 and odk/settings/settings.mk to no longer set -DWIN32 in an incompatible [API CHANGE] commit.  There are no occurrences of WIN32 across odk/examples/ at least, so hopefully it is not used too widely in third party code either.  There might be third party build systems that do not use the SDK and currently do -DWIN32 "manually," but even if they are not adapted that's harmless as _WIN32 is implicitly defined by the compiler.However, there is a number of -DWIN32 in other parts of our code base (RepositoryExternal.mk, external/, redland/, soltools/) that should be audited, too.

There are no occurrences of WIN32 across odk/examples/ at least, so hopefully it is not used too widely in third party code either.  There might be third party build systems that do not use the SDK and currently do -DWIN32 "manually," but even if they are not adapted that's harmless as _WIN32 is implicitly defined by the compiler.However, there is a number of -DWIN32 in other parts of our code base (RepositoryExternal.mk, external/, redland/, soltools/) that should be audited, too.

text: Patch Set 2:This is more complicated that I thought... This already works: Dim ud as new "com.sun.star.util.Date" Dim d as Date d = DateSerial(1,2,3) ud = d*but* this does not: Dim d as Date d = DateSerial(1,2,3) aDateControl.Date = d aDateControl.DateMax = dStill have to test: aResultSet.updateDate(3, d)I don't understand the whole interplay of how a value is set to another...At a rather high level, there is:  SbiRuntime::StepPUT  SbiRuntime::StepSETCLASSand maybe others....On lower level there is:  SbxValue::operator=  SbxValue::Get  SbxValue::PutI notice that SbxValue::operator= already has special magic to automagically convert between byte array and string, so it lookedgood to add the automagic conversion from Date to com.sun.star.Date/Time there... But it is not obvious to mehow to see which object type is expected... I need to test whetherit wants a com.sun.star.util.Date, Time or DateTime.There seem to be two cases...Either *this is a SbxObject and then I should use GetClassName()Or *this is a SbUnoProperty and then I need to use something likethis->aUnoProp->Type.getTypeName()?
Text: Patch Set 2:This is more complicated that I thought... This already works: Dim ud as new "com.sun.star.util.Date" Dim d as Date d = DateSerial(1,2,3) ud = d*but* this does not: Dim d as Date d = DateSerial(1,2,3) aDateControl.Date = d aDateControl.DateMax = dStill have to test: aResultSet.updateDate(3, d)I don't understand the whole interplay of how a value is set to another...At a rather high level, there is:  SbiRuntime::StepPUT  SbiRuntime::StepSETCLASSand maybe others....On lower level there is:  SbxValue::operator=  SbxValue::Get  SbxValue::PutI notice that SbxValue::operator= already has special magic to automagically convert between byte array and string, so it lookedgood to add the automagic conversion from Date to com.sun.star.Date/Time there... But it is not obvious to mehow to see which object type is expected... I need to test whetherit wants a com.sun.star.util.Date, Time or DateTime.There seem to be two cases...Either *this is a SbxObject and then I should use GetClassName()Or *this is a SbUnoProperty and then I need to use something likethis->aUnoProp->Type.getTypeName()?

text: Patch Set 2:Well, the problem is that, when the message box pops up, the application is still in dnd mode. Visible via the dnd cursor, and the fact one has to click twice on the msg box buttons (once to leave the dnd mode, another time to actually click the button).My hunch would be, that on either mac or windows, this locks up, because we request user input in the middle of a drop operation.Are you looking into this further? If not, a workable minimal solution would be to default to *not* mess with the aspect ratio in the case of dnd (but don't show a message box to ask).
Text: Patch Set 2:Well, the problem is that, when the message box pops up, the application is still in dnd mode. Visible via the dnd cursor, and the fact one has to click twice on the msg box buttons (once to leave the dnd mode, another time to actually click the button).My hunch would be, that on either mac or windows, this locks up, because we request user input in the middle of a drop operation.Are you looking into this further? If not, a workable minimal solution would be to default to *not* mess with the aspect ratio in the case of dnd (but don't show a message box to ask).

text: Patch Set 1:While performing STring to OUString conversion, I saw some code that could be tricky but of which I have no background and so I don't know if it works as espected.I inserted a NOTE on a file suggesting a possible error.Also, the [Fill|Get]*Name can return their input value "to be filled" as a result in some cases and there are also some loops which iteratively call them without cleaning that input variable, which look quite suspicious to me.I will put some comments on that code as soon as possible.
Text: Patch Set 1:While performing STring to OUString conversion, I saw some code that could be tricky but of which I have no background and so I don't know if it works as espected.I inserted a NOTE on a file suggesting a possible error.Also, the [Fill|Get]*Name can return their input value "to be filled" as a result in some cases and there are also some loops which iteratively call them without cleaning that input variable, which look quite suspicious to me.I will put some comments on that code as soon as possible.

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedI would like to hear opinion from from the design team (Stefan) before we do this change in 4.1.I am not sure of the typical workflow with the autoplay presentations. I think about speakers that do not want to be interrupted by the LO GUI and just want to see the slides. They might be against this change.A better solution would be to fix opening the file:   + autoplay presentation when it is opened from the      command line   + edit the presentation when it is opened from LO editor      (Impress)I think that people are used to work this way, see http://www.dailygyan.com/2008/04/how-to-edit-powerpoint-show-pps-or-ppsx.html     editor

text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergeAgree with Petr here ÔÇô way back when I was still a user of AutoPlay presentations, I used them because they seemed more like standalone applications to me.I see these major uses of AutoPlay presentations:* wanting to avoid having to go through the entire presentation software in front of your audience* wanting to make things easier (e.g. think, a secretary preparing a presentation for a rather tech-illiterate boss, "just double-click this icon and it starts")* sending colleagues "funny"/"cute" slideshowsNone of these applications is really helped by leaving the application open at the end.What may be a better idea would be to add an item "Edit Presentation" to the in-presentation context menu.
Text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergeAgree with Petr here 脭脟么 way back when I was still a user of AutoPlay presentations, I used them because they seemed more like standalone applications to me.I see these major uses of AutoPlay presentations:* wanting to avoid having to go through the entire presentation software in front of your audience* wanting to make things easier (e.g. think, a secretary preparing a presentation for a rather tech-illiterate boss, "just double-click this icon and it starts")* sending colleagues "funny"/"cute" slideshowsNone of these applications is really helped by leaving the application open at the end.What may be a better idea would be to add an item "Edit Presentation" to the in-presentation context menu.

text: Patch Set 1: (4 inline comments)1) IMHO the negative year fix should go in independently of the time zone issue.3) Why should DateTimeRange contain only one time zone, as opposed to one for   the start value and one for the end value?3) You add time zone information to dates. I don't know the meaning of that.   What would it mean, how would it behave, what would it be used for?   For example, naively, one would think that combining a date with a time,   one would get a datetime. How does one get a datetime by combining   2003-05-17+05 with 23:00-06?   FWIW, SQL does not define a DATE WITH TIME ZONE type.4) I have my doubts about time-zoned time without a date.   How do you convert 20:00+00 to time zone +10?   Just "wrap around" modulo 24, i.e. make it 06:00+10?   If you answer yes to that question (that is, always compute modulo 24),   then what is the difference between 06:00+11 and 06:00-13?   The difference only makes sense if one speaks of dates...   Which says that timezones don't make sense unless we know at what date   to apply them.   FWIW, SQL defines a TIME WITH TIME ZONE TYPE, *but* here's what   the PostgreSQL documentation has to say about it:   The type time with time zone is defined by the SQL standard, but the definition exhibits properties which lead to questionable usefulness. In most cases, a combination of date, time, timestamp without time zone, and timestamp with time zone should provide a complete range of date/time functionality required by any application.   (...) we recommend using date/time types that contain both date and time when using time zones. We do not recommend using the type time with time zone (though it is supported by PostgreSQL for legacy applications and for compliance with the SQL standard).I have half a mind to add timezone *only* to DateTime and DateTimeRange,not to Date and not to Time. Note that this would more-or-less eliminateall conversion problems, and "unlock" the scenario "don't add timezoneto structs, but convert everything to UTC", since conversion of datetimevalues across timezones is AFAIK well-defined. "Convert everything to UTC"is SQL's behaviour; in SQL all non-timezoned values are assumed to be atlocal time and a date is converted to the timestamp "same date at time 00:00".Alternative approach to your "isTimezoned": have a separate struct "DateTimeTZ"?Your "isTimezoned" flag should IMHO be called "isUTC".Do we actually *need* *any* "unknown timezone / local timezone" value in memory?We could just make some assumption (UTC or local TZ) on import/parse/readand store only UTC in memory. Oh, but it would be convenient for our APIs to havethe capacity to take implicitly-localTZ values, yes.If we go the "assume that values without explicit time zone are in local time" route,then that flag should be called "isUTC".So, I've spoken of what SQL does as a reference;https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/LibreOffice4#Changes_deferred_until_4.1mentions XMLSchema-2. Let's see what it does for another reference: - It (optionally) timezones everything: date, time and datetime. - I don't see a datetimerange in it. - It understands a date as a 24-hour interval   (a DateTimeRange, from date 00:00:00.00000000 to 23:59:59.999999999 for most days,    that is except for leap seconds),    while SQL seems to consider it more like an instant, time 00:00 at that day. - A value without timezone is "unknown timezone" and not comparable   to a value with timezone, but on the other hand, section 3.2.7 also calls   untimezoned values "local values", which supports the idea that they are   "local time". But "local time" is unspecified in an interchange file format,   because the file may move from one timezone to the other.   In SQL, everything is convertible/comparable because each session has an   active "local timezone" which is used for all untimezoned values.Pragmatically, how close to XMLSchema-2 do we need to be?1) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a date with timezone?2) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a time (*not* datetime) with timezone?3) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where there can be a   datetime with timezone OR a datetime without timezone and the difference   has some semantic significance (other than "interpret value without   timezone in this timezone").4) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a datetime value without timezone and preserve unmodified as   without timezone?   The kind of scenario I'm thinking of is:   We read a datetime value without timezone from some file, and the file   does not give a context that tells us what time zone to interpret that in,   the user changes stuff, but not the part with that datetime value,   *and* when saving the file again, we need to write back the same value,   as opposed to say the UTC value of that datetime-in-local-timezone   or the same datetime value with local-timezone affixed.5) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a datetime value without timezone, do changes on it and preserve   it as without timezone?   The kind of scenario I'm thinking of is:   We read a datetime value without timezone from some file, and the file   does not give a context that tells us what time zone to interpret that in,   the user e.g. tells us "add one hour to that datetime value",   *and* when saving the file again, we need to write back the new value   as untimezoned, as opposed to say the UTC value of that   datetime-in-local-timezone or the same datetime value with local-timezone   affixed.

In most cases, a combination of date, time, timestamp without time zone, and timestamp with time zone should provide a complete range of date/time functionality required by any application. Oh, but it would be convenient for our APIs to havethe capacity to take implicitly-localTZ values, yes.If we go the "assume that values without explicit time zone are in local time" route,then that flag should be called "isUTC".So, I've spoken of what SQL does as a reference;https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/LibreOffice4#Changes_deferred_until_4.1mentions XMLSchema-2. Let's see what it does for another reference: - It (optionally) timezones everything: date, time and datetime. - I don't see a datetimerange in it. - It understands a date as a 24-hour interval   (a DateTimeRange, from date 00:00:00.00000000 to 23:59:59.999999999 for most days,    that is except for leap seconds),    while SQL seems to consider it more like an instant, time 00:00 at that day. - A value without timezone is "unknown timezone" and not comparable   to a value with timezone, but on the other hand, section 3.2.7 also calls   untimezoned values "local values", which supports the idea that they are   "local time". But "local time" is unspecified in an interchange file format,   because the file may move from one timezone to the other.   In SQL, everything is convertible/comparable because each session has an   active "local timezone" which is used for all untimezoned values.Pragmatically, how close to XMLSchema-2 do we need to be?1) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a date with timezone?2) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a time (*not* datetime) with timezone?3) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where there can be a   datetime with timezone OR a datetime without timezone and the difference   has some semantic significance (other than "interpret value without   timezone in this timezone").4) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a datetime value without timezone and preserve unmodified as   without timezone?   The kind of scenario I'm thinking of is:   We read a datetime value without timezone from some file, and the file   does not give a context that tells us what time zone to interpret that in,   the user changes stuff, but not the part with that datetime value,   *and* when saving the file again, we need to write back the same value,   as opposed to say the UTC value of that datetime-in-local-timezone   or the same datetime value with local-timezone affixed.5) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a datetime value without timezone, do changes on it and preserve   it as without timezone?   The kind of scenario I'm thinking of is:   We read a datetime value without timezone from some file, and the file   does not give a context that tells us what time zone to interpret that in,   the user e.g. tells us "add one hour to that datetime value",   *and* when saving the file again, we need to write back the new value   as untimezoned, as opposed to say the UTC value of that   datetime-in-local-timezone or the same datetime value with local-timezone   affixed.

text: Patch Set 2:>> 4) I have my doubts about time-zoned time without a date.>>     How do you convert 20:00+00 to time zone +10?>>     Just "wrap around" modulo 24, i.e. make it 06:00+10?> yes>> If you answer yes to that question (that is, always compute modulo 24),>> then what is the difference between 06:00+11 and 06:00-13?>> The difference only makes sense if one speaks of dates...>> Which says that timezones don't make sense unless we know at what date>> to apply them.> there is no difference: both denote the same set of inifinitely many instants.For the sake of the following paragraphs, I'm going to assume we want to keepthe timezone in the struct (as opposed to converting timezoned values to UTC).As far as reasonably possible, data structures should have a canonical format:Don't artificially introduce different values that denote the same. If we reallyare to consider that a time is a value in timeline quotiented by 24h interval(that is a representative of the equivalence class "all moments in the timelineseparated by 24h intervals), then we have no reason to allow (for the timezonevalue) anything overlapping. Your code currently says everything has to bebetween -840 and +840 inclusive. With this interpretation, we should makeone of the following choices: - timezone between -719 and +720 - timezone between -720 and +719 - timezone between 0 and 1439That's the logical conclusion of the interpretation you propose.What I had in mind was another interpretation (which I thinkis consistent with the SQL standard's behaviour): - a timezone region is a part of the earth surface, politically   defined, that has the same time (offset to UTC); that is   calendars and clocks agree all across this zone).   (Many specific points on the surface of the globe hop from    one timezone to another twice a year.) - a datetime is a moment in time in some timezone region. - a datetime is made of two parts, namely a date and a time. - the timezone is attached to the time part of datetime.In this interpretation, the timezone value between -840 and +840refers to a region of earth. Given two timezone regions, whetherclocks agree between these two timezones is a valid question,but not the only one and besides the point for data encoding;they are different timezone regions. E.g. timezone region +660(+11 hours) and timezone region -780 (-13 hours). Clocks agreeacross these two timezones, but calendars don't, so they aredifferent timezone regions where clocks just happen to agree.We could make the following valid choice / observation:XMLSchema-2 has fucked up semantics on time / date / ...,but for adherence to standards and interoperability, we"need" to adhere to it rather than doing something morecorrect.>> Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we>> need to import or export a date with timezone?>> dunno about OOXMLThen bring (one of) our resident expert(s) in this discussion.> (...) ODF at least has numerous attributes of type date.> it says nothing about time zones so by referencing the XMLSchema-2> types they are allowed _everywhere_ a non-time-zoned date is allowed.So basically you are saying our hands are tied, we need to cover everythingXMLSchema-2 allows. Taking your word on that, further discussion on thefollowing points is pointless, we need - timezoned date in the range -840 to +840 - timezoned time in the range -840 to +840 - timezoned datetime in the range -840 to +840 - untimezoned date, time and datetime. - Base will have to map these concepts to the   SQL world to the best of possibilities. E.g., ignore   (drop) the timezone on timezoned dates, or   throw an exception when given a timezoned date   (require only untimezoned date).The remaining decision to be made is whether the UNO structsshould encode the timezone explicitly or be "all timezoned valuesare in UTC time". The issue is muddled a bit because the UNOstructs are both our internal working structures and our "external"(scripting) API date types. I'll discuss the two uses separately.I'm really torn on this issue. Seeing LibreOffice as a programmingplatform, the UNO structs are the data types of our "standardlibrary". By putting explicit timezone in the structs, we makethe programmer's life easier because (s)he does not have todeal with converting to UTC before making an API call. We alsomake hir life more difficult because (s)he has to deal with non-UTCtime for each *result* of an API call.Here's what I would consider optimal: - All our (date)time API calls take and return UTC (date)time or   untimezoned (date)time. That is, our (date)time structure   does not have a timezone in it. It is UTC or untimezoned. - We provide a UNO service that provides utility functions that   1) convert between timezoned (date)time on the one hand       and untimezoned time in a caller-provided timezone on       the other hand (*two* incoming arguments: a (date)time       *and* an offset to UTC).   2) convert between timezoned (date)time on the one hand       and untimezoned time in local timezone on the other hand       (*one* incoming argument: a (date)time). - Hmm... As an alternative / complement to the above service,   the (date)time struct constructors takes an optional argument   that says "the values I'm giving are UTC / localtime / untimezoned"   (we add a new enum with these three values), and the constructor   makes the appropriate localtime->UTC conversion.   Can we do that in UNO? I'm unsure. Actually, I don't expect so.The spanner in the works, and the reason I'm torn, is timezoned dates.They don't fit the above schema. I hate them. For timezoned dates,we *have* to include an explicit timezone in the struct, or expect thatcode will store timezoned dates as a pair of values (a date and anoffset) - bleh. This gives us an inconsistent interface between dateon one hand and (date)time on the other hand.So, the choice boils down to: - inconsistent, but best for (date)time: use UTC for timezoned data.   explicit timezone for timezoned date. - consistent, but unnecessarily annoying for (date)time: add explicit   timezone everywhere. Provide a UNO service that answers the   question "is this the same point in time"? (that is, semantic equality)Do we *really* *really* need timezoned dates, or are they a bugin the ODF specification?Now, I turn to our internal use. IMHO, untimezoned values should justbe incomparable to timezoned values. Throw an error if it comes up.The user of the values should "know" / decide what to do: - strip / discard timezone - convert to/from localtime - convert to/from UTC time - throw an error - ...In particular, different file formats may have different requirements.Different parts of code may have different requirements. Don't forceanything on them. Provide utility functions to do the conversion andthat's it.Having *two* sets of structs (one for timezoned and one for untimezoned)has the advantage that nobody will "naively" try to compare them...IMHO it fits this model better. No need to introduce an exception for"incomparable date/time/datetime value" and no need to handlethat exception everywhere.

ODF at least has numerous attributes of type date.> it says nothing about time zones so by referencing the XMLSchema-2> types they are allowed _everywhere_ a non-time-zoned date is allowed.So basically you are saying our hands are tied, we need to cover everythingXMLSchema-2 allows. Taking your word on that, further discussion on thefollowing points is pointless, we need - timezoned date in the range -840 to +840 - timezoned time in the range -840 to +840 - timezoned datetime in the range -840 to +840 - untimezoned date, time and datetime. - Base will have to map these concepts to the   SQL world to the best of possibilities. E.g., ignore   (drop) the timezone on timezoned dates, or   throw an exception when given a timezoned date   (require only untimezoned date).The remaining decision to be made is whether the UNO structsshould encode the timezone explicitly or be "all timezoned valuesare in UTC time". The issue is muddled a bit because the UNOstructs are both our internal working structures and our "external"(scripting) API date types. I'll discuss the two uses separately.I'm really torn on this issue. Seeing LibreOffice as a programmingplatform, the UNO structs are the data types of our "standardlibrary". By putting explicit timezone in the structs, we makethe programmer's life easier because (s)he does not have todeal with converting to UTC before making an API call. We alsomake hir life more difficult because (s)he has to deal with non-UTCtime for each *result* of an API call.Here's what I would consider optimal: - All our (date)time API calls take and return UTC (date)time or   untimezoned (date)time. That is, our (date)time structure   does not have a timezone in it. It is UTC or untimezoned. - We provide a UNO service that provides utility functions that   1) convert between timezoned (date)time on the one hand       and untimezoned time in a caller-provided timezone on       the other hand (*two* incoming arguments: a (date)time       *and* an offset to UTC).   2) convert between timezoned (date)time on the one hand       and untimezoned time in local timezone on the other hand       (*one* incoming argument: a (date)time). - Hmm... As an alternative / complement to the above service,   the (date)time struct constructors takes an optional argument   that says "the values I'm giving are UTC / localtime / untimezoned"   (we add a new enum with these three values), and the constructor   makes the appropriate localtime->UTC conversion.   Can we do that in UNO? I'm unsure. Actually, I don't expect so.The spanner in the works, and the reason I'm torn, is timezoned dates.They don't fit the above schema. I hate them. For timezoned dates,we *have* to include an explicit timezone in the struct, or expect thatcode will store timezoned dates as a pair of values (a date and anoffset) - bleh. This gives us an inconsistent interface between dateon one hand and (date)time on the other hand.So, the choice boils down to: - inconsistent, but best for (date)time: use UTC for timezoned data.   explicit timezone for timezoned date. - consistent, but unnecessarily annoying for (date)time: add explicit   timezone everywhere. Provide a UNO service that answers the   question "is this the same point in time"? (that is, semantic equality)Do we *really* *really* need timezoned dates, or are they a bugin the ODF specification?Now, I turn to our internal use. IMHO, untimezoned values should justbe incomparable to timezoned values. Throw an error if it comes up.The user of the values should "know" / decide what to do: - strip / discard timezone - convert to/from localtime - convert to/from UTC time - throw an error - ...In particular, different file formats may have different requirements.Different parts of code may have different requirements. Don't forceanything on them. Provide utility functions to do the conversion andthat's it.Having *two* sets of structs (one for timezoned and one for untimezoned)has the advantage that nobody will "naively" try to compare them...IMHO it fits this model better. No need to introduce an exception for"incomparable date/time/datetime value" and no need to handlethat exception everywhere.

That is, our (date)time structure>    does not have a timezone in it. It is UTC or untimezoned.but this would mean that (to be able to preserve user-supplied time-zoneoffsets) everywhere you want to store a time-zoned value you need anadditional Property to store an explicit time-zone if it isn'tcontained in the value itself.>  - Hmm... text: Patch Set 2: This need some tweaks before it is mergedSo, unless one of you has something else to say, I think the discussion has outrun its course.I vote -1, but I can be overruled.I remain convinced that we are designing a flawin our API / cross-platform programming platformby catering only to these two use cases: - combination of timepoint and geographical location (timezone) - date and/or time in a undefined/unknown/... timezoneand not catering to the COMMON use case: - timepoint (purely and alone)In some way, even if the internal LibreOffice code only has usefor the two first usecases, our programming API should offera full and maximally convenient interface to our users(programmers using our scripting API).
Text: Patch Set 2: This need some tweaks before it is mergedSo, unless one of you has something else to say, I think the discussion has outrun its course.I vote -1, but I can be overruled.I remain convinced that we are designing a flawin our API / cross-platform programming platformby catering only to these two use cases: - combination of timepoint and geographical location (timezone) - date and/or time in a undefined/unknown/... timezoneand not catering to the COMMON use case: - timepoint (purely and alone)In some way, even if the internal LibreOffice code only has usefor the two first usecases, our programming API should offera full and maximally convenient interface to our users(programmers using our scripting API).

text: Patch Set 2:I don't think it makes sense for the DateTimeWithTimezone struct's DateTimeInTZ member to have the possibility of having different IsTimeZoned values.What about:1) DateTimeBase (or RawDateTime?) -> a copy of the current DateTime: NanoSeconds, Seconds, Minutes, Hours, Day, Month, Year2) DateTime: derives from DateTimeBase, adds IsTimeZoned bool member.3) DateTimeWithTimezone has a "DateTimeBase DateTimeInTZ;" member and a "short TimeZone;" member.I've thought long and hard about the "store in UTC" vs "store in localtime" issue.IMO, "store in UTC" is preferable:1) It aligns our API with what (AFAIK) most APIs do.2) Since our "store in localtime" is really "store in what was the local timezone at the moment that LibreOffice started", and not "store in what the OS tells you is the local timezone right now", we need to tell our users (programmers/scripters using our API) to use _LibreOffice's_ notion of localtime (that is, offset to UTC that defines localtime), rather than the system one's (and provide a UNO service that provides the offset). I'm rather worried about creeping bugs in the whole LibreOffice/extension ecosystem where scripts / extensions will blindly copy a UNO DateTime into a system structure (such as e.g. in Python a time.struct_time) and pass it to a library expecting local time (such as Python's time.mktime), and get (sometimes) wrong results.This is a concern "only" in long-running processes (or more precisely, processes that keep running across a DST change, the computer travelling, etc), but IMO there are several legitimate scenarios where this happens: - People that (like me) leave their computer on in the night with stuff left for the next day still open - LibreOffice quickstarter on Windows, probably? - A LibreOffice process running on a server (with --headless), and other programs / scripts connect to it through URP - laptops & pocket computers (e.g. smartphones, tablets, ...) put to hibernation before travel by plane and woken thereafter3) More generally, "store in startup locatime" forces our users to deal with a *third* timezone; they already have to deal with UTC and with localtime-as-understood-by-system, now we introduce them a different timezone that is nearly, but not quite the same as the latter, namely localtime-as-understood-by-UNO.4) "store in startup localtime" makes (serialisation of) our UNO DateTime struct NOT SUITABLE for interchange, EVEN ON THE SAME MACHINE.What problem were you trying to solve by advocating "store in localtime"? From your email:1) (...) VCL does not have a DateTime widget, but a DateField and a TimeField (...) cannot transparently convert from UTC to local timezone, because they would need both date+time to do that.Well, yes. As I understand things, these widgets only deal (and until they are changed, *can* *only* deal) with Time values with IsTimeZoned==false. If some other code reads their Value property, it is then that code's responsibility to interpret that as in a specific timezone.One could argue that since legacy code will generally blissfully ignore the IsTimeZoned member, it gives better backwards compatibility. This assumes that older OO.org/LibreOffice usually served local time in css.util.(Date)Time, which is not obvious to me. It seems to be the case in *some* places, but not in others, so we need a general cleanup anyway. OOXMLDocPropHandler::GetDateTimeFromW3CDTF is an example of a codepath that puts UTC in a UNO DateTime.Any other reason for "store in startup-time localtime"?

I'm rather worried about creeping bugs in the whole LibreOffice/extension ecosystem where scripts / extensions will blindly copy a UNO DateTime into a system structure (such as e.g. in Python a time.struct_time) and pass it to a library expecting local time (such as Python's time.mktime), and get (sometimes) wrong results.This is a concern "only" in long-running processes (or more precisely, processes that keep running across a DST change, the computer travelling, etc), but IMO there are several legitimate scenarios where this happens: - People that (like me) leave their computer on in the night with stuff left for the next day still open - LibreOffice quickstarter on Windows, probably? - A LibreOffice process running on a server (with --headless), and other programs / scripts connect to it through URP - laptops & pocket computers (e.g. smartphones, tablets, ...) put to hibernation before travel by plane and woken thereafter3) More generally, "store in startup locatime" forces our users to deal with a *third* timezone; they already have to deal with UTC and with localtime-as-understood-by-system, now we introduce them a different timezone that is nearly, but not quite the same as the latter, namely localtime-as-understood-by-UNO.4) "store in startup localtime" makes (serialisation of) our UNO DateTime struct NOT SUITABLE for interchange, EVEN ON THE SAME MACHINE.What problem were you trying to solve by advocating "store in localtime"? From your email:1) (...) VCL does not have a DateTime widget, but a DateField and a TimeField (...) cannot transparently convert from UTC to local timezone, because they would need both date+time to do that.Well, yes. As I understand things, these widgets only deal (and until they are changed, *can* *only* deal) with Time values with IsTimeZoned==false. If some other code reads their Value property, it is then that code's responsibility to interpret that as in a specific timezone.One could argue that since legacy code will generally blissfully ignore the IsTimeZoned member, it gives better backwards compatibility. This assumes that older OO.org/LibreOffice usually served local time in css.util.(Date)Time, which is not obvious to me. It seems to be the case in *some* places, but not in others, so we need a general cleanup anyway. OOXMLDocPropHandler::GetDateTimeFromW3CDTF is an example of a codepath that puts UTC in a UNO DateTime.Any other reason for "store in startup-time localtime"?

text: Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)> In lcl_ConvertTimeZone() in sax/source/tools/converter.cxx, > you are attempting to convert times between timezones. > I don't think this can be done safely without access to a > DST (Daylight Savings Time) database. It depends what you call "timezone". If it is something like "Europe/Amsterdam", that is "the time in Amsterdam", then yes, DST matters. But here, the notion of timezone is just an offset from UTC. That is, we consider that Amsterdam *changes* timezone twice per year. In this case, sure, we can freely / safely convert, we just have to subtract the offset.
Text: Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)> In lcl_ConvertTimeZone() in sax/source/tools/converter.cxx, > you are attempting to convert times between timezones. > I don't think this can be done safely without access to a > DST (Daylight Savings Time) database. It depends what you call "timezone". If it is something like "Europe/Amsterdam", that is "the time in Amsterdam", then yes, DST matters. But here, the notion of timezone is just an offset from UTC. That is, we consider that Amsterdam *changes* timezone twice per year. In this case, sure, we can freely / safely convert, we just have to subtract the offset.

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedAs already discussed elsewhere, I still think this is not needed and it is ultimately the use cases requiring a static empty string that should to be cleaned up rather.But if this were to be included, it needs fixing:* The sal library must only export C functions, not C++ ones.* All entities exported by the sal library must be listed in sal.map.* @since tags are missing.* A C++ function should be placed in a namespace, not use an "rtl_..." name.* Using "(void)" as parameter list of a C++ function is frowned upon.
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedAs already discussed elsewhere, I still think this is not needed and it is ultimately the use cases requiring a static empty string that should to be cleaned up rather.But if this were to be included, it needs fixing:* The sal library must only export C functions, not C++ ones.* All entities exported by the sal library must be listed in sal.map.* @since tags are missing.* A C++ function should be placed in a namespace, not use an "rtl_..." name.* Using "(void)" as parameter list of a C++ function is frowned upon.

text: Patch Set 1:1946794a is a mechanical removal of rtl:: prefixes, so it can't introduce new code. Ironically, since this function gets inlined, replacing that static OUString with plain "" actually reduces the size of the .o by about 3%.Without a proof otherwise I consider the empty string pattern to be just an ugly hack for whatever historical reason, similar to RTL_CONSTASCII_USTRINGPARAM, and I don't consider it worth it.
