text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is merged"if you look at rtl_uString_new() (sal/rtl/strtmp.cxx around 1130), then there already is a global empty string."This looks to me like it is a global empty rtl_uString, not a global empty OUString. The patterns you suggest look like they create a fresh OUString each time, with always the same pData member.How much is saved by having a global OUString is unclear to me.I'm worried that the new function returns a non-const reference. Unless I'm mistaken, this means that a caller can modify this OUString and then all other callers will get a non-empty string! It should return a const reference.While you are at it, make the static variable a const, also.

text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergeWith the caveat that I presume the intent is not code 'cleaning', but doxygenification...two things:1/ random changing of // into //< or /// is not helping if that does not fit with how doxygen actually work... for instance, inside the implementation of a function I wonder what is intended2/ if you are going to tackle the very valuable goal of improving the doxygen documentation of a module, then stick to one and do it starting from the logical top (making sure the file/classes are documented)then work your way through the public header section, and eventually the private header section...Do not just randomly change a line or two here and there.. especially across completely unrelated source file.Note that this is much more work than it seems, since useful documentation require that you actually read and understand the class you are documenting... if it was as simple of a mechanical s@//@//<@ then we would have written a script to do so already.

text: Patch Set 4: No scoreI am sorry that it takes so long, but I am about to write down my doctoral thesis at the moment so there is a shortening on time...I just found out how to create menus but I still need to find the mechanism that un-grays them. Work is in progress.But I dislike the idea of a popup because that would mean to block the user with a question any time he pastes on selection. You said you were confused (or at least, you were confused) that when pasting from draw results in an overwrite while pasting from writer removes the selection first. That is the idea which was build in before that the program THINKS FOR YOU, because you perhaps dont want to overwrite when pasting from the same program but you perhaps want to. But programs should not think because they are stupid, and if they are thinking based on wrong assumptions they are seen as doing erratic behavior. There HAS to be another menu point that explicitly offers you that option. Even if I have to hide it in some sub-menu. I am going to finish this. Perhaps this weekend.

text: Patch Set 1:Not sure if I like this as it perpetuates the misconception that Calc, Writer, Impress etc would be separate "applications". Sure, anybody who works on the code a bit more, or is capable of checking what processes are running in what situations, will notice that this isn't the case, but still.On the other hand, I do like it *if* this is supposed to turn into something that can be used through --disable-base to also bypass *build* of for instance all database-related functionality in *all* aspects of LO, i.e. what the currently stalled --disable-database-connectivity hack was supposed to to.
Text: Patch Set 1:Not sure if I like this as it perpetuates the misconception that Calc, Writer, Impress etc would be separate "applications". Sure, anybody who works on the code a bit more, or is capable of checking what processes are running in what situations, will notice that this isn't the case, but still.On the other hand, I do like it *if* this is supposed to turn into something that can be used through --disable-base to also bypass *build* of for instance all database-related functionality in *all* aspects of LO, i.e. what the currently stalled --disable-database-connectivity hack was supposed to to.

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedI agree with Tor's concerns - the idea that you can disable eg. charting, or calc - and still be able to load documents is -seriously- poisonous: it essentially cannot be done reliably -nor- are we interested in fixing the bugs.Last time I discussed this with you; I believe I mentioned that (from my perspective) this would only be acceptable in master with some serious warnings. As soon as a single one of these disable options is used we need to:* remove any versioning information from Help->About - and replace it with some scary string: "un-supportable version configured - this product is missing key functionality and will not work"  [ might do it ].* display a huge warning at the end of configure:  "You disabled some pieces of LibreOffice - you are now running an un-supported configuration against which we are not interested in receiving bug reports, you are on your own. Please, under no circumstances package or distribute  this sort of build, it will lead only to you getting a very hard stare."* Preferably add some form of interactive confirmation of this during the build to make it even harder for packagers to do this: a simple "hit enter to continue" followed by a 'read' statement might do it at the end of configure ;-)Anyhow - at least with that - if someone has shipped that - we can detect and ignore them more easily, and (I hope) packagers will not be so foolish as to do this.How does that sound ? :-)

As soon as a single one of these disable options is used we need to:* remove any versioning information from Help->About - and replace it with some scary string: "un-supportable version configured - this product is missing key functionality and will not work"  [ might do it ].* display a huge warning at the end of configure:  "You disabled some pieces of LibreOffice - you are now running an un-supported configuration against which we are not interested in receiving bug reports, you are on your own. Please, under no circumstances package or distribute  this sort of build, it will lead only to you getting a very hard stare."* Preferably add some form of interactive confirmation of this during the build to make it even harder for packagers to do this: a simple "hit enter to continue" followed by a 'read' statement might do it at the end of configure ;-)Anyhow - at least with that - if someone has shipped that - we can detect and ignore them more easily, and (I hope) packagers will not be so foolish as to do this.How does that sound ? :-)

text: Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveAs already expressed elsewhere:http://nabble.documentfoundation.org/Master-branch-now-requires-liborcus-0-5-0-or-higher-tp4049684p4051339.htmlI am wary of spreading the tree of build scenarios even further. Its not as if we dont have enough work with the existing ones. However, with big-fat-red-warnings suggested by Michael, I think this is acceptable. After all Lionels point stands: Distros are doing it, so it is done already -- and _if_ its done, the right place is upstream, not some packaging hack.Oh, one more thing: This should not only get a warning in the binary, but also big one at the end of ./configure, saying that it is an "experimental and unsupported build, use at own risk ...".E.g. subsequentchecks will obviously fail with partial builds, and it not the job of those maintaining those tests to fix that up, but must be part of the work on this feature (as is helping out unsuspecting newcomers accidentally enabling this and asking for help on the list or IRC) before it can move anywhere from "experimental and unsupported".

Its not as if we dont have enough work with the existing ones. However, with big-fat-red-warnings suggested by Michael, I think this is acceptable. After all Lionels point stands: Distros are doing it, so it is done already -- and _if_ its done, the right place is upstream, not some packaging hack.Oh, one more thing: This should not only get a warning in the binary, but also big one at the end of ./configure, saying that it is an "experimental and unsupported build, use at own risk ...".E.g. subsequentchecks will obviously fail with partial builds, and it not the job of those maintaining those tests to fix that up, but must be part of the work on this feature (as is helping out unsuspecting newcomers accidentally enabling this and asking for help on the list or IRC) before it can move anywhere from "experimental and unsupported".

text: Patch Set 2:Initially I thought that discard-cancel-save was the order on GNOME as well, but when searching for where the GNOME VS KDE/Windows difference is implemented in vcl, I could not find it. Then I checked in my SLED VM (admittedly running GNOME2) that at least 3.6 had save-discard-cancel order on GNOME as well, so hopefully there is simply no platform logic needed here. But maybe I'm wrong. ;-)
Text: Patch Set 2:Initially I thought that discard-cancel-save was the order on GNOME as well, but when searching for where the GNOME VS KDE/Windows difference is implemented in vcl, I could not find it. Then I checked in my SLED VM (admittedly running GNOME2) that at least 3.6 had save-discard-cancel order on GNOME as well, so hopefully there is simply no platform logic needed here. But maybe I'm wrong. ;-)

text: Patch Set 2: Do not mergea) The "close without saving"-"cancel"-"save" order was actually intentional, cause I'm using GNOME e.g. fire up gedit or glade and make a change and close without saving and that's the order there. It always bugged me that our order was different.b) We don't currently have particular per-platform button ordering anywhere AFAIK, but it would not be hard to add it now, at least for the MessageDialog buttonbox. i.e. switch off Application::GetDesktopEnvironment in and use reorderWithinParent based off their types/idsLeave it with me and I'll cook up something tomorrow to try and keep everyone happy by following the current desktop environment default ordering.
Text: Patch Set 2: Do not mergea) The "close without saving"-"cancel"-"save" order was actually intentional, cause I'm using GNOME e.g. fire up gedit or glade and make a change and close without saving and that's the order there. It always bugged me that our order was different.b) We don't currently have particular per-platform button ordering anywhere AFAIK, but it would not be hard to add it now, at least for the MessageDialog buttonbox. i.e. switch off Application::GetDesktopEnvironment in and use reorderWithinParent based off their types/idsLeave it with me and I'll cook up something tomorrow to try and keep everyone happy by following the current desktop environment default ordering.

text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergeWe don't want it to open *every* time after exporting. That would be hugely annoying. fdo#37222 says "*Possibility* to open exported PDF in a simple way immediately after export required". So presumably we want an option on the PDF export dialog to indicate whether the user want it opened in the default PDF-viewing application right after export or not.
Text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergeWe don't want it to open *every* time after exporting. So presumably we want an option on the PDF export dialog to indicate whether the user want it opened in the default PDF-viewing application right after export or not.

text: Patch Set 1:Haven't really looked at anything here in depth, but one thing to note is that on Mac OS X native UNO components in extensions expect to find the URE libraries via @executable_path/urelibs/ paths.  (Where the relevant executables include, but are not necessarily limited to, "uno" from URE and "soffice".)  No longer providing those paths would thus be an incompatible change that can break existing extensions.
Text: Patch Set 1:Haven't really looked at anything here in depth, but one thing to note is that on Mac OS X native UNO components in extensions expect to find the URE libraries via @executable_path/urelibs/ paths.  (Where the relevant executables include, but are not necessarily limited to, "uno" from URE and "soffice".)  No longer providing those paths would thus be an incompatible change that can break existing extensions.

text: Patch Set 1:We already moved the zoo of mi, li, ss, si, lx ... suffixes to "lo". IIRC I wanted to drop the suffix completely back then, but somehow we ended with "lo". So before dropping it, maybe digging in the mailing list to see the reasoning?As all uses of this are in CXX and none in headers, and the dynamic loading of a lib isnt something we do a million times, how about dropping the macro voodoo complete and simply use a plain old function that concats some good old strings?
Text: Patch Set 1:We already moved the zoo of mi, li, ss, si, lx ... suffixes to "lo". IIRC I wanted to drop the suffix completely back then, but somehow we ended with "lo". So before dropping it, maybe digging in the mailing list to see the reasoning?As all uses of this are in CXX and none in headers, and the dynamic loading of a lib isnt something we do a million times, how about dropping the macro voodoo complete and simply use a plain old function that concats some good old strings?

text: Patch Set 1:Hi Tor,The remove-and-rebuild test is indeed the criteria that I'm using. There's too many files to check by hand so a automated or at least semi-automated approach is necessary.Anyway, thanks for the comments! I hadn't thought about indirect inclusion. How about this refined approach:For each .cxx file,1) Use the brute-force approach to find candidate headers for removal, and use "g++ -H" to dump out a full list of all included headers 2) If a candidate header shows up *once* in the list from g++ -H, it's definitely unnecessary and we remove it. If it shows up more than once (via indirect inclusion), then we leave it alone for now.This should give a smaller list of includes to remove, or in the case of no indirect inclusions, the same list.Are there any other pitfalls that are worth looking out for? Cheers,Michael
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Tor,The remove-and-rebuild test is indeed the criteria that I'm using. There's too many files to check by hand so a automated or at least semi-automated approach is necessary.Anyway, thanks for the comments! I hadn't thought about indirect inclusion. How about this refined approach:For each .cxx file,1) Use the brute-force approach to find candidate headers for removal, and use "g++ -H" to dump out a full list of all included headers 2) If a candidate header shows up *once* in the list from g++ -H, it's definitely unnecessary and we remove it. If it shows up more than once (via indirect inclusion), then we leave it alone for now.This should give a smaller list of includes to remove, or in the case of no indirect inclusions, the same list.Are there any other pitfalls that are worth looking out for? Cheers,Michael

text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergeSorry, no. The assert is there for a reason. It is *good* to use lots of assertions in the code. We certainly don't want to remove them. In a non-debug build that assert() expands to nothing, and thus to the compiler it seems that s is unused.So the correct fix is to either make the compiler ignore the unusedness of s by adding a   (void) s;   statement, or replace s with the expression that is assigned to it inside the assert().
Text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergeSorry, no. The assert is there for a reason. It is *good* to use lots of assertions in the code. We certainly don't want to remove them. In a non-debug build that assert() expands to nothing, and thus to the compiler it seems that s is unused.So the correct fix is to either make the compiler ignore the unusedness of s by adding a   (void) s;   statement, or replace s with the expression that is assigned to it inside the assert().

text: Patch Set 1:Is there a reason why you see the need for python unit tests? When evaluating the options for our unit testing frameworks we also evaluated the use of python to write our tests and decide against it for several reasons including the problems while debugging the tests.I'm a bit concerned with adding a new language for testing the c++ code. We have already the java test which go through the uno java bridge and it turned out to be a real pain to maintain these tests.Personally I prefer to keep tests in the same language as the code that should be tested to make it easier to maintain them.
Text: Patch Set 1:Is there a reason why you see the need for python unit tests? When evaluating the options for our unit testing frameworks we also evaluated the use of python to write our tests and decide against it for several reasons including the problems while debugging the tests.I'm a bit concerned with adding a new language for testing the c++ code. We have already the java test which go through the uno java bridge and it turned out to be a real pain to maintain these tests.Personally I prefer to keep tests in the same language as the code that should be tested to make it easier to maintain them.

text: Patch Set 1:Stephan, LO targeting a version > 1.5 does not need to change jvmfwk because newer java versions can ALWAYS consume older class files, so regardless of the version we are targeting, jvmfwk can continue to produce class files tagged with the 1.5 version.
Text: Patch Set 1:Stephan, LO targeting a version > 1.5 does not need to change jvmfwk because newer java versions can ALWAYS consume older class files, so regardless of the version we are targeting, jvmfwk can continue to produce class files tagged with the 1.5 version.

text: Patch Set 1: No scoreStephan, then I say we should just remove that configure mechanism. If we say we support 1.5+, then we should just unconditionally generate 1.5-compatible class files.People keep getting confused anyhow, thinking that they have to set the configure flag to match their currently installed version of java.
Text: Patch Set 1: No scoreStephan, then I say we should just remove that configure mechanism. If we say we support 1.5+, then we should just unconditionally generate 1.5-compatible class files.People keep getting confused anyhow, thinking that they have to set the configure flag to match their currently installed version of java.

text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisAre you sure that closing a listen socket on linux willget you out of an accept on another thread ?http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2486335/wake-up-thread-blocked-on-accept-callI have used signal (SIGUSR1/2), or the work around that your patch remove in the past myself... and since that was also coded there, I'm enclined to think that closing a listening socket from another thread might not be a reliable way to exit from the accept block.But maybe that 'bug' in linux is not there anymore andone can rely on close() doing the obvious... But I would not _assume_ that it is true, since clearly at some point it was not.
Text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisAre you sure that closing a listen socket on linux willget you out of an accept on another thread ?http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2486335/wake-up-thread-blocked-on-accept-callI have used signal (SIGUSR1/2), or the work around that your patch remove in the past myself... and since that was also coded there, I'm enclined to think that closing a listening socket from another thread might not be a reliable way to exit from the accept block.But maybe that 'bug' in linux is not there anymore andone can rely on close() doing the obvious... But I would not _assume_ that it is true, since clearly at some point it was not.

text: Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)Lionel:Sorry, I made a mistake with gerrit patch."thought you might be interested in this one. What Noel proposed could be very useful indeed but could there be cases where we do want specific treatment if first parameter NULL? (and so the NULL argument should be dealt before calling macros SQL_IS_RULE and others)"
Text: Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)Lionel:Sorry, I made a mistake with gerrit patch."thought you might be interested in this one. What Noel proposed could be very useful indeed but could there be cases where we do want specific treatment if first parameter NULL? (and so the NULL argument should be dealt before calling macros SQL_IS_RULE and others)"

text: Patch Set 1:In this specific case and with the current SQL grammar, pParamRef cannot be NULL: a general_set_fct has at least four children (and in particular strictly more than two), so pParamRef has been initialised with: pParamRef = pColumnRef->getChild(nColumnRefPos);That's too subtle for coverity (and possibly warrants at least a comment).I'm not opposed to adding a specific NULLness check, which would future-proof the code a bit against changes in the grammar.Adding the NULLness check to the macro looks good to me from a safety POV; it could make the code in general a bit slower, but I don't think the impact would be significant enough that anybody would care.
Text: Patch Set 1:In this specific case and with the current SQL grammar, pParamRef cannot be NULL: a general_set_fct has at least four children (and in particular strictly more than two), so pParamRef has been initialised with: pParamRef = pColumnRef->getChild(nColumnRefPos);That's too subtle for coverity (and possibly warrants at least a comment).I'm not opposed to adding a specific NULLness check, which would future-proof the code a bit against changes in the grammar.Adding the NULLness check to the macro looks good to me from a safety POV; it could make the code in general a bit slower, but I don't think the impact would be significant enough that anybody would care.

text: Patch Set 1: AbandonedThank you Lionel for your feedback.I'm really hesitating about all this, the more I think about this the more I consider the check in SQL_IS_RULE like equivalent to hide the problem. I suppose I must be wrong but I prefer to abandon this patch.
Text: Patch Set 1: AbandonedThank you Lionel for your feedback.I'm really hesitating about all this, the more I think about this the more I consider the check in SQL_IS_RULE like equivalent to hide the problem. I suppose I must be wrong but I prefer to abandon this patch.

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedcss.awt.grid.GridColumn appears to be a confused attempt at creating a service for something that isn't.  (Objects that implement XGridColumn are apparently obtained via XGridColumnModel.createColumn, not by instantiating them at the global service factory).  Better mark it deprecated than converting it to new-style.css.awt.grid.DefaultGridColumnModel looks OK.
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedcss.awt.grid.GridColumn appears to be a confused attempt at creating a service for something that isn't.  (Objects that implement XGridColumn are apparently obtained via XGridColumnModel.createColumn, not by instantiating them at the global service factory).  Better mark it deprecated than converting it to new-style.css.awt.grid.DefaultGridColumnModel looks OK.

text: Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)Hmmm, if we are already customizing the categories, I wonder if we should rename it from 'verified' to 'tinderbox', as the 'default workflow' proposed by the gerrit authors uses 'verified' very different -- for manual testing of a fix: http://source.android.com/source/life-of-a-patch.htmlJust some random rambling as I dont know how much additional work that is, but it might spare newcomer to LibreOffice some confusion (esp. if they are used other customs from other projects).
Text: Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)Hmmm, if we are already customizing the categories, I wonder if we should rename it from 'verified' to 'tinderbox', as the 'default workflow' proposed by the gerrit authors uses 'verified' very different -- for manual testing of a fix: http://source.android.com/source/life-of-a-patch.htmlJust some random rambling as I dont know how much additional work that is, but it might spare newcomer to LibreOffice some confusion (esp. if they are used other customs from other projects).

text: Patch Set 2:'VRIF' is generic category, i. e. you can verify by a tinderbox, or you can verify manually.If you introduce new category: TNDB for Tinderbox, then both have to be positive: VRIF & TNDB.What Norbert come up with is to have the follow values for VRIF -2,-1,0,+1,+2And let gerrit buildbot verification only vote -1,+1,+2, so that the developer still can overwrite the failure (-1) with his +2, in case he thinks it was false negative.
Text: Patch Set 2:'VRIF' is generic category, i. e. you can verify by a tinderbox, or you can verify manually.If you introduce new category: TNDB for Tinderbox, then both have to be positive: VRIF & TNDB.What Norbert come up with is to have the follow values for VRIF -2,-1,0,+1,+2And let gerrit buildbot verification only vote -1,+1,+2, so that the developer still can overwrite the failure (-1) with his +2, in case he thinks it was false negative.

text: Patch Set 2:My proposal was rather to have no 'verified' field as other gerrit installations use 'verified' in the sense it is used on e.g. bugzilla: 'I have run the application and can confirm the bug is gone with this.' -- which is not what our tinderboxes do (or can do).So using a field titled 'tinderbox' would be a bit more honest: a +1/+2 just means that, and a developers manually giving a +2 there is meaning just that: 'I tested the build or am reasonably confident that it doesnt break the build (but I have not tested the fix to remove the bug its claiming to fix)'.No blocking whatsoever from my side, just some thoughts.
Text: Patch Set 2:My proposal was rather to have no 'verified' field as other gerrit installations use 'verified' in the sense it is used on e.g. bugzilla: 'I have run the application and can confirm the bug is gone with this.' -- which is not what our tinderboxes do (or can do).So using a field titled 'tinderbox' would be a bit more honest: a +1/+2 just means that, and a developers manually giving a +2 there is meaning just that: 'I tested the build or am reasonably confident that it doesnt break the build (but I have not tested the fix to remove the bug its claiming to fix)'.No blocking whatsoever from my side, just some thoughts.

text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisAs far as I see the modified cases are triggered when something goes wrong as the svx and sw/sc/sd constants of page description properties are out of sync. text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisHm, not sure if this is the good direction. During debugging, it's annoying to have getter/setter methods in the header files, as if you modify those, several files are rebuilt. That's the problem implementation classes solve. I don't think it's a benefit to shrink source code size by moving more code to headers.

text: Patch Set 3: Fails; I would prefer that you didn't submit thisThe hardest part of this was finding out that X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect was involved, so kudos to discovering that.The workaround to search the lower levels if a glyph isn't found however is a bit of a bodge, because I don't think we shuold be asking for the wrong glyphs there in the first place. I think http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/commit/?id=98f56121858b4bea54d056a073005a10648785c6 should work instead.In MultiSalLayout::GetBoundRect we loop through each fallback font and union each level's GetBoundRect to get the result, which seems reasonable, except that for each level that's means a call to SalLayout::GetBoundRect which calls X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect.Those sublevels SalLayouts don't know that they are sublevels so they never set the level bits on their glyphs. Which results in X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect always searching for that glyph in the level 0 font, so there's a mismatch between the font the SalLayout's are created to use and the font that gets used.Now, SalLayout::GetBoundRect is a fairly simple thing, it just calls GetNextGlyphs 1 by 1 and X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect on the result of that.  So I *think* that if we remove the specialized MultiSalLayout::GetBoundRect in favour of the default implementation, then because MultiSalLayout::GetNextGlyphs is specialized to do-the-right-thing and set up the glyph ids correctly, then we bubble the ids down to X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect correctly to get it to use the right font and we get the correct bounding size.
Text: Patch Set 3: Fails; I would prefer that you didn't submit thisThe hardest part of this was finding out that X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect was involved, so kudos to discovering that.The workaround to search the lower levels if a glyph isn't found however is a bit of a bodge, because I don't think we shuold be asking for the wrong glyphs there in the first place. I think http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/commit/?id=98f56121858b4bea54d056a073005a10648785c6 should work instead.In MultiSalLayout::GetBoundRect we loop through each fallback font and union each level's GetBoundRect to get the result, which seems reasonable, except that for each level that's means a call to SalLayout::GetBoundRect which calls X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect.Those sublevels SalLayouts don't know that they are sublevels so they never set the level bits on their glyphs. Which results in X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect always searching for that glyph in the level 0 font, so there's a mismatch between the font the SalLayout's are created to use and the font that gets used.Now, SalLayout::GetBoundRect is a fairly simple thing, it just calls GetNextGlyphs 1 by 1 and X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect on the result of that.  So I *think* that if we remove the specialized MultiSalLayout::GetBoundRect in favour of the default implementation, then because MultiSalLayout::GetNextGlyphs is specialized to do-the-right-thing and set up the glyph ids correctly, then we bubble the ids down to X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect correctly to get it to use the right font and we get the correct bounding size.

text: Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisI don't like this. Given that "python" in Debian is python2.x and python3 is "python3", without extra options this will always fall back to python 2. Even if you probably want system-python and prefer the "default, supported" one. which is 3...This is another occurance of the detect-everything magic, which we should avoid.(Yes, that contradicts my first comment, but I rethought this...)

text: Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisThis change improves situation somewhat in the case that the search term is present only in cell A1 in the sense that "Search key not found" doesn't pop up anymore, but if the search key occurs elsewhere in the sheet the search still finds that other occurrence instead. Actually the change only suppresses the dialog but does not change the behavior.Note also the scenario described in https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=36800#c9"Before I press replace, I want to confirm that the correct reference will be replaced (A2 also contains "quick", which I don't want replaced).  If I press "find", it will go to Cell A2.  But if, instead of "find", I pressed "replace", it would replace the "quick" in Cell A1, not Cell A2."Additionally, with this change you now don't get the "LibreOffice Calc has searched to the end of the sheet. Do you want to continue at the beginning?" dialog anymore if the occurrence is only in cell A1 and A1 is also the current cell. This is inconsistent, the dialog is presented if the search key occurs in any other cell only.What we actually needed would be that the search would find the current cell first (as does replace), and not touch the logic when dialogues are presented.

Actually the change only suppresses the dialog but does not change the behavior.Note also the scenario described in https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=36800#c9"Before I press replace, I want to confirm that the correct reference will be replaced (A2 also contains "quick", which I don't want replaced).  If I press "find", it will go to Cell A2.  But if, instead of "find", I pressed "replace", it would replace the "quick" in Cell A1, not Cell A2."Additionally, with this change you now don't get the "LibreOffice Calc has searched to the end of the sheet. Do you want to continue at the beginning?" dialog anymore if the occurrence is only in cell A1 and A1 is also the current cell. This is inconsistent, the dialog is presented if the search key occurs in any other cell only.What we actually needed would be that the search would find the current cell first (as does replace), and not touch the logic when dialogues are presented.

text: Patch Set 1: Do not submitthis patch is bogus since it will disable updates of most kinds of fields completely.the problem here appears to be that the page number fields are expanded when opening the Print dialog, and for reasons i've never understood the page number is stored in the SwPageNumberFieldType which is shared by all page number fields and so all fields get the value of the last one.

text: Patch Set 1: Fails; Do not submitNice idea :-)  But.. it doesn't work as intended.First, the function should not calculate both paths (which is automatically done to pass results of expressions as arguments), it should work more like the IF() function, where a conditional path is only calculated for the corresponding condition.Second, this implementation works only for some cases. =IFERROR(1/0,2)works and result is 2, but already =IFERROR(1/0,2+3)propagates the #DIV/0! error instead of returning 5. Also =IFERROR(1+1,1/0)propagates the #DIV/0! error instead of returning 2.I suggest you take a look at the implementation of ocIf and use a similar approach with only one conditional path instead of two, for which the condition is calculated from the expression's result whether it is an error or not and then a jump is executed or not. There is some special code in the compiler to calculate jump paths (lookout for ocIf), and handling is different from normal functions in the interpreter. Feel free to ask for details and pointers on the mailing list.
Text: Patch Set 1: Fails; Do not submitNice idea :-)  But.. it doesn't work as intended.First, the function should not calculate both paths (which is automatically done to pass results of expressions as arguments), it should work more like the IF() function, where a conditional path is only calculated for the corresponding condition.Second, this implementation works only for some cases. =IFERROR(1/0,2)works and result is 2, but already =IFERROR(1/0,2+3)propagates the #DIV/0! error instead of returning 5. Also =IFERROR(1+1,1/0)propagates the #DIV/0! error instead of returning 2.I suggest you take a look at the implementation of ocIf and use a similar approach with only one conditional path instead of two, for which the condition is calculated from the expression's result whether it is an error or not and then a jump is executed or not. There is some special code in the compiler to calculate jump paths (lookout for ocIf), and handling is different from normal functions in the interpreter. Feel free to ask for details and pointers on the mailing list.

(and if that doesn't work and we need to re-insert those pesky spaces I guess the solution might be to somehow get the SwHolePortion to change the underline to none for the extra spaces it emits)

text: Patch Set 2: Do not submitThanks for tackling this issue ! I have a few comments however:It seems to me that using isalpha / isprint on string characters like this is a particularly horrible way to achieve this :-)To copy/paste a similar chunk of text twice like that is rather poor style - in programming for maintainability the aim is always to minimise the number of new lines we add: to maximise the sharing of lines of code etc.As such - I'd really strongly prefer as much of the if (rtl) { } cases to be shared with the non-rtl cases - can we not setup variables that alter the order of iteration / layout placement / rendering in advance and then use them in a shared block later ?When we do:+            // this code are for reverse the number of sildes in TitleThe title we have there seems to come from:void PresenterPaneBase::PaintBorder (const awt::Rectangle& rUpdateBox)...            mxBorderPainter->paintBorder(                mxPaneId->getResourceURL(),                mxBorderCanvas,                aLocalBorderBox,                rUpdateBox,                msTitle);msTitle - can we not translate translate and/or generate that msTitle (SetTitle?) in the first instance ?Is that created from a template in:void PresenterController::UpdatePaneTitles (void)if so - we should fix it there in just one place :-)That template prolly comes from the (localised?) configuration and just needs changing there ?Anyhow - thanks again for looking at this - with a few tweaks (as above) I think we can make it a lot sweeter.Thanks !

text: Patch Set 1: Do not submitThe presenter console is currently built as an extension, which means it must not link to vcl. Grab me on IRC if you are interested in doing that and need pointers.

text: Patch Set 1: Fails; No scoreI just compiled this, ran with SAL_RTL_ENABLED=1 and I see no change at all in either the button ordering or the mouse event handling. Is that what is expected ?FWIW - I think a real solution is going to need to be more involved than just re-ordering the buttons; the fundamental problem is that VCL is reflecting / mirroring the mouse events that come in - and nothing in the presenterconsole is prepared for this: the quickest hack might be to mirror them back if we can easily by using a helperfunction to re-write aEvent inside each mouseMoved callback - that is if indeed we can do that mirroring effectively.
Text: Patch Set 1: Fails; No scoreI just compiled this, ran with SAL_RTL_ENABLED=1 and I see no change at all in either the button ordering or the mouse event handling. Is that what is expected ?FWIW - I think a real solution is going to need to be more involved than just re-ordering the buttons; the fundamental problem is that VCL is reflecting / mirroring the mouse events that come in - and nothing in the presenterconsole is prepared for this: the quickest hack might be to mirror them back if we can easily by using a helperfunction to re-write aEvent inside each mouseMoved callback - that is if indeed we can do that mirroring effectively.

text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisI think you should split this into three patches, one for Unix-only code, one for cross-platform code, and one for Windows-only code. That would make it easier to actually verify.I see at least one real problem in the patch for crashrep/source/unx/main.cxx: you change it to use %u for a size_t variable that isn't cast. This breaks when compiled for 64-bit, where %u is for 32-bit unsigned int, and size_t is 64-bit. There might be other similar issues elsewhere in the patch. But note that the crashrep module is not built so your changes to it won't even get compiled...That said, I wonder if it is correct of that main.cxx to use size_t for the return value of ftell(). Is there no Unix where in 32-bit code ftell() still returns a 64-bit value?
Text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisI think you should split this into three patches, one for Unix-only code, one for cross-platform code, and one for Windows-only code. That would make it easier to actually verify.I see at least one real problem in the patch for crashrep/source/unx/main.cxx: you change it to use %u for a size_t variable that isn't cast. This breaks when compiled for 64-bit, where %u is for 32-bit unsigned int, and size_t is 64-bit. There might be other similar issues elsewhere in the patch. But note that the crashrep module is not built so your changes to it won't even get compiled...That said, I wonder if it is correct of that main.cxx to use size_t for the return value of ftell(). Is there no Unix where in 32-bit code ftell() still returns a 64-bit value?

text: Patch Set 1: Do not submitHmm, I am confused by all the changes:1. In the dmake fix, it does not make sense to save   the number of read items and just increment it.      Instead, it would make sense to check if it really   did read the item, for example:      if (fread( (char *)&flhdr, sizeof(flhdr), 1, f ) != 1) return (-1);   2. In the lpsolve fix, it is not a good idea to redirect all   error messages to /dev/null. It would hide real build   errors as well.      Instead, it would be better to fix the lpsolve code   to do not produce warnigns at all.3. The concat-deps.c is strange as well. It is a similar   problem like in dmake.      IMHO, we need to return an error if it does not write   the whole item => you need to modify the function   print_fullpaths to return integer instead of void.   Then you could use something like:      if (fwrite(token, token_len, 1, stdout) != 1) return EIO;      Of course, you need to handle the print_fullpaths return   value where it is called.
Text: Patch Set 1: Do not submitHmm, I am confused by all the changes:1. In the dmake fix, it does not make sense to save   the number of read items and just increment it.      Instead, it would make sense to check if it really   did read the item, for example:      if (fread( (char *)&flhdr, sizeof(flhdr), 1, f ) != 1) return (-1);   2. In the lpsolve fix, it is not a good idea to redirect all   error messages to /dev/null. It would hide real build   errors as well.      Instead, it would be better to fix the lpsolve code   to do not produce warnigns at all.3. The concat-deps.c is strange as well. It is a similar   problem like in dmake.      IMHO, we need to return an error if it does not write   the whole item => you need to modify the function   print_fullpaths to return integer instead of void.   Then you could use something like:      if (fwrite(token, token_len, 1, stdout) != 1) return EIO;      Of course, you need to handle the print_fullpaths return   value where it is called.

text: Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisI am sorry for the late response. I am busy with preparing the tag for 3.6.3-rc3.Hmm, I still do not like your solution. In short:1. It would be better to squash all the commits into one. It is easier to review. Also it would help if you later investigate the git history. You could use     git rebase -i origin/master   and follow the instructions2. You patch hides potential errors using thatif( function_call(...) ) ; construct . It means that the application could proceed random data. Instead, it should propagate the errors. For example, it should return (-1) in dmake if it was not able to read the data. I wrote this in the first comment already.

It means that the application could proceed random data. Instead, it should propagate the errors. For example, it should return (-1) in dmake if it was not able to read the data. text: Patch Set 2:the difference between build.pl and tail_build implementations of module.all is that with build.pl all dependent modules are built completely while for tail_build only the target module is built completely, and from the others only the directly needed targets are build, so adding dependencies to solenv/gbuild/Module.mk doesn't help.but i still don't like the patch :)just look at how many places load a "fps_office" resource...i think there are some more options:1. move the failing tests to subsequentcheck, that would be much simpler2. go though all resource loading calls and add explicit resource dependencies to each Library_foo.mk that contains a call.   i guess these are loaded via ResMgr::CreateResMgr or possibly via ResMgr::SearchCreateResMgr as well; 94 calls3. put in some hack to be used only by unit tests that loads all resources from a different path, and add to each test some rule that copies all needed resources to a test specific directoryhmm i don't like 3. much either...
Text: Patch Set 2:the difference between build.pl and tail_build implementations of module.all is that with build.pl all dependent modules are built completely while for tail_build only the target module is built completely, and from the others only the directly needed targets are build, so adding dependencies to solenv/gbuild/Module.mk doesn't help.but i still don't like the patch :)just look at how many places load a "fps_office" resource...i think there are some more options:1. move the failing tests to subsequentcheck, that would be much simpler2. go though all resource loading calls and add explicit resource dependencies to each Library_foo.mk that contains a call.   i guess these are loaded via ResMgr::CreateResMgr or possibly via ResMgr::SearchCreateResMgr as well; 94 calls3. put in some hack to be used only by unit tests that loads all resources from a different path, and add to each test some rule that copies all needed resources to a test specific directoryhmm i don't like 3. much either...

text: Patch Set 2:oh wait there is another option which i don't like:4. re-create the module level dependencies from */prj/build.lst in tail_build, so that modules are always built completely.i think this would limit parallelism too much (but it would have the advantage that it would also limit parallel linking so we get less OOM problems :) )
Text: Patch Set 2:oh wait there is another option which i don't like:4. re-create the module level dependencies from */prj/build.lst in tail_build, so that modules are always built completely.i think this would limit parallelism too much (but it would have the advantage that it would also limit parallel linking so we get less OOM problems :) )

text: Patch Set 1: Do not submitI think this change is wrong. Simply removing the code leads to the situation that all input is parsed against the standard default language/locales's General format, effectively accepting anything that could be parsed as a number whatsoever, including date and time. If values were to be formatted in a different locale already a simple number containing a decimal separator could not work.It looks like actually the format index should be obtained from the corresponding input field instead as it was set in ScaleTabPage::SetNumFormat() with, for example, aFmtFldMax.SetFormatKey( nFmt )
Text: Patch Set 1: Do not submitI think this change is wrong. Simply removing the code leads to the situation that all input is parsed against the standard default language/locales's General format, effectively accepting anything that could be parsed as a number whatsoever, including date and time. If values were to be formatted in a different locale already a simple number containing a decimal separator could not work.It looks like actually the format index should be obtained from the corresponding input field instead as it was set in ScaleTabPage::SetNumFormat() with, for example, aFmtFldMax.SetFormatKey( nFmt )
